text_en: A - In the name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate. All praise is due to Allah; we praise Him, seek His help, and ask His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the consequences of our deeds. Whomever Allah guides, none can misguide; and whomever He allows to go astray, none can guide. I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah alone, with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. {O you who believe, fear Allah as He should be feared, and do not die except as Muslims} [Al-Imran: 102]. {O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from a single soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever watchful over you} [An-Nisa: 1]. {O you who believe, fear Allah and speak words of sincere guidance. He will correct your deeds and forgive your sins. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly attained a great success} [Al-Ahzab: 70-71]. As for what follows: the truest speech is the Book of Allah, and the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad ﷺ. The worst of matters are their innovations; every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance leads to the Fire. Allah Almighty said: {Blessed is He in whose hand is dominion, and He is over all things competent} [Al-Mulk: 1], {He who created death and life to test you as to which of you is best in deed, and He is the Almighty, the Forgiving} [Al-Mulk: 2].
foot_note: None

text: - B - And He said: {Every soul will taste death. And We test you with evil and with good as trial; and to Us you will be returned} [Al-Anbiya: 35]. And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "What have I to do with the world? I am not in the world but as a rider who sought shade under a tree, then went and left it" (1). Then, "Since his guidance (peace be upon him) in funerals was the best guidance, contrary to the guidance of other nations, encompassing kindness to the deceased and treating him with what benefits him in his grave and on the Day of his Return, and kindness to his family and relatives, and establishing the servitude of the living regarding how he treats the dead. And it was from his guidance in funerals to establish servitude to the Lord, Blessed and Exalted, in the most perfect manner, and kindness to the deceased, preparing him for Allah in the best and most excellent condition, and his standing and the standing of his companions in rows praising Allah, seeking forgiveness for him, asking for forgiveness, mercy, and overlooking for him. Then walking in front of him until he deposits him in his grave. Then he and his companions stand before him at his grave, asking for steadfastness for him when he is most in need of it. Then he maintains connection with him by visiting his grave, greeting him, and supplicating for him, just as the living maintains connection with his companion in the abode of the world. So, the first of that is attending to him in his illness, reminding him of the Hereafter, and commanding him...
foot_note: 1. (1) Authentic Hadith, extracted in "Takhrij Fiqh al-Sirah by Al-Ghazali" (p. 478, 4th Edition), and in "Al-Ahadith al-Sahihah" (No. 438). Therefore, I included it in my book "Sahih al-Jami' al-Saghir wa Ziyadatuhu," may Allah the Exalted facilitate its completion by His grace and favor.

text: - C - to make a will and repent, and commanding those present to prompt him to say the testimony 'La ilaha illa Allah' (There is no god but Allah) so that it may be his last words. Then forbidding the customs of nations that do not believe in Resurrection and Gathering, such as slapping cheeks, tearing clothes, shaving heads, raising voices in wailing and lamentation, and their corollaries. And he legislated humility for the deceased, weeping without sound, and sadness of the heart. He used to do that and say: 'The eye tears, and the heart grieves, but we do not say except what pleases the Lord.' And he legislated for his Ummah praising [Allah], saying 'Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi raji'un' (Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return), and being pleased with Allah. And that was not contradictory to the tearing of the eye and the sadness of the heart. Therefore, he was the most pleased of creation with His decree and the greatest of them in praise for Him, yet he wept on the day his son Ibrahim died, out of compassion and mercy for the child and tenderness towards him, while the heart was filled with pleasure with Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and gratitude to Him, and the tongue occupied with His remembrance and praise" (1). And since many people today are very far from...
foot_note: 1. (1) From the words of Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, in the "First Chapter of Funerals" from "Zad al-Ma'ad" (1/197). It continues: "And when this scene and combining the two matters became difficult for some of the gnostics (Arifin), on the day his son died, he started laughing! He was asked: Do you laugh in this situation?! He said: Indeed, Allah the Exalted decreed a matter, so I loved to be pleased with His decree. This was problematic for a group of people of knowledge, so they said: How did the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) weep on the day his son Ibrahim died, while he is the most pleased of creation with Allah, and the pleasure of this gnostic reaches the point of laughing! So I heard =

text: - D - Allah's guidance (peace be upon him) in all acts of worship, including (funerals), due to their turning away from studying knowledge, especially the science of Hadith and Sunnah, and their dedication to material sciences and working to amass wealth. One of my dear friends asked me, on the occasion of the death of one of his female relatives on Friday, 11 Rabi' al-Thani, 1373 AH, to write a brief treatise on "The Etiquette of Funerals in Islam," so that he or someone else could print and distribute it to those gathered for condolences during their customary days, seizing the opportunity of their gathering to introduce them to the Sunnah of their Prophet so that they may follow it, be guided by its guidance, and be enlightened by its light. Although I had started writing some other works, I promised him good, due to the cooperation in reviving the Sunnah and killing innovation involved in that. So I hastened to fulfill his wish and accomplish his request. But I had hardly started doing so when it became clear to me that the matter was further than being achieved with that speed, and broader than being collected in a treatise distributed to people on such an occasion. That is because the etiquette and rules of funerals are very numerous, and a large part of them are matters on which scholars' opinions differed and views conflicted. Some prohibit a thing while another permits it, and some obligate a thing while another does not allow it, and some...
foot_note: 1. = Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah say: The guidance of our Prophet (peace be upon him) was more perfect than the guidance of this gnostic. He gave servitude its due right, so his heart expanded for pleasure with Allah and mercy for the child and tenderness towards him. So he praised Allah and was pleased with Him in His decree, and wept out of mercy and compassion. So compassion led him to weep, and his servitude to Allah and love for Allah led him to pleasure and praise. This gnostic's heart was too narrow to combine the two matters and his inner self did not expand to witness them both and uphold them both, so the servitude of pleasure distracted him from the servitude of mercy and compassion".

text: - E - consider it a Sunnah while another considers it an innovation, and so on... just as is the case in many other issues in most chapters of Sharia, confirming the saying of Allah the Exalted: {...but they will not cease to differ (118) Except whom your Lord has given mercy...} [Hud: 118, 119]. Therefore, it was necessary first of all to collect the individual issues of "Funerals," then study them meticulously, track the evidences of the disputed ones, critique them in the light of the sciences of "Principles of Hadith" and "Principles of Jurisprudence," and choose the preponderant one among them, without any bias towards a specific school of thought (Madhhab) or being influenced by a custom that has dominated until it became as if it were a religion that must be followed! It is not hidden from the people of knowledge who practiced authorship that accomplishing such a work requires diligent pursuit, profound effort, beautiful patience, and a long time. After its completion, the requested treatise can be authored in a form that reassures the soul, expands the chest, and maximizes the benefit. Therefore, I mentioned a summary of this to the brother referred to, apologizing. He accepted my excuse, may Allah reward him with good, but he returned asking me to start this work, urged me to do it, and insisted on it, hoping for much good from it. So I sought Allah's guidance (Istikhara), and dedicated myself to study and review for nearly three months, working night and day, except for what was necessary of work in my profession and sleep indispensable for my body's rest, until I was able to prepare this book which is in the hands of the honorable reader. It would have required more time than was estimated for it, were it not that a large part of its issues and Hadiths had been verified by me in some of my other compilations, and that is why you see me referring to them in some places in it.
foot_note: None

text: - F - I tried to investigate in it everything related to its subject from the issues that have evidence from the Book and the Sunnah, and I turned away from what was based merely on opinion, because the subject is purely devotional, with no room for analogy (Qiyas) in it, except what is necessary of clear analogy. I included in its beginning some chapters and issues that are not usually mentioned in the "Chapter of Funerals" in general books of Fiqh, such as the Will (Wasiyyah), signs of a good ending, and the like. Some of it might not be mentioned in them at all, such as Chapter (5, 8, and 9), Issue (30), Paragraph (C and D) of Issue (74), Issues (98, 105, 99, 107, 113, and 125), and Paragraph (7) of Issue (128) despite its importance and the frequent affliction of people with it, and the Mutawatir Hadiths concerning it, and Paragraph (10) of it. I was inspired by reality for its arrangement, so I opened it with a chapter: (1 - What is obligatory upon the sick person) regarding satisfaction with the Decree, patience with Destiny, abandoning wishing for death, fulfilling rights, making a will and witnessing to it... Then: (2 - Prompting the dying person) and what is upon those present regarding prompting him and commanding him with the Testimony (Shahada). Then (3 - What is upon those present after his death) regarding closing his eyes, supplicating for him, covering him, hastening his preparation, and rushing to pay off his debt. Then (4 - What is permissible for those present and others) regarding uncovering his face, kissing him, and weeping over him.
foot_note: None

text: - G - Then (5 - What is obligatory upon the relatives of the deceased) regarding patience, satisfaction with the Decree, Istirja' (saying Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi raji'un), and the wife's mourning (Ihdad) for her husband. Then (6 - What is prohibited for them) regarding wailing, striking cheeks, tearing pockets (clothes), and other things like announcing his death on minarets. Then (7 - Permissible Death Announcement). Then (8 - Signs of a Good Ending). Then (9 - People's Praise for the Deceased). Then (10 - Washing the Deceased). And so on until Burial and Visiting Graves. I concluded it with a special chapter on Funeral Innovations. I encompassed in it all the innovations I came across stated in a book from the books of people of knowledge, ancient and modern, attributing every innovation to its place in their books. And what was not attributed to them is what the scientific methodology in the principles of innovations judges to be among them, but I did not see anyone who stated it among them. And many of them are innovations of the present time. I ask Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, to benefit with this book everyone who reads it, and to write for me its reward and the like for the one who was the cause of its authorship and the one who undertook its printing. Indeed, He is Hearing, Responsive. Damascus, 24 Muharram, year 1388 AH (1). Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani
foot_note: 1. (1) The book was expected to be issued in 1385 after the typesetting was done and it was prepared for printing, but the stoppage of the Islamic Office presses from Dhu al-Qi'dah 1384 until mid-Rabi' al-Awwal 1388 prevented that. And Allah is the One sought for help in every situation. The Publisher

text:
(1) What is Obligatory upon the Sick Person
1 - The sick person must be satisfied with Allah's decree, be patient with His destiny, and think positively of his Lord; that is better for him. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Amazing is the affair of the believer, indeed all of his affair is good, and that is for no one except the believer. If prosperity befalls him, he is grateful and that is good for him, and if adversity befalls him, he is patient and that is good for him." And he (peace be upon him) said: "None of you should die except while he thinks positively of Allah the Exalted." Both narrated by Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad.
2 - He should be between fear and hope, fearing Allah's punishment for his sins, and hoping for the mercy of his Lord, due to the Hadith of Anas: "That the Prophet (peace be upon him) entered upon a young man while he was dying, and said: How do you find yourself? He said: By Allah, O Messenger of Allah, I hope for Allah, and I fear my sins. So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: These two do not gather in the heart of a servant in such a situation except that Allah gives him what he hopes for and secures him from what he fears." Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi and its chain is Hasan (good), and Ibn Majah, and Abdullah bin Ahmad in "Zawa'id al-Zuhd" (p. 24/25) and Ibn Abi al-Dunya as in "Al-Targhib" (4/141).
foot_note: None

text:
3 - No matter how severe the illness becomes, it is not permissible for him to wish for death, due to the Hadith of Umm al-Fadl (may Allah be pleased with her): "That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) entered upon them, and Abbas, the uncle of the Messenger of Allah, was complaining [of illness], so Abbas wished for death. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to him: O Uncle! Do not wish for death. For if you are a doer of good, then being delayed allows you to increase good to your good, which is better for you. And if you are an evildoer, then being delayed allows you to seek favor [repent] from your evil, which is better for you. So do not wish for death." Extracted by Al-Hakim (1/339) and he said: "Authentic according to the conditions of the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim)" and Al-Dhahabi agreed. But it is only according to the condition of Al-Bukhari. The two Sheikhs and Al-Bayhaqi (3/377) and others extracted from the Hadith of Anas raised (Marfu') similar to it, and in it: "If he must do so, let him say: O Allah, keep me alive as long as life is good for me, and cause me to die if death is good for me."
4 - If he has rights [owed to others] upon him, let him fulfill them to their owners, if that is easy for him. Otherwise, he should bequeath that. For he (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever has a wronging against his brother regarding his honor (1) or his wealth, let him resolve it with him, before a Day comes wherein there will be no dinar nor dirham. If he has righteous deeds, they will be taken from him and given to his companion. And if he has no righteous deeds, some of the bad deeds of his companion will be taken and cast upon him." Extracted by Al-Bukhari and Al-Bayhaqi (3/369) and others. And he (peace be upon him) said: "Do you know who the bankrupt is? They said: The bankrupt among us is the one who has no dirhams and no goods. He said: The bankrupt of my Ummah is the one who comes on the Day of Resurrection with prayer, fasting, and zakat, but he comes having insulted this one, slandered this one, consumed the wealth of this one, shed the blood of this one, and beaten this one. So this one is given from his good deeds, and this one from his good deeds. If his good deeds run out before what is upon him is judged, their sins are taken and cast upon him, then he is cast into the Fire." Narrated by Muslim (8/18).
foot_note: 1. (1) Honor (Al-Irḍ): The locus of praise and blame in a person, whether in himself or regarding those whose affairs concern him. "Nihayah".

text:
And he (peace be upon him) also said: "Whoever dies owing a debt, there is no dinar or dirham there, but rather good deeds and bad deeds." Extracted by Al-Hakim (2/27) and the context is his, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad (2/70 - 82) from two paths from Ibn Umar. The first is authentic as Al-Hakim said and Al-Dhahabi agreed, and the second is Hasan as Al-Mundhiri said (3/34). And Al-Tabarani narrated it in Al-Kabir with the wording: "Debt is of two types: whoever dies intending to pay it off, I am his guardian. And whoever dies not intending to pay it off, that is the one from whom good deeds will be taken; there will be no dinar or dirham on that Day (1)". And Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) said: "When Uhud approached, my father called me at night and said: I do not see myself but being killed among the first of those killed from the companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him), and I am not leaving behind me anyone dearer to me than you except the soul of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). I have a debt, so pay it off, and treat your sisters well. We reached the morning, and he was the first to be killed..." The Hadith. Extracted by Al-Bukhari.
5 - It is necessary to hasten with such a will, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "It is not the right of a Muslim person who spends two nights and has something he wants to make a will about, except that his will is written by his head." Ibn Umar said: "No night has passed me since I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say that except that I have my will." Narrated by the two Sheikhs and the authors of the Sunan and others.
6 - He must make a will for his relatives who do not inherit from him, due to the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {Prescribed for you when death approaches [any] one of you if he leaves wealth [is that he should make] a bequest for the parents and near relatives according to what is acceptable - a duty upon the righteous.} [Al-Baqarah: 180]
7 - He is allowed to bequeath one-third of his wealth, and it is not permissible to exceed it; rather, it is better to decrease from it, due to the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said:
foot_note: 1. (1) It is an authentic Hadith supported by what precedes it, and by the Hadith of Aisha at the end of Issue (17).

text:
"I was with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in the Farewell Pilgrimage, and I became sick with an illness that brought me close to death. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) visited me, so I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have much wealth, and no one inherits from me except a daughter of mine. Shall I bequeath two-thirds of my wealth? He said: No. I said: Half of my wealth? He said: No. I said: Then a third of my wealth? He said: The third, and the third is much. Indeed, O Sa'd! That you leave your heirs rich is better for you than leaving them dependent, begging from people (and he gestured with his hand). Indeed, O Sa'd, you will never spend a spending seeking thereby the Face of Allah except that you will be rewarded for it, even the morsel you place in your wife's mouth. (He said: So after that, the third became permissible)". Extracted by Ahmad (1524) and the context is his, the two Sheikhs, and the two additions are for Muslim and the authors of the Sunan. Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "I wished that people would reduce from the third to the fourth in wills, because the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: The third is much." Extracted by Ahmad (2029, 2076), the two Sheikhs, Al-Bayhaqi (6/269), and others.
8 - And two just Muslim men should witness that. If they are not found, then two men from non-Muslims, provided that their testimony is verified upon doubt according to the explanation mentioned in the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {O you who have believed, testimony [should be taken] among you when death approaches one of you at the time of bequest - [that of] two just men from among you or two others from outside if you are traveling through the land and the disaster of death strikes you. Detain them after the prayer and let them both swear by Allah if you doubt [their testimony, saying], "We will not exchange our oath for a price, even if he should be a near relative, and we will not withhold the testimony of Allah. Indeed, we would then be of the sinful." (106) But if it is found that those two were guilty of sin (1), then two others shall stand in their place [who are] foremost [in claim] from those who have a lawful right.}
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning: If it happens that it is discovered that the two swearing witnesses deserved sin by lying and concealing in the testimony, or by treachery and concealing some of the estate when entrusted with it, then the obligatory action, or what is done to establish the truth, is that the oath is returned to the heirs by having two other men stand in their place from the relatives of the deceased who inherit from him, those against whom that sin was committed by the crime against them and treachery towards them. As mentioned in "Tafsir Al-Manar," and refer to the complete discussion in it (7/222).

text:
{And [let them] swear by Allah, "Our testimony is truer than their testimony, and we have not transgressed. Indeed, we would then be of the wrongdoers." (107) That is more likely that they will give testimony according to its [true] objective, or [at least] they would fear that [other] oaths might be taken after their oaths. And fear Allah and listen; and Allah does not guide the defiantly disobedient people (108)} [Al-Ma'idah: 106 - 108]
9 - As for the will for parents and relatives who inherit from the testator, it is not permissible, because it is abrogated by the verse of inheritance. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) explained that most clearly in his sermon during the Farewell Pilgrimage, saying: "Indeed, Allah has given everyone who has a right his right, so there is no will for an heir" (1). Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi who classified it as Hasan, and Al-Bayhaqi (6/264) who indicated its strengthening, and he was correct, for its chain is Hasan, and it has many supporting evidences in Al-Bayhaqi and "Majma' al-Zawa'id" (4/212).
10 - Harming in the will is prohibited, such as bequeathing to deprive some heirs of their right to inheritance, or preferring some over others in it, due to the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {(For men is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave... be it little or much - an obligatory share...)} [Al-Nisa: 7] and in the last of them: {(...after any bequest he [may have] made or debt, not being harmful... A command from Allah, and Allah is Knowing and Forbearing)} [Al-Nisa: 12]. And due to his saying (peace be upon him): "There should be no harming and no reciprocating harm. Whoever harms, Allah will harm him, and whoever causes difficulty, Allah will cause difficulty for him." Extracted by Al-Daraqutni (522) and Al-Hakim (2/57-58) from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. Al-Dhahabi agreed with Al-Hakim on his statement "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim," but the truth is that it is a Hasan Hadith as Al-Nawawi said in "Al-Arba'in" and Ibn Taymiyyah in "Al-Fatawa" (3/262) due to its many paths and supporting evidences. Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab mentioned them in "Sharh Al-Arba'in" (p. 219, 220), then I extracted it in "Irwa' al-Ghalil" No. 888).
foot_note: 1. (1) So the abrogator is the Quran, and the Sunnah is merely clarifying that as we mentioned, and as is clear from his sermon (peace be upon him), contrary to what many think that the Hadith is the abrogator. Then some contemporaries exploited that and claimed that Ahad Hadith abrogates the Quran. You have known the answer, which is that the abrogator is only the Quran. Even if we concede that the abrogator is the Hadith, it is suitable for abrogation by consensus, because all scholars accepted it. Moreover, it is a Mutawatir Hadith, as known by anyone who has examined its many paths scattered in the collections and Musnads of Sunnah. Perhaps we will be successful in extracting them and verifying the discussion on them in a separate volume. Then I collected its paths and extracted them in "Irwa' al-Ghalil" No. (16), and its paths exceeded ten, from eight Companions, some authentic, some Hasan, and some whose weakness is mended.

text:
11 - An unjust will is invalid and rejected, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever introduces into this affair of ours that which is not part of it, it is rejected." Extracted by the two Sheikhs in their "Sahihs," Ahmad, and others. And due to the Hadith of Imran bin Husayn: "That a man freed six slaves (1) at his death. His heirs from the Bedouins came and informed the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) of what he did. He said: Did he do that!? They said: [Yes]. He said: Had we known, God willing, we would not have prayed over him. He said: So he cast lots among them, freed two of them, and returned four to slavery." Extracted by Ahmad (4/446) and Muslim similarly, as well as Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, and others.
12 - Since innovation in religion is prevalent among many people in this time, especially regarding funerals, it was obligatory for a Muslim to bequeath that he be prepared and buried according to the Sunnah, acting upon the saying of the Exalted: {O you who have believed, protect yourselves and your families from a Fire whose fuel is people and stones, over which are [appointed] angels, harsh and severe; they do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded (6)} [At-Tahrim: 6]. Therefore, the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to advise that. The traditions from them regarding what we mentioned are numerous, so there is no harm in restricting to some of them:
A - From 'Amir bin Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas that his father said during the illness in which he died: "Make a Laḥd (niche) for me, and set up bricks over me, as was done for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)." Extracted by Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi (3/407), and others.
B - From Abu Burdah who said: "Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) advised when death approached him, saying: When you proceed with my funeral procession, hasten with me. Do not follow me with incense burners. Do not place anything on my niche that prevents the dust from reaching me. Do not build a structure over my grave. I call you to witness that I am innocent of every Halqah (shaved head wailer), Saliqah (loud wailer), or Khariqah (clothes tearer). They said: Did you hear anything about it? He said: Yes, from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)."
foot_note: 1. (1) Plural of Rajul (man).

text:
Extracted by Ahmad (4/397) and Al-Bayhaqi (3/395) with this completeness, and Ibn Majah with a Hasan chain.
C - From Hudhayfah who said: "If I die, do not announce me to anyone, for I fear that it would be Na'y (forbidden death announcement), and I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbidding Na'y." Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi (2/129) and he said: "Hasan Hadith," and others narrated it similarly. It will come in "Death Announcement." There are other traditions in this chapter coming in Issue (47).
Based on the above, Al-Nawawi, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, said in "Al-Adhkar": "It is recommended for him with emphatic recommendation to advise them to avoid the innovations that have become customary in funerals, and to emphasize the covenant regarding that."
foot_note: None

text:
(2) Prompting the Dying Person
13 - When death approaches him, those with him must do several things:
A - To prompt him with the Testimony (Shahada), due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Prompt your dying ones to say La ilaha illa Allah. (Whoever's last words are La ilaha illa Allah at death will enter Paradise some day, even if he was afflicted before that by what he was afflicted)." And he used to say: "Whoever dies knowing that there is no god but Allah enters Paradise." And in another Hadith: "Whoever dies associating nothing with Allah enters Paradise." Muslim extracted them in his Sahih, and the addition in the first Hadith is in Ibn Hibban (719 Mawarid) (1).
B, C - To supplicate for him and say only good in his presence, due to the Hadith of Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "When you visit the sick or the dead, say good, for the angels say Amen to what you say." Extracted by Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi (3/384), and others.
14 - Prompting (Talqin) is not mentioning the Shahada in the presence of the dying person and making him hear it, but rather commanding him to say it, contrary to what some think. The evidence is the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him):
foot_note: 1. (1) It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Mu'adh bin Jabal, and its chain is Hasan as I clarified in "Irwa' al-Ghalil" (679), and its wording will come in Signs of a Good Ending "Issue 25".

text:
"That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) visited a man from the Ansar, and said: O Uncle! Say: La ilaha illa Allah. He said: Am I a maternal uncle or a paternal uncle? He said: Rather, a maternal uncle. He said: Is it better for me to say: La ilaha illa Allah? The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Yes." Extracted by Imam Ahmad (3/152, 154, 268) with an authentic chain according to the condition of Muslim.
15 - As for reciting Surah Yasin near him and facing him towards the Qiblah, no authentic Hadith has been established regarding it. Rather, Sa'id bin al-Musayyib disliked facing him towards it and said: "Is the dying person not a Muslim!?" From Zur'ah bin Abd al-Rahman that he witnessed Sa'id bin al-Musayyib in his illness, and Abu Salamah bin Abd al-Rahman was with him. Sa'id fainted, so Abu Salamah ordered that his bed be turned towards the Kaaba. When Sa'id regained consciousness, he said: Did you turn my bed!? They said: Yes. He looked at Abu Salamah and said: I think it was with your knowledge (1)? He said: I ordered them! So Sa'id ordered that his bed be returned. Extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4/76) with an authentic chain from Zur'ah.
16 - There is no harm in a Muslim attending the death of a disbeliever to present Islam to him, hoping that he embraces Islam, due to the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "A Jewish boy used to serve the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he fell ill. The Prophet (peace be upon him) came to visit him and sat by his head. He said to him: Submit (to Islam). He looked at his father who was with him. His father said to him: Obey Abu al-Qasim (peace be upon him). So he submitted to Islam. The Prophet (peace be upon him) went out saying: Praise be to Allah who saved him from the Fire. (When he died, he said: Pray over your companion)." Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (3/175, 227, 280, 260), and the addition is his in a narration.
foot_note: 1. (1) The original says: (Ilmik/your knowledge), and perhaps the correct is what we established.

text:
(3) What is Upon Those Present After His Death
17 - When he passes away and surrenders the soul, several things are incumbent upon them:
A, B - To close his eyes and also supplicate for him, due to the Hadith of Umm Salamah who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) entered upon Abu Salamah, and his eyes were fixed open. He closed them and then said: Indeed, when the soul is taken, the sight follows it. Some of his family wailed, so he said: Do not supplicate against yourselves except for good, for the angels say Amen to what you say. Then he said: O Allah, forgive Abu Salamah, raise his rank among the guided, grant him a successor in his descendants who remain, forgive us and him, O Lord of the Worlds, expand his grave for him, and illuminate it for him." Extracted by Muslim, Ahmad (6/297), Al-Bayhaqi (3/334), and others.
C - To cover him with a cloth that conceals his entire body, due to the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): "That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), when he died, was covered with a Hibra garment." Extracted by the two Sheikhs in their Sahihs, Al-Bayhaqi (3/385), and others.
D - This applies to other than the one who dies while in Ihram. As for the Muhrim (pilgrim in Ihram), his head and face should not be covered, due to the Hadith of Ibn Abbas who said: "While a man was standing at Arafat, he fell from his mount and it broke his neck, or he said: it killed him. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Wash him with water and sidr, and shroud him in two garments (and in a narration: in his two garments), and do not apply Hanut (perfume) to him...
foot_note: None

text:
(and in a narration: and do not perfume him), and do not cover his head (nor his face), for he will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection reciting Talbiyah." Extracted by the two Sheikhs in their "Sahihs," Abu Nu'aym in "Al-Mustakhraj" (f 139-140), and Al-Bayhaqi (3/390 - ). The addition is not in Al-Bukhari.
E - To hasten his preparation and taking him out if his death is confirmed, due to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) raised (Marfu'): "Hasten with the funeral..." The Hadith. It will come in full in Chapter (47). There are two other Hadiths in this chapter more explicit than this, but they are weak, so we disregarded them.
foot_note: 1. (1) As for the first Hadith, it is from Ibn Umar raised (Marfu') with the wording: "If one of you dies, do not detain him, and hasten him to his grave, and let the Opening of Al-Baqarah be recited at his head and its ending at his feet." Extracted by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam al-Kabir" (3/208/2) and Al-Khallal in "Al-Qira'ah 'inda al-Qubur" (f 25/2) from the path of Yahya bin Abdullah bin Al-Dahhak Al-Babluti, told us Ayyub bin Nahik Al-Halabi Al-Zuhri - freed slave of the family of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas - said: I heard Ata' bin Abi Rabah Al-Makki say: I heard Ibn Umar say: then he mentioned it. I say: This is a weak chain and has two defects: First: Al-Babluti - is weak as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Taqrib." Second: His sheikh Ayyub bin Nahik, he is weaker than him. Abu Hatim and others weakened him, Al-Azdi said: Matruk (abandoned). Abu Zur'ah said: Munkar al-Hadith (rejected in Hadith). Al-Hafiz mentioned another Hadith for him in "Al-Lisan" which is clearly Munkar, from the path of Yahya bin Abdullah told us Ayyub from Mujahid from Ibn Umar raised (Marfu'). Then he said: "Yahya is weak, but he does not bear this." Then he said:! So if you know this, it is amazing of Al-Hafiz where he said in "Al-Fath" (3/143) regarding this Hadith of Al-Tabarani: "Its chain is Hasan"! And Al-Shawkani quoted it from him in "Nayl al-Awtar" (3/309) and approved it! As for Al-Haythami, he said in "Al-Majma'" (3/44): "Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir, and in it is Yahya bin Abdullah Al-Babluti and he is weak." He missed that Ayyub bin Nahik is also in it, and he is worse than him as preceded. As for the second Hadith, it is from Husayn bin Wahwah: "That Talhah bin Al-Bara' fell ill, so the Prophet (peace be upon him) came to visit him. He said: I do not see Talhah except that death has occurred to him, so inform me of him so that I may witness him and pray over him, and hasten him, for it is not fitting for the corpse of a Muslim to be detained among his family." =

text:
F - To bury him in the land where he died, and not transfer him to another, because it contradicts the haste commanded in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah mentioned previously. Similar to it is the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: "When it was the day of Uhud, the slain were carried to be buried in Al-Baqi'. Then the caller of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) called out: Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) commands you to bury the slain in their places where they fell - after my mother had carried my father and my uncle balanced (1) (and in a narration: she balanced them) (on a camel) to bury them in Al-Baqi' - so they were returned (and in a narration he said: So we returned them with the slain where they were killed)." Extracted by the four authors of Sunan, Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (196 - Mawarid) and the other narration is his, Ahmad (3/297 - 380), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/57) with an authentic chain. Al-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih Hadith." The addition is Ahmad's in a narration whose wording will come in Issue Chapter (80). Therefore, Aisha said when her brother died in the valley of Abyssinia and was carried from his place: "I do not find in myself, or what saddens me in myself is only that I wished he was buried in his place" (2). Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi with an authentic chain.
G - That some of them rush to pay off his debt from his wealth, even if it exhausts all of it. If he has no wealth, the state must pay on his behalf if he strove to pay it. If it does not do so, and some of them volunteer to do so, it is permissible. There are Hadiths regarding this:
First: From Sa'd bin Al-Atwal (may Allah be pleased with him):
foot_note:
1. = Extracted by Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi (3/386 - 387), and in it is Urwah - and it is said 'Uzrah - bin Sa'id Al-Ansari from his father, and both are unknown as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Taqrib." Moreover, inferring from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah for what we mentioned is based on the meaning of (hasten) being hastening its preparation. But according to the view that the meaning is hastening its carrying to its grave, the inference is not valid. This view is what Al-Qurtubi and then Al-Nawawi found apparent, and Al-Hafiz strengthened the first view with the two Hadiths we just discussed, and what is in it is not hidden. 
1. Meaning I tied them on the two sides of the camel like balanced loads. 
2. Al-Nawawi said in "Al-Adhkar": "If he bequeaths to be transferred to another land, his will is not executed, for transfer is forbidden according to the correct chosen view said by the majority and stated by the verifiers."

text:
"That his brother died and left three hundred dirhams, and left dependents. He said: I wanted to spend it on his dependents. He said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said to me: Indeed, your brother is detained by his debt (so go) and pay it off for him. (So I went and paid it off for him, then I came) and said: O Messenger of Allah, I have paid it off for him except for two dinars claimed by a woman, and she has no proof. He said: Give her, for she is truthful (and in a narration: telling the truth)." Extracted by Ibn Majah (2/82), Ahmad (4/136, 5/7), and Al-Bayhaqi (10/142). One of his chains is authentic, and the other is like the chain of Ibn Majah, and Al-Busiri authenticated it in "Al-Zawa'id"! The context of the Hadith and the second narration are for Al-Bayhaqi, and it and the additions are for Ahmad in a narration.
Second: From Samurah bin Jundub: "That the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed over a funeral (and in a narration: prayed Subh). When he finished, he said: Is there anyone here from the family of so-and-so? (A man said: He is here). He said: A man dragging his Izar stood up from the back of the people (three times no one answered him), (The Prophet (peace be upon him) said to him: What prevented you in the first two times from answering me?) Listen, I did not mention your name except for good. Indeed, so-and-so - a man among them - is detained by his debt (from Paradise. If you wish, redeem him, and if you wish, surrender him to the punishment of Allah). If you could see his family and those who investigate his affair, they stood up and paid it off for him, (until no one claimed anything from him)" (1). Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/84), Al-Nasa'i (2/233), Al-Hakim (2/25, 26), Al-Bayhaqi (6/4 / 76), Al-Tayalisi in his Musnad (No. 891, 892), and likewise Ahmad (5/11, 13, 20). Some of them from Al-Sha'bi from Samurah, and some inserted Sam'an bin Mashnaj between them, and only on the second way is it authentic. The other narration is for the two Musnads. The first and second additions are for Al-Hakim, as well as the third and fifth. The second is for Al-Bayhaqi. The third and fourth are for Ahmad. The fifth is for Al-Tayalisi, and for him, Ahmad, and Abu Dawood is the sixth.
foot_note: 1. (1) It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam al-Kabir" (f 156/2) with a weak chain.

text: Third from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: "A man died, so we washed him, shrouded him, perfumed him, and placed him for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) where funerals are placed, at the Station of Gabriel. Then we informed the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to pray over him. He came with us, (stepped) a few steps, then said: Perhaps your companion has a debt? They said: Yes, two dinars. So he stayed back. (He said: Pray over your companion). A man from us called Abu Qatadah said to him: O Messenger of Allah, they are upon me. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) kept saying: They are upon you and in your wealth, and the deceased is free from them? He said: Yes. So he prayed over him. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) whenever he met Abu Qatadah would say: (And in a narration: Then he met him the next day and said:) What did the two dinars do? (He said: O Messenger of Allah, he only died yesterday). Until the end of that (And in the other narration: Then he met him the next day and said: What happened to the two dinars?) He said: I have paid them off, O Messenger of Allah. He said: Now his skin has cooled for him." (1) Extracted by Al-Hakim (2/58) and the context is his, Al-Bayhaqi (6/74 - 75), Al-Tayalisi (167 3), and Ahmad (3/330) with a Hasan chain as Al-Haythami said (3/39). As for Al-Hakim, he said: "Authentic in chain"! And Al-Dhahabi agreed! The other narration with the additions are with all of them except Al-Hakim, except the second addition which is for Al-Tayalisi alone.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning due to the lifting of punishment from him after the payment of his debt.

text:
Two Notes:
1 - This Hadith implies that Abu Qatadah's payment of the debt was after the Prophet's (peace be upon him) prayer over the deceased. This is problematic, as it is authentically reported from Abu Qatadah himself that he paid it before the prayer as will be mentioned in Issue (55) paragraph (F). If the story is not interpreted as multiple incidents, then Abu Qatadah's narration is more authentic than Jabir's Hadith, because it contains Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil, about whom there is discussion, and he is Hasan in Hadith when he does not contradict [others], but with contradiction, he is not a proof. And Allah knows best.
2 - These Hadiths indicate that the deceased benefits from the debt being paid on his behalf, even if it is from other than his child, and that payment lifts the punishment from him. They are among the specific exceptions to the generality of the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives} [Al-Najm: 39] and to his saying (peace be upon him): "When a person dies, his deeds are cut off except from three..." The Hadith narrated by Muslim, Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad, and Ahmad. However, paying on his behalf is one thing and giving charity on his behalf is another. Payment is more specific than charity. Otherwise, the Hadiths narrated regarding giving charity on his behalf refer to the child's charity for the parents, which is from their earning according to the text of the Hadith. So it is not permissible to analogize the stranger to them, because it is an analogy with a difference as is apparent. Nor is charity analogized to payment [of debt], because it is more general than it as we mentioned. Perhaps we will discuss this issue with some detail at the end of the book, God willing.
Fourth Hadith: From Jabir also. "That his father was martyred on the day of Uhud, and left six daughters, and left a debt of (thirty Wasqs). (The creditors were harsh in demanding their rights). When the time for harvesting the palms came, I went to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, you know that my father was martyred on the day of Uhud and left much debt, and I would like the creditors to see you. He said: Go and heap every type of date separately. So I did, then I called him. (He came to us when it was morning). When they saw him, they were harsh with me at that moment. When he saw what they were doing, he walked around the largest heap three times (and prayed for blessing in its fruit), then sat on it, then said:
foot_note: None

text:
Call your companions. He continued measuring for them until Allah fulfilled my father's trust (1). And I, by Allah, would have been satisfied if Allah fulfilled my father's trust and I returned to my sisters with not even a date. By Allah, all the heaps remained complete, until I looked at the heap upon which the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was sitting, as if it had not decreased by a single date. (I met the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) at sunset and mentioned that to him, so he laughed and said: Go to Abu Bakr and Umar and inform them. They said: We knew when the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did what he did that this would happen)." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (5/46, 171, 319, 6/462, 463) and the context with additions is his. Narrated similarly by Abu Dawood (2/15), Al-Nasa'i (2/127, 128), Al-Darimi (1/22 - 25), Ibn Majah (2/82 - 83), Al-Bayhaqi (6/64), and Ahmad (3/313, 365, 373, 391, 397) at length and briefly. In Ahmad, there are many additions which I did not include fearing prolongation.
Fifth: From him also, he said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to stand and deliver a sermon. He would praise Allah and extol Him with what He is worthy of, and say: Whomsoever Allah guides, none can misguide, and whomsoever He misguides, none can guide. Indeed, the best speech is the Book of Allah, and the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad. The worst of matters are newly invented ones, and every newly invented matter is an innovation (and every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire). When he mentioned the Hour, his eyes would redden, his voice would rise, and his anger would intensify, as if he were warning an army (saying): The enemy is attacking you morning and evening. Whoever leaves wealth, it is for his heirs, and whoever leaves dependents (Diya') (2) or debt, it is upon me and to me, and I am closer to the believers (and in a narration: to every believer than his own self)." Extracted by Muslim (3/11), Al-Nasa'i (1/234), Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Sunan" (3/2 13 - 214) and in "Al-Asma' wa al-Sifat" (p. 82), Ahmad (3/296, 311, 338 - 371) and the context is his, and Abu Nu'aym in "Al-Hilyah" (3/189). The first addition is his, and for Al-Nasa'i and Al-Bayhaqi
foot_note:
1. (1) Meaning his bequest to him to pay off the debt on his behalf. See his Hadith regarding that in the first chapter of Issue Four. 
2. Meaning family/dependents. Ibn Al-Athir said: "Its origin is the Masdar (verbal noun) of 'Da'a yadi'u diya'an' (to be lost/perish), so the dependents were named by the Masdar just as you say:...

text:
and its chain is authentic according to the condition of Muslim. The second addition is for him and Al-Bayhaqi. The third and fourth are for Ahmad. The second narration is for Muslim. There is a Hadith from Abu Hurairah in the Two Sheikhs and others on this subject, and his Hadith will come in Issue (55) Paragraph (F) Second Hadith.
Sixth: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever from my Ummah carries a debt, then strives to pay it off but dies without paying it, I am his guardian." Extracted by Ahmad (6/74) and its chain is authentic according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs. Al-Mundhiri said (3/33): "Narrated by Ahmad with a good chain, Abu Ya'la, and Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat." Similarly in "Al-Majma'" (4/132) except that he said: "And the narrators of Ahmad are the narrators of the Sahih" (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Shawkani (4/21) attributed it to Ibn Majah, which is an error, for I did not find it with him after much searching, nor did Al-Nabulsi cite it in "Al-Dhakha'ir." Had it been with him, Al-Mundhiri would have attributed it to him, and Al-Haythami would not have cited it in "Al-Majma'" as is known among those occupied with this noble science.

text:
(4) What is Permissible for Those Present and Others
18 - It is permissible for them to uncover the face of the deceased and kiss him, and weep over him for three days. There are Hadiths regarding this:
First: From Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: "When my father was killed, I started uncovering the cloth from his face and weeping. They forbade me, but the Prophet (peace be upon him) did not forbid me. (Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) ordered it to be lifted). My aunt Fatimah started weeping, so the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Whether you weep or do not weep, the angels continued to shade him with their wings until you lifted him." Extracted by the Two Sheikhs, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (3/298). The addition is for Muslim and Al-Nasa'i.
Second: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) came on his horse from his dwelling in Al-Sunh until he dismounted and entered the mosque, (while Umar was speaking to the people). He did not speak to the people until he entered upon Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her). He went towards the Prophet (peace be upon him) who was covered with a Hibra garment. He uncovered his face, then leaned over him and kissed him (between his eyes), then wept and said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Prophet of Allah. Allah will not combine two deaths upon you. As for the death which was written for you, you have died it. In a narration: You have died the death after which you will never die."
foot_note: None

text:
Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/89), Al-Nasa'i (1/260 - 261) and the addition is his in a narration, Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (2155), Al-Bayhaqi (3/406), and others.
Third: From Aisha also: "That the Prophet (peace be upon him) entered upon Uthman bin Maz'un while he was dead. He uncovered his face, then leaned over him and kissed him, and wept until I saw tears flowing on his cheeks." Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi (2/135) who authenticated it, Al-Bayhaqi, and others. It has a supporting evidence with a Hasan chain which can be reviewed in "Majma' al-Zawa'id" (3/20).
Fourth: From Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "We entered with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) upon Abu Sayf - who was the wet nurse's husband (1) for Ibrahim (peace be upon him). The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) took Ibrahim and kissed him and smelled him. Then we entered upon him after that while Ibrahim was breathing his last. The eyes of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) began to shed tears. Abd al-Rahman bin Awf said to him: Even you, O Messenger of Allah? He said: O Ibn Awf! It is mercy. Then he followed it with another [tear/statement] and said: The eye tears, and the heart grieves, and we do not say except what pleases our Lord. And indeed, O Ibrahim, we are saddened by your separation." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/35), Muslim, and Al-Bayhaqi (4/69) similarly.
Fifth: From Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with him): "That the Prophet (peace be upon him) gave the family of Ja'far three days before coming to them, then he came to them and said: Do not weep over my brother after today..." The Hadith. Narrated by Abu Dawood (2/124) and Al-Nasa'i (2/292) and its chain is authentic according to the condition of Muslim. Ahmad extracted it more completely, and its wording will come in "Condolences" God willing.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning the husband of Ibrahim's (peace be upon him) wet nurse.

text:
(5) What is Obligatory upon the Relatives of the Deceased
19 - It is obligatory upon the relatives of the deceased when the news of his death reaches them to do two things:
First: Patience and satisfaction with the Decree, due to the saying of the Exalted: {And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient, (155) Who, when disaster strikes them, say, "Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return." (156) Those are the ones upon whom are blessings from their Lord and mercy. And it is those who are the [rightly] guided. (157)} [Al-Baqarah: 155 - 157]. And due to the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by a woman at a grave who was weeping. He said to her: Fear Allah and be patient. She said: Go away from me, for you have not been afflicted with my calamity! He said: She did not recognize him. It was said to her: He is the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)! She was seized by something like death. She came to the door of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and did not find doorkeepers there. She said..." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/115 - 116), Muslim (3/40 - 41), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/65), and the context is his.
Patience upon the death of children has a great reward. Many Hadiths have come regarding that, I will mention some of them:
First: "No Muslim has three children die, and the Fire touches him except for the fulfillment of the oath."
foot_note: None

text:
Extracted by the Two Sheikhs and Al-Bayhaqi (67/4) from Abu Hurairah.
Second: "There are no two Muslims who have three children die before reaching puberty except that Allah admits them and their parents into Paradise by virtue of His mercy. He said: They will be at a gate of the gates of Paradise, and it will be said to them: Enter Paradise. They will say: Not until our parents come. It will be said to them: Enter Paradise, you and your parents, by virtue of Allah's mercy." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/265), Al-Bayhaqi (4/68), and others from him, and its chain is authentic according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs.
Third: "Any woman who has three children die, they will be a screen for her from the Fire. A woman said: And two? He said: And two." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/94), Muslim, and Al-Bayhaqi (4/67) from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him).
Fourth: "Allah is not pleased for His believing servant, if He takes away his beloved from the people of the earth and he remains patient and seeks reward, with a reward less than Paradise." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/264) from Abdullah bin Amr with a Hasan chain.
Second Matter: From what is obligatory upon relatives: Istirja', which is to say: (Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi raji'un) as came in the previous verse, and add to it his saying: "Allahumma ajurni fi musibati wa akhlif li khayran minha" (O Allah, reward me in my calamity and replace it for me with something better), due to the Hadith of Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: "There is no Muslim whom a calamity befalls and he says what Allah commanded him (Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi raji'un), O Allah, reward me in my calamity and replace it for me with something better, except that Allah replaces it for him with something better. She said: When Abu Salamah died, I said: Which Muslim is better than Abu Salamah, the first household to migrate to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)? Then I said it, so Allah replaced him for me with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). She said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent Hatib bin Abi Balta'ah to me to propose to me for him. I said: I have a daughter and I am jealous. He said: As for her daughter, we pray to Allah to make her independent of her, and I pray to Allah to remove the jealousy." Extracted by Muslim (3/37), Al-Bayhaqi (4/65), and Ahmad (6/309).
foot_note: None

text:
20 - It does not contradict patience if a woman refrains from all adornment, mourning the death of her child or other than him, if she does not exceed three days, except for her husband, for whom she mourns four months and ten days, due to the Hadith of Zaynab bint Abi Salamah who said: "I entered upon Umm Habibah, the wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him), and she said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: 'It is not lawful for a woman who believes in Allah and the Last Day (to) mourn for a deceased person for more than three nights, except for a husband, [for whom she mourns] four months and ten days.' Then I entered upon Zaynab bint Jahsh - when her brother died - she asked for perfume and applied it, then said: I have no need for perfume, except that I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say..." and she mentioned the Hadith. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/114, 9/400 - 401).
21 - But if she does not mourn for other than her husband, to please the husband and fulfill his desire from her, it is better for her, and much good is hoped for them from that, as happened to Umm Sulaym and her husband Abu Talhah Al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with them both). There is no harm in recounting their story here - despite its length - due to the benefits, admonitions, and lessons in it. Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "Malik, the father of Anas, said to his wife Umm Sulaym - who is the mother of Anas -: This man - meaning the Prophet (peace be upon him) - prohibits wine. So he left until he came to Sham and died there. Abu Talhah came and proposed to Umm Sulaym, speaking to her about it. She said: O Abu Talhah! One like you is not rejected, but you are a disbelieving man, and I am a Muslim woman, it is not proper for me to marry you! He said: What is that? Your opportunity? She said: And what is my opportunity? He said: Yellow and white [gold and silver]! She said: I do not want yellow or white, I want Islam from you. (If you submit [become Muslim], that is my dowry, and I do not ask you for other than it). He said: Who will do that for me? She said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) will do that for you. So Abu Talhah set off intending the Prophet (peace be upon him). The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was sitting among his companions. When he saw him, he said: Abu Talhah has come to you with the brightness of Islam between his eyes. He informed the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) what Umm Sulaym said, so he married her on that. Thabit (who is Al-Bunani, one of the narrators of the story from Anas) said: We have not heard of a dowry that was greater than it, that she accepted Islam as a dowry. So he married her. She was a woman with beautiful eyes, in which there was smallness. She was with him until a son was born to him. Abu Talhah loved him intensely. The boy fell sick (intensely sick), and Abu Talhah was humbled by his sickness or weakened by it.
foot_note: None

text: (Abu Talhah used to get up for the morning prayer, perform ablution, come to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and pray with him, and stay with him until close to midday. Then he would come, nap, and eat. When he prayed Dhuhr, he would get ready and go, and would not come back until the 'Atamah (Isha) prayer). Abu Talhah went out in the evening to the Prophet (peace be upon him) (and in a narration: to the mosque) and the boy died. Umm Sulaym said: No one should announce his son to Abu Talhah until I am the one who announces it to him. So she prepared the boy (and covered him), and placed him (in the corner of the house). Abu Talhah came from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and entered upon her (and with him were people from the people of the mosque from his companions). He said: How is my son? She said: O Abu Talhah, he has never been calmer since he complained [of illness] than now (and I hope he has rested!). She brought him his dinner (and offered it to them, so they ate, and the people left). (He said: So he went to his bed and laid his head). Then she got up and perfumed herself, (and beautified herself for him better than she used to do before that). (Then she came until she entered the bed with him. As soon as he smelled the scent of perfume, he did what a man does with his wife). (When it was the end of the night) she said: O Abu Talhah, tell me, if a people lent a loan to a people, then asked them for it, did they have the right to withhold it from them? He said: No. She said: Indeed, Allah Almighty lent you your son as a loan, then He took him back to Himself, so seek reward and be patient! He became angry then said: You left me until I fell into what I fell into [intercourse], then you announced my son to me! (So he said Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi raji'un, and praised Allah). (When he reached morning, he performed Ghusl), then went early to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) (and prayed with him) and informed him. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: May Allah bless you both in your night that passed. She became heavy with that pregnancy. Umm Sulaym used to travel with the Prophet (peace be upon him), going out when he went out, and entering with him when he entered. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: When she gives birth, bring the boy to me. (He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was on a journey and she was with him. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to not enter Medina at night (Turuqan) when coming from a journey. They approached Medina, and labor pains hit her. Abu Talhah was detained with her, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went on. Abu Talhah said: O Lord, You know that I like to go out with Your Messenger when he goes out, and enter with him when he enters, and I have been detained by what You see. He said: Umm Sulaym says: O Abu Talhah, I do not find what I used to find [of pain]. So they proceeded. He said: Labor hit her when they arrived). So she gave birth to a boy. She said to her son Anas: (O Anas! Let him not taste anything until you go early with him to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). (And she sent some dates with him). He said: He spent the night crying, and I spent the night leaning (1) over him, guarding him until I reached morning. So I went early to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), (and he had a Burdah on him), and he was branding camels or sheep (I came to him). When he looked at him, he said to Anas: Did...
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning: Inclining.

text: Bint Milhan give birth? He said: Yes. (He said: Wait, I will be free for you). He said: So he put down what was in his hand, took the boy and said: (Is there anything with him? They said: Yes, dates). The Prophet (peace be upon him) took (some) dates (chewed them, then gathered his saliva), (then opened his mouth, and put it in it). He began rubbing the boy's palate (Tahnik), and the boy began smacking his lips: (sucking some of the sweetness of the dates and the saliva of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). So the first thing to open the intestines of that boy was (1) the saliva of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). He said: Look at the Ansar's love for dates. (He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, name him. He said:) (He wiped his face) and named him Abdullah. (There was no young man among the Ansar better than him). He said: Many men (2) came out from him [his progeny], and Abdullah was martyred in Persia." Extracted by Al-Tayalisi (No. 2056) and the context is his, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/65 - 66), Ibn Hibban (725), and Ahmad (3/105 - 106, 181, 196, 287, 290) and all additions are his as will come. Al-Bukhari (3/132 - 133) and Muslim (6/174 - 175) narrated it briefly restricting to the story of the boy's death. Al-Nasa'i (2/87) narrated a part from its beginning. The first addition is his. The sixth, eighth, fifteenth, and sixteenth are for Al-Bukhari. The nineteenth and twenty-second are for Muslim. The rest are for Ahmad as preceded. I took special care to collect the narrations of this story and its wordings, due to the splendor and majesty in it, and so that the reader may take a comprehensive and truthful idea about it, and thus the lesson and benefit are completed.
