text:
(6) What is Prohibited for the Relatives of the Deceased
22 - The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prohibited matters that some people used to do and still do when someone dies among them. It is obligatory to know them to avoid them, so they must be explained:
A - Wailing (Niyahah) (1), and there are many Hadiths concerning it:
1 - "Four things in my Ummah are from the affairs of Jahiliyyah, they will not leave them: Boasting about lineage, defaming lineage, seeking rain by the stars, and wailing. And he said: If the wailing woman does not repent before her death, she will be raised on the Day of Resurrection wearing a garment of tar and a shield of scabies." Narrated by Muslim (3/45) and Al-Bayhaqi (4/63) from the Hadith of Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari.
2 - "Two things in people are disbelief (Kufr) for them: Defaming lineage, and wailing over the dead." Narrated by Muslim (1/58 45), Al-Bayhaqi (4/63), and others from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah.
3 - "When Ibrahim, the son of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), died, Usamah bin Zaid shouted. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: This is not from me, and the shouter has no right. The heart grieves, and the eye tears, and the Lord is not angered." Narrated by Ibn Hibban (743) and Al-Hakim (1/382) from Abu Hurairah with a Hasan chain.
foot_note: 1. (1) It is something more than weeping. Ibn al-Arabi said: "Wailing is what the Jahiliyyah used to do. Women would stand facing each other shouting, throwing dust on their heads, and beating their faces." Quoted by Al-Abi on Muslim.

text:
4 - From Umm 'Atiyyah who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) took a pledge from us with the oath of allegiance that we should not wail. But none of us fulfilled [it] (meaning among the women who pledged allegiance) except five: Umm Sulaym, Umm Al-Ala, the daughter of Abu Sabrah the wife of Mu'adh, or the daughter of Abu Sabrah, and the wife of Mu'adh." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/137), Muslim (3/46) and the wording is his, Al-Bayhaqi (4/62), and others.
5 - From Anas bin Malik: "That when Umar bin Al-Khattab was stabbed, Hafsah wailed (loudly) over him. He said: O Hafsah, did you not hear the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: The one wailed over is punished?! And he wailed over him. And in another: (in his grave) due to what was wailed over him." Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim (and the context is his), Al-Bayhaqi (4/72 - 73), and Ahmad (No. 268, 288, 290, 315, 334, 254, 386) from paths from Umar, at length and briefly. Ibn Hibban narrated in his "Sahih" (741) only the story of Hafsah.
6 - "Indeed, the deceased is punished by the weeping of his family over him." And in a narration: "The deceased is punished in his grave by what was wailed over him." Extracted by the Two Sheikhs and Ahmad from the Hadith of Ibn Umar. The other narration is for Muslim and Ahmad. Ibn Hibban narrated it in his Sahih (742) from the Hadith of Imran bin Husayn similar to the first narration.
7 - "Whoever is wailed over is punished by what was wailed over him (on the Day of Resurrection)" (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) In this Hadith is a clarification that the weeping mentioned in the Hadith before it is not absolute weeping, but specific weeping which is wailing. The Hadith of Umar mentioned earlier in the second narration indicated this, which is his saying: "by some weeping...". Moreover, the apparent meaning of this Hadith and the two before it is problematic, because it conflicts with some principles of Sharia and its established rules such as the saying of the Exalted: "And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another." Scholars have differed in answering this into eight opinions, and the closest two to correctness are: =

text:
Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/126), Muslim (3/45), Al-Bayhaqi (4/72), and Ahmad (4/245, 252, 255).
8 - From Al-Nu'man bin Bashir who said: "Abdullah bin Rawahah (may Allah be pleased with him) fainted, so his sister Amrah started weeping: 'O my mountain! O such and such! O such and such!' enumerating his qualities. When he regained consciousness, he said: Nothing was said except that it was said to me: Are you like that!? So when he died, she did not weep over him." Extracted by Al-Bukhari and Al-Bayhaqi (4/64).
B, C - Striking cheeks and tearing pockets (clothes), due to his saying (peace be upon him): "He is not of us who strikes the cheeks, tears the pockets, and calls with the call of Jahiliyyah." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/127 - 128, 129), Muslim (1/70), Ibn Al-Jarud (257), Al-Bayhaqi (4/63 - 64), and others from the Hadith of Ibn Masud.
foot_note:
1. = First: What the majority went to, which is that the Hadith applies to the one who requested wailing over him in his will, or did not advise leaving it while knowing that people usually do it. For this reason, Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak said: "If he forbade them during his life but they did something of that after his death, nothing is upon him" (1). And punishment (Adhab) according to them means penalty ('Uqab). Second: That the meaning is "he feels pain by hearing his family's weeping over him, feels pity for them, and grieves, and that is in the Barzakh (interval between death and resurrection), not on the Day of Resurrection. This was the view of Muhammad bin Jarir Al-Tabari and others, and Ibn Taymiyyah, Ibn Al-Qayyim, and others supported it. They said: "The meaning is not that Allah punishes him because of the living's weeping over him. 'Adhab (torment/suffering) is more general than 'Uqab (penalty/punishment), as in his saying: 'Travel is a piece of 'Adhab'. This is not a punishment for a sin, but rather suffering and pain" (2). This might be supported by his saying in Hadith (5 and 6): "in his grave". I used to lean towards this view for a period of time, then it appeared to me that it is weak due to its contradiction with the seventh Hadith which restricted the punishment to being "on the Day of Resurrection". It is clear that this cannot be interpreted as they mentioned. Therefore, the preponderant view with us is the view of the majority. There is no contradiction for them between this restriction and the other restriction in his saying "in his grave", rather one is added to the other, resulting in that he is punished in his grave and on the Day of Resurrection. And this is clear, God willing. _________ 
1. 'Umdat al-Qari (4/74). 
2. See the words of Ibn Taymiyyah in "Majmu'at al-Rasa'il al-Muniriyyah" (2/209) and Ibn Al-Qayyim in "Al-Tahdhib" (4/290 - 293).

text:
D - Shaving hair, due to the Hadith of Abu Burdah bin Abu Musa who said: "Abu Musa fell sick with an illness and fainted. His head was in the lap of a woman from his family. A woman from his family shouted, but he was unable to answer her anything. When he regained consciousness, he said: I am innocent of whom the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was innocent of. Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was innocent of the Saliqah (1), the Haliqah (shaver), and the Shaqqah (clothes tearer)." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/129), Muslim (1/70), Al-Nasa'i (1/263), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/64).
E - Letting hair loose (disheveling), due to the Hadith of a woman among those who pledged allegiance, who said: "Among what the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) took from us in the good (Ma'ruf) that he took pledge from us not to disobey him in, was that we should not scratch a face, nor call woe, nor tear a pocket, nor spread out (dishevel) hair." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/59) and from his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/64) with an authentic chain.
Letting beards grow by some men for a few days out of grief for their deceased, then returning to shaving them after that passes! This letting grow is in the meaning of spreading out hair as is apparent. Added to that is that it is an innovation, and he (peace be upon him) said: "Every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire." Narrated by Al-Nasa'i and Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Asma' wa al-Sifat" with an authentic chain from Jabir.
F - Announcing his death on top of minarets and the like, because it is from Na'y (forbidden announcement). It is proven from Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman that: "When someone died among his family, he would say: Do not announce him to anyone, I fear that it would be Na'y, for I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbidding Na'y."
foot_note: 1. (1) She is the one who raises her voice upon the calamity of death.

text: Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi (2/129) who classified it as Hasan, Ibn Majah (1/450), Ahmad (5/406) and the context is his, and Al-Bayhaqi (4/74). The Marfu' (Prophetic) part was extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4/97) and its chain is Hasan as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath". Na'y linguistically: Is informing of the death of the deceased. So according to this, it includes every informing. However, authentic Hadiths have come indicating the permissibility of a type of informing. Scholars restricted the absolute prohibition with them and said: What is meant by Na'y is the announcement that resembles what the people of Jahiliyyah used to do of shouting at the doors of houses and markets as will come. Therefore, I said:
foot_note: None

text:
(7) Permissible Death Announcement
23 - It is permissible to announce the death if it is not accompanied by what resembles the Na'y of Jahiliyyah. It may be obligatory if there is no one with him to undertake his rights of washing, shrouding, praying over him, and the like. There are Hadiths regarding this:
First: From Abu Hurairah: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) announced the death of Negus (Al-Najashi) on the day he died. He went out to the Musalla (prayer place), lined them up, and said four Takbirs." Extracted by the Two Sheikhs and others. It will be mentioned with all its additions from various paths in Issue (60) Seventh Hadith.
Second: From Anas who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Zayd took the banner and was struck, then Ja'far took it and was struck, then Abdullah bin Rawahah took it and was struck - and the eyes of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) were shedding tears - then Khalid bin Al-Walid took it without command and victory was granted to him." Extracted by Al-Bukhari who titled a chapter for it... [text missing or garbled] ... himself." And before it with his saying: "Chapter: A man announces to the family of the deceased himself." Al-Hafiz said: "The benefit of this title is to indicate that Na'y is not entirely forbidden, but rather what the people of Jahiliyyah used to do was forbidden. They used to send someone to announce the news of the deceased's death at the doors of houses...
foot_note: None

text:
I say: And if this is accepted, then shouting it from the tops of minarets is Na'y (forbidden announcement) a fortiori. Therefore, we firmly stated its prohibition in the paragraph before this one. Other matters might be associated with it which are themselves other prohibitions, such as taking wages for this shouting! And praising the deceased with what is known to be untrue about him, like their saying: "Prayer for the pride of the glorious nobles, and the remnant of the righteous predecessors..."!
24 - It is recommended for the informer to ask people to seek forgiveness for the deceased, due to the Hadith of Abu Qatadah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent the army of commanders. Zayd bin Harithah is over you, if Zayd is struck then Ja'far bin Abi Talib, if Ja'far is struck then Abdullah bin Rawahah Al-Ansari. Ja'far jumped up and said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah, I did not expect you to appoint Zayd over me. He said: Proceed, for you do not know which is better. So they set off and stayed as long as Allah willed. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) ascended the pulpit and ordered that 'The prayer is gathering' be called. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: Good news, or good news has come - Abd al-Rahman (meaning Ibn Mahdi) doubted -, shall I not inform you about this raiding army of yours? They set off and met the enemy. Zayd was struck as a martyr, so seek forgiveness for him - so the people sought forgiveness for him -. Then Ja'far bin Abi Talib took the banner and charged at the people until he was killed as a martyr. I bear witness for him with martyrdom, so seek forgiveness for him. Then Abdullah bin Rawahah took the banner and planted his feet firmly until he was killed as a martyr, so seek forgiveness for him. Then Khalid bin Al-Walid took the banner - and he was not one of the commanders, but he appointed himself -. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) raised his two fingers and said: O Allah, he is a sword from Your swords, so grant him victory - so from that day Khalid was named the Sword of Allah -. Then he said: Mobilize and support your brothers, and let no one stay behind. So the people mobilized in intense heat, walking and riding." Extracted by Ahmad (5/299, 300 - 301) and its chain is Hasan. In this chapter, there is [a report] from Abu Hurairah and others regarding his saying (peace be upon him) when the death of Negus was announced to the people: "Seek forgiveness for your brother." It will come in Issue (60) p. 87 - 88 (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) From what preceded, you know the error of people today in some countries saying: "Al-Fatihah for the soul of so-and-so." It is contrary to the mentioned Sunnah, so it is an innovation without doubt, especially since recitation does not reach the dead according to the correct view, as will be detailed later, God willing.

text:
(8) Signs of a Good Ending
25 - The Wise Lawgiver has set clear signs indicating a good ending - may Allah Almighty write it for us by His grace and favor. Whichever person dies with one of them, it is a glad tiding for him, and what a glad tiding!
First: Pronouncing the Shahada at death. There are Hadiths concerning it:
1 - "Whoever's last words are La ilaha illa Allah enters Paradise." Extracted by Al-Hakim and others with a Hasan chain from Mu'adh. It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah preceded in "Prompting" Paragraph (A) p. 10.
2 - From Talhah bin Ubaidullah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "Umar saw Talhah bin Ubaidullah heavy [sad/troubled]. He said: What is the matter, O Abu so-and-so? Perhaps the wife of your uncle has upset you, O Abu so-and-so? He said: No - (and he praised Abu Bakr) - except that I heard from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) a Hadith which nothing prevented me from asking him about except reliance upon it, until he died. I heard him say: I know a word that no servant says at his death except that his color brightens and Allah relieves him of his distress. He said: So Umar said: I know what it is! He said: And what is it? He said: Do you know a word greater than the word he commanded his uncle with at death: La ilaha illa Allah? Talhah said: You have spoken the truth, it is it, by Allah, it is it." Extracted by Imam Ahmad (No. 1384) and its chain is authentic, Ibn Hibban (2) similarly, and Al-Hakim (1/350, 351) and the addition is his. He said: "Authentic according to their condition" and Al-Dhahabi agreed. There are Hadiths in this chapter mentioned in "Prompting."
foot_note: None

text:
Second: Dying with sweat on the forehead, due to the Hadith of Buraydah bin Al-Khasib (may Allah be pleased with him): "That he was in Khorasan, and he visited a brother of his who was sick. He found him dying, and behold, he was sweating on his forehead. He said: Allah is Greatest! I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: The death of a believer is with sweat on the forehead." Extracted by Ahmad (5/357, 360) and the context is his, Al-Nasa'i (1/259), Al-Tirmidhi (2/128) who classified it as Hasan, Ibn Majah (1/443 - 444), Ibn Hibban (730), Al-Hakim (1/761), and Al-Tayalisi (808). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim" and Al-Dhahabi agreed! There is some question about this which there is no room to mention here, especially since one of Al-Nasa'i's chains is authentic according to the condition of Al-Bukhari. It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him). Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and "Al-Kabir," and its narrators are trustworthy narrators of the Sahih, as in "Al-Majma'" (2/325).
Third: Dying on the night of Friday or its day, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "There is no Muslim who dies on Friday, or the night of Friday, except that Allah protects him from the trial of the grave." Extracted by Ahmad (6582 - 6646) from two paths from Abdullah bin Amr, and Al-Tirmidhi from one of the two aspects. It has supporting evidences from Anas, Jabir bin Abdullah, and others. So the Hadith, with the sum of its paths, is Hasan or Sahih (1).
Fourth: Martyrdom on the battlefield. Allah the Exalted said: {And never think of those who have been killed in the cause of Allah as dead. Rather, they are alive with their Lord, receiving provision, (169) Rejoicing in what Allah has bestowed upon them of His bounty, and they receive good tidings about those [to be martyred] after them who have not yet joined them - that there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve. (170) They receive good tidings of favor from Allah and bounty and [of the fact] that Allah does not allow the reward of believers to be lost (171)} [Al-Imran: 169 - 171]. There are Hadiths regarding this:
1 - "The martyr has six qualities with Allah: He is forgiven with the first gush of his blood, he sees his seat in...
foot_note: 1. (1) Refer to "Tuhfat al-Ahwadhi"

text:
Paradise, he is protected from the punishment of the grave, he is secure from the Greatest Terror, he is adorned with the garment of faith, he is married to the Houris (Hur al-'Ayn), and he intercedes for seventy people of his relatives." Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi (3/17) who authenticated it, Ibn Majah (2/184), and Ahmad (131) and its chain is authentic. Then he extracted it (4/200) from the Hadith of Ubadah bin Al-Samit and from the Hadith of Qays Al-Judhami (4/200), and their chains are also authentic.
2 - From a man from the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him): "That a man said: O Messenger of Allah, why are the believers tested in their graves except the martyr? He said: The flashing of swords over his head is sufficient as a trial." Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (1/289) and from him Al-Qasim Al-Sarakusti in "Al-Hadith" (2/165 / 1) and its chain is authentic.
(Note): This martyrdom is hoped for the one who asks for it sincerely from his heart, even if martyrdom in battle is not facilitated for him, due to the evidence of his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever asks Allah for martyrdom sincerely, Allah will raise him to the status of the martyrs even if he dies on his bed." Extracted by Muslim (2/49) and Al-Bayhaqi (9/169) from Abu Hurairah. It has supporting evidences in "Al-Mustadrak" (2/77).
Fifth: Dying as a fighter (Ghazi) in the cause of Allah. There are two Hadiths:
1 - "What do you consider the martyr among you? They said: O Messenger of Allah, whoever is killed in the cause of Allah is a martyr. He said: Indeed, the martyrs of my Ummah would then be few. They said: Then who are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Whoever is killed in the cause of Allah is a martyr, whoever dies in the cause of Allah is a martyr, whoever dies in a plague is a martyr, whoever dies of a stomach disease (1) is a martyr, and the drowned one is a martyr." Extracted by Muslim (6/51) and Ahmad (2/522) from Abu Hurairah.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning by abdominal disease, which is dropsy and swelling of the belly. It is also said: it is diarrhea, and it is said: the one who complains of his belly.

In this chapter, there is [a report] from Umar in Al-Hakim (2/109) and Al-Bayhaqi.
2 - "Whoever sets out (i.e., goes out) in the cause of Allah and dies or is killed is a martyr, or his horse or camel tramples him, or a venomous creature stings him, or he dies on his bed by whatever death Allah wills, he is a martyr and he will have Paradise." Extracted by Abu Dawood (1/391), Al-Hakim (2/78), and Al-Bayhaqi (9/166) from the Hadith of Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari, and Al-Hakim authenticated it, but it is only Hasan.
Sixth: Dying of plague (Ta'un). There are Hadiths:
1 - From Hafsah bint Sirin: Anas bin Malik said to me: How did Yahya bin Abi Amrah die? I said: Of plague. He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Plague is martyrdom for every Muslim." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (10/156 - 157), Al-Tayalisi (2113), and Ahmad (3/150, 220, 223, 258 - 265).
2 - From Aisha that she asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) about the plague? The Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) informed her: "That it was a punishment Allah sends upon whom He wills, but Allah made it a mercy for the believers. There is no servant who is afflicted with plague and stays in his land patiently knowing that nothing will befall him except what Allah has written for him, except that he will have the like of the reward of a martyr." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (10/157 - 158), Al-Bayhaqi (3/376), and Ahmad (6/64, 145, 252).
3 - "The martyrs and those who died of plague will come. The people of plague will say: We are martyrs. It will be said: Look, if their wounds are like the wounds of martyrs, flowing with blood that smells like musk, then they are martyrs. And they will find them so." Extracted by Imam Ahmad (4/185) and Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (Collection 6/55 / 2) with a Hasan chain as Al-Hafiz said (10/159) from 'Utbah bin Abd Al-Sulami (may Allah be pleased with him). It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Al-Irbad bin Sariyah (may Allah be pleased with him) extracted by Al-Nasa'i (2/63),

In this chapter, there is [a report] from Abu Hurairah, and the first Hadith preceded in "The Fifth Paragraph," and it will also come in "The Eighth and Ninth." And from Ubadah, it will come in "The Tenth."
Seventh: Dying of a stomach disease. There are two Hadiths:
1 - "...and whoever dies in the stomach [disease] is a martyr." Narrated by Muslim and others, and it preceded in full in "The Fifth."
2 - From Abdullah bin Yasar who said: "I was sitting with Sulayman bin Surad and Khalid bin 'Urfutah. They mentioned a man who died, he died of his stomach. They desired to be witnesses to his funeral. One of them said to the other: Didn't the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: 'Whoever is killed by his stomach will not be punished in his grave'? The other said: Yes (and in a narration: You have spoken the truth)." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/289), Al-Tirmidhi (2/160) who classified it as Hasan, Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (No. 728 - Mawarid), Al-Tayalisi (1288), and Ahmad (4/262) and its chain is authentic.
Eighth and Ninth: Dying by drowning and collapsing [of a building/structure]. Due to his saying (peace be upon him): "The martyrs are five: The one who dies of plague, the one who dies of a stomach disease, the one who dies of drowning, the one who dies under debris (Sahib al-Hadm), and the martyr in the cause of Allah." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (6/33 - 34), Muslim (6/51), Al-Tirmidhi (2/159), and Ahmad (2/325, 533) from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah.
Tenth: The death of a woman in her post-partum period due to her child. Due to the Hadith of Ubadah bin Al-Samit: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) visited Abdullah bin Rawahah. He said: He moved (1) for him from his bed. He said: Do you know who the martyrs of my Ummah are? They said: Being killed as a Muslim is martyrdom. He said: Indeed, the martyrs of my Ummah would then be...

few! Being killed as a Muslim is martyrdom, plague is martyrdom, and the woman killed by her child being Jum'a (1) is martyrdom, (her child drags her by his umbilical cord (2) to Paradise)." Extracted by Ahmad (4/201 - 5/323), Al-Darimi (2/208), and Al-Tayalisi (582) and its chain is authentic. It has other paths in "Al-Musnad" (4/315, 317, 328). In this chapter, there is [a report] from Safwan bin Umayyah in Al-Darimi, Al-Nasa'i (1/289), and Ahmad (6/465 - 466). And from Uqbah bin Amir in Al-Nasa'i (2/62 - 63). And from Rashid bin Hubaysh in Ahmad (3/289), and its narrators are trustworthy. Al-Mundhiri said in "Al-Targhib" (2/201): "Its chain is... [text missing]" and in it is the addition which is in the Hadith of Ubadah in Al-Tayalisi and Ahmad. And from Jabir bin Atik, and its wording will come in the next paragraph:
Eleventh and Twelfth: Dying by burning and pleurisy (Dhat al-Janb) (3). There are Hadiths, the most famous of which is from Jabir bin Atik raised (Marfu'): "Martyrs are seven besides being killed in the cause of Allah: The one who dies of plague is a martyr, the drowned is a martyr, the one with pleurisy is a martyr, the burned is a martyr, the one who dies under debris is a martyr, and the woman who dies pregnant (Bi-Jum') (4) is a martyr." Extracted by Malik (1/232 - 233), Abu Dawood (2/26), Al-Nasa'i (1/261), Ibn...

1. (1) She is the one who dies while there is a child in her womb. See the words of "Al-Nihayah" in the upcoming comment shortly. 
2. Al-Surrah is what remains after cutting of what the midwife cuts, and Al-Surar is what she cuts, and it is also Al-Surr with Damma. 
3. It is a hot tumor that occurs in the membrane lining the ribs. 
4. In "Al-Nihayah": "Meaning she dies while there is a child in her womb. It was said: the one who dies as a virgin. Al-Jum' with Damma means combined, like Dhukhr meaning Mudhkhar (stored). Al-Kisa'i pronounced the Jeem with Kasra. The meaning is that she died with something combined in her not separated from her, like a pregnancy or virginity." I say: The intended meaning here is definitely pregnancy, evidenced by the Hadith mentioned previously in "The Tenth" with the wording "killed by her child being Jum'a".

Majah (2/185 - 186), Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (1616 - Mawarid), Al-Hakim (1/352), and Ahmad (5/446). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic in chain"! And Al-Dhahabi agreed! I do not doubt the authenticity of its text, because it has many supporting evidences, most of which have preceded. Al-Tabarani narrated from the Hadith of Rabi' Al-Ansari raised (Marfu') similarly without mentioning debris. Al-Mundhiri said, followed by Al-Haythami (5/300): "And its narrators are those used as proof in the Sahih." Ahmad (4/157) narrated from the Hadith of Uqbah bin Amir raised (Marfu') with the wording: "The one who dies of pleurisy is a martyr." Its chain is Hasan in supporting evidences. This sentence came in some paths of the Hadith of Abu Hurairah preceded in "The Fifth," extracted by Ahmad (2/441 - 442) and in it is Muhammad bin Ishaq who is a Mudallis and he used 'an'ana [said 'from'].
Thirteenth: Dying of Tuberculosis (Al-Sull), due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Killing in the cause of Allah is martyrdom, the woman in post-partum (Nufasa') is martyrdom, burning (1) is martyrdom, drowning is martyrdom, tuberculosis (Al-Sull) is martyrdom, and the stomach disease is martyrdom." It says in "Majma' al-Zawa'id" (2/317 - 301): "Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat, and in it is Mandal bin Ali, and there is much talk about him but he has been trusted." Ahmad added in a narration of his: "And tuberculosis." And its narrators are trustworthy, and Al-Mundhiri classified it as Hasan as preceded. It has another supporting evidence in "Al-Majma'".

Fourteenth: Dying while defending property intended to be usurped. There are Hadiths:
1 - "Whoever is killed defending his property, (and in a narration: whoever's property is desired unjustly and he fights and is killed) is a martyr." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (5/93), Muslim (1/87), Abu Dawood (2/285), Al-Nasa'i (2/173), Al-Tirmidhi (2/315) who authenticated it, Ibn Majah (2/123), and Ahmad (1668, 6823, 6829). All of them with the second narration except Al-Bukhari and Muslim with the first, which is a narration for Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad (6822) from Abdullah bin Amr.
2 - From Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "A man came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, what if a man comes wanting to take my property? He said: Do not give him your property. He said: What if he fights me? Fight him. He said: What if he kills me? He said: Then you are a martyr. He said: What if I kill him? He said: He is in the Fire." Extracted by Muslim (1/87), and Al-Nasa'i (2/173) and Ahmad (1/339 - 360) extracted it from another path from him.
3 - From Mukhariq (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "A man came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: A man comes to me wanting my property? He said: Remind him of Allah. He said: If he does not remember? He said: Then seek help against him from the authority. He said: If the authority is far from me (and he rushes upon me)? He said: Fight for your property until you become one of the martyrs of the Hereafter, or you protect your property." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad (5/294, 294, 295) and the addition is his, and its chain is authentic according to the condition of Muslim.
Fifteenth and Sixteenth: Dying while defending religion and life (self). There are two Hadiths:
foot_note: None

1 - "Whoever is killed defending his property is a martyr, whoever is killed defending his family is a martyr, whoever is killed defending his religion is a martyr, and whoever is killed defending his blood is a martyr." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/275), Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi (2/316) who authenticated it, and Ahmad (1652, 1653) from Sa'id bin Zaid, and its chain is authentic.
2 - "Whoever is killed defending against injustice to him is a martyr" (1). Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (2/173 - 174) from the Hadith of Suwayd bin Muqarrin, and Ahmad (2780) from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas. Its chain is authentic if it is safe from the disconnection between Sa'd bin Ibrahim bin Abd al-Rahman bin Awf and Ibn Abbas, but one of the two paths strengthens the other, and in the first there is one whom no one declared trustworthy except Ibn Hibban.
Seventeenth: Dying while guarding (Murabit) in the cause of Allah. We mention two Hadiths in it:
1 - "Guarding (Ribat) for a day and a night is better than fasting a month and praying its nights. And if he dies, his deed that he used to do continues for him, his provision flows to him, and he is safe from the Tempter (Al-Fattan)." Narrated by Muslim (6/51), Al-Nasa'i (2/62), Al-Tirmidhi (3/18), Al-Hakim (2/80), and Ahmad (5/440, 441) from the Hadith of Salman Al-Farisi. Al-Tabarani narrated it and added: "And he is resurrected on the Day of Resurrection as a martyr." But in its chain are those whom Al-Haythami did not know in his "Majma'" (5/290), and Al-Mundhiri remained silent about it in his "Targhib" (2/150).
2 - "Every dead person has his deeds sealed except the one who died guarding in the cause of Allah, for his deed grows for him until the Day of Resurrection, and he is safe from the trial of the grave." Extracted by Abu Dawood (1/391), Al-Tirmidhi (3/2) who authenticated it, Al-Hakim (2/144), and Ahmad (6/20) from the Hadith of Fadalah bin Ubayd. Al-Hakim said:

Eighteenth: Dying upon a righteous deed, due to his saying (peace be upon him) "Whoever says: La ilaha illa Allah: "Whoever says: La ilaha illa Allah seeking the Face of Allah and his life is sealed with it enters Paradise. And whoever fasts a day seeking the Face of Allah and his life is sealed with it enters Paradise. And whoever gives a charity seeking the Face of Allah and his life is sealed with it enters Paradise." Extracted by Ahmad (5/391) from Hudhayfah who said: "I leaned the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) against my chest and he said" then he mentioned it. Its chain is authentic. Al-Mundhiri said (2/61) "There is no harm in it."

(9) People's Praise for the Deceased
26 - Praise with good for the deceased by a group of truthful Muslims, at least two, from his neighbors who knew him, from those of righteousness and knowledge, necessitates Paradise for him. There are Hadiths regarding this:
1 - From Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "A funeral passed by the Prophet (peace be upon him) and they praised it with good, (and tongues followed in praise). They said: He used to - as far as we know - love Allah and His Messenger). The Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) said: It is obligatory, it is obligatory, it is obligatory. Then a funeral passed and they spoke ill of it, (and tongues followed it in evil). (They said: An evil man he was in the religion of Allah). The Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) said: It is obligatory, it is obligatory, it is obligatory. Umar said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, a funeral passed and they spoke ill of it, and you said: It is obligatory, it is obligatory, it is obligatory? The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Whom you praised with good, Paradise is obligatory for him, and whom you spoke ill of, the Fire is obligatory for him. (The angels are the witnesses of Allah in the sky, and) you are the witnesses of Allah on earth, you are the witnesses of Allah on earth, you are the witnesses of Allah on earth. (And in a narration: And the believers are the witnesses of Allah on earth). (Indeed, Allah has angels who speak on the tongues of the children of Adam regarding what is in a person of good and evil).'" Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/177 - 178, 5/192 - 193), Muslim (3/53), Al-Nasa'i (1/273), Al-Tirmidhi (2/158) who authenticated it, Ibn Majah (1/454), Al-Hakim (1/377), Al-Tayalisi (2062), and Ahmad (3/179, 186, 197, 211, 245, 281) from paths from...
foot_note: None

text:
Anas, and the context is Muslim's. The other narration is Ibn Majah's, and a narration for Ahmad and Al-Bukhari. All additions except the second to last are for Ahmad. The first of them is for Al-Bukhari, and the last is for Al-Hakim who authenticated it, and Al-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said. Abu Dawood (2/72), Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Tayalisi (2388), and Ahmad (2/261, 466, 470, 498, 528) extracted it from two paths from Abu Hurairah. The last addition is for Al-Nasa'i from him, and its chain is authentic, and the other path has a Hasan chain.
2 - From Abu Al-Aswad Al-Dili who said: "I came to Medina while there was a disease in it, and they were dying in great numbers. I sat with Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him), and a funeral passed by, and good was spoken of it. Umar said: It is obligatory. I said: What is obligatory, O Commander of the Faithful? He said: I said as the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Any Muslim for whom four testify to good, Allah enters him into Paradise. We said: And three? He said: And three. He said: We said and two? He said: And two. Then we did not ask him about one." Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi who authenticated it, Al-Bayhaqi (4/75), Al-Tayalisi (No. 23), and Ahmad (No. 129, 204).
3 - "There is no Muslim who dies, and four of the people of the households of his closest neighbors testify that they know nothing but good from him, except that Allah Almighty and Blessed says: I have accepted your statement, or He said: your testimony, and I have forgiven him what you do not know" (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Know that the sum of these three Hadiths indicates that this testimony is not specific to the Companions, but it is also for those after them from the believers who follow their path in faith, knowledge, and truthfulness. This was asserted by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar in "Al-Fath," so let whoever wants more explanation refer to his words. Moreover, restricting the testimony to four in the third Hadith, apparently it was before the Hadith of Umar before it, in which the testimony of two suffices, and that is the relied upon [view]. Furthermore, as for people's saying today after the funeral prayer in some countries: "What do you bear witness regarding him? Bear witness good for him!" And they answer by saying righteous, or from the people of goodness, and the like, this is definitely not what is meant by the Hadith. Rather, it is an ugly innovation, because it was not from the practice of the Salaf, and because those who testify to that usually do not know the deceased. Indeed, they may testify contrary to what they know in response to the desire of the one asking for the testimony of good, thinking that this benefits the deceased, and being ignorant that the beneficial testimony is only that which conforms to the reality in the soul of the one testifying, as indicated by his saying in the first Hadith "Indeed, Allah has angels who speak on the tongues of the children of Adam regarding what is in a person of good and evil."

It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah: extracted by Ahmad (2/408), and in it is a sheikh from the people of knowledge who was not named, and the narrator from him is Abdul-Hamid bin Ja'far Al-Ziyadi, and I did not find a biography for him. Death during an Eclipse
27 - If someone's death coincides with the eclipse of the sun or the moon, that does not indicate anything. Believing that it indicates the greatness of the deceased is from the superstitions of Jahiliyyah which the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) nullified on the day his son Ibrahim (peace be upon him) died, and the sun eclipsed. He addressed the people, praised Allah and extolled Him, then said: "As to what follows, O people, the people of Jahiliyyah used to say that the sun and the moon do not eclipse except for the death of a great person. Indeed, they are two signs from the signs of Allah; they do not eclipse for the death of anyone nor for his life. But Allah frightens His servants with them. So if you see anything of that, rush to His remembrance, supplication, seeking forgiveness, and to charity, freeing slaves, and prayer in the mosques until it clears." This context is picked from a collection of Hadiths I cited in a book of mine on "Eclipse Prayer" in which I discussed its paths and wordings, then collected their summary at the end in one context, and this is part of it. Most of it is in the "Two Sahihs" and "The Sunan."

text:
(10) Washing the Deceased
28 - When the deceased dies, it is obligatory upon a group of people to hasten to wash him. As for hastening, its evidence preceded in Chapter Three (Issue 17 Paragraph E), (p. 13). As for the obligation of washing, it is due to his (peace be upon him) command for it in more than one Hadith:
1 - "Wash him with water and sidr..." Its full wording and extraction passed in the referred issue (Paragraph D), (p. 12-13).
2 - His saying (peace be upon him) regarding his daughter Zaynab (may Allah be pleased with her): "Wash her three, or five, or seven, or more than that..." The Hadith. It will come in full with its extraction in the next issue.
29 - The following matters should be observed in washing him:
First: Washing him three times or more according to what those undertaking his washing see fit.
Second: That the washings be odd numbered (Witr).
Third: That sidr, or what takes its place in cleaning like potash and soap, be combined with some of them.
foot_note: None

text:
Fourth: That something of perfume, and camphor is best, be mixed with the last washing.
Fifth: Undoing the braids and washing them well.
Sixth: Combing his/her hair.
Seventh: Making it into three braids for a woman and casting them behind her.
Eighth: Starting with the right side and the places of ablution (Wudu).
Ninth: That men undertake washing the male, and women the female, except what is exempted as will be explained.
The evidence for these matters is the Hadith of Umm 'Atiyyah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "The Prophet (peace be upon him) entered upon us while we were washing his daughter (Zaynab), and said: Wash her three, or five (or seven), or more than that, if you see fit, (She said: I said: Odd number? He said: Yes), and put camphor or something of camphor in the last one. When you finish, inform me. When we finished, we informed him, so he threw his Haqwu (1) to us and said: Cover her (2) with it (meaning his Izar/waist wrapper), (She said: And we combed her into three (horns/braids), (and in a narration: we undid it then washed it) (and braided her hair into three thirds: her two sides and her forelock) and cast them [behind her]), (She said: And he said to us: Start with her right side and the places of ablution from her)." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/99 - 104), Muslim (3/47 - 48), Abu Dawood (2/60 - 61), Al-Nasa'i (1/266 - 267), Al-Tirmidhi (2/130 - 131), Ibn Majah (1/445), Ibn Al-Jarud (258, 259), and Ahmad (5/84 - 85, 4076 - 408). Al-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih Hadith, and the practice is upon this among the people of knowledge." The second narration is for Al-Bukhari and Al-Nasa'i. The first addition is for Muslim, the second for him, Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, and Al-Nasa'i. The third is for Al-Nasa'i, and the Two Sheikhs have its meaning. The fourth is for Al-Bukhari and Abu Dawood.
foot_note:
1. (1) Meaning his Izar. Ibn Al-Athir said: "The origin of Haqwu is the place where the Izar is tied, and its plural is Aḥqu and Aḥqā', then the Izar was named by it due to proximity." 
2. Meaning make it her shi'ar (undergarment). Shi'ar is the garment that touches the body because it touches the hair (Sha'r).

text:
The fifth is for him, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad. The sixth is for the Two Sheikhs and Ahmad. The seventh is for Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad. The last is for all of them.
Tenth: That he be washed with a cloth or similar under a cover for his body after stripping him of all his clothes, for such was the practice during the time of the Prophet (peace be upon him) as indicated by the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): "When they wanted to wash the Prophet (peace be upon him), they said: By Allah, we do not know, should we strip the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) of his clothes as we strip our dead, or wash him with his clothes on? While they differed, Allah cast sleep upon them until there was not a man among them except his chin was on his chest. Then a speaker spoke to them from the side of the house, they did not know who he was: Wash the Prophet (peace be upon him) with his clothes on. So they got up to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and washed him while his shirt was on him, pouring water over the shirt and rubbing him with the shirt, not their hands. Aisha used to say: If I had known beforehand about my affair what I know now, none would have washed him except his wives." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/60), Ibn Al-Jarud in "Al-Muntaqa" (257), Al-Hakim (3/59 - 60) who authenticated it according to the condition of Muslim!, Al-Bayhaqi (3/387), Al-Tayalisi (No. 1530), and Ahmad (6/726) with an authentic chain. Ibn Majah (1/446) narrated from it Aisha's saying at the end: "If I had known..." and Ibn Hibban narrated it in his Sahih (2156).
Eleventh: Exempted from what was mentioned in (Fourth) is the Muhrim, for it is not permissible to perfume him due to his saying in the Hadith which was referred to recently: "Do not apply Hanut to him, and in a narration: And do not perfume him... for he will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection reciting Talbiyah." Extracted by the Two Sheikhs and others as preceded p. 12-13.
Twelfth: Also exempted from what was mentioned in (Ninth) are the spouses, for it is permissible for each of them to undertake washing the other, since there is no evidence preventing it, and the default is permissibility, especially since it is supported by two Hadiths:
1 - From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said:
foot_note: None

text:
"If I had known beforehand about my affair what I know now, none would have washed the Prophet (peace be upon him) except his wives" (1). Extracted by Ibn Majah, and Abu Dawood and others narrated it at the end of her Hadith mentioned recently regarding the washing of the Prophet (peace be upon him).
2 - From her also, she said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) returned to me from a funeral in Al-Baqi', and I was feeling a headache in my head, saying: 'O my head!' He said: 'Rather, I, O my head! What harm would it do you if you died before me, so I washed you, shrouded you, then prayed over you and buried you'." Extracted by Ahmad (6/228), Al-Darimi (1/37 - 38), Ibn Majah (1/448), Ibn Hisham in "Al-Sirah" (2/366 - Bulaq), Al-Daraqutni (192), and Al-Bayhaqi (3/396). In all of their chains is Muhammad bin Ishaq who used 'an'ana [said 'from'], except in Ibn Hisham's narration where he explicitly stated hearing (Tahdith), so the Hadith is proven, and praise be to Allah. However, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar mentioned in "Al-Talkhis" (5/125 Muniriyah Edition) that Salih bin Kaysan followed him in it according to Ahmad and Al-Nasa'i. I say: It is in Ahmad (6/144) but it does not contain the explicit mention of washing. So refer to Al-Nasa'i's narration, perhaps it is in it, for I did not see the Hadith in his Minor Sunan, perhaps it is in his Major one.
Thirteenth: That the one who washes him be the most knowledgeable of the Sunnah of washing, especially if he is from his family and relatives, because those who undertook washing him (peace be upon him) were as we mentioned. Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "I washed the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and I started looking for what usually comes from the deceased but I saw nothing. He was pure alive and dead, may Allah bless him and grant him peace." Extracted by Ibn Majah (1/447), Al-Hakim (1/362), and Al-Bayhaqi (3/388). Its chain is authentic as said in "Al-Zawa'id" (f 92/1). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs." Al-Dhahabi critiqued him saying: "I say: It has disconnection." I say: This is groundless, for the Hadith is from the narration of Ma'mar from Al-Zuhri from Sa'id bin...
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Bayhaqi said: "So she expressed regret over that, and regret is only over what is permissible." I say: And permissibility is the view of Imam Ahmad as narrated by Abu Dawood in his "Masa'il" p. 149.

text:
...Al-Musayyib from Ali. This is a connected chain known for their narration from one another. As for Ma'mar from Al-Zuhri, and Al-Zuhri from Sa'id, it is too famous to mention. As for Sa'id's narration from Ali, it is also connected as indicated by Al-Hafiz in "Al-Tahdhib." He even went so far as to say that he heard from Umar as well (1). In the Mursal of Al-Sha'bi, it is stated that Al-Fadl, meaning Ibn Al-Abbas, and Usamah bin Zaid washed the Prophet (peace be upon him) with Ali (may Allah be pleased with him). Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/69) and its chain is authentic Mursal. It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas. Extracted by Ahmad (3/358) with a weak chain.
30 - For the one who undertakes washing him, there is a great reward with two conditions:
First: That he conceals him, and does not speak of what he might see of disliked things, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever washes a Muslim and conceals him, Allah forgives him forty times. And whoever digs for him and buries him, he is granted reward like the reward of a dwelling he provided him until the Day of Resurrection. And whoever shrouds him, Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection from the silk and brocade of Paradise." Extracted by Al-Hakim (1/354, 362) and Al-Bayhaqi (3/395) from the Hadith of Abu Rafi' (may Allah be pleased with him). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim." Al-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said. Al-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Kabir" with the wording: "Forty major sins." Al-Mundhiri said (4/171) and Al-Haythami followed him (3/21): "Its narrators are those used as proof in the Sahih." Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in "Al-Dirayah" (1/40): "Its chain is strong."
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: What he mentioned regarding Umar is questionable, and there is no room now to clarify it. As for his hearing from Ali, it is authentic, because Ali died in the year 40, and Sa'id was twenty-eight years old at that time, so where is the disconnection?!

text:
Second: That he seeks thereby the Face of Allah, desiring no reward or thanks or anything of worldly matters, because it is established in the Sharia that Allah the Blessed and Exalted does not accept of acts of worship except what is purely for His Noble Face. The evidences for that from the Book and Sunnah are very many. I suffice here with mentioning six of them:
1 - The saying of the Blessed and Exalted: {Say, "I am only a man like you, to whom has been revealed that your god is one God. So whoever would hope for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone."} [Al-Kahf: 110], meaning: he does not intend by it other than the Face of Allah Exalted.
2 - His saying also: {And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion...} [Al-Bayyinah: 5].
3 - His saying (peace be upon him): "Actions are but by intentions, and every man shall have only what he intended. Thus he whose emigration was to Allah and His Messenger, his emigration was to Allah and His Messenger. And he whose emigration was to achieve some worldly benefit or to take some woman in marriage, his emigration was to that for which he emigrated." Extracted by Al-Bukhari at the beginning of his "Sahih," Muslim, and others from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him).
4 - His saying also: "Give glad tidings to this Ummah of eminence, establishment in the lands, victory, and elevation in religion. And whoever among them does the work of the Hereafter for the sake of the world, he has no share in the Hereafter." Extracted by Ahmad and his son in Zawa'id "Al-Musnad" (5/134), Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (Mawarid), and Al-Hakim (4/311) who said: "Authentic in chain." Al-Dhahabi agreed, and Al-Mundhiri approved it (1/31). I say: Abdullah's chain is authentic according to the condition of Al-Bukhari.
foot_note: None

text:
5 - From Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "A man came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: What do you say about a man who fought seeking reward and fame, what is for him? He said: Nothing is for him. He repeated it three times, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saying to him: Nothing is for him. Then he said: Indeed, Allah does not accept of deeds except what is purely for Him and by which His Face is sought." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (2/59) and its chain is good (Jayyid) as Al-Mundhiri said (1/24).
6 - His saying (peace be upon him): "Allah the Mighty and Majestic said: I am the most self-sufficient of partners, needing no partnership. Whoever does a deed in which he associates anyone else with Me, I am innocent of him, and it is for the one he associated." Narrated by Ibn Majah in "Al-Zuhd" from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, and its chain is authentic according to the condition of Muslim. He extracted it in his "Sahih" (8/223) similarly.
31 - It is recommended for the one who washed [the dead] to perform Ghusl (ritual bath), due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever washes a dead person, let him perform Ghusl, and whoever carries him, let him perform Wudu (ablution)." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/62 - 63), Al-Tirmidhi (2/132) who classified it as Hasan, Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (751 - Mawarid), Al-Tayalisi (2314), and Ahmad (280, 433, 454, 472). From paths from Abu Hurairah. Some of its paths are Hasan, and some are authentic according to the condition of Muslim (1). Ibn al-Qayyim listed eleven paths from him in "Tahdhib al-Sunan," then said: "These paths indicate that the Hadith is preserved (Mahfuz)." I say: Ibn al-Qattan authenticated it, as did Ibn Hazm in "Al-Muhalla" (1/250, 2/23 - 25) and Al-Hafiz in "Al-Talkhis" (2/134 - Muniriyah) and said: The apparent command implies obligation, but we did not say so because of two Hadiths: First, his saying (peace be upon him): "You are not required to perform Ghusl for washing your dead if you wash him, for your dead is not impure (Najis), so it is sufficient for you to wash your hands."
foot_note: 1. (1) I have explained that thoroughly in my book "Al-Thamar al-Mustatab" - "Book of Ghusl".

text:
Extracted by Al-Hakim (1/386) and Al-Bayhaqi (3/398) from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Al-Bukhari" and Al-Dhahabi agreed! But it is only Hasan in chain as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Talkhis" because it contains Amr bin Amr, about whom there is discussion. Al-Dhahabi himself said in "Al-Mizan" after citing the sayings of Imams about him: "His Hadith is Salih Hasan."
Second: The saying of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him): "We used to wash the dead, so some of us would perform Ghusl and some of us would not perform Ghusl." Extracted by Al-Daraqutni (191) and Al-Khatib in his History (5/424) with an authentic chain as Al-Hafiz said. Imam Ahmad indicated this, for Al-Khatib narrated from him that he urged his son Abdullah to write this Hadith.
32 - It is not prescribed to wash the martyr slain in battle, even if it happens that he was Junub (in a state of major ritual impurity). There are Hadiths regarding this:
First: From Jabir who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Bury them in their blood - meaning on the day of Uhud - and he did not wash them. (And in a narration) he said: I am a witness over these. Wrap them in their blood, for there is no wound incurred (for the sake of Allah) except that it comes on the Day of Resurrection bleeding, its color the color of blood, and its smell the smell of musk." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/165) with the first narration, Abu Dawood (2/60), Al-Nasa'i (1/277 - 278), Al-Tirmidhi (2/147) who authenticated it, Ibn Majah (1/461 - 462), Al-Bayhaqi (4/10) with the other narration, and Ibn Sa'd in "Al-Tabaqat" (Vol 3 Part 1 p 7) and the addition is his. Its chain is authentic according to the condition of Muslim. The other narration has another path in Al-Musnad (3/296) from the narration of Ibn Jabir from Jabir raised (Marfu') with the wording: "Do not wash them, for every wound will exude musk on the Day of Resurrection, and he did not pray over them." Its chain is authentic if Ibn Jabir is Abd al-Rahman, but if it is Muhammad the brother of Abd al-Rahman, then it is weak. It is not clear to me which of them is intended here. As for Al-Shawkani, he said in "Nayl al-Awtar" (4/25): "It is a narration with no defect."
foot_note: None

text:
It has a third path, extracted by Ahmad (5/431 - 432) from the narration of Abdullah bin Tha'labah bin Su'ayr, who has vision [saw the Prophet] but hearing from him is not proven, so it is Mursal Sahabi which is a proof. The chain to him is authentic, and Al-Bayhaqi connected it (4/11) from his Hadith from Jabir.
Second: From Abu Barzah that the Prophet (peace be upon him) was in a battle of his, and Allah granted him victory. He said to his companions: Do you miss anyone? They said: Yes, so-and-so, and so-and-so, and so-and-so. Then he said: Do you miss anyone? They said: No. He said: But I miss Julaybib. Seek him. He was sought among the slain, and they found him next to seven he had killed, then they killed him! The Prophet (peace be upon him) came and stood over him and said: He killed seven then they killed him! This one is of me, and I am of me and I am of him (he said it twice or thrice). (Then he said with his arms like this and spread them). He said: So he placed him on his forearms, he had no bed except the forearms of the Prophet (peace be upon him). He said: So a grave was dug for him and he was placed in his grave. He did not mention washing." Extracted by Muslim (7/152) and the context is his, Al-Tayalisi (924) and the two additions are his, Ahmad (4/421, 425), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/21).
Third: From Anas: "That the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, and were buried in their blood, and he did not pray over them (except Hamzah)." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/59) and the addition is his and Al-Hakim's - whose wording will come - and Al-Tirmidhi (2/138 - 139) who classified it as Hasan, Ibn Sa'd (3 Part 1 p 8), Al-Hakim (1/365 - 366), Al-Bayhaqi (4/10 - 11), and Ahmad (3/128). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim," and Al-Dhahabi agreed. Al-Nawawi said in "Al-Majmu'" (5/265) after attributing it to Abu Dawood alone: "Its chain is Hasan or Sahih." I say: It is Hasan in my view, although it is according to the condition of Muslim.
Fourth: From Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr in the story of Uhud and the martyrdom of Hanzalah bin Abi 'Amir, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said:
foot_note: None

text:
"Indeed, your companion is being washed by the angels, so ask his companion [wife]." She said: He went out while Junub (in major impurity) when he heard the alarming call (1). The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "That is why the angels washed him." Extracted by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", Al-Hakim (3/204), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/15) with a good (Jayyid) chain as Al-Nawawi said in a place in "Al-Majmu'" (5/260) then forgot that and said later (5/263): "And we mentioned that it is a weak Hadith"! Glory be to the One who does not forget. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim"! And Al-Dhahabi approved it!
Fifth: From Ibn Abbas who said: "Hamzah bin Abdul-Muttalib and Hanzalah bin Al-Rahib were struck, and they were Junub. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: I saw the angels washing them." Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (3/1489) and its chain is Hasan, as Al-Haythami said in "Al-Majma'" (3/23). Al-Hakim narrated it (3/195) without mentioning Hanzalah, and said: "Authentic in chain." Al-Dhahabi critiqued him and was correct, but it has a strong Mursal supporting evidence extracted by Ibn Sa'd (Vol 3 Part 1 p 9) from Al-Hasan Al-Basri raised (Marfu') similarly. I say: Its chain is authentic, all its narrators are trustworthy. In it is a refutation of Al-Hafiz, for he described the Hadith of Ibn Abbas as Gharib (strange) because it mentioned Hamzah in it, although he said about its chain: There is no harm in it, as Al-Shawkani quoted from him (4/26). It appears that Al-Hafiz, may Allah have mercy on him, did not come across this supporting evidence (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) It is the voice that one is terrified of and fears. "Nihayah". 
2. Know that the indication of the Hadith regarding the non-legitimacy of washing the Junub martyr is what the Shafi'is and others mentioned, that if it were obligatory, it would not have been dropped by the washing of the angels, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) would have ordered his washing, because the intent is the human's worship through it. See "Al-Majmu'".

text:
(11) Shrouding the Deceased
33 - After finishing washing the deceased, shrouding him is obligatory, due to the Prophet's (peace be upon him) command for that in the Hadith of the Muhrim whose she-camel broke his neck: "...and shroud him..." Agreed upon, and it preceded in full in Chapter (3) Paragraph (D). (p. 12-13)
34 - The shroud or its price should be from the deceased's wealth, even if he leaves nothing else, due to the Hadith of Khabbab bin Al-Aratt who said: "We migrated with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in the cause of Allah, seeking the Face of Allah, so our reward became due upon Allah. Some of us passed away without eating anything of their reward. Among them was Mus'ab bin Umayr, he was killed on the day of Uhud, and nothing was found for him, (and in a narration: and he did not leave) except a Namirah (woolen garment). If we covered his head with it, his feet appeared, and if we placed it on his feet, his head appeared. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: Place it over his head (and in a narration: cover his head with it), and put Idhkhir (1) over his feet. And among us is he whose fruit has ripened and he is harvesting it." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/110), Muslim (3/45) and the context is his, Ibn Al-Jarud in
foot_note: 1. (1) With Kasra on Hamza and Kha - a well-known sweet-smelling grass.

text:
"Al-Muntaqa" (260), Al-Tirmidhi (357) who authenticated it, Al-Nasa'i (1/269), Al-Bayhaqi (3/401), and Ahmad (6/695). The second narration is for him and Al-Tirmidhi. Abu Dawood narrated part of it (2/14, 62) saying regarding Mus'ab: "He was killed on the day of Uhud..." etc. The third narration is for him. In this chapter, there is [a report] from Abd al-Rahman bin Awf extracted by Al-Bukhari and others.
35 - The shroud should be sufficient and ample, covering his entire body, due to the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him): "That the Prophet (peace be upon him) delivered a sermon one day and mentioned a man from his companions who died and was shrouded in an insufficient shroud, and was buried at night. The Prophet (peace be upon him) rebuked burying a man at night until he is prayed over unless a person is compelled to do that. And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'When one of you shrouds his brother, let him shroud him well (if he is able).'" Extracted by Muslim (3/50), Ibn Al-Jarud (268), Abu Dawood (2/62), and Ahmad (3/295, 329). The last sentence of it was narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (2/133) and Ibn Majah from the Hadith of Abu Qatadah. Al-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Hadith." I say: Rather, it is an authentic Hadith, for its chain from Jabir is authentic (1), so how about when the Hadith of Abu Qatadah is added to it? Siddiq Hasan Khan attributed it in "Al-Rawdah al-Nadiyyah" (1/164) to Muslim, which is an error. The addition is Ahmad's in a narration of his. Scholars said: "The meaning of shrouding well is its cleanliness, thickness, covering, and being average. It does not mean extravagance, excessiveness, and preciousness in it."
foot_note: 1. (1) It has another path from Jabir, extracted by him and the one before it by Al-Hakim in "Al-Mustadrak" (1-369), and its chain is authentic.

text:
As for Al-Nawawi's condition that it be of the type of his clothing in life, neither more luxurious nor inferior, I have reservations about it. Because besides lacking evidence, his clothing in life might be precious or poor, so how can his shroud be made of the same type!?
36 - If the shroud falls short of that, and ample shroud is not available, his head and whatever length of his body possible should be covered with it, and whatever remains exposed should be covered with Idhkhir or other grass. There are two Hadiths concerning this:
First: From Khabbab bin Al-Aratt in the story of Mus'ab regarding his Namirah: "Place it over his head (and in a narration: cover his head with it) and put Idhkhir over his feet." Agreed upon, and it preceded in full in Issue (34), (p. 57).
Second: From Harithah bin Mudarrib who said: "I entered upon Khabbab while he had been cauterized (in his stomach) seven times. He said: Were it not that I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: 'Let none of you wish for death,' I would have wished for it. I saw myself with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) not possessing a dirham, and now in the corner of my house are forty thousand dirhams! Then his shroud was brought. When he saw it, he wept and said: But Hamzah did not have a shroud except a black-and-white striped garment (Burdah Malha'); if placed on his head it shrank from his feet, and if placed on his feet it shrank from his head, so Idhkhir was placed on his feet." Extracted by Ahmad (6/395) with this completeness, and his chain is authentic. And Al-Tirmidhi without his saying: "Then his shroud was brought..." and said: "Hasan Sahih Hadith." The Two Sheikhs and others narrated the prohibition of wishing for death from another path. It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Anas, which we will mention, God willing, in the next issue.
37 - If shrouds are scarce and the dead are many, it is permissible to shroud a group of them in one shroud, and the one who knew more Quran among them is placed first towards the Qiblah, due to the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When it was the day of Uhud, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by Hamzah bin Abdul-Muttalib, and he had been mutilated...
foot_note: None

text:
...He said: Were it not that Safiyyah would be (upset), I would have left him (until the birds and beasts ate him) (1), so that Allah would resurrect him from the bellies of birds and beasts. So he shrouded him in a Namirah. (She was) such that if she covered his head his feet appeared, and if she covered his feet his head appeared. So he covered his head. He did not pray over anyone of the martyrs other than him. And he said: I am a witness over you today. (He said: The slain were many and the clothes were few. He said:) He used to combine three and two in one grave, and ask which of them knew more Quran, so he would put him first in the Laḥd (niche). And he shrouded two and three men in one garment" (2). Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/59), Al-Tirmidhi (2/138 - 139) who classified it as Hasan, Ibn Sa'd (Vol 3 Part 1 p 8), Al-Hakim (1/365 - 366) and the context is his, and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/10 - 11), and Ahmad (3/128). The additions are his. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim," and Al-Dhahabi agreed. But it is only Hasan as preceded in the Third of Issue (32). (p. 53).
38 - It is not permissible to remove the clothes of the martyr in which he was killed; rather, he is buried while wearing them, due to his saying (peace be upon him) regarding the slain of Uhud: "Wrap them in their clothes." Extracted by Ahmad (5/431) with this wording. In a narration of his: "Wrap them in their blood." Likewise, Al-Nasa'i extracted it (1/282). Al-Shawkani attributed it (4/34) to Abu Dawood which is an error. In this chapter, there is [a report] from Jabir, Abu Barzah, and Anas, so see Issue (32) Hadith First, Second, and Third (p. 52 - 53).
foot_note:
1. (1) They are beasts and birds that feed on all carcasses. Plural: 'Awafi. 
2. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said: "The meaning of the Hadith is that he used to divide one garment among the group, so each one would be shrouded in part of it out of necessity, even if it only covered part of his body. The completion of the Hadith indicates this, that he used to ask about the one who knew more Quran and put him first in the Laḥd. If they were all in one garment, he would have asked about the best of them before that so as not to lead to undoing the shrouding and repeating it." Mentioned in "Awn al-Ma'bud" (3/165). This interpretation is the correct one. As for the saying of those who interpreted it literally, it is wrong and contrary to the context of the story as Ibn Taymiyyah explained. Even further from correctness is the one who said: the meaning of 'one garment' is 'one grave'! Because this is explicitly stated in the Hadith, so there is no meaning to repeating it.

text:
39 - It is recommended to shroud him with one or more garments over his clothes, as the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did with Mus'ab bin Umayr and Hamzah bin Abdul-Muttalib. Their story preceded in Issue (34, 36, 37). There are two other stories in this chapter:
First: From Shaddad bin Al-Had: "That a man from the Bedouins came to the Prophet (peace be upon him), believed in him and followed him. Then he said: I will migrate with you. The Prophet (peace be upon him) entrusted him to some of his companions. When the Battle of (Khaybar) took place, the Prophet (peace be upon him) gained some spoils (in it). He divided them and allocated a share for him. He gave his share to his companions, as he was looking after their rear. When he came to them, they gave it to him. He said: What is this? They said: A share he allocated for you. He said: I did not follow you for this, but I followed you so that I might be shot here - and he pointed to his throat - with an arrow and die, and enter Paradise. He said: If you are truthful with Allah, He will be truthful with you. They stayed for a while, then rose to fight the enemy. He was brought to the Prophet (peace be upon him) carried, having been hit by an arrow where he had pointed. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Is it him? They said: Yes. He said: He was truthful with Allah so He was truthful with him. Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) shrouded him in the Prophet's (peace be upon him) Jubbah (cloak), then put him forward and prayed over him. Among what appeared of his prayer was: O Allah, this is Your servant, he went out as a migrant in Your cause, and was killed as a martyr. I am a witness to that." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/277), Al-Tahawi in "(1/291), Al-Hakim (3/595 - 596), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/15 - 16). I say: Its chain is authentic. All its narrators are according to the condition of Muslim except Shaddad bin Al-Had, for whom he did not extract anything, but there is no harm, for he is a known Companion. As for Al-Shawkani's saying in "Nayl al-Awtar" (3/37) following Al-Nawawi in "Al-Majmu'" (5/565): that he is a Tabi'i! This is a clear delusion, so do not be misled by it.
Second: From Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) disliked that she see them, so he said: The woman, the woman! He said: I realized she was my mother Safiyyah,
foot_note: None

text:
so I went out running to her, and I caught up to her before she reached the slain. He said: She pushed (1) me in my chest, and she was a strong woman. She said: Get away, no land for you. I said: Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) firmly commanded you. So she stopped and took out two garments she had. She said: These are two garments I brought for my brother Hamzah, for news of his killing reached me, so shroud him in them. He said: So we came with the two garments to shroud Hamzah in them, and behold, beside him was a man from the Ansar slain, done to him as was done to Hamzah. We found it shameful and shy to shroud Hamzah in two garments while the Ansari had no shroud. So we said: One garment for Hamzah and one garment for the Ansari. We estimated them and one was larger than the other, so we cast lots between them, and shrouded each of them in the garment that fell to him." Extracted by Ahmad (1418) and the context is his with a Hasan chain. And Al-Bayhaqi (3/401) and his chain is authentic.
40 - The Muhrim is shrouded in his two garments in which he died, due to his saying (peace be upon him) regarding the Muhrim whose she-camel broke his neck: "...and shroud him in his two garments (in which he assumed Ihram)..." It preceded in full in Chapter (3) Paragraph (D), (p. 12 - 13). This addition was narrated by Al-Nasa'i and also Al-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam al-Kabir" (f 165/2) from two paths from Amr bin Dinar from Ibn Jubayr from Ibn Abbas. And this is an authentic chain.
41 - Several matters are recommended regarding the shroud:
First: Whiteness, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Wear white of your clothes, for they are the best of your clothes, and shroud your dead in them." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/176), Al-Tirmidhi (2/132) who authenticated it, Ibn Majah (1/449), Al-Bayhaqi (3/245), Ahmad (3426), and Al-Diya' in "Al-Mukhtarah" (60/229 / 2). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim," and Al-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning: she struck and pushed.

text:

42 - Extravagance in the shroud is not permissible, nor exceeding three [garments], because it is contrary to how he was shrouded, especially since the living are more in need of it. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed Allah disliked three things for you: gossip (Qil wa Qal), wasting wealth, and asking too many questions" (1).

(12) Carrying and Following the Funeral
43 - Carrying the funeral and following it is obligatory, and that is a right of the Muslim deceased upon Muslims. There are Hadiths regarding this, I mention two of them:
First: His saying (peace be upon him): "The right of a Muslim (and in a narration: obligatory for a Muslim upon his brother) are five: Returning the greeting, visiting the sick, following funerals, accepting an invitation, and blessing the sneezer." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/88) and the context is his, Muslim (7/3) with the second narration, Ibn Majah (1/439), Ibn Al-Jarud (261), and Ahmad (2/372, 412, 540). And he said in a narration of his: "Six." And he added: "And if he asks you for advice, advise him," which is also a narration for Muslim. All of them extracted it from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah. In this chapter, there is [a report] from Al-Bara' bin Azib in the Two Sheikhs and others.
Second: His saying also: "Visit the sick, and follow funerals; they remind you of the Hereafter." Extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4/73), Al-Bukhari in "Al-Adab Al-Mufrad" (p. 75), Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (709 - Mawarid), Al-Tayalisi (1/224), Ahmad (3/27,...

32, 48), and Al-Baghawi in "Sharh al-Sunnah" (1/166 / 1) from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. I say: Its chain is Hasan. It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Awf bin Malik without the last sentence. Narrated by Al-Tabarani. Refer to "Al-Majma'" (2/299).
44 - Following it is of two ranks:
First: Following it from its family's place until the prayer over it.
Second: Following it from its family's place until the burial is finished.
Both were done by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated saying: "When we came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) (meaning Medina), if a deceased among us was present [dying], we informed the Prophet (peace be upon him). He would attend him and seek forgiveness for him until he passed away. Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) and those with him would leave [with the body] until it was buried. Sometimes this detention would be prolonged for the Prophet (peace be upon him). When we feared hardship upon him from that, some of the people said to others: If we did not inform the Prophet of anyone until he passes away, then when he passes away we inform him, there would be no hardship or detention upon him in that. So we did that. We used to inform him of the deceased after he died, so he would come and pray over him. Sometimes he would leave, and sometimes he would stay until the deceased was buried. We were like that for a while. Then we said: If the Prophet (peace be upon him) did not go out, and we carried our funeral to him so he prays over it at his house, that would be easier for him. So we did, and that has been the matter until today." Extracted by Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (753 - Mawarid), Al-Hakim (1/353 - 364 - 365), and from him Al-Bayhaqi (3/74), and Ahmad (3/66) similarly. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs"! It is only Sahih (authentic), because it contains Sa'id bin Ubayd bin Al-Sabbaq, and they did not extract anything for him.
45 - There is no doubt that the second rank is better than the first, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever witnesses the funeral (from its house), (and in a narration: whoever follows the funeral of a Muslim out of faith and seeking reward) until it is prayed over, he has a Qirat. And whoever witnesses it until it is buried, (and in the other narration: finished...

...with it), he has two Qirats (of reward). It was said: (O Messenger of Allah) And what are the two Qirats? He said: Like two great mountains. (And in the other narration: Each Qirat is like Uhud)." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (1/89 - 90, 3/150, 154), Muslim (3/51 - 52), Abu Dawood (2/63 - 64), Al-Nasa'i (1/282), Al-Tirmidhi (2/150) who authenticated it, Ibn Majah (1/467 - 468), Ibn Al-Jarud (261), Al-Bayhaqi (3/412 - 413), Al-Tayalisi (2581), and Ahmad (2/233, 246, 320, 401, 458, 470, 474, 493, 521, 531) from many paths from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him). The second narration is for Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad. The first addition is for Muslim, Abu Dawood, and others. The other two additions are for Al-Nasa'i.
The Hadith has supporting evidences from a group of Companions (may Allah be pleased with them).
First: From Thawban in Muslim, Al-Tayalisi (985), and Ahmad (5/276 - 277, 282 - 283 - 284).
Second and Third: From Al-Bara' bin Azib and Abdullah bin Mughaffal, in Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad (4/86, 294).
Fourth: From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. Narrated by Ahmad (3/20, 27, 97) from two paths from him. It has other supporting evidences mentioned by Al-Hafiz in "Al-Fath" (3/153).
In some of the supporting evidences from Abu Hurairah, there are beneficial additions which it is good to mention: "Ibn Umar used to pray over it, then leave. When the Hadith of Abu Hurairah reached him, he said: (Abu Hurairah has narrated too much to us, (and in a narration: he found it too great)). (So he sent Khabbab to Aisha to ask her about Abu Hurairah's statement then return to him and inform him what she said. Ibn Umar took a handful of pebbles from the mosque turning them in his hand until the messenger returned to him. He said: Aisha said: Abu Hurairah spoke the truth. Ibn Umar threw the pebbles that were in his hand to the ground then said:) We have indeed missed many Qirats. (This reached Abu Hurairah so he said: Indeed, I was not distracted from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) by a deal...
