...in the market, nor by planting palm shoots (1). I only used to stick to the Prophet (peace be upon him) for a word he would teach me, and for a morsel he would feed me). (Ibn Umar said to him: You, O Abu Hurairah, were the most adhering of us to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and the most knowledgeable of us regarding his Hadith)." All these additions are for Muslim, except the last one, which is for Ahmad (2/2 - 3, 387) and likewise Sa'id bin Mansur with an authentic chain as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath." The one before it is for Al-Tayalisi and its chain is authentic according to the condition of Muslim. The second addition is for the Two Sheikhs, and the second narration in it is for Al-Tirmidhi and Ahmad. The last addition is explicit that Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) contacted Abu Hurairah himself, and this is supported by a narration in Muslim and others with the wording: Ibn Umar said: O Abu Hurr, look at what you narrate from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). So Abu Hurairah went to him until he took him to Aisha. He said to her: O Mother of the Believers, I adjure you by Allah, did you hear the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: (he mentioned the Hadith)? She said: Yes, by Allah. Abu Hurairah said: Indeed, I was not... etc. The apparent meaning of all this contradicts the narration that he sent Khabbab to Ibn Umar. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar reconciled the two narrations by saying that when the messenger returned to Ibn Umar informing him of Aisha['s confirmation], that reached Abu Hurairah, so he walked to Ibn Umar and made him hear that from Aisha directly (face to face).
Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) has another Hadith regarding the virtue of witnessing a funeral. He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Who among you woke up fasting today? Abu Bakr said: I. He said: Who among you visited a sick person today? Abu Bakr said: I. He said: Who among you witnessed a funeral today? Abu Bakr said: I. He said: Who fed a needy person today? Abu Bakr said: I. He (peace be upon him) said: These qualities do not gather in a man in a day except that he enters Paradise." Extracted by Muslim in his "Sahih" (3/92, 7/110) and Al-Bukhari in "Al-Adab Al-Mufrad" p. 75.
46 - This virtue in following funerals is for men only, not women, due to the Prophet's (peace be upon him) prohibition for them from following it, which is a prohibition of dislike (Makruh Tanzihi). Umm 'Atiyyah (may Allah be pleased with her) said:
foot_note: 1. (1) With Shaddah on Ya, small palm trees.

text:
"We were forbidden (and in a narration: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade us) from following funerals, but it was not strictly enforced upon us." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (1/328 - 329, 3/162), Muslim (3/47) and the context is his, Abu Dawood (2/63), Ibn Majah (1/487), Ahmad (6/408, 409), as well as Al-Bayhaqi (4/77) and Al-Isma'ili. The other narration is his, and it is a narration for Al-Bukhari as Mu'allaq (suspended).
47 - Funerals should not be followed by what contradicts the Sharia. Textual evidence has come regarding two things: raising voices in weeping, and following it with incense. That is in his saying (peace be upon him): "Do not follow the funeral with voice or fire." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/64) and Ahmad (2/427, 528, 532) from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah. Its chain contains someone unnamed, but it is strengthened by its raised (Marfu') supporting evidences and some stopped (Mawquf) traditions. As for the supporting evidences, from Jabir that the Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade following the deceased with voice or fire. Al-Haythami said (3/29): "Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and in it is someone not mentioned [unknown]." And from Ibn Umar who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade following a funeral with a mourning wailer (Rannah)." Extracted by Ibn Majah (1/479 - 480) and Ahmad (5668) from two paths from Mujahid from him. It is Hasan by the sum of the two paths. And from Abu Musa regarding the prohibition of following the deceased with an incense burner. Its wording preceded in Issue (12) Paragraph (B), (p. 8). As for the traditions (Athar), from Amr bin Al-Aas that he said in his will: "When I die, let no wailing woman nor fire accompany me." Extracted by Muslim (1/78) and Ahmad (4/199). And from Abu Hurairah that he said when death approached him: "Do not pitch a tent over me, and do not follow me with an incense burner (and in a narration: with fire)." Narrated by Ahmad and others with an authentic chain as will come after an issue, the Second Hadith.
foot_note: None

text:
48 - Attached to that is raising the voice with Dhikr (remembrance) in front of the funeral, because it is an innovation, and due to the saying of Qays bin Abbad: "The Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to dislike raising the voice near funerals." Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi (4/74) with a chain whose narrators are trustworthy. And because it resembles the Christians, for they raise their voices with something from their gospels and supplications with elongation, melodious chanting, and sadness (1). More repulsive than that is escorting it with playing musical instruments in front of it with sad tunes as is done in some Islamic countries imitating the disbelievers. And Allah is the One sought for help.
49 - It is obligatory to hasten in walking with it, a walk less than Raml (jogging), and there are Hadiths regarding that:
First: "Hasten with the funeral. For if it is righteous, then it is good you are advancing it to. And if it is other than that, then it is an evil you are putting down from your necks." Extracted by the Two Sheikhs, and the context is Muslim's, and the authors of the four Sunan, authenticated by Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad (2/240, 280, 488) and Al-Bayhaqi (4/21) from paths from Abu Hurairah. He has another Hadith similar to the following.
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Nawawi, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, said in "Al-Adhkar" (p. 203): "Know that the correct and chosen way, and what the Salaf (may Allah be pleased with them) were upon, is silence while walking with the funeral. No voice should be raised with recitation, Dhikr, or anything else. The wisdom in it is apparent, which is that it is calmer for his mind and more conducive to thinking about what relates to the funeral, which is what is required in this situation. This is the truth, and do not be deceived by the large number of those who oppose it. Abu Ali Al-Fudayl bin Iyad (may Allah be pleased with him) said what means: 'Stick to the paths of guidance and do not be harmed by the small number of those walking them, and beware of the paths of misguidance and do not be deceived by the large number of those perishing.' We have narrated in Sunan Al-Bayhaqi what implies what I said (referring to the saying of Qays bin Abbad). As for what the ignorant do of reading over the funeral in Damascus and elsewhere, reciting with elongation and taking speech out of its context, it is forbidden by consensus of scholars. I have clarified its repulsiveness and the severity of its prohibition, and the sinfulness of whoever is able to deny it but does not deny it, in the book 'Etiquette of Recitation'. And Allah is the One sought for help."

text:
Second: "When the funeral is placed, and men carry it on their necks, if it was righteous it says: Take me forward (take me forward). And if it was not righteous it says: Oh woe to it, where are they taking it!? Everything hears its voice except man, and if he heard it, he would fall unconscious (thunderstruck)." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/142), Al-Nasa'i (1/270), Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (3/41, 58) from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him). The first addition is attested to by the Hadith of Abu Hurairah that he said when death approached him: "Do not pitch a tent over me, do not follow me with an incense burner, and hasten with me, for I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: 'When a righteous man is placed on his bier, he says: Take me forward...'" Similar Hadith, without his saying "Everything hears its voice..." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (764), Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi (No. 2336), and Ahmad (2/292, 274, 500) with an authentic chain according to the condition of Muslim.
Third: From Abd al-Rahman bin Jawshan who said: "I was in the funeral of Abd al-Rahman bin Samurah. Ziyad and men from his freed slaves started walking on their heels in front of the bier, saying: Gently, may Allah bless you. Abu Bakrah caught up with them in some of the alleys of Medina and charged at them with his mule, and struck them with the whip, and said: Let go! By the One who honored the face of Abu Al-Qasim (peace be upon him), I saw us at the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) almost jogging with it (Raml)." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/65), Al-Nasa'i (1/271), Al-Tahawi (1/276), Al-Hakim (1/255), Al-Bayhaqi (4/22), Al-Tayalisi (883), and Ahmad (5/36 - 38). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic." And Al-Dhahabi agreed, and before him Al-Nawawi in "Al-Majmu'" (5/272) (1).

50 - It is permissible to walk in front of it, behind it, to its right, and to its left, provided one is close to it. Except the rider, he proceeds behind it, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "The rider (proceeds) behind the funeral, and the walker where he wishes near it, (behind it, in front of it, to its right, and to its left, close to it). And the child is prayed over, (and forgiveness and mercy are supplicated for his parents)." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/65), Al-Nasa'i (1/275 - 276), Al-Tirmidhi (2/144), Ibn Majah (1/451, 458), Al-Tahawi (1/278), Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (769), Al-Bayhaqi (84, 25), Al-Tayalisi (701 - 702), and Ahmad (4/247, 248 - 249, 249, 252) from the Hadith of Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah. Al-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih Hadith." Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Al-Bukhari." Al-Dhahabi agreed. And it is as they said. The context is Al-Nasa'i's and Ahmad's in a narration. The three additions are for Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, and Al-Tayalisi. The first two are for Ahmad, and the third is for Al-Bayhaqi. Abu Dawood and Ibn Hibban said: "The miscarried fetus (Al-Saqt)" instead of "The child," which is a narration for Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad. Al-Hafiz attributed it in "Al-Talkhis" (5/147) to Al-Tirmidhi as well, which is an error, for his wording is like the group's.
51 - Both walking in front of it and behind it are proven from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in action, as Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) said:
foot_note: 1. = that the corpse might burst or change and the like, then one should be deliberate." I say: The apparent command implies obligation, and Ibn Hazm held this view (5/154 - 155), and we did not find evidence diverting it to recommendation, so we stopped at it. Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Zad al-Ma'ad": "As for the people's slow creeping walk today, step by step, it is a disliked innovation, contrary to the Sunnah, and includes imitation of the People of the Book, the Jews."

text:
"That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar used to walk in front of the funeral and behind it." Extracted by Al-Tahawi (1/278) from two paths from Yunus bin Yazid from Ibn Shihab from him. I say: This is an authentic chain according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs (1).
51 - However, walking behind it is better, because it is the implication of his saying (peace be upon him): "And follow the funerals," and similar meanings preceded in Issue (43) at the beginning of this chapter. It is supported by the saying of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): "Walking behind it is better than walking in front of it, like the superiority of a man's prayer in congregation over his prayer alone." Extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4/101), Al-Tahawi (1/279), Al-Bayhaqi (4/9 25), Ahmad (754), as well as Ibn Hazm in "Al-Muhalla" (5/165) and Sa'id bin Mansur from two paths from him. Al-Hafiz said (3/143) regarding one of them: "Its chain is Hasan, and it is Mawquf taking the ruling of Marfu', but Al-Athram narrated from Ahmad that he criticized its chain." I say: But it is strengthened by the other path (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: As for what is in "Al-Jawhar al-Naqi" (4/25): "And in the Musannaf of Abd al-Razzaq from Ma'mar from Ibn Tawus from his father who said: 'The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) never walked except behind the funeral until he died.' And this is an authentic chain according to the condition of the Group." I say: How so, when it is Mursal? For Tawus is a Tabi'i and he sent it (Mursal), and Mursal is not a proof according to them. It is contradicted by the authentic Hadith of Anas. Al-Shawkani (4/62) also declared it defective due to Irsal, but he said: "I did not come across it in any of the books of Hadith." 
2. Note: Al-Shawkani said following his previous statement: "It was narrated in Al-Bahr from Al-Thawri that he said: The rider walks behind it, and the walker in front of it. What he said is supported by the aforementioned Hadith of Al-Mughirah that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The rider is behind the funeral, and the walker is in front of it, close to it, to its right or to its left.' Extracted by the authors of Sunan and authenticated by Ibn Hibban and Al-Hakim. This is a strong view..." I say: No, for the Hadith with this wording was narrated by Ahmad from the path of Al-Mubarak bin Fadalah, and he has weakness. Others added: "behind it and in front of it..." as previously indicated. Al-Mubarak also narrated it in Al-Tayalisi. So it is obligatory to take it, and it is a text for choice, not for preferring advancing over it. It is strange that the author of Al-Muntaqa mentioned this addition in the place Al-Shawkani himself referred to by saying "aforementioned," then he overlooked it.

text:
52 - Riding is permissible provided one proceeds behind it, due to his saying (peace be upon him): "The rider proceeds behind the funeral..." This preceded in full in Issue (50). But walking is better, because it is what is known from him (peace be upon him), and it was not narrated that he rode with it. Rather, Thawban (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was brought a mount while he was with the funeral, but he refused to ride it. When he left, a mount was brought and he rode. He was asked about it? He said: The angels were walking, so I would not ride while they were walking. When they left, I rode." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/64 - 65), Al-Hakim (1/355), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/23). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs." Al-Dhahabi agreed and it is as they said.
53 - As for riding after leaving it, it is permissible without dislike, due to the aforementioned Hadith of Thawban. Similar is the Hadith of Jabir bin Samurah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed over Ibn al-Dahdah (and we were witnesses), (and in a narration: He went out to the funeral of Ibn al-Dahdah (walking)), then a bare horse was brought, a man hobbled it, and he rode it (when leaving). It began to prance with him (1), and we followed him running behind him, (and in a narration: around him). He said: A man from the people said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: How many a hanging or lowering bunch of dates in Paradise is for Ibn al-Dahdah." Extracted by Muslim (2/60 - 61) and the context is his, Abu Dawood (2/65), Al-Nasa'i (1/284), Al-Tirmidhi (2/138) who authenticated it, Al-Bayhaqi (4/22 - 23), Al-Tayalisi (760 - 761), and Ahmad (5/98 - 99, 102) from paths from Simak bin Harb from him.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning it jumps and takes short steps.

text:
The second narration is for Al-Nasa'i, and the addition in it is for Al-Tirmidhi in one of his narrations, and its meaning is for Al-Tayalisi. The third narration is for Abu Dawood and Al-Tirmidhi, and for Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad in a narration of theirs. The first addition is for Al-Nasa'i and the other for Abu Dawood (1).
54 - As for carrying the funeral on a cart or car designated for funerals, and the mourners escorting it while in cars, this form is not prescribed at all, for several reasons:
First: It is from the customs of the disbelievers, and it is established in Sharia that it is not permissible to imitate them in it. There are very many Hadiths regarding this, which I encompassed and extracted in my book "Hijab al-Mar'ah al-Muslimah fi al-Kitab wa al-Sunnah" (The Veil of the Muslim Woman in the Book and the Sunnah), some commanding and urging to differ from them in their acts of worship, dress, and customs, and some from his action (peace be upon him) in differing from them in that. Whoever wishes to view them may refer to it (2).
Second: It is an innovation in worship, contradicting the practical Sunnah in carrying the funeral, and everything like that from newly invented matters is misguidance by consensus.
Third: It misses the purpose of carrying and escorting it, which is remembering the Hereafter, as stated by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in the Hadith mentioned at the beginning of this chapter with the wording:
foot_note:
1. (1) It is explicit that he (peace be upon him) rode upon his return from the funeral. This was hidden from Abu Al-Tayyib Siddiq Hasan Khan, so he used this Hadith as evidence in "Al-Rawdah" (1/173) that the follower of the funeral has the choice to walk in front of it or behind it, saying: The Companions were walking around the funeral of Ibn al-Dahdah! This is an error from two aspects: First: There is nothing in the Hadith mentioning what he said. Rather, it is explicit that they were walking around the Prophet (peace be upon him), and there is no correlation between the two matters as is apparent. Second: That was sufficient when leaving the funeral as preceded. Perhaps the cause of the illusion is the narration of Umar bin Musa bin Al-Wajih from Simak with it with the wording: "I saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) with the funeral of Thabit bin Al-Dahdah on a horse with white legs and forehead under him, without a saddle, with the people around him. He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) dismounted and prayed over him then sat until he finished with him. Then he stood and sat on his horse and set off with men walking around him." Extracted by Ahmad (5/99). This is explicit in riding during escorting it as well, but with this context it is false (Batil) because this Umar bin Musa used to fabricate Hadith, so he is not used as proof when agreeing, let alone when contradicting! 
(2) "The Islamic Office" has printed it a second time, with additions not in the previous edition.

text:
"...and follow funerals, they remind you of the Hereafter."
I say: Escorting it in that form misses this noble goal for people completely or partially. It is not hidden from the insightful that carrying the deceased on shoulders, and seeing those escorting it while it is on their heads, is more effective in achieving remembrance and admonition than escorting it in the mentioned form. I would not be exaggerating if I said: What drove the Europeans to it is their fear of death and everything that reminds of it, due to the dominance of materialism over them and their disbelief in the Hereafter!
Fourth: It is a strong cause for reducing those escorting it and those desiring to obtain the reward mentioned previously in Issue (45) of this chapter, because not everyone can hire a car to escort it.
Fifth: This form does not agree, closely or remotely, with what is known about the pure, tolerant Sharia regarding distance from formalities and protocols, especially in such a grave matter: Death!
Truly I say: If there were nothing in this innovation except this contradiction, that would be enough to reject it. So how about when joined by the violations and evils previously explained and other things I do not mention!
55 - Standing for it is abrogated, and it is of two types:
A - The standing of the seated person if it passes by him.
B - The standing of the one escorting it upon its arrival at the grave until it is placed on the ground.
The evidence for that is the Hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him), and it has wordings:
First: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) stood for the funeral so we stood, then he sat so we sat." Extracted by Muslim (3/59), Ibn Majah (1/468), Al-Tahawi (1/383), Al-Tayalisi (150), and Ahmad No. (631, 1094, 1167).
Second: "He used to stand for funerals, then sat afterwards." Narrated by Malik (1/332), and from him Al-Shafi'i in "Al-Umm" (1/247) and Abu Dawood (2/64).
Third: From the path of Waqid bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Mu'adh who said:
foot_note: None

text:
"I witnessed a funeral among Banu Salimah, so I stood up. Nafi' bin Jubayr said to me: Sit, for I will inform you about this with certainty. Mas'ud bin Al-Hakam Al-Zurqi told me that he heard Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) in the courtyard of Kufa saying: 'The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to order us to stand for the funeral, then he sat after that, and ordered us to sit'." Extracted by Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad (627), Al-Tahawi (1/282), and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" this aspect with another wording, which is:
Fourth: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) stood with funerals until they were placed, and the people stood with him. Then he sat after that, and ordered them to sit."
Fifth: From the path of Isma'il bin Mas'ud (1) bin Al-Hakam Al-Zurqi from his father who said: "I witnessed a funeral in Iraq, and I saw men standing waiting for it to be placed. I saw Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) signaling to them to sit, for the Prophet (peace be upon him) had ordered us to sit after standing" (2). Extracted by Al-Tahawi (1/282) with a Hasan chain.
56 - It is recommended for the one who carries it to perform ablution (Wudu), due to his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever washes a dead person, let him perform Ghusl, and whoever carries him, let him perform Wudu." It is an authentic Hadith, as previously explained in Issue (31).
foot_note:
1. (1) In the original "Isma'il bin Al-Hakam bin Mas'ud," the correct is what I established. It seems it was inverted by the printer or some copyists. 
2. I say: This wording and the one before it are explicit that standing for it until it is placed falls under the prohibition, and that it is abrogated. So the saying of Siddiq Hasan Khan in "Al-Rawdah" (1/176) after establishing the abrogation of standing for it if it passes: "As for the standing of people behind it until it is placed on the ground, it is firm (Muhkam) and not abrogated." This is a clear error, contradicting the two wordings we mentioned. Apparently, he did not come across them.

text:
(13) Praying over the Funeral
57 - Praying over the deceased Muslim is a communal obligation (Fard Kifayah), because of his (peace be upon him) command for it in Hadiths. I mention among them the Hadith of Zaid bin Khalid Al-Juhani: "That a man from the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) died on the day of Khaybar. They mentioned that to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). He said: 'Pray over your companion.' The faces of the people changed because of that. He said: 'Indeed, your companion stole (Ghal) from the booty in the cause of Allah.' So we searched his belongings and found beads from the beads of the Jews not worth two dirhams!" Extracted by Malik in "Al-Muwatta" (2/14), Abu Dawood (1/425), Al-Nasa'i (1/278), Ibn Majah (2/197), and Ahmad (4/114 - 5/192) with an authentic chain. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to their condition," but there is a reservation about it which I clarified in "Al-Ta'liqat al-Jiyad 'ala Zad al-Ma'ad." In this chapter, there is [a report] from Abu Qatadah, his Hadith will come in the next issue p. 82, and from Abu Hurairah in it, p. 84.
58 - Two persons are exempted from this, so prayer over them is not obligatory:
First: The child who has not reached puberty, because the Prophet (peace be upon him) did not pray over his son Ibrahim (peace be upon him). Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: "Ibrahim, the son of the Prophet (peace be upon him), died when he was eighteen months old, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did not pray over him."
foot_note: None

text:
Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/166) and from his path [Ibn] Hazm (5/158) and Ahmad (6/267). Its chain is Hasan, as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah," and Ibn Hazm said: "This is an authentic report"! (1).
Second: The martyr, because the Prophet (peace be upon him) did not pray over the martyrs of Uhud and others. Three Hadiths regarding that were mentioned previously in Issue (32), (p. 5 2).
However, that does not negate the legitimacy of praying over them without obligation, as will come in the Hadiths regarding them in the following issue:
59 - It is prescribed to pray over those mentioned below:
First: The child, even if it was a miscarriage (Saqt) (which is what falls from its mother's womb before completion). There are two Hadiths regarding this:
1 - "...and the child (and in a narration: the miscarriage) is prayed over, and forgiveness and mercy are supplicated for his parents." Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and others with an authentic chain, and it preceded in full in Issue (50).
2 - From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "A boy from the boys of the Ansar was brought to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and he prayed over him. Aisha said: I said: Blessed is this one, a bird from the birds of Paradise, he did no evil nor did he reach it. He said: Or other than that,
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: The correct view is what Al-Hafiz said. Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned in "Zad al-Ma'ad" (1/203) from Imam Ahmad that he said: "This is a Munkar Hadith." Perhaps he meant "Fard (solitary) Hadith," for this is transmitted from him regarding some well-known authentic Hadiths. Know that it does not detract from the establishment of the Hadith that it was narrated from him (peace be upon him) that he prayed over his son Ibrahim. Because that has not been authentically proven from him, even if it came from paths, they are all defective either by Irsal or severe weakness, as you see detailed in "Nasb al-Rayah" (2/279 - 280). Ahmad narrated (3/281) from Anas that he was asked: Did the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) pray over his son Ibrahim? He said: I do not know. Its chain is authentic. Had he prayed over him, it would not have been hidden from Anas, God willing, and he served him for ten years.

text:
O Aisha? Allah Almighty and Exalted created Paradise and created people for it, and created them while they were in the loins of their fathers. And He created the Fire and created people for it, and created them while they were in the loins of their fathers" (1). Extracted by Muslim (8/55), Al-Nasa'i (276 9 1), and Ahmad (6/208). The wording is Al-Nasa'i's. Its chain is authentic, all its narrators are trustworthy narrators of Muslim, except his sheikh Amr bin Mansur, who is Thiqah Thabt (trustworthy, firm).
It appears that the miscarriage is only prayed over if the soul has been breathed into it, which is if it completes four months, then dies. But if it falls before that, [it is not prayed over] because it is not a deceased as is obvious. The basis for that is the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him) raised (Marfu'): "The creation of one of you is gathered in his mother's womb for forty days, then it is a clot (Alaqah) for a like period, then it is a morsel (Mudghah) for a like period, then an angel is sent to him... and breathes the soul into him." Agreed upon.
Some stipulated that the miscarriage must cry out (show signs of life), due to the Hadith: "If the miscarriage cries out, it is prayed over and inherited." But it is a weak Hadith not to be used as proof, as clarified by scholars (2).
Second: The Martyr. There are many Hadiths, I suffice with mentioning some of them:
1 - From Shaddad bin Al-Had:
foot_note:
1. (1) Al-Nawawi, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, said: "Scholars of Muslims whose opinion counts have agreed that whoever dies from the children of Muslims is among the people of Paradise. The answer to this Hadith is that perhaps he forbade her from rushing to definitive judgment without evidence, or he said that before he knew that the children of Muslims are in Paradise." Al-Sindi answered in his footnotes on Al-Nasa'i with another answer, the summary of which is: He only denied her certainty of Paradise for a specific child. He said: Certainty regarding a specific individual is not correct because the faith of the parents in reality is unseen, and it is the criteria with Allah the Exalted. 
2. See "Nasb al-Rayah" (2/277), "Al-Talkhis" (5/146 - 147), "Al-Majmu'" (5/255), and my book "Naqd al-Taj al-Jami' lil-Usul al-Khamsah" (No. 293). The Hadith is only authentic without mentioning prayer in it, as I verified in "Irwa' al-Ghalil" (1704), may Allah facilitate its printing.

text:
"That a man from the Bedouins came to the Prophet (peace be upon him), believed in him and followed him, then said: I will migrate with you... They stayed for a while, then rose to fight the enemy. He was brought to the Prophet (peace be upon him)... Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) shrouded him in his Jubbah, then put him forward and prayed over him...". Extracted by Al-Nasa'i and others with an authentic chain, and it preceded in full in Issue (39) (p. 61).
2 - From Abdullah Al-Zubayr: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) ordered Hamzah on the day of Uhud, so he was covered with a Burdah. Then he prayed over him and said nine Takbirs. Then the slain were brought, lined up, and he would pray over them and him with them." Extracted by Al-Tahawi in "Ma'ani al-Athar" (1/290) and its chain is Hasan. All its narrators are trustworthy and well-known, and Abu Ishaq explicitly stated the narration. It has many supporting evidences, some of which I mentioned in "Al-Ta'liqat al-Jiyad" in Issue (75).
3 - From Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him): "That the Prophet (peace be upon him) passed by Hamzah who had been mutilated, and also by one of the martyrs other than him - meaning the martyrs of Uhud." (1) Extracted by Abu Dawood with a Hasan chain, and it is an abridgment of his Hadith preceded in Issue (37). (p. 57 - 58).
4 - From Uqbah bin Amir Al-Juhani: "That the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) went out one day and prayed over the people of Uhud his prayer over the dead [after eight years] [like one bidding farewell to the living and the dead]. Then he turned to the pulpit [and praised Allah and extolled] Him! Then he said: I am a predecessor for you, and I am a witness over you. [And your appointment is the Pool] and by Allah I am looking at my Pool right now. [And its width is as between Ayla to Juhfah]. - And I have been given the keys to the treasuries of the earth, or the keys to the earth. And by Allah I do not fear for you that you will associate others with Allah after me, but I fear for you [the world] that you will compete for it [and fight one another and perish as those before you perished].
foot_note: 1. (1) Perhaps he means praying over others independently, for it is not appropriate to pray over others joined with him as in the Hadith before it. These two Hadiths are not contradicted by the Hadith of Jabir mentioned earlier that he (peace be upon him) did not pray over the martyrs of Uhud, because it is negating, and the affirming is given precedence over the negating. See the details in "Nayl al-Awtar".

text:
He said: So it was the last look I looked at the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)]." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/64 - 7/279 - 280 and 302), Muslim (7/67), and Ahmad (4/149, 153, 154). The context is Al-Bukhari's. The first, second, sixth, and seventh additions are his. Muslim has the second and fifth and what follows. Ahmad has the first to fourth. Al-Bayhaqi (4/14) narrated it and has all additions except the third and fifth. Al-Tahawi (1/290) extracted it, as did Al-Nasa'i (1/277) and Al-Daraqutni (p. 197) briefly, and Al-Daraqutni has the first addition (1).
Third: Whoever is killed in carrying out a Hadd (punishment) of Allah's limits, due to the Hadith of Imran bin Husayn "That a woman from Juhaynah came to the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) while she was pregnant from adultery. She said: O Prophet of Allah, I have committed an offense warranting Hadd, so execute it upon me. The Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) called her guardian and said: Treat her well, and when she delivers bring her to me. He did. The Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) ordered regarding her, so her clothes were tied around her, then he ordered regarding her and she was stoned. Then he prayed over her. Umar said to him: Do you pray over her, O Prophet of Allah, when she has committed adultery? He said: She has repented a repentance that if it were divided among seventy of the people of Medina, it would suffice them. Have you found a repentance better than her sacrificing herself for Allah the Exalted?" Extracted by Muslim (5/121), Abu Dawood (2/233), Al-Nasa'i (1/278), Al-Tirmidhi (2/325) who authenticated it, Al-Darimi (2/180), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/18 and 19). Ibn Majah (2/116 and 117) narrated it briefly.
Fourth: The immoral person (Fajir) indulging in sins and prohibitions, such as the one who abandons prayer and Zakat while acknowledging their obligation, the adulterer, the alcohol addict, and similar sinners. They are prayed over, except that it is appropriate for the people of knowledge and religion to leave praying over them, as a punishment and deterrent for their likes, just as the Prophet (peace be upon him) did. There are Hadiths regarding this:
foot_note: 1. (1) Someone might say: It is established in these Hadiths the legitimacy of praying over martyrs, and the default is that it is obligatory, so why is obligation not asserted! I say: Because of what was mentioned in Issue (58). We add to that here: Many Companions were martyred in the Battle of Badr and others, and it was not transmitted that the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed over them. If he had done so, they would have transmitted it from him. This indicates that praying over them is not obligatory. Therefore, Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Tahdhib al-Sunan" (4/295): (The correct view in the issue is that he has the choice between praying over them and leaving it, due to the coming of traditions for both matters. This is one of the narrations from Imam Ahmad, and it is the most fitting with his principles and school). I say: There is no doubt that praying over them is better than leaving it if it is easy, because it is supplication and worship.

text:
1 - From Ibn Qatadah who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) whenever he was invited to a funeral, he would ask about it. If it was praised with good, he stood and prayed over it. And if it was praised with other than that, he said to its family: It is up to you regarding it, and he did not pray over it." Extracted by Ahmad (5/399, 300, 301) and Al-Hakim (1/364) who said: "Authentic according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs," and Al-Dhahabi agreed. It is as they said.
2 - From Jabir bin Samurah who said: "A man fell ill, and people cried out over him. His neighbor came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: He has died. He said: How do you know? He said: I saw him. The Messenger of Allah said: He has not died. He said: He returned and people cried out over him. His wife said: Go to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and inform him. The man said: O Allah, curse him! He said: Then the man went and saw him having slaughtered himself with a broad arrowhead (Meshqas). He went to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and informed him that he had died. He said: How do you know? He said: I saw him slaughtering himself with a Meshqas he had! He said: You saw him? He said: Yes. He said: Then I will not pray over him." Extracted with this completeness by Abu Dawood (2/65) with an authentic chain according to the condition of Muslim. Muslim (3/66) extracted it briefly, as did Al-Nasa'i (1/279), Al-Tirmidhi (2/161), Ibn Majah (1/465), Al-Hakim (1/364), Al-Bayhaqi (4/19), Al-Tayalisi (779), and Ahmad (5/87, 91, 92, 96, 94 - 97, 102, 107). Al-Tirmidhi said: "This is a Hasan Hadith. The people of knowledge differed regarding this. Some of them said: One prays over everyone who prayed towards the Qiblah, and over the one who killed himself. This is the view of Sufyan Al-Thawri and Ishaq. Ahmad said: The Imam does not pray over the one who killed himself, but other than the Imam prays over him." Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Al-Ikhtiyarat" (p. 52): "Whoever refrains from praying over one of them (meaning the killer, the defrauder, and the debtor who has no means to pay) as a deterrent for others like them from such action, it is good. And if he refrains outwardly and supplicates for him inwardly, to combine the two interests, it is better than missing one of them."
foot_note: None

text:
3 - From Zaid bin Khalid in the Hadith of the Prophet's (peace be upon him) refraining from praying over the one who stole from the booty (Ghal) and his saying to his companions: "Pray over your companion... Indeed, your companion stole from the booty in the cause of Allah!" Extracted by the authors of Sunan with an authentic chain as previously explained in Issue (57).
Fifth: The debtor who did not leave wealth to pay off his debt. He is prayed over, but the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) left praying over him in the beginning of the matter. There are Hadiths regarding this:
1 - From Salamah bin Al-Akwa' who said: "We were sitting with the Prophet (peace be upon him) when a funeral was brought. They said: Pray over it. He said: Does he have any debt? They said: No. He said: Did he leave anything? They said: No. So he prayed over it. Then another funeral was brought, so they said: O Messenger of Allah, pray over it. He said: Does he have any debt? It was said: Yes. He said: Did he leave anything? They said: Three dinars [He said: So he signaled with his fingers three cauterizations (meaning three is little/ok?)], so he prayed over it. Then the third was brought, and they said: Pray over him. He said: Did he leave anything? They said: No. He said: Does he have any debt? They said: Three dinars. He said: Pray over your companion. [A man from the Ansar called Abu Qatadah] said: Pray over him, O Messenger of Allah, and his debt is upon me." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/368, 369 and 374) and Ahmad (4/47, 50) and the addition is his. Al-Nasa'i (1/278) narrated the third story from it.
2 - From Abu Qatadah (may Allah be pleased with him) similar to the third story in the Hadith of Salamah bin Al-Akwa' and he narrated the one before it. In it: "Do you see if I pay it off for him, will you pray over him? He said: If you pay it off for him completely, I will pray over him. He said: So Abu Qatadah went and paid it off for him. He said: Have you paid what he owed? He said Yes. So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) called for him and prayed over him." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/378), Al-Tirmidhi (2/161), Al-Darimi (2/263), Ibn Majah (2/75), and Ahmad (5/297, 301, 302, 304, 311) and the context is his, and its chain is...
foot_note: None

text:
authentic according to the condition of Muslim. The others do not have Abu Qatadah's leaving and paying the debt then the Prophet's (peace be upon him) prayer over him.
3 - From Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) similar to it, and he added at the end: "When Allah granted victory to His Messenger, he said: I am closer to every believer than his own self. Whoever leaves a debt, its payment is upon me, and whoever leaves wealth, it is for his heirs." Narrated by Abu Dawood (2/85) and Al-Nasa'i (1/278) with an authentic chain according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs. It has another path from Jabir with another addition, which has preceded.
4 - From Abu Hurairah: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to have the dead man who owed debt brought to him. He would ask: Did he leave anything to pay his debt? If he was told that he left enough to pay, he would pray over him. Otherwise, no. He would say: Pray over your companion. When Allah granted him victories, he said: I am closer to the believers than their own selves [in this world and the Hereafter, read if you wish: {The Prophet is more worthy of the believers than themselves} [Al-Ahzab: 6]]. So whoever dies leaving a debt [and did not leave enough to pay], its payment is upon me, and whoever leaves wealth, it is for his heirs." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (4/376 - 9/425), Muslim (5/62), Al-Nasa'i (1/379), Ibn Majah (2/77), Al-Tayalisi (2338), and Ahmad (2/399 and 453). The context is Muslim's. The two additions are Al-Bukhari's, and the first of them is Ahmad's. Al-Tirmidhi (3/178) extracted from it what is his [the Prophet's] speech and authenticated it, as well as Al-Darimi (2/263), Al-Tayalisi (2524), and Ahmad (2/287, 318, 334, 335, 356, 399, 450, 464, 527) similarly, which is Muslim's narration and likewise Al-Bukhari with close wordings (8/420 and 12/7, 22, 40) from many paths from Abu Hurairah. Abu Bishr Yunus bin Habib, the narrator of Musnad Al-Tayalisi, said after the Hadith: "I heard Abu Al-Walid - meaning Al-Tayalisi - say: By this, those Hadiths that came regarding the one who owes debt were abrogated."
foot_note: None

text_en: Sixth: Before burial, one may perform the funeral prayer over the deceased, or some may pray over him while others do not, and they pray at his grave. The imam in the second case should be one who has not prayed over him. There are narrations regarding this: 1. From ‘Abdullāh ibn ‘Abbās (may Allah be pleased with them), he said: “A man died—whom the Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to visit—and they buried him at night. When morning came, they informed him. He said: ‘Why did you not inform me?’ They said: ‘It was night and dark; we did not want to dig for his grave.’ So he came to his grave and prayed over him, [he said: ‘We stood and formed behind him’], [‘I was among them’], [and he pronounced four Takbīrs].” Reported by al-Bukhārī, Ibn Mājah, Muslim, al-Nasā’ī, al-Tirmidhī, Abū al-Jārūd, al-Bayhaqī, al-Ṭayālisī, and Aḥmad. 2. From Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): “A black woman used to clean (or collect scraps and sticks from) the mosque. She died, and the Prophet ﷺ missed her. He asked about her after a few days and was told she had died. He said: ‘Why did you not inform me?’ They said: ‘She died at night and was buried; we did not want to wake you.’ He said: ‘It is as if they belittled her matter. Show me her grave.’ They showed it, and he came to her grave and prayed over her. Then, according to Thābit or another narration, these graves are filled with darkness for their occupants, but Allah illuminates them through my prayers.”
foot_note: None

text: Second: That in a narration by Al-Bukhari with the wording: "That a woman or a man used to sweep the mosque, and I do not see him to be other than a woman." It seemed probable to the narrator that it was a woman. Third: The Hadith was reported via another path from Abu Hurairah, in which the narrator did not doubt; its wording is: "The Prophet missed a black woman who used to pick up rags and sticks from the mosque, so he said: 'Where is so-and-so?' They said: 'She died'." He mentioned the Hadith. Al-Bayhaqi cited it in this manner (2/440 - 4/32) via the path of Al-Ala' bin Abdul-Rahman from his father from him. Ibn Khuzaimah also narrated it in his "Sahih" as mentioned in "Al-Fath". The first addition is from Al-Bayhaqi and Ibn Khuzaimah, and its first part is from Ahmad. The second is from Muslim and Al-Bayhaqi in a narration, and Al-Bukhari has its meaning. Abu Dawood and "The Two Musnads" have the second part of it. The third addition is from Al-Bayhaqi, and the fourth is his in a narration, and for Muslim and likewise Ahmad; and he [Ahmad] has the addition from the statement of Thabit, which is also with Al-Bayhaqi. Al-Hafiz [Ibn Hajar], following Al-Bayhaqi, considered it probable that the fourth addition is interpolated (Mudraj) in the Hadith and that it is from the Mursal narrations of Thabit. Ibn at-Turkumani disagreed with them, holding that it is connected (Musnad) from the narration of Abu Rafi' from Abu Hurairah "because it is like that in Sahih Muslim," but this statement of Thabit supports what the first two went to. It is strengthened by the fact that the Hadith was reported from the narration of Ibn Abbas as well, and this addition is not in it; At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (3/128/2). Yes, this addition or its meaning is proven as connected (Musnad) in another Hadith, which is: 3 - On the authority of Yazid bin Thabit - who was older than Zaid - he said: "We went out with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, [one day], and when he reached Al-Baqi', he saw a new grave. He asked about it, and they said: 'So-and-so (a female client of the tribe of so-and-so).' He recognized her and said: 'Why did you not inform me about her?' They said: '[She died at noon, and] you were napping and fasting, so we disliked properly to disturb you.' He said: 'Do not do that. I must know; no dead person among you dies while I am among you except that you inform me of him, for my prayer over him is a mercy.' Then he came to the grave, and we lined up behind him, and he said four Takbirs over it."
foot_note: None

text: Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (1/284), Ibn Majah (1/465, 466), Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (759 - Mawarid), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/48). The context belongs to Ibn Majah, and the additions are from Al-Nasa'i. Its chain of narration is authentic according to the conditions of Muslim for all of them. 4 - On the authority of some Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to visit the sick among the poor Muslims and their weak ones, and follow their funerals, and no one else would pray over them. A poor woman from the people of Al-'Awali had been ill for a long time, and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to ask her neighbors who attended to her about her, "and he commanded them not to bury her if anything happened to her (i.e., she died) so that he could pray over her. That woman died at night, and they carried her and brought her with the funerals—or he said: to the place of funerals—at the Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace (1), so that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, could pray over her as he had commanded them. However, they found that he had gone to sleep after the Isha prayer," so they disliked waking (2) the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, from his sleep, so they prayed over her. Then they took her away. When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, woke up, he asked her neighbors who attended to him about her. They informed him of her news and that they disliked waking the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, for her. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to them: "Why did you do that? Let's go." So they went with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, until they stood at her grave. They lined up behind the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, as they line up for funeral prayer, and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over her and said four Takbirs just as he says Takbir over funerals." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi (4/48) with an authentic chain, and Al-Nasa'i (1/280, 281) in summary. Seventh: Whoever dies in a land where there is no one to pray the present prayer over him, a group of Muslims should pray the absent prayer (Salat al-Ghaib) over him, due to the prayer of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, over the Negus (Al-Najashi). This was narrated by a group of his Companions, some adding to others. I have collected their Hadiths regarding this, then I cited them in one context approximately for benefit. The context is for the Hadith of Abu Hurairah: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, announced to the people [while he was in Medina] the death of the Negus [Ashamah] [the ruler of Abyssinia] on the day in which he died. [He said: A brother has died (and in a narration: Today a righteous servant of Allah has died)]
foot_note: 1. (1) It is east of the Prophet's Mosque, and today it is the land extending along the length of the Mosque from the north to the south beside the Women's Gate. (2) They did not wake him; 'Yahjudu' is from the words that carry opposite meanings (Addad).

text: (righteous) [in a land other than yours] [so stand and pray over him], [They said: Who is he? He said: The Negus] [and he said: Seek forgiveness for your brother]. He said: So he went out with them to the place of prayer (Musalla) (and in a narration: Al-Baqi') [then he stepped forward and they lined up behind him] [in two rows], [He said: So we lined up behind him as one lines up for the dead, and we prayed over him as one prays over the dead] [and nothing is deemed but that the funeral is placed before him] [He said: So he led us and prayed over him], and he said four Takbirs (over him)." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/90, 145, 155, 157), Muslim (3/54) - and the wording is his - Abu Dawood (2/68, 69), Al-Nasa'i (1/265, 280), Ibn Majah (1/467), Al-Bayhaqi (4/49), At-Tayalisi (2300), and Ahmad (2/241, 280, 289, 348, 438, 439, 479, 529) via paths from Abu Hurairah. The first addition is for Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad; the second for Al-Bukhari; the third for Ibn Majah; the seventh for the Two Sheikhs [Bukhari & Muslim], Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad. The tenth, the second part of it, is for Ahmad, and he has it in full from someone other than Abu Hurairah as will come. The last addition is for Muslim. At-Tirmidhi (2/140) narrated part of it and authenticated it, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over the Negus and said four Takbirs; and it is a narration of At-Tayalisi (2296). 2 - Then Al-Bukhari (3/145, 146), Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, At-Tayalisi in (1681), and Ahmad (3/295, 319, 355, 361, 363, 369, 400) narrated it via paths of the Hadith of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him. The second, third, and fourth additions are for the Two Sheikhs and Ahmad; and the fifth and sixth are his; and the ninth is for Muslim and Al-Nasa'i; and for Al-Nasa'i is the first sentence of the tenth addition. The twelfth addition is for Muslim and Ahmad. 3 - Then Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi (2/149) - and he authenticated it - Ibn Majah, Ibn Hibban, Al-Bayhaqi, At-Tayalisi (749), and Ahmad (4/433, 431, 439, 441, 446) narrated it from Imran, and it contains the fourth addition according to all of them, and the tenth according to At-Tayalisi, Al-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad, and he has the one after it, and so does Ibn Hibban.
foot_note: None

text: 4 - Then Ibn Majah, At-Tayalisi (1068), and Ahmad (4/7) narrated it from Hudhayfah bin Asid, and it contains the fourth and fifth additions according to them. Likewise, they have the sixth, except for At-Tayalisi. 5 - Then Ibn Majah and Ahmad (4/64 - 5/376) narrated it from Majma' bin Harithah Al-Ansari. Al-Busiri said in "Az-Zawa'id": "Its chain is authentic," and "Trustworthy narrators narrated it." It contains the fourth addition, and Ibn Majah has the ninth. 6 - Then At-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah narrated it from Abdullah bin Umar like the abbreviated Hadith of Abu Hurairah found in At-Tirmidhi. Its chain is also authentic. 7 - Then Ahmad (4/264 - 263) narrated it from Jarir bin Abdullah in a Marfu' form with the wording: "Your brother the Negus has died, so seek forgiveness for him" (1). Its chain is Hasan. Know that what we have mentioned regarding the prayer for the absent is what the Hadith supports and nothing else. A group of verifiers (Muhaqqiqin) of the schools of thought preceded us in choosing this. Here is a summary of the words of Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, in this regard. He said in "Zad al-Ma'ad" (1/205, 206): "It was not from his guidance, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and his Sunnah to pray over every absent dead person, for many people from the Muslims died while they were absent, and he did not pray over them. It is authentically established from him that he prayed over the Negus his prayer over the dead. There was a difference of opinion on this regarding three paths:
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: In these Hadiths, there is evidence from aspects that are not hidden that the Negus Ashamah was a Muslim. This is supported by the fact that the explicit text came from him confirming his belief in the Prophethood of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, commanded us to set out to the land of the Negus" - and he mentioned the story, and in it - "And the Negus said: I testify that he is the Messenger of Allah, and that he is the one whom Jesus son of Mary gave glad tidings of. Were it not for the kingship I am in, I would have come to him to carry his sandals." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi with an authentic chain as Al-Bayhaqi said, as quoted by Al-Iraqi in "Takhrij Al-Ihya" (2/200). It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud narrated by At-Tayalisi (346), and other supporting evidences in Musnad Ahmad (5/290 and 292).

text: 1 - That this is legislation and a Sunnah for the Ummah to pray over every absent person; this is the saying of Al-Shafi'i and Ahmad. 2 - Abu Hanifa and Malik said: This was specific to him (the Prophet), and it is not for anyone else. 3 - Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: The correct view is that if the absent person dies in a land where he was not prayed over, the absent prayer is prayed over him, just as the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over the Negus because he died among the disbelievers and had not been prayed over. But if he was prayed over where he died, the absent prayer is not prayed over him, because the obligation was dropped by the Muslims' prayer over him. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over the absent and left it (in other cases), and his doing it and leaving it are both Sunnah. This has its place, and Allah knows best. There are three opinions in the Madhhab of Ahmad, and the most correct of them is this detailed one. I say: This was chosen by the text of the verifiers from the Shafi'is. Al-Khattabi said in "Ma'alim as-Sunan" what implies: I say: The Negus was a Muslim man who believed in the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and verified his prophethood. "However, he used to conceal his faith. When a Muslim dies, it is obligatory upon the Muslims to pray over him. But since he was among the people of disbelief, and there was no one in his presence to fulfill the right of prayer over him, it became necessary for the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, to do that, as he is his Prophet, his Guardian (Wali), and the one with the most right over him. This - and Allah knows best - is the reason that called him to pray over him in the unseen (in absentia). Based on this, if a Muslim dies in any land, and his right to be prayed over has been fulfilled, then one who is in another land absent from him does not pray over him. But if it is known that he was not prayed over due to an obstacle or a valid excuse, the Sunnah is to pray over him and not leave that due to the distance. When they pray over him, they face the Qiblah, and they do not face the land of the deceased if it is in other than the direction of the Qiblah. Some scholars have gone to the dislike of praying for the absent dead, and they claimed that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was specific in this action, as he was in the ruling of one witnessing the Negus, based on what was narrated in some reports "that the flags of the earth were leveled for him until he could see his place" (1). This is a corrupt interpretation because...
foot_note: 1. (1) An-Nawawi mentioned in "Al-Majmu'" (5/253) that this report is from fantasies! Then he mentioned the Hadith of Al-Ala' bin Zaid regarding the folding of the earth for the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, until he went and prayed over Mu'awiyah in Tabuk, and he said that it is a weak Hadith, weakened by the Huffaz (Hadith Masters), among them Al-Bukhari and Al-Bayhaqi.

text: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, if he did something from the actions of the Shariah, it is upon us to follow him and emulate him, and specificity is not known except with evidence. What clarifies this is that he, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, went out with the people to the Musalla (place of prayer) and lined them up, and they prayed with him. Thus, it is known that this interpretation is corrupt, and Allah knows best. Al-Ruyani - who is also a Shafi'i - deemed good what Al-Khattabi went to. It is also the Madhhab of Abu Dawood, for he titled the Hadith in his "Sunan" with his saying: "Chapter on Praying over a Muslim who dies in the lands of Shirk (polytheism)." The verifying scholar Sheikh Salih Al-Maqbili, from the later scholars, also chose this as in "Nayl al-Awtar" (4/43). He cited as evidence the addition that occurred in some paths of the Hadith: "Your brother has died in a land other than yours, so stand and pray over him," and its chain is on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. What supports the lack of legitimacy of praying over every absent person is that when the Rightly Guided Caliphs and others died, none of the Muslims prayed the absent prayer over them. Had they done so, the transmission of that would have been mutawatir (widely transmitted) from them. Compare this with what many Muslims are upon today regarding praying over every absent person, especially if he has fame and repute, even if only from a political aspect, and is not known for righteousness or service to Islam. Even if he died in the Makkan Sanctuary and thousands upon thousands prayed the present prayer over him during the Hajj season; compare what we mentioned with such a prayer, and you will know with certainty that it is from the innovations (Bid'ah) about which a scholar of his Sunnah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the way of the Salaf, may Allah be pleased with them, would not doubt. 60 - It is forbidden (Haram) to pray over, seek forgiveness for, and ask for mercy upon disbelievers and hypocrites (1) due to the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {And do not pray [the funeral prayer, as-Salah] over any of them who has died - ever - or stand at his grave. Indeed, they disbelieved in Allah and His Messenger and died while they were defiantly disobedient.} [At-Tawbah: 84]. The reason for the revelation of the verse is what Abdullah bin Umar and his father narrated, and the context belongs to him. He said:
foot_note: 1. (1) They are those who conceal disbelief and display Islam. Their disbelief only becomes apparent through what leaks from their words regarding criticism of some rulings of the Shariah and finding them repugnant, and their claim that they contradict reason and taste! Our Lord, the Blessed, pointed to this reality in His saying: {Or do those in whose hearts is disease think that Allah would never expose their [feelings of] hatred? And if We willed, We could show them to you, and you would know them by their mark; but you will surely know them by the tone of [their] speech. And Allah knows your deeds.} Examples of these hypocrites are many in our present age, and Allah is the One whose help is sought.

text: "When Abdullah bin Ubayy bin Salul died, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was invited to pray over him. When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stood up, I jumped towards him [until I stood in front of his chest], [and I grabbed his garment] and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, will you pray over [the enemy of Allah] Ibn Ubayy while he said on such-and-such day such-and-such!?' I enumerated his statements against him (1). [Did not Allah forbid you from praying over the hypocrites when He said:] {Ask forgiveness for them or do not ask forgiveness for them. If you should ask forgiveness for them seventy times - never will Allah forgive them...} [At-Tawbah: 80]. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, smiled and said: 'Back off from me, O Umar!' When I persisted, he said: 'I have been given a choice so I chose. [It was said to me: ({Ask forgiveness for them or do not ask forgiveness for them. If you should ask forgiveness for them seventy times - never will Allah forgive them...} [At-Tawbah: 80]). If I knew that if I increased over seventy he would be forgiven, I would have increased over it.' [He said: 'He is a hypocrite'] (2). He said: So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over him (3) [and we prayed with him], [and he walked with him and stood at his grave until he finished with it]. Then he left, and it was only a short while until the two verses of Bara'ah (At-Tawbah) were revealed: {And do not pray over any of them who has died - ever - or stand at his grave. Indeed, they disbelieved in Allah and His Messenger and died while they were defiantly disobedient.} [At-Tawbah: 84]. [He said: (So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, never prayed over a hypocrite after him, nor did he stand at his grave until Allah took his soul), He said: I wondered afterwards at my boldness with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, on that day.] And Allah and His Messenger know best."
foot_note:
1. (1) He refers by that to the likes of his saying: (Do not spend on those who are with the Messenger of Allah until they disband) and his saying: (The more honorable will surely expel therefrom the more humble). 
2. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Fath al-Bari" (8/270): "Umar only asserted that he was a hypocrite based on what appeared from his conditions. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did not accept his saying and prayed over him to treat him according to the apparent ruling of Islam, and to maintain the apparent ruling, and because of the honor to his son whose righteousness was verified, and for the benefit of reconciling his people and warding off harm. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in the beginning, used to be patient with the harm of the polytheists and would pardon and forgive. Then he was commanded to fight the polytheists, so his pardoning and forgiveness continued for those who displayed Islam even if their inner self was contrary to that, for the interest of reconciliation and not driving people away from him. That is why he said: 'Let not the people talk that Muhammad kills his companions.' When the Conquest happened, and the polytheists entered Islam, and the people of disbelief became few and humiliated, he was commanded to confront the hypocrites and hold them to the bitter truth, especially since that was before the revelation of the explicit prohibition of praying over the hypocrites and other things he was commanded regarding confronting them. With this explanation, the confusion regarding what happened in this story is removed, by the praise of Allah Almighty." 
3. I say: He only prayed over him after he had been placed in his pit and brought out from it by his command, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he clothed him in his shirt as will come in Issue (94).

text: Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/177 - 8/270), Al-Nasa'i (1/279), At-Tirmidhi (3/117, 118), and Ahmad (No. 95) from Umar. The first, third, fifth, eighth, and ninth additions are for Ahmad and At-Tirmidhi, and he authenticated it. The other additions are for Al-Bukhari except the sixth, which is for Muslim. Al-Bukhari has the second addition from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, and it is for At-Tabari as in "Al-Fath". Then Al-Bukhari (8/286 Vol 270 - 10/218), Muslim (7/116 - 8/120, 121), Al-Nasa'i (1/269), At-Tirmidhi (3/118, 119), Ibn Majah (1/464, 465), Al-Bayhaqi (3/402), and Ahmad (4680) extracted it from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, and it contains the second and sixth additions. And from Al-Musayyib bin Hazn, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "When death approached Abu Talib, the Messenger of Allah came to him and found Abu Jahl, Abdullah bin Abi Umayyah, and Al-Mughirah with him. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'O Uncle, you are the greatest of people in right upon me, and the best of them in favor to me. You are greater in right upon me than my father, so [say] La ilaha illa Allah (There is no deity but Allah), a word I will testify for you with before Allah.' Abu Jahl and Abdullah bin Umayyah said: 'O Abu Talib, do you turn away from the religion of Abdul-Muttalib?' The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, kept offering it to him and repeating that statement to him, until Abu Talib said the last thing he spoke to them: 'He is on the religion of Abdul-Muttalib,' and he refused to say: La ilaha illa Allah (2). [He said: Were it not that Quraish would shame me - saying: nothing carried him to do that except anxiety/fear - I would have delighted your eye with it!] (The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: By Allah, I will surely ask forgiveness for you as long as I am not forbidden from you. (The Muslims started asking forgiveness for their dead who died as polytheists, so Allah Almighty revealed: {It is not for the Prophet and those who have believed to ask forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they were relatives, after it has become clear to them that they are companions of Hellfire} [At-Tawbah: 113], and Allah revealed regarding Abu Talib, saying to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: {Indeed, [O Muhammad], you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of the [rightly] guided} [Al-Qasas: 56]!! Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/173 - 7/154 - 8/274, 410, 411), Muslim, Al-Nasa'i (1/286), Ahmad (5/433), and Ibn Jarir in his Tafsir (11/27). The context is his and likewise Muslim's. The second addition is his in some manuscripts as mentioned by Al-Hafiz from Al-Qurtubi, and it is witnessed by the narration of Al-Bukhari and others with its meaning.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning Abu Jahl and Ibn Abi Umayyah.

text: The story was reported from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah in summary by Muslim and At-Tirmidhi (4/159) - who graded it Hasan - and they have the third addition; and Al-Hakim (2/335 and 336) - who authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed - and he has the first addition. It is also with Ibn Jarir from the Hadith of Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib via Mursal chain, but it has the ruling of connected (Mawsul) because he is the one who narrated the Hadith from Al-Musayyib bin Hazn, who is his father. It was also reported from the Hadith of Jabir. Al-Hakim also extracted it and authenticated it, and Al-Dhahabi agreed. It contains the fourth addition, which is with Ibn Jarir via Mursal chain from Mujahid and from Amr bin Dinar. And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "I heard a man asking forgiveness for his parents while they were polytheists. I said: 'Do you ask forgiveness for your parents while they are polytheists!?' He said: [Did not Abraham ask forgiveness while he (his father) was a polytheist?] He said: So I mentioned that to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace!? So it was revealed: {It is not for the Prophet and those who have believed to ask forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they were relatives, after it has become clear to them that they are companions of Hellfire (113) And the request of forgiveness of Abraham (1) for his father was only because of a promise he had made to him. But when it became apparent to him that he was an enemy to Allah, he disassociated himself from him. Indeed, Abraham was compassionate and patient.} [At-Tawbah: 113, 114]. Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (11/28), At-Tirmidhi (4/120) - and he graded it Hasan - Ibn Jarir (11/28), Al-Hakim (2/335), and Ahmad (771, 1085). The context is his, and its chain is Hasan. Al-Hakim said "Authentic chain," and Al-Dhahabi agreed (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: This seeking of forgiveness is only what Allah Almighty recounted about him at the end of Surah Ibrahim: (Our Lord, forgive me and my parents and the believers the Day the account is established). The exegetes mentioned that this supplication from him was after the death of his father and after his migration to Makkah, as witnessed by the context of the verses in which the mentioned verse appeared at the end. Based on that, the clarification mentioned in the verse of seeking forgiveness must have been after his father's death as well, and that was by Allah informing him. Ibn Abi Hatim extracted with an authentic chain, as Al-Suyuti said in "Al-Fatawa" (2/419), from Ibn Abbas who said: "Abraham kept asking forgiveness for his father until he died. When he died, it became clear to him that he was an enemy of Allah, so he did not ask forgiveness for him." 
2. In this Hadith, the reason for the revelation of the verse is different from the reason mentioned in the Hadith before it. There is no contradiction between them due to the possibility of multiple reasons for revelation as happened in other verses. Al-Hafiz supported this in "Al-Fath" (8/412).

text: An-Nawawi, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said in "Al-Majmu'" (5/144, 258): "Praying over the disbeliever and supplicating for forgiveness for him is Haram (forbidden) by the text of the Qur'an and Consensus (Ijma')" (1). 61 - Congregation (Jama'ah) is obligatory in the funeral prayer just as it is obligatory in the prescribed prayers, based on two proofs: First: The Prophet's, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, persistence in it. Second: His saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "Pray as you have seen me praying." Extracted by Al-Bukhari. The Companions praying over the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, individually without anyone leading them does not contradict what we mentioned, because it was a special case whose reason is unknown. Thus, it is not permissible to leave what he, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, persisted in throughout his blessed life because of it, especially since the mentioned case was not reported with an authentic chain that establishes proof, even if it was narrated via paths that strengthen each other (2). If it is possible to reconcile it with what we mentioned of his guidance, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding congregation in the funeral, then so be it. Otherwise, his guidance takes precedence "because it is more established and better guiding.
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: From this, you know the error of some Muslims today in seeking mercy and pleasure for some disbelievers. This is frequent from some newspaper and magazine owners. I heard one of the Arab leaders known for religiosity seeking mercy for (Stalin) the communist, who along with his ideology is among the severest enemies of the religion! That was in a speech delivered by the mentioned President on the occasion of the death of the aforementioned, broadcasted on the radio! There is no wonder at this coming from such a ruler, but the wonder is from some Islamic preachers that in the likes of this... where he said in a treatise of his: "May Allah have mercy on Bernard Shaw..." Some trustworthy people informed me about a Sheikh who used to pray over those who died from the Ismailis while believing they are not Muslims because they do not view prayer or Hajj [as obligatory] and they deify humans! Yet, he prays over them out of hypocrisy and flattery to them. To Allah is the complaint, and He is the One whose help is sought. 
2. Al-Bayhaqi extracted in his Sunan (4/30) two Hadiths from them, and one of them is from Ibn Majah (1/498, 500). Ahmad (5/81) narrated a third Hadith, and Al-Hafiz remained silent about it in "At-Talkhis" (5/187). Its men are the trustworthy men of Muslim except Abu 'Usaym. Al-Baghawi said: "I do not know if he has companionship (Suhba) or not." In the chapter, there are other Hadiths which Al-Hafiz cited in the mentioned chapter, then he said: "Ibn Dihyah said: The correct view is that the Muslims prayed over him individually, no one leading them. Al-Shafi'i asserted this. He said: That was due to the greatness of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace - may my father and mother be ransomed for him - and their competition that no single person should take the leadership in praying over him. And Allah knows best.

text: If they pray over it individually, the obligation is dropped, but they sin by leaving the congregation, and Allah knows best (1). 62 - The minimum number reported for the congregation to be valid in it is three. In the Hadith of Abdullah bin Abi Talha: "That Talha invited the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, for Umair bin Abi Talha when he died. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came to him and prayed over him in their house. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stepped forward, and Abu Talha was behind him, and Umm Sulaim was behind Abu Talha, and there was no one else with them." Extracted by Al-Hakim (1/365) and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/30: 31). Al-Hakim said: "This is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs, and a strange Sunnah regarding the permissibility of women praying over funerals." Al-Dhahabi agreed. I say: It is only on the condition of Muslim alone because it contains 'Umarah bin Ghaziyyah, and Al-Bukhari did not narrate from him except in suspended form (Ta'liq). Al-Haythami said about the Hadith in "Al-Majma'" (3/34): "At-Tabarani narrated it in 'Al-Kabir' and its men are the men of the Sahih." It has a supporting evidence from the Hadith of Anas with its meaning. Extracted by Imam Ahmad (2/217). 63 - The larger the gathering, the better it is for the deceased and more beneficial, due to his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "There is no deceased person over whom a community of Muslims prays, reaching one hundred, all of them interceding for him, except that they are granted intercession for him." And in another Hadith: "He is forgiven." Extracted by Muslim (3/53), Al-Nasa'i (1/281, 282), At-Tirmidhi - and he authenticated it - (2/143, 144), Al-Bayhaqi (4/30), At-Tayalisi (1526), and Ahmad (6/32, 40, 97, 231) from the Hadith of Aisha with the first wording.
foot_note: 1. (1) An-Nawawi said in "Al-Majmu'" (5/314): "Funeral prayer is permissible individually without disagreement, but the Sunnah is to pray it in congregation due to the famous authentic Hadiths regarding that, along with the consensus of the Muslims."

text: And Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (3/266) from the Hadith of Anas, and Ibn Majah (1/453) from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah with the other wording. Its chain is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. The deceased may be forgiven even if the number is less than one hundred if they are Muslims whose monotheism is not mixed with any polytheism (Shirk), due to his saying: "There is no Muslim man who dies, and forty men stand for his funeral prayer, who do not associate anything with Allah, except that Allah accepts their intercession for him." Extracted by Muslim, Abu Dawood (2/64), Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (2509) from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas. Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad (6/331, 334) narrated it from the Hadith of Maymunah, the wife of the Prophet, in summary, and its chain is Hasan. 65 - It is recommended that they line up behind the Imam in three rows (1) or more, due to two Hadiths narrated regarding that: First: From Abu Umamah who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over a funeral and with him were seven people. So he made three a row, two a row, and two a row." Narrated by At-Tabarani in (1) "Al-Kabir". Al-Haythami said in "Al-Majma'" (3/432): "It contains Ibn Lahi'ah 'and there is discussion about him'." I say: That is due to his memory, for there is no accusation against him in himself, so his Hadith in supporting evidences is acceptable. That is why I cited it as a witness for the following Hadith, which is: Second: From Malik bin Hubayrah who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said:
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Shawkani said (4 - 47): "The minimum to be called a row is two men, and there is no limit for its maximum."

text: "There is no Muslim who dies and three rows of Muslims pray over him except that it becomes obligatory (and in a wording: except that he is forgiven)." He said: (Meaning Marthad bin Abdullah Al-Yazani): "Malik used to, if the people of the funeral were few, divide them into three rows due to the Hadith." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/63) - and the context is his - At-Tirmidhi (2/143), Ibn Majah (1/454), Al-Hakim (1/362, 363), Al-Bayhaqi (4/30), and Ahmad (4/79). The other wording is his, and likewise in a narration for Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Hakim, who said: "Authentic on the condition of Muslim," and Al-Dhahabi agreed! At-Tirmidhi said, followed by An-Nawawi in "Al-Majmu'" (5/212): "Hasan Hadith," and Al-Hafiz confirmed it in "Al-Fath" (3/145). It contains in all their chains Muhammad bin Ishaq, who is Hasan in Hadith if he explicitly states he heard (narrated), but here he used 'an' (from). So I do not know the basis for their grading it Hasan, let alone Sahih!? 65 - If there is no one with the Imam except one man, he does not stand beside him as is the Sunnah in other prayers, but rather he stands behind the Imam, due to the previous Hadith in Issue (33), which says: "So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stepped forward, and Abu Talha was behind him, and Umm Sulaim was behind Abu Talha, and there was no one else with them." 66 - The Ruler (Wali) or his deputy has more right to lead in it than the guardian (Wali of the deceased), due to the Hadith of Abu Hazim who said: "I was present on the day Al-Hasan bin Ali died. I saw Al-Hussein bin Ali saying to Sa'id bin Al-Aas - poking him in his neck and saying: - Step forward, for were it not a Sunnah, I would not have put you forward" (and Sa'id was the Governor of Medina on that day) (1) and there was something between them."
foot_note: 1. (1) He saw the Prophet; the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, died when he was nine years old. He was forbearing and dignified, from the nobles of Quraish. He was one of those who wrote the Mushaf for Uthman. He employed him over Kufa, and he led the people in the invasion of Tabaristan. Mu'awiyah employed him over Medina. He died in his palace at Al-'Arsah, three miles from Medina in the year (58), and was buried in Al-Baqi'.
