text: Extracted by Al-Hakim (3/171) and Al-Bayhaqi (4/28), and he added at its end: "Abu Hurairah said: Do you begrudge the son of your Prophet the soil in which you bury him, while I heard the Messenger of Allah say: Whoever loves them has loved me, and whoever hates them has hated me?" Ahmad also extracted it (2/531) with this addition, but he did not narrate the story of putting Sa'id forward for prayer, but indicated it by saying: "So he mentioned the story." Then Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain," and Al-Dhahabi agreed. Al-Haythami cited the Hadith in "Al-Majma'" (3/31) in full with the addition, then said: "Narrated by At-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and Al-Bazzar, and its men are trustworthy." Al-Hafiz attributed it in "At-Talkhis" (5/275) to them along with Al-Bayhaqi and said: "It contains Salim bin Abi Hafsah who is weak, but Al-Nasa'i and Ibn Majah narrated it from another path from Abu Hazim with a similar meaning. Ibn al-Mundhir said in 'Al-Awsat': There is nothing higher in the chapter than it, because the funeral of Al-Hasan was attended by a large group of Companions and others." I say: This is the speech of Al-Hafiz, and there is some questionable matter in it which you will see in the footnote. (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) That is from two aspects: First: His absolute labeling of Ibn Abi Hafsah as weak contradicts what he said in his biography in "At-Taqrib": "Truthful (Saduq), except that he is an extreme Shi'i." I say: If he is truthful, then his Hadith is Hasan at the lowest levels, and it does not harm him that he is a Shi'i as established in the science of terminology. His Hadith here is strengthened by the fact that Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in a narration of his from the path of Ismail bin Raja' Al-Zubaidi, who said: I was informed by one who witnessed Al-Hussein bin Ali when he died... So he mentioned the Hadith in summary, and in it is Al-Hussein's saying to Sa'id: "Step forward, for were it not a Sunnah, I would not have put you forward." This Ismail is trustworthy, and he followed up Ibn Abi Hafsah, so it is a strong follow-up (Mutaba'ah). Even though the one who witnessed the story was not named in it, Salim named him as you saw, and others did too, as Al-Hafiz indicated by saying "but Al-Nasa'i and Ibn Majah narrated it..." But there is what follows: Second: I did not find the Hadith in the "Funerals" of Sunan Al-Nasa'i and Ibn Majah, nor did Al-Nabulsi mention it in "Adh-Dhakha'ir" in the Musnad of Al-Hussein nor in the Musnad of Abu Hazim. And Allah knows best. =

text: 67 - If the Ruler or his deputy is not present, then the one most worthy of leading is the one who recites the Book of Allah most, then according to the order mentioned in his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "The one who recites the Book of Allah most should lead the people. If they are equal in recitation, then the most knowledgeable of them in the Sunnah. If they are equal in the Sunnah, then the earliest of them in Hijrah (migration). If they are equal in Hijrah, then the earliest of them in Islam (or age). A man should not lead another man in his domain (authority), nor should he sit in his house on his place of honor except by his permission." Extracted by Muslim (2/133) and others from the authors of Sunan and Masanid from the Hadith of Abu Mas'ud Al-Badri Al-Ansari. I have extracted it in "Sahih Abi Dawood" (No. 594, 598). The one who recites most leads even if he is a boy who has not reached puberty, due to the Hadith of Amr bin Salamah: "That they (meaning his people) came as a delegation to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. When they wanted to leave, they said: O Messenger of Allah, who should lead us? He said: The one among you who has collected (memorized) the Qur'an most or taken the Qur'an most. There was no one among the people
foot_note: 1. = Ibn Hazm cited this story in "Al-Muhalla" (5/441) with a form of certainty weakening it, even though he did not adopt the ruling it implies. He said: "We said: We have not left a consensus for you so that you can oppose us with this, but if the Ummah disputes, it is obligatory to refer to the Qur'an and Sunnah, and in the Qur'an and Sunnah is what we have presented." I say: It seems Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, does not view the statement of a Companion "The Sunnah is such-and-such" as having the ruling of Marfu' (elevated to the Prophet), and this contradicts what is established in the two fundamentals (Usul) that such is in the ruling of Marfu', and it is the correct view, Allah willing. More clarification on this will come in Issue (73). As for what Ibn Hazm indicated regarding the "Qur'an and Sunnah", he means the Almighty's saying (And those of [blood] relationship are more entitled [to inheritance] in the decree of Allah), and his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in the following Hadith in the next issue "And a man should not lead a man in his family" as in a narration that Ibn Hazm used as evidence that the ones most entitled to pray over the deceased are the guardians/relatives. It is not hidden that this is reasoning using the general text, while our evidence, which is the Hadith of Al-Hussein, may Allah be pleased with him, is specific, and it is given precedence as established in Usul. That is why the majority of scholars went to what we mentioned, such as Abu Hanifa, Malik, Ahmad, Ishaq, Ibn al-Mundhir, and Al-Shafi'i in his old opinion as in "Al-Majmu'" (5/217). Then I realized and said: The Hadith has no generality regarding what we are discussing, because its meaning is: No one should pray as Imam leading the owner of the house in his house. This is clear from the collection of narrations of the Hadith. In a narration by Muslim: "And a man should not lead a man in his family," and in another by him "And do not lead a man in his family nor in his authority." This is an argument against Ibn Hazm because the apparent meaning is also that what is intended is the Sultan (Authority) who has the guardianship of people's affairs. The apparent meaning is also that he is given precedence over others even if they recite more Qur'an than him. See Al-Shawkani (3/134).

text: who had collected what I had collected, so they put me forward while I was a boy, wearing a cloak of mine. He said: I never attended a gathering of Jarm except that I was their Imam, and I pray over their funerals until this day of ours." Extracted by Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi with an authentic chain. Its origin is in Al-Bukhari but it does not contain the place of witness, which is a narration for Abu Dawood. I have extracted it in "Sahih Abi Dawood" No. (599 and 602). 68 - If several funerals of men and women gather, one prayer is prayed over them. The males - even if they are young - are placed closest to the Imam, and the funerals of females closest to the Qiblah. There are Hadiths regarding that: First: From Nafi' from Ibn Umar: "That he prayed (1) over nine funerals together. He placed the men next to the Imam and the women next to the Qiblah, lining them up in one row. The funeral of Umm Kulthum bint Ali, the wife of Umar bin Al-Khattab, and a son of hers named Zaid were placed together. The Imam on that day was Sa'id bin Al-Aas, and among the people were Ibn Abbas, Abu Hurairah, Abu Sa'id, and Abu Qatadah. The boy was placed closest to the Imam." A man said: I objected to that, so I looked at Ibn Abbas, Abu Hurairah, Abu Sa'id, and Abu Qatadah and said: What is this? They said: It is the Sunnah." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/280), Ibn Al-Jarud in "Al-Muntaqa" (267, 268), Al-Daraqutni (194), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/33). I say: The chain of Al-Nasa'i and Ibn Al-Jarud is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. Al-Hafiz restricted himself in "At-Talkhis" (5/276) to attributing it to Ibn Al-Jarud alone and said:
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: Meaning as an Imam, as indicated by the context, and Al-Bayhaqi stated that explicitly in a narration of his in the Hadith following this one, as we will mention there. This does not contradict his saying later: "And the Imam on that day was Sa'id bin Al-Aas" because the meaning is that he was the Amir (Prince/Governor). Al-Hafiz said: "It is possible that Ibn Umar led them in reality with the permission of Sa'id bin Al-Aas, and his statement 'that the Imam was Sa'id bin Al-Aas' is interpreted to mean the Amir, combining the two narrations."

text: (And its chain is authentic). As for An-Nawawi, he said (5/224): "Al-Bayhaqi narrated it with a Hasan chain"! Second: From Ammar, the client of Al-Harith bin Nawfal "that he witnessed the funeral of Umm Kulthum and her son. The boy was placed closest to the Imam, [and the woman was placed behind him, so he prayed over her]. I objected to that, and in the group were Ibn Abbas, Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, Abu Qatadah, and Abu Hurairah. [So I asked them about that], and they said: This is the Sunnah." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/66) - and the context is his - and from his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/33) and Al-Nasa'i (1/280). The two additions are his. Its chain is authentic on the condition of Muslim. An-Nawawi said (5/224): "And its chain is authentic. This Ammar is a Tabi'i, a client of Bani Hashim, and they agreed on his trustworthiness." Al-Bayhaqi said: "Hammad bin Salamah narrated it from Ammar bin Abi Ammar without the manner of placement similarly, and mentioned that the Imam was Ibn Umar. He said: And in the group were Al-Hasan, Al-Hussein, Abu Hurairah, and about eighty of the Companions of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Al-Sha'bi narrated it mentioning the manner of placement similarly, and mentioned that the Imam was Ibn Umar, but did not mention the questioning. He said: And behind him were Ibn Al-Hanafiyyah, Al-Hussein, and Ibn Abbas, and in a narration: Abdullah bin Ja'far). 69 - It is permissible to pray a prayer over each of the funerals, because it is the origin, and because the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did that regarding the martyrs of Uhud. There are two Hadiths regarding that: First: From Abdullah bin Az-Zubair, and it was presented in Issue (59), Hadith (2) page 82. Second: From Ibn Abbas who said: "When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stood over Hamzah, he ordered regarding him, so he was prepared towards the Qiblah. Then he said nine Takbirs over him. Then the martyrs were gathered to him. Every time a martyr was brought, he was placed next to Hamzah, so he prayed over him and over the martyrs with him until he prayed over him and the martyrs seventy-two prayers."
foot_note: None

text: Extracted by At-Tabarani in his "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (3/107, 108) via the path of Muhammad bin Ishaq, narrated to me by Muhammad bin Ka'b Al-Qurazi and Al-Hakam bin Utaybah from Miqsam and Mujahid from him. I say: This is a good chain (Jayyid); its men are all trustworthy. Muhammad bin Ishaq explicitly stated narration (Tahdith), so the doubt of his Tadlis (obfuscation) is removed. It seems that Imam Al-Suhayli and Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar did not come across this chain, for Al-Hafiz said in "At-Talkhis" (5/153, 154): "And in the chapter is also the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, narrated by Ibn Ishaq who said: Narrated to me by one whom I do not accuse from Miqsam, the client of Ibn Abbas, from Ibn Abbas... (I say: He mentioned the Hadith similarly except that he said: 'seven' instead of 'nine', then he said:) Al-Suhayli said: If the one Ibn Ishaq left unnamed is Al-Hasan bin 'Umarah, then he is weak; otherwise, he is unknown and there is no proof in it. End quote. I say: What led Al-Suhayli to that is what occurred in the introduction of 'Muslim' from Shu'bah that Al-Hasan bin 'Umarah narrated to him from Al-Hakam from Miqsam from Ibn Abbas 'that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over the slain of Uhud.' So I asked Al-Hakam? He said: He did not pray over them.' End quote. However, the Hadith of Ibn Abbas was narrated from other paths..." I say: Then he mentioned some of them, and the path of At-Tabarani is not among them. It indicates that the unnamed person in that narration is not unknown or weak, but rather a known trustworthy narrator, who is Muhammad bin Ka'b Al-Qurazi or Al-Hakam bin Utaybah, or both of them together. Al-Hakam's statement in the narration of Muslim "He did not pray over them" does not deceive regarding this, due to the possibility that Al-Hakam forgot what he had narrated, as happened similarly to others in other Hadiths. Even if we accept for the sake of argument that Al-Hakam's denial of his Hadith impugns its authenticity from him, we do not accept that it impugns the authenticity of the Hadith itself as long as another trustworthy narrator, Al-Qurazi, narrated it. This is clear, if Allah Almighty wills. (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) An-Nawawi said in "Al-Majmu'" (5-225): They agreed that it is better to single out each one with a prayer, except the author of "At-Tatimmah" who asserted that it is better to pray over them all at once, because it involves hastening the burial which is commanded. The first view is the Madhhab, because it involves more action and is more hopeful for acceptance, and it is not a significant delay. And Allah knows best.

text: 71 - Regarding praying over the funeral in the Mosque, due to the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: "When Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas died, the wives of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, sent word to pass his funeral through the Mosque so they could pray over him. They did so, and he was stopped near their chambers so they could pray over him. He was taken out through the Gate of Funerals which was towards the seats (Al-Maqa'id). News reached them that the people criticized that and said: This is an innovation; funerals were not taken into the Mosque! This reached Aisha, so she said: How hasty are people to criticize what they have no knowledge of! They criticized us for passing a funeral through the Mosque, [By Allah] the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did not pray over Suhail bin Bayda [and his brother] except in the middle of the Mosque." Extracted by Muslim (3/63) via two paths from her, and the authors of the Sunan and others. I have extracted it in "Ahkam Al-Masajid" from my book "Ath-Thamar Al-Mustatab". The additions are for Muslim except the first one which is for Al-Bayhaqi (4/51). 72 - But it is better to pray over it outside the Mosque in a place designated for prayer over funerals, as was the case during the time of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and it is the predominant practice of his guidance regarding it. There are Hadiths regarding that: First: From Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him: "That the Jews came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, with a man from them and a woman who had committed adultery. So he ordered regarding them, and they were stoned near the place of funerals at the Mosque" (1). Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/155) and he titled it, and the fourth Hadith coming up, with "Chapter: Prayer over Funerals at the Musalla and the Mosque." Second: From Jabir who said: "A man from among us died, so we washed him... and we placed him for the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, where funerals are placed near the Maqam of Jibril. Then we informed the Messenger of Allah for the prayer over him, so he came with us... and prayed over him..."
foot_note: 1. Al-Hafiz said in Al-Fath: "The Musalla of funerals was adjacent to the Prophet's Mosque, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, from the eastern side." He said in another place (12 - 108): "The Musalla is the place where Eid and funerals used to be prayed, and it is on the side of Baqi' Al-Gharqad." _________

text: Extracted by Al-Hakim and others, and it was presented in full in Issue (17) Hadith Three from Paragraph (Z), (p. 16) and in the Chapter on the authority of some Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. And he said his Hadith in Issue (59) Hadith (4) from (Sixth), (p. 89). Third: From Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Jahsh, who said: "We were sitting in the courtyard of the Mosque where funerals are placed, and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was sitting among us, so the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, raised his gaze to the sky..." Extracted by Ahmad (5/289) and Al-Hakim (2/24) who said: "Authentic chain." Al-Dhahabi agreed in his "Talkhis" and Al-Mundhiri confirmed it in his "Targhib" (3/34). It contains Abu Kathir, the client of Muhammad bin Jahsh; Ibn Abi Hatim mentioned him (4/2/429 430) and did not mention any disparagement or endorsement regarding him. Similarly, Al-Haythami said in "Al-Majma'" (4/127): "Hidden (Mastur)" and Ibn Hibban did not include him in "Ath-Thiqat". Despite that, Al-Hafiz said about him in "At-Taqrib": "Trustworthy (Thiqah)"! And he mentioned in "At-Tahdhib" that a group of trustworthy narrators narrated from him and that he was born during the life of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. So the likes of him, "his Hadith is Hasan if Allah Almighty wills, especially in supporting evidences. Fourth: From Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: "That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, announced the death of the Negus on the day he died, went out to the Musalla, lined them up, and said four Takbirs"... Extracted by the Two Sheikhs and others with many wordings and additions which have been mentioned previously grouped in one context with other additions in Hadiths of other groups of Companions, and I have clarified that in Issue (59) Hadith Seven, (p. 89 - 90). Al-Bukhari titled the Hadith with what it indicates regarding praying in the Musalla as previously mentioned in the first Hadith.
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: Among the strange things is the stance of Al-Hafiz Al-Bayhaqi regarding this Sunnah, I mean praying over the funeral in the Musalla. He did not dedicate a specific chapter for it in his large book "As-Sunan Al-Kubra" despite the abundance of Hadiths reported regarding it as you saw, even though he dedicated =

text: 72 - It is not permissible to pray over it between the graves, due to the Hadith of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him: "That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade praying over funerals between the graves." Extracted by Al-A'rabi in his "Mu'jam" (Q 235/1) and At-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat" (1/80/2), and from his path Al-Diya' Al-Maqdisi in "Al-Ahadith Al-Mukhtarah" (79/2 - Musnad Anas). Al-Haythami said in "Al-Majma'" (3/36): "And its chain is Hasan." I say: It has another path from Anas with Al-Diya' by which the Hadith is strengthened. Abu Bakr Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated in "Al-Musannaf" (81 65/1 - Al-Kawakib) and Abu Bakr bin Al-Athram as in "Fath Al-Bari" by Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali (65/81/1 - Al-Kawakib) from Anas: "He used to dislike that a mosque be built between graves"... Its men are the trustworthy men of the Two Sheikhs. The Hadith is witnessed by what is mutawatir from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding the prohibition of taking graves as mosques. I have mentioned what was reported regarding that in the beginning of my book "Tahdhir as-Sajid min Ittikhadh al-Qubur Masajid" (Warning the Prostrator against taking Graves as Mosques), and I will mention some of it in Issue (128 paragraph 9). 73 - The Imam stands behind the head of the man, and the middle of the woman. There are two Hadiths regarding this: First: From Abu Ghalib Al-Khayyat who said:
foot_note: 1. = a single chapter for praying over it in the Mosque, although there is nothing in it except the Hadith of Aisha. Then some Shafi'is followed his way in their summaries and neglected praying over it in the Musalla, such as An-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, in "Minhaj at-Talibin" (Q 34 - 2), where he said: "And it is permissible to pray over it in the Mosque." If he had added to that something like "And it is Sunnah to pray over it in the Musalla," he would have been correct. Al-Bajuri did the opposite in his footnote on Ibn Al-Qasim, saying (1 - 424): "It is Sunnah that the prayer over it be in a mosque"! Then he did not mention praying over it in the Musalla!! The truth is what we mentioned regarding the recommendation (Sunnah) along with the saying of permissibility of praying over it in the Mosque due to the Hadith of Aisha, but interpreting it as being for an incidental reason is far-fetched, because if it were so, it would not have been hidden from Sayyidah Aisha and those with her from the Mothers of the Believers, and they would not have requested bringing the funeral into the Mosque without an excuse. This is clear if Allah Almighty wills.

text: "I witnessed Anas bin Malik praying over the funeral of a man, so he stood at his head (and in a narration: the head of the bier). When he was lifted, the funeral of a woman from Quraish or the Ansar was brought. It was said to him: O Abu Hamzah, this is the funeral of so-and-so daughter of so-and-so, so pray over her. So he prayed over her and stood in her middle (and in a narration: at her buttocks, and upon her was a green bier). Among us was Al-Ala' bin Ziyad Al-Adawi (1). When he saw the difference in his standing over the man and the woman, he said: O Abu Hamzah, is this how the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to stand where you stood, and from the woman where you stood? He said: Yes. He said: So Al-Ala' turned to us and said: Preserve (memorize) this)." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/66, 67), At-Tirmidhi (2/146) - and he graded it Hasan - Ibn Majah, At-Tahawi (1/283), Al-Bayhaqi (4/32), At-Tayalisi (No. 2149), and Ahmad (3/118, 204). The context is his. All of them extracted it via the path of Hammam bin Yahya from Abu Ghalib, except Abu Dawood, who extracted it via the path of Abdul-Warith - who is Ibn Sa'id - from him. At-Tahawi also extracted it in a narration of his in summary. Its chain from both paths is authentic; their men are the men of the Two Sahihs except Abu Ghalib, who is trustworthy as in "At-Taqrib" by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar. It is amazing how he mentioned in the explanation of the following Hadith of Samurah in "Al-Fath" (3/157) that Al-Bukhari indicated the weakening of this Hadith, then he remained silent on that and did not critique it with anything! The second narration is for At-Tayalisi and Al-Bayhaqi via the path of Ahmad. The third narration is for Abu Dawood, and it is with the aforementioned with similar meaning without the word "green" (2).
foot_note: 1. (1) His Kunya is Abu Nasr. He is among the trustworthy Tabi'in, and was among the worshippers and reciters of the people of Basra. He died in the year ninety-four. (2) I say: With Abu Dawood there is another addition that must be mentioned and its condition clarified, which is: "Abu Ghalib said: So I asked about his action in standing over the woman at her buttocks. They told me that it was only because there were no biers (covered litters), so the Imam used to stand opposite her buttocks to screen her from the people." This reasoning is rejected from several aspects: First: It comes from an unknown person, and what is such has no value. Second: It is contrary to what the narrator of the Hadith himself, Anas may Allah be pleased with him, did, for he stood in her middle despite her being in a bier, and that indicates the invalidity of that reasoning. It is supported by the following aspect: =

text: Second: From Samurah bin Jundub who said: "I prayed behind the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he prayed over Umm Ka'b who died while in childbirth (Nifas), so the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stood for the prayer over her in her middle." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (6/153 - 157), Muslim (3/60) - and the context is his - Abu Dawood (2/67), Al-Nasa'i (1/280), At-Tirmidhi (2/147) - and he authenticated it - Ibn Majah (1/455), Ibn Al-Jarud (267), At-Tahawi (1/280), Al-Bayhaqi (4/34), At-Tayalisi (902), and Ahmad (5/1914). The Hadith is clear in indication that the Sunnah is for the Imam to stand opposite the middle of the woman, and it is the meaning of Anas's Hadith: "at her buttocks". Indeed, this increases clarity, for it is more explicit in indicating the intent than the Hadith of Samurah.
foot_note: 1. = Third: That it contradicts what those present at Anas's prayer understood, among them Al-Ala' bin Ziyad Al-Adawi. When he inquired from Anas about this Sunnah, he turned to his companions and said to them: "Memorize," so if it were justified by that cause which would nullify the Sunnah, Al-Ala' would not have cared for it with this great care - and commanded his companions to memorize it. This is apparent, praise be to Allah. Therefore, the majority of scholars did not turn to this interpretation, so they went to what the Hadith indicated of standing at the head of the man and the middle of the woman. Among them are Imam Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq as in "Al-Majmu'" (5/225). Al-Shawkani said (4 - 57): "And it is the truth." I say: Some Hanafis chose it, rather it is a saying of Abu Hanifa himself as in "Al-Hidayah" (1/462) and Abu Yusuf also as in "Sharh Al-Ma'ani" (1/284) by Imam At-Tahawi, and he preferred it over their other saying which is "he stands for the man and woman opposite the chest"! It is also the saying of Imam Muhammad, and the Hanafis are upon it. It was argued for them in "Al-Hidayah" by saying "because it is the place of the heart, and in it is the light of faith, so standing at it is an indication of intercession for his faith." Then he mentioned Abu Hanifa's first saying and that he argued with the saying of Anas "it is the Sunnah", so the author of "Al-Hidayah" answered him by saying: "We say its interpretation is: her funeral was not in a bier so he stood between her and them." I say: You have known from the previous the invalidity of this interpretation. Even if we concede to them, "what is their proof for opposing the Hadith in its first part which is standing opposite the head of the man? They said: Rather he stands opposite his chest. I wish I knew what drives them to openly oppose the Sunnah with such invalid justifications and their saying: "because it is the place of the heart..." You see them saying it in an opinion of theirs; why didn't they take it as Imam At-Tahawi, may Allah have mercy on him, did, so they would be correct in Sunnah and take the saying of the Imams at the same time? With this explicit opposition to this Sunnah and others, regarding which there is no ambiguity, they attribute those who accuse them of prioritizing opinion over Sunnah to fanaticism against them!

text: 74 - He says Takbir (Allah is Greatest) over it four or five, up to nine Takbirs. All of that is established from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so whichever he does is sufficient for him. It is better to vary, doing this sometimes and that sometimes, as is the case in similar matters like the opening supplications, the forms of Tashahhud, the Abrahamic prayers, and the like. If adhering to one type is necessary, then it is the four because the Hadiths regarding it are more numerous. Here is the clarification of that: A - As for the four, there are Hadiths about it from a group of Companions. First: From Abu Hurairah, and his Hadith passed in Issue (59) (Seventh) regarding the prayer over the Negus and that he, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said four Takbirs over him (p. 89). Second: From Ibn Abbas, and it passed in the issue referred to regarding the prayer over the man who was buried at night. In (Sixth), Hadith (1 - ) (p. 87). Third: From Yazid bin Thabit in his prayer, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, over a female client of Bani so-and-so in her grave, and it is in the place referred to after the Hadith of Ibn Abbas. Fourth: From some Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding his prayer, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, over the poor woman in her grave, and her Hadith is mentioned following the Hadith of Yazid bin Thabit referred to previously. Fifth: From Abu Umamah (1) may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "The Sunnah in the prayer over the funeral is to recite in the first Takbir the Mother of the Qur'an (Al-Fatihah) silently, then say three Takbirs, and the Taslim is at the last one." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/281) and from him Ibn Hazm (5/129) with an authentic chain as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath", and An-Nawawi preceded him in "Al-Majmu'" (5/33) and added: "on the condition of the Two Sheikhs." At-Tahawi (1/288) extracted it similarly and added at the end of the Hadith:
foot_note: 1. (1) He is not Abu Umamah Al-Bahili, the famous Companion, but this is another one known by his Kunya as well, and his name is As'ad, and it is said Sa'd bin Sa'd bin Hunaif Al-Ansari, counted among the Companions. He saw the Prophet but did not hear from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so the Hadith is from the Mursal narrations of Companions, which are proof.

text: Al-Zuhri said: So I mentioned what Abu Umamah told me of that to Muhammad bin Suwaid Al-Fihri, and he said: And I heard Ad-Dahhak bin Qais narrating from Habib bin Maslamah (1) regarding the prayer over the funeral similar to what Abu Umamah told you." Its chain is also authentic, and it is with Al-Nasa'i, but he did not go beyond Ad-Dahhak bin Qais with it. Likewise, Al-Shafi'i narrated it with an addition in its text as will come in Issue (79) p. (121, 122). Sixth: From Abdullah bin Abi Awfa who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say four Takbirs." Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi (4/35) with an authentic chain during a Hadith that will come in full in the Issue. B - As for the five, due to the Hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Layla who said: "Zaid bin Arqam used to say four Takbirs over our funerals, and he said five Takbirs over a funeral, so I asked him and he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say them, (so I will not leave them (for anyone after him) ever)." Extracted by Muslim (3/56), Abu Dawood (2/67, 68), Al-Nasa'i (1/281), At-Tirmidhi (2/140), Ibn Majah (1/458), At-Tahawi (1/285), Al-Bayhaqi (4/36), At-Tayalisi (674), and Ahmad (4/367, 368, 372) from him. Then At-Tahawi, Al-Daraqutni (191, 192), and Ahmad (4: 370) extracted it via other paths from him similarly, and the addition is theirs and the one in parentheses is for Al-Daraqutni. At-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih Hadith. Some people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and others went to this; they saw saying five Takbirs over the funeral. Ahmad and Ishaq said: If the Imam says five Takbirs over the funeral, he follows the Imam." C - As for the six and seven, there are some suspended (Mawquf) reports (Athar) regarding them, but they have the ruling of elevated (Marfu') Hadiths, because some senior Companions performed them in the presence of Companions without any of them objecting.
foot_note: 1. (1) He is Habib bin Maslamah bin Malik Al-Fihri Al-Makki. He used to be called Habib of the Romans because of his frequent entry upon them as a fighter. His companionship is disputed. Al-Hafiz said: "The correct view is its establishment, but he was young."

text: First: From Abdullah bin Ma'qil: "That Ali bin Abi Talib prayed over Sahl bin Hunaif, and he said six Takbirs over him. Then he turned to us and said: He was a Badri (veteran of Badr)." Al-Sha'bi said: "Alqamah came from the Levant (Sham) and said to Ibn Mas'ud: Your brothers in the Levant say five Takbirs over their funerals. If only you would set a limit for us that we can follow. (1) So Abdullah lowered his head for a while then said: Look at your funerals and say Takbir over them whatever your Imams say; there is no specific time nor number." Extracted by Ibn Hazm in "Al-Muhalla" (5, 126) in this entirety, and he said: "And this chain is utmost in authenticity." I say: Abu Dawood extracted the story of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, from it in his questions (Masail) from Imam Ahmad (p. 152), At-Tahawi (1/287), Al-Hakim (3/409), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/36). Their chain is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. It is in Al-Bukhari in "Al-Maghazi" (7/253) without his saying "six...". The story of Ibn Mas'ud was extracted by At-Tahawi and Al-Bayhaqi (4/37) similarly. Second: From Abd Khair who said: "Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, used to say six Takbirs over the people of Badr, five over the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and four over the rest of the people." Extracted by At-Tahawi and Al-Daraqutni (191) and via his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/37). Its chain is authentic; its men are all trustworthy. Third: From Musa bin Abdullah bin Yazid: "That Ali prayed over Abu Qatadah and said seven Takbirs over him, and he was a Badri."
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning you define for us a specific number, as derived from "An-Nihayah". Based on this, his saying at the end of the report "nor number" is an explanation and clarification of his saying "no time/limit".

text: Extracted by At-Tahawi and Al-Bayhaqi (4/36) with an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim - but Al-Bayhaqi faulted it by saying: "It is a mistake, because Abu Qatadah, may Allah be pleased with him, remained for a long time after Ali, may Allah be pleased with him." Al-Hafiz rejected this in "At-Talkhis" (1665) saying: "I say: This is a non-impugning fault, because it has been said: Abu Qatadah died during the Caliphate of Ali, and this is the preferred view. Ibn at-Turkumani preceded him to this in 'Al-Jawhar Al-Naqi', so refer to it (1). D - As for the nine, there are two Hadiths regarding it: First: From Abdullah bin Az-Zubair: "That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over Hamzah and said nine Takbirs over him..." (2). It passed in full with its extraction in (Second) of Issue (59) (p. 82). Second: From Abdullah bin Abbas who said: "When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stood over Hamzah... he ordered regarding him so he was prepared towards the Qiblah, then he said nine Takbirs over him..." and it also passed in Issue (69) Hadith Two, (p. 104).
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: So these are authentic reports from the Companions indicating that the practice of five and six Takbirs continued after the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, contrary to those who claimed consensus on four only. Ibn Hazm verified the invalidity of this claim in "Al-Muhalla" (5/124 - 125). 
2. This number is the maximum we have come across in Takbir over the funeral, so one stops at it and does not exceed it. He may decrease from it down to four, which is the minimum reported. Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Zad al-Ma'ad" after mentioning some of the reports and news we cited: "These are authentic reports, so there is no reason to prevent them, and the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did not forbid what exceeds four, rather he did it, and his Companions after him." I say: Those who prevent increasing over four argued with two things:

text: 75 - It is prescribed for him to raise his hands in the first Takbir, and there are two Hadiths regarding it: First: From Abu Hurairah: "That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said Takbir over a funeral, so he raised his hands in the first Takbir, and placed the right hand over the left."
foot_note: 1. = First: Consensus, and the error of that has been explained. Second: What came in some Hadiths "The last of what the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said Takbir over the funeral was four." The answer: It is a weak Hadith; it has paths, some weaker than others, so it is not suitable to hold onto it to reject what is established from him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, by authentic, widespread chains. Al-Hafiz said in "At-Talkhis" (5/167) and before him Al-Hazimi in "Al-I'tibar" (p. 95) and Al-Bayhaqi in "As-Sunan" (74/3): "It was narrated from more than one aspect, all of them weak." As for what appeared in "Al-Majmu'" (3/35): "And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over the slain of Uhud and said nine Takbirs nine times, then seven seven, then four four until he joined Allah. Narrated by At-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and Al-Awsat and its chain is Hasan." It is rejected from two aspects: First: It contradicts the saying of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar and the Imams before him who explicitly stated that all paths of the Hadith are weak. Second: The Hadith was extracted by At-Tabari in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (3/120/2) and its chain is thus: Narrated to us Ahmad bin Al-Qasim At-Ta'i, Bishr bin Al-Walid Al-Kindi, Narrated to us Abu Yusuf the Judge, Narrated to me Nafi' bin Umar, he said I heard Ata' bin Abi Rabah narrating from Ibn Abbas with it. I say: A chain like this is not good, for it contains three defects: First: Abu Yusuf the Judge, who is Yaqub bin Ibrahim; Ibn Al-Mubarak and others weakened him, and Al-Fallas described him as having many mistakes. Second: The weakness of Bishr bin Al-Walid Al-Kindi, for he had become senile. Third: The contradiction in its chain, for At-Tabarani (3/119/1) and Al-Hazimi in "Al-I'tibar" (95) extracted it from a group who said from Nafi' Abu Hormuz from Ata' from Ibn Abbas with it until he said: "People of Badr" instead of "Slain of Uhud". This is how Al-Haythami cited it and said: "It contains Nafi' Abu Hormuz and he is weak." I say: Rather he is very weak; Ibn Ma'in called him a liar, and Abu Hatim said: "Abandoned (Matruk), his Hadith is gone." I say, so he is the bane of the Hadith, and he is the one who narrated it from Ata'. What occurred in the first path that it is Nafi' bin Umar - who is trustworthy - is an illusion from some of its narrators, and the likely one is Al-Kindi who had become senile as you knew.

text: Extracted by At-Tirmidhi (2/165), Al-Daraqutni (192), Al-Bayhaqi (284), and Abu Ash-Sheikh in "Tabaqat Al-Asbahaniyyin" (p. 262) with a weak chain, but it is witnessed by the following Hadith, which is: Second: From Abdullah bin Abbas "That the Messenger of Allah used to raise his hands over the funeral in the first Takbir, then he would not repeat." Extracted by Al-Daraqutni with a chain whose men are trustworthy except Al-Fadl bin As-Sakan, for he is unknown. Ibn at-Turkumani remained silent about him in "Al-Jawhar Al-Naqi" (4/44)! Then At-Tirmidhi said after the first Hadith: This is a strange Hadith. People of knowledge differed on this. Most people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and others held that a man raises his hands in every Takbir. It is the saying of Ibn Al-Mubarak, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq. Some people of knowledge said: He does not raise his hands except in the first time. It is the saying of At-Thawri and the people of Kufa. It was mentioned from Ibn Al-Mubarak that he said regarding the prayer over the funeral: He does not clasp his right over his left. Some people of knowledge held that he clasps his left as he does in prayer." In "Al-Majmu'" by An-Nawawi (5/232): "Ibn al-Mundhir said in his book 'Al-Ishraf wa Al-Ijma'': They agreed that he raises in the first Takbir, and differed regarding the rest" (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: We did not find in the Sunnah what indicates the legitimacy of raising in other than the first Takbir, so we do not see the legitimacy of that. It is the Madhhab of the Hanafis and others, and Al-Shawkani and other verifiers chose it. Ibn Hazm went to this saying (5/128): "As for raising the hands, it has not come from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that he raised in any of the funeral Takbirs except in the first Takbir only. So it is not permissible to do that, because it is an action in prayer for which no text has come. It only came from him, peace be upon him, that he said Takbir and raised his hands in every lowering and raising, and there is no lowering and raising in it. The wonder is from Abu Hanifa's saying to raise hands in every Takbir in the funeral prayer, while it never came from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and his prevention of raising hands in every lowering and raising in other prayers, while it is authentic from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace." I say: What he attributed to Abu Hanifa is narrated in the books of commentators from the Hanafis, so do not be changed by what appeared in the footnote on "Nasb ar-Rayah" (2/285) of wonder at this... attribution. It is the choice of many Imams of Balkh among them as in "Al-Mabsut" by As-Sarakhsi (2/64), but the practice among Hanafis is contrary to that, which is what As-Sarakhsi asserted. However, they see =

text: 76 - Then he places his right hand on the back of his left palm, the wrist, and the forearm, then he tightens them on his chest. There are Hadiths regarding that; I must mention some of them: First: From Abu Hurairah in Marfu' form in his previously mentioned Hadith just now: "...and placed the right over the left." Although its chain is weak, its meaning is correct by the witness of the following Hadiths, for by their generality they include the funeral prayer just as they include all other than the prescribed prayers like Istisqa' (Rain prayer), Kusuf (Eclipse prayer), and others. Second: From Sahl bin Sa'd who said: "The people were commanded that a man place the right hand on his left forearm in prayer." Extracted by Malik in "Al-Muwatta" (1/174) and from his path Al-Bukhari (2/178) - and the context is his - and likewise Imam Muhammad in "Al-Muwatta" (156), Ahmad (5/336), and Al-Bayhaqi (2/28). Third: From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Prophet of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: "We, the assembly of Prophets, were commanded to hasten our breaking of the fast, delay our Suhur, and to place our right hands over our left hands in prayer." Extracted by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (885 - Mawarid), At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and in "Al-Awsat" (1/10 - 1), and from their path Al-Diya' Al-Maqdisi in "Al-Mukhtarah" (63/10/2). (1/174). It has another path from Ibn Abbas.
foot_note: 1. = raising hands in the extra Takbirs in the Eid prayers even though it has no basis either from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace! See "Al-Muhalla" (5/83). Yes, Al-Bayhaqi (4/44) narrated with an authentic chain from Ibn Umar that he used to raise his hands on every Takbir of the funeral Takbirs. So whoever thinks that he does not do that except by instruction (Tawqif) from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, implies he may raise. As-Sarakhsi mentioned regarding Ibn Umar the contrary of this, and that is something for which we know no basis in the books of Hadith.

text: Extracted by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and Al-Diya' Al-Maqdisi with an authentic chain. It has witnesses I mentioned in the extraction of our book "Sifat Salat al-Nabi (Description of the Prophet's Prayer), may Allah bless him and grant him peace." Fourth: From Tawus who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to place the right hand on his left hand, then tighten them on his chest while he was in prayer." Extracted by Abu Dawood (1/121) with a good chain from him. Although it is Mursal, it is a proof according to everyone. As for those who use Mursal as proof absolutely, it is apparent - and they are the majority of scholars. As for those who do not use it as proof unless it is narrated as connected (Mawsul) or has witnesses, then this has two witnesses: First: From Wa'il bin Hujr: "That he saw the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, place his right over his left then place them on his chest." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his Sahih as in "Nasb ar-Rayah" (1/314), and Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in his Sunan (2/30) via two paths from him, one strengthening the other. Second: From Qabisah bin Hulb from his father who said: I saw the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, leave from his right and his left, and I saw him - he said - place this on his chest, and Yahya (who is Ibn Sa'id) described the right over the left above the joint." Extracted by Ahmad (5/226) with a chain whose men are the trustworthy men of Muslim except Qabisah. Al-Ajli and Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy, but no one narrated from him except Simak bin Harb. Ibn al-Madini and Al-Nasa'i said "Unknown", and in "At-Taqrib" it says he is "Acceptable (Maqbul)". I say: So the likes of him, his Hadith is Hasan in witnesses. That is why At-Tirmidhi said after extracting the Hadith of taking the left with the right from this: "Hasan Hadith." So these are three Hadiths stating that the Sunnah is placing on the chest. No one who comes across their collection doubts that they are suitable for inferring that.
foot_note: None

text: As for placing below the navel, it is weak by agreement as An-Nawawi, Az-Zayla'i and others said, and I have clarified that in the Extraction referred to previously. 77 - Then he recites Fatihat al-Kitab (The Opening of the Book) and a Surah (1) after the first Takbir, due to the Hadith of Talha bin Abdullah bin Awf who said: I prayed behind Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, over a funeral, so he recited Fatihat al-Kitab (and a Surah, and he recited aloud until he made us hear. When he finished, I took his hand and asked him? So he) said: (I only recited aloud) so that you would know that it is Sunnah (and Truth)." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/158), Abu Dawood (2, 68), Al-Nasa'i (1/281), At-Tirmidhi (2/142), Ibn Al-Jarud in "Al-Muntaqa" (264), Al-Daraqutni (191), and Al-Hakim (1/358 - 386). The context is Al-Bukhari's. The first addition is Al-Nasa'i's, and its chain is authentic. Ibn Al-Jarud has the mention of the Surah from it. Both have the third with the authentic chain. Al-Hakim has the second from another path from Ibn Abbas with a Hasan chain. In the chapter, there are narrations from a group of Companions; the Hadith of one of them comes in the issue following this. Then At-Tirmidhi said after the Hadith: "This is a Hasan Sahih Hadith. The practice is upon this according to some people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and others; they choose that one recites Fatihat al-Kitab after the first Takbir. It is the saying of Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq. Some people of knowledge said: One does not recite in the prayer over the funeral; rather...
foot_note: 1. (1) In it is an indication of the lack of legislation of the Opening Supplication (Du'a al-Istiftah), and it is the Madhhab of the Shafi'is and others. Abu Dawood said in "Al-Masail" (153): "I heard Ahmad being asked about the man doing Istiftah over the funeral: Subhanaka... ! He said: I have not heard [of it]."

text: it is praise of Allah, prayer (blessings) upon His Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and supplication for the deceased. It is the saying of At-Thawri and others from the people of Kufa." (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: This Hadith and what is in its meaning is a proof against them. It should not be said: It does not explicitly attribute that to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, because we say: The saying of a Companion "From the Sunnah is such-and-such" is connected (Musnad) elevated (Marfu') to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, according to the correct opinions even according to the Hanafis. Rather, An-Nawawi said in "Al-Majmu'" (5/232): "It is the correct Madhhab stated by the majority of scholars from our companions in Usul and others from the Usulis and Muhaddithin." I say: The verifier Ibn Al-Humam asserted this in "At-Tahrir", and his commentator Ibn Amir Hajj said (2/224): "This is the saying of our early companions, and the author of Al-Mizan, the Shafi'is, and the majority of Muhaddithin took it." I say: Based on this, it is among the wonders that the Hanafis do not take this Hadith despite its authenticity and its coming from more than one aspect, and despite its suitability to prove the Sunnah according to their method and principles! Imam Muhammad said in "Al-Muwatta" (p. 175): "There is no recitation over the funeral, and it is the saying of Abu Hanifa." Similar is in "Al-Mabsut" by As-Sarakhsi (2/64). When some of the later ones among them saw the distance of this saying from correctness, and its shunning of the Hadith, they said it is permissible to recite Al-Fatihah on the condition that he intends by it Supplication and Praise of Allah! They conditioned that only to reconcile - in their claim - between the Hadith and the saying of their Imam, as if his saying is another authentic Hadith that should be paired with the authentic Hadith and then reconciled! Even though this condition is invalid in itself due to lack of narration, the establishment of reciting a Surah with Al-Fatihah in the Hadith invalidates it, and it is absolute so that condition cannot be stipulated in it either! They have another wonder! Which is their saying "that reciting Subhanaka - after the first Takbir is from the Sunan of prayer over the funeral"! Even though there is no basis for that in the Sunnah as previously noted in the footnote (p. 119). So they combined affirming what has no basis in the Sunnah and denying the legitimacy of what was reported in it!! If you say: The verifier Ibn Al-Humam said in "Fath al-Qadir" (1/459): "They said: He does not recite Al-Fatihah, unless he recites it with the intention of Praise, and recitation has not been established from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace." I say: This statement from such a verifier is more amazing than all that preceded, for the establishment of recitation from him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, is something not hidden from the likes of him with its occurrence in "Sahih Al-Bukhari" and others as previously clarified. Therefore, it is overwhelmingly likely that he indicates by that that the Hadith does not stand as evidence to prove recitation because of his saying in it "Sunnah" based on the difference we previously mentioned. If the matter is as such, then this is another wonder, for his Madhhab is that the Companion's saying "Sunnah" has the ruling of Musnad Marfu' to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, as previously quoted from his book "At-Tahrir". They have proceeded upon that in their branches (Furu'), so take for example the following issue. He said in "Al-Hidayah": "If they carry the deceased on the bier, they take its four corners; the Sunnah was reported regarding that. Al-Shafi'i said: The Sunnah is that... So Ibn Al-Humam said in the context of refuting what they attributed to Al-Shafi'i: =

text: Then the first addition in the Hadith was narrated by Abu Ya'la also in his "Musnad" as in "Al-Majmu'" by An-Nawawi (5/234) and he said: "Its chain is authentic." Al-Hafiz confirmed it in "At-Talkhis" (5/165). An-Nawawi used this addition as evidence for the recommendation of a short Surah. There is nothing in the Hadith indicating that it should be short, so perhaps the evidence for that is what passed regarding the request to hasten the funeral to its grave, and Allah knows best. 78 - And he reads silently, due to the Hadith of Abu Umamah bin Sahl who said: "The Sunnah in the prayer over the funeral is to recite in the first Takbir the Mother of the Qur'an (Al-Fatihah) silently, then say three Takbirs, and the Taslim is at the last one." Extracted by Al-Nasa'i and others with an authentic chain as passed in Issue (74) Hadith Five from Paragraph (A), (111). 79 - Then he says the Takbir (Second Takbir), and prays for (sends blessings upon) the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, due to the mentioned Hadith of Abu Umamah that a man from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, informed him: "That the Sunnah in the prayer over the funeral is that the Imam says Takbir, then recites Fatihat al-Kitab after the first Takbir silently to himself, then prays for the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and sincerely makes supplication for the funeral in the (three) Takbirs, not reciting in any of them, then he says Taslim silently to himself (when he leaves (to his right), and the Sunnah is that those behind him do like what their Imam did)."
foot_note: 1. = "It has been authenticated from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, contrary to what they went to." Then he cited from the path of Abu Ubaidah from his father Abdullah bin Mas'ud who said: "Whoever follows the funeral, let him take all sides of the bier, for it is from the Sunnah." Narrated by Ibn Majah (1/451) and Al-Bayhaqi (194 - 20). Ibn Humam said: "So it becomes obligatory to rule that this is the Sunnah, and if its contrary is realized from some of the Salaf, it is for an incidental reason." Look how he made Ibn Mas'ud's saying "from the Sunnah" into the ruling of Marfu', and did not make Ibn Abbas's saying likewise! Is the source of this contradiction oversight or fanaticism for the Madhhab, may Allah save us from it?! This is assuming the authenticity of that from Ibn Mas'ud, so how about when it is not authentic, because it is broken (Munqati'); Abu Ubaidah did not reach his father as in "Al-Jawhar Al-Naqi" by At-Turkumani Al-Hanafi. That is why I turned away from citing this alleged Sunnah in this book of ours, just as we turned away from its opposite attributed to Al-Shafi'i due to lack of its report.

text: Extracted by Al-Shafi'i in "Al-Umm" (1/239 - 240) and from his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/39) and Ibn Al-Jarud (265) from Al-Zuhri from Abu Umamah. Al-Zuhri said at its end: "Muhammad Al-Fihri narrated to me from Ad-Dahhak bin Qais that he said similar to the saying of Abu Umamah." Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, do not say 'the Sunnah and the Truth' except for the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, if Allah Almighty wills." Al-Hakim extracted it (1/360) and from him Al-Bayhaqi, except that he said: "Men from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, informed me." The rest is similar, and it contains the two additions. He added in its second chain "Habib bin Maslamah" as passed in the narration of At-Tahawi in the issue referred to previously (74). Then Al-Hakim added: "Al-Zuhri said: Abu Umamah narrated that to me while Ibn Al-Musayyib was listening, and he did not deny that upon him." He said: "Authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs," and Al-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said. The apparent meaning of his saying after mentioning the recitation "then he prays for the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace" is that it is only after the second Takbir, not before it, because if it were before it, it would not occur in the Takbirs but before them, as is clear. The Hanafis, Shafi'is and others said this, contrary to Ibn Hazm (D / 129) and Al-Shawkani (3/53). As for the formula of prayer upon the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in the funeral, I have not come across it in any of the authentic Hadiths (1). So it appears that the funeral does not have a special formula, but rather one uses a formula from the established formulas in the Tashahhud in the prescribed prayer (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) A formula close to the Abrahamic prayer was narrated from Ibn Mas'ud, but its chain is very weak, so one does not occupy oneself with it. Al-Sakhawi cited it in "Al-Qawl Al-Badi'" p. (153 - 154) and Ibn al-Qayyim in "Jala' al-Afham", and he said (255): "So it is recommended to pray upon him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in the funeral as one prays upon him in the Tashahhud because the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, taught that to his Companions when they asked him about the manner of praying upon him." 
2. These are seven formulas I presented in "Sifat Salat al-Nabi (Description of the Prophet's Prayer), may Allah bless him and grant him peace." The Islamic Office has printed it, the third edition, and it contains important additions. Then the fourth edition was printed.

text: 80 - Then he performs the remaining Takbirs, and sincerely supplicates in them for the deceased, due to the Hadith of Abu Umamah mentioned previously just now, and his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "When you pray over the dead, then make supplication sincere for him" (1). Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/68), Ibn Majah (1/456), Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and (754 - Mawarid), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/40) from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah. Ibn Ishaq explicitly stated narration (Tahdith) in Ibn Hibban. 81 - And he supplicates in it with what is established from him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, over a funeral. I have memorized from his supplication while he was saying: "O Allah, forgive him and have mercy on him, give him well-being and pardon him, honor his reception and expand his entrance, wash him with water, snow and hail, and cleanse him from sins as You cleansed (and in a narration: as the white garment is cleansed of dirt), and replace for him a home better than his home, and a family better than his family, and a spouse (and in a narration: a wife) better than his spouse, and admit him into Paradise, and protect him from the torment of the grave and from the torment of the Fire. He said: So I wished that I were that dead person." Extracted by Muslim (3/59 - 60), Al-Nasa'i (1/271), Ibn Majah (1/4256), Ibn Al-Jarud (264 - 265), Al-Bayhaqi (4/40), At-Tayalisi (999), and Ahmad (6/23 and 28). The context is Muslim's. The second narration is his in a report, and it is for the rest of them except Ahmad. He and Al-Bayhaqi have the third narration.
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Sindi said: Meaning single him out with supplication. Al-Munawi said: "Meaning supplicate for him with sincerity and presence of heart, because the purpose of this prayer is seeking forgiveness and intercession for the deceased, and its acceptance is only hoped for when sincerity and supplication are present. That is why supplication was legislated in the prayer over him that is not legislated like it in the supplication for the living. Ibn al-Qayyim said: This invalidates the saying of those who claim that the dead does not benefit from supplication." I say: In the narration of Al-Hakim from the Hadith of Abu Umamah mentioned previously "and he sincerely prays in the three Takbirs", the word prayer (Salat) here means supplication (Dua) evidenced by the first narration "and make supplication sincere" because the original meaning of Salat in language is Dua. So from the strange interpretations is what is in "Al-Qawl Al-Badi'" (p. 152) "and he makes prayer sincere, meaning he raises his voice in his prayer with the three Takbirs"!

text: In the narration of Ibn Majah and At-Tayalisi, the deceased was a man from the Ansar, but its chain contains Faraj bin Fadalah who is weak, from Ismah bin Rashid who is unknown. The Hadith was extracted by At-Tirmidhi (2/141) in summary and he said: "Hasan Sahih Hadith. Muhammad bin Ismail - meaning Al-Bukhari - said: The most authentic thing in this chapter is this Hadith." Second: From Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, "used to, if he prayed over a funeral, say: O Allah, forgive our living and our dead, our present and our absent, our young and our old, our male and our female. O Allah, whomever You keep alive among us, keep him alive on Islam, and whomever You cause to die among us, cause him to die on Faith. O Allah, do not deprive us of his reward, and do not send us astray after him." Extracted by Ibn Majah (1/456) and Al-Bayhaqi (4/41) via the path of Muhammad bin Ibrahim At-Taymi from Abu Salamah from him; and Abu Dawood (2/68), At-Tirmidhi (2/141), Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (757 - Mawarid), Al-Hakim (1/358), Al-Bayhaqi as well, and Ahmad (2/368) via the path of Yahya bin Abi Kathir from Abu Salamah with it similarly, without his saying "O Allah, do not deprive us..." for it is with Abu Dawood alone. Yahya explicitly stated narration (Tahdith) in Al-Hakim, then he said: "Authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs." Al-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said, and it was faulted with what is not impugning. Yahya has two other chains in it, with Ahmad (4/170, 308) and Al-Bayhaqi. The Hadith has a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas similarly. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". Third: From Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over a man from the Muslims, so I heard him say:
foot_note: None

text: O Allah, indeed so-and-so son of so-and-so is in Your protection and the rope of Your neighborliness, so save him from the trial of the grave and the punishment of the Fire. You are the People of Loyalty and Truth, so forgive him and have mercy on him, indeed You are the Forgiving, the Merciful." Extracted by Abu Dawood (2/68), Ibn Majah (1/456), Ibn Hibban in his Sahih (758), and Ahmad (3/471) with an authentic chain if Allah Almighty wills. Ibn al-Qayyim cited it among what was preserved of his supplication, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and An-Nawawi remained silent about it in "Al-Majmu'". Fourth: From Yazid bin Rukanah bin Al-Muttalib who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to, if he stood for the funeral to pray over it, say: 'O Allah, Your servant and the son of Your maidservant needed Your mercy, and You are free of punishing him. If he was a doer of good, then increase his good deeds, and if he was a wrongdoer, then overlook him.' (Then he supplicates whatever Allah wills him to supplicate)." Extracted by Al-Hakim (1/359) and he said: "Its chain is authentic, and Yazid bin Rukanah and Abu Rukanah are both Companions." Al-Dhahabi agreed. At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Kabir" with the addition as in "Al-Majma'" (4/33 / 34) and Ibn Qani' as in "Al-Isabah". It has a witness from the path of Sa'id Al-Maqburi that he asked Abu Hurairah: How do you pray over the funeral? He said: By Allah, I will inform you. I follow it from its family, then when it is placed, I say Takbir and praise Allah, and pray upon His Prophet. Then I say: O Allah, indeed he is Your servant, son of Your servant, and son of Your maidservant. He used to testify that there is no god but You and that Muhammad is Your servant and Messenger, and You know him best. O Allah, if he was a doer of good, increase his good deeds, and if he was a wrongdoer, overlook his bad deeds. O Allah, do not deprive us of his reward, and do not test us after him." Extracted by Malik (1 - 227) and from him Muhammad bin Al-Hasan (164 - 165) and Ismail the Judge in "Fadl as-Salat ala an-Nabi, may Allah bless him and grant him peace" No. 5 (93) 27. Its chain is suspended (Mawquf) very authentic. Al-Haythami cited the supplication from it as elevated (Marfu') from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah and said:
foot_note: 1. (1) It was released recently with our verification, printed by The Islamic Office.

text: Narrated by Abu Ya'la and its men are the men of the Sahih." It was presented previously with another wording containing the last sentence of it, which is Type (Second) (p. 124). 82 - Supplication between the last Takbir and the Taslim is prescribed, due to the Hadith of Abu Ya'fur from Abdullah bin Abi Awfa, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "I witnessed him saying four Takbirs over a funeral, then he stood for a while - meaning - supplicating. Then he said: 'Did you think I was going to say five Takbirs?' They said: 'No.' He said: 'Indeed, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say four Takbirs.'" Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi (4 - 35) with an authentic chain. Then he (4/42, 43), Ibn Majah (1/457), Al-Hakim (1/360), and Ahmad (4 - 383) extracted it via the path of Ibrahim Al-Hajari from Ibn Abi Awfa with it, except that he elevated it to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, (and added after his saying: Indeed, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say four Takbirs: Then he would remain for a while saying whatever Allah willed him to say, then he said Taslim)." Al-Hakim said: "This is an authentic Hadith, and Ibrahim was not criticized with proof." I say: Yes he was, and that is why Al-Dhahabi critiqued him saying: I say they weakened Ibrahim." I say: That is due to his poor memory. Al-Hafiz indicated that by saying in "At-Taqrib": "Soft in Hadith (Layyin), he elevates suspended reports" (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Benefits: First: Al-Hafiz said in "At-Talkhis" (1825): "Some scholars said the difference in Hadiths regarding supplication over the funeral is interpreted to mean that he used to supplicate over a deceased person with one supplication, and over another with a different one. What he commanded was the principle of supplication." Second: Al-Shawkani said in "Nayl al-Awtar" (55 4): "If the one prayed over is a child, it is recommended that the one praying says: O Allah, make him a predecessor, a stored treasure, and a reward for us. Al-Bayhaqi narrated that from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, and Sufyan narrated similar to it in 'Al-Jami'ah' from Al-Hasan." =

text: 83 - Then he says Taslim twice like his Taslim in the prescribed prayer, one to his right and the other to his left, due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "Three habits the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to do which people abandoned: One of them is saying Taslim over the funeral like the Taslim in prayer." Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi (4/43) with a Hasan chain, and An-Nawawi said (5/239): "A good chain." In "Majma' az-Zawa'id" (3/34): "Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' and its men are trustworthy." It has been established in "Sahih Muslim" and others from Ibn Mas'ud that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say Taslim twice in prayer. This clarifies that what is intended by his saying in the first Hadith: "like the Taslim in prayer" means the two known Taslims.
foot_note: 1. = I say: The Hadith of Abu Hurairah with Al-Bayhaqi has a Hasan chain, and there is no harm in acting upon it in such a place, even if it is suspended, provided it is not taken as a Sunnah in a way that leads to thinking it is from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. What I choose is to supplicate in the prayer over the child with Type (Second) because of his saying in it: "and our young... O Allah, do not deprive us of his reward, and do not send us astray after him." Imam Ahmad went to the recommendation of supplication in this place, as narrated by Abu Dawood in "Al-Masail" (153) from him, and it is the Madhhab of the Shafi'is. An-Nawawi argued for them in "Al-Majmu'" (5/239) with the Hadith of Al-Hajari mentioned above, and arguing with what is before it is stronger. It is a proof against the Hanafis where they said: "Then he says the fourth Takbir and says Taslim without any remembrance between them." Third: The Shafi'is also went to the obligation of absolute supplication for the deceased due to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah previously mentioned: "...then make supplication sincere for him." This is true, but they restricted it to the third Takbir, and An-Nawawi admitted that it is a mere claim, so he said (5/236): "The place of this supplication is the third Takbir, and it is obligatory in it, and does not suffice in other than it without disagreement (among them), but there is no clear evidence for restricting it to it. They agreed that no specific supplication is appointed for it." I say: However, preferring what preceded of his supplications, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, over what some people deemed good is something a Muslim should not hesitate about, for the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. That is why Al-Shawkani said (4/55): "Know that mentions of supplications not narrated from him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, have occurred in books of Fiqh, but holding onto what is established from him is better." I say: Rather I believe it is obligatory upon one who has knowledge of what was reported from him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Turning away from it then leads to fear that the saying of Allah Almighty applies to him: (Do you exchange that which is better for that which is lower)?

text: It is probable that he means in addition to that that he used to say one Taslim also, considering that this was also from his Sunnah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in prayer as well. Meaning that he, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, sometimes said Taslim twice and sometimes one Taslim, but the first is more frequent. However, this probability is far-fetched because the single Taslim, although established from him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was not narrated by Ibn Mas'ud, so it does not appear that it enters into his mentioned saying "like the Taslim in prayer". And Allah knows best. The Hadith has a witness narrated by Sharik from Ibrahim Al-Hajari who said: "Abdullah bin Abi Awfa led us in prayer over the funeral of his daughter. He remained for a while until we thought he would say Takbir five times, then he said Taslim to his right and his left. When he finished, we said to him: What is this? He said: I do not increase for you over what I saw the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, doing, or: this is how the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did. Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi (4/43) and its chain is weak because of Al-Hajari as passed in the previous issue. Some of it was authenticated from him via another path as elevated (Marfu'), and some as suspended (Mawquf), as we mentioned there. Ahmad narrated in "Masail Abi Dawood from him" (153) from Ata' bin As-Sa'ib who said: "I saw Ibn Abi Awfa pray over a funeral and he said Taslim once (one Taslim)." But its chain is weak; it contains Abu Waki' Al-Jarrah bin Malih, who is weak and some accused him. The Hanafis went to the two Taslims as in "Al-Mabsut" (2/65), Ahmad in a narration from him as in "Al-Insaf" (2/525) (1), and the Shafi'is as in "Sharh Ibn Qasim Al-Ghazzi" (1/431 - Bajuri) who said: "But it is recommended to add 'Wa Rahmatullah Wa Barakatuh'." 85 - It is permissible to restrict oneself to the first Taslim only, due to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him: "That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed over a funeral, said four Takbirs over it, and said Taslim once." Extracted by Al-Daraqutni (191) and Al-Hakim (1/360) and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/43) via the path of Abu Al-Anbas from his father from him.
foot_note: 1. Among the exaggerations is the saying of Ibn Al-Mubarak: "Whoever says Taslim over the funeral with two Taslims is ignorant, ignorant. Narrated by Abu Dawood in "Al-Masail" (154) with an authentic chain from him.

text: I say: And its chain is Hasan as I clarified in "At-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad". It is witnessed by the Mursal of Ata' bin As-Sa'ib that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said Taslim over the funeral once. Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi in suspended form. It is strengthened by the practice of a group of Companions upon it. Al-Hakim said after it: "The narration regarding it is authentic from Ali bin Abi Talib, Abdullah bin Umar, Abdullah bin Abbas, Jabir bin Abdullah, Abdullah bin Abi Awfa, and Abu Hurairah that they used to say Taslim over the funeral once." I say: Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Al-Bayhaqi provided chains for most of these reports, and added to them "Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', Abu Umamah, and others". There is some reservation in my view regarding applying "Authentic" (Sahih) to the narration of Ibn Abi Awfa, because its chain contains Al-Jarrah bin Malih who is weak as passed shortly, unless Al-Hakim had it from another path, which I do not think. Imam Ahmad went to these reports in the famous view from him. Abu Dawood said (153): "I heard Ahmad being asked about Taslim over the funeral? He said: Like this, and he turned his neck to his right (and said: As-Salamu Alaikum Wa Rahmatullah)." I say: The addition of "Wa Barakatuh" in this Taslim is prescribed, contrary to some of them, due to its establishment in some paths of the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud previously mentioned regarding the two Taslims in the obligatory prayer, and likewise in this issue of funeral prayer as preceded. Ibn Qasim Al-Ghazzi mentioned in his explanation its recommendation here in the two Taslims. Al-Bajuri rejected that on him in his footnote (1/431) and went to its lack of legitimacy here and in the obligatory prayer. The correct view is what we mentioned. 85 - (1) The Sunnah is to say Taslim in the funeral silently; the Imam and those behind him are equal in that, due to the Hadith of Abu Umamah passed in the Issue with the wording:
foot_note: 1. (1) The previous issue number 85 on p. 128 is actually Issue number 84.

text: "Then he says Taslim silently to himself when he leaves, and the Sunnah is that those behind him do like what their Imam did." It has a suspended (Mawquf) witness; Al-Bayhaqi extracted (4/43) from Ibn Abbas that he: "Used to say Taslim in the funeral as a concealed Taslim." Its chain is Hasan. Then he narrated from Abdullah bin Umar that he: "Used to, when he prayed over funerals, say Taslim so that he could make those next to him hear." Its chain is authentic. (1) 86 - It is not permissible to pray over the funeral in the three times during which prayer is forbidden unless for a necessity, due to the Hadith of Uqbah bin Amir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "Three hours the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to forbid us to pray in or to bury our dead in: When the sun rises distinctly until it rises high, when the pillar of noon stands until the sun declines, and when the sun tilts for setting until it sets." Extracted by Muslim (2/208), Abu Awana in his Sahih (1/368), Abu Dawood (2/66), Al-Nasa'i (1/283), At-Tirmidhi (2/144) - and he authenticated it - Ibn Majah (1/463), Al-Bayhaqi (4/32), At-Tayalisi (No. 1001), and Ahmad (5/152) via the path of Ali bin Rabah from him. Al-Bayhaqi added:
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: It seems that because of the difference in these two reports, the opinions of the Hanbalis differed on this issue. It came in "Al-Insaf" (5/523): "He said in 'Al-Furu'': The apparent meaning of the companions' speech is that the Imam says Taslim aloud, and the apparent meaning of Ibn Al-Jawzi's speech is that he says it silently." Then he cited from "Al-Madhhab" and "Masbuk Adh-Dhahab" what witnesses to Ibn Al-Jawzi's speech. It is the preponderant view due to the Hadith of Abu Umamah.

text: "He said: I said to Uqbah: Is burial done at night? He said: Yes, Abu Bakr was buried at night." Its chain is authentic. (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) The Hadith in its generality covers the prayer over the funeral, and this is what the Companions understood. Malik narrated in "Al-Muwatta" (1/228) and via his path Al-Bayhaqi from Muhammad bin Abi Harmalah that Zainab bint Abi Salamah died while Tariq was the Amir of Medina. Her funeral was brought after the Morning Prayer (Subh), and placed in Al-Baqi'. He said: Tariq used to pray Subh very early (in darkness). Ibn Abi Harmalah said: I heard Abdullah bin Umar say to the family: Either you pray over your funeral now, or you leave it until the sun rises high. Its chain is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. Then Malik narrated from Ibn Umar who said: Funeral prayer is prayed after Asr and after Subh if they were prayed at their times. Its chain is authentic too. Al-Bayhaqi narrated with a good chain from Ibn Juraij, Ziyad informed me that Ali informed him that a funeral was placed in the graveyard of the people of Basra when the sun turned yellow, so he did not pray over it until the sun set. So Abu Barzah commanded the caller to call for prayer then established it. Abu Barzah stepped forward and prayed Maghrib with them - and among the people was Anas bin Malik, and Abu Barzah is from the Ansar from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace - then they prayed over the funeral. Al-Khattabi said in "Al-Ma'alim" (4/327) summarized: People differed on the permissibility of praying over the funeral and burying in these three hours. Most people of knowledge went to the dislike of praying over it in these times. It is the saying of Ata', An-Nakha'i, Al-Awza'i, At-Thawri, the People of Opinion (Ahlu-Ra'y), Ahmad, and Ishaq. Al-Shafi'i sees prayer and burial at any hour of night or day. The saying of the majority is more appropriate due to its agreement with the Hadith." I say: From this you know that An-Nawawi's claim of consensus on the permissibility of this prayer is an illusion from him, may Allah have mercy on him.

text: (14) Burial and its Requisites 87 - It is obligatory to bury the dead even if he is a disbeliever. There are two Hadiths regarding this: First: From a group of Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, among them Abu Talha Al-Ansari - and the context is his: "That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ordered regarding twenty-four men from the leaders of Quraish on the Day of Badr, (so they were dragged by their legs) and thrown into a well (Tawa) (1) from the wells of Badr, filthy and malignant (some over others), (except for what happened with Umayyah bin Khalaf, for he swelled in his armor and filled it, so when they went to move him he disintegrated (2), so they left him and threw over him what covered him of earth and stones). He, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to, if he prevailed over a people, stay in the open area (Al-Arsah) (3) for three nights. When it was the third day at Badr, he ordered his mount, so its saddle was fastened. Then he walked and his Companions followed him, and they said: We do not see him setting out except for some need of his, until he stood at the edge of the well (Ar-Rakiyy) (4). He began calling them by their names and the names of their fathers (and they had become carcasses): (O Abu Jahl bin Hisham, O Utbah bin Rabi'ah, O Shaibah bin Rabi'ah, O Walid bin Utbah), would it have pleased you that you obeyed Allah and His Messenger? For indeed we found what our Lord promised us to be true, so have you found what your Lord promised to be true? He said: (Umar heard the saying of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so he said: O Messenger of Allah! You speak to bodies that have no spirits (souls), (and do they hear? text:
The detail: The truth is that what the group narrated is correct, and what Aisha narrated is also correct; each is trustworthy, and there is no contradiction between the two narrations. Second: From Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When Abu Talib died, I came to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and said: 'Your uncle, the old (misguided) man, has died, (who will bury him?).'
