text: "'A Kufan Tabi'i, trustworthy.' Al-Hafiz said in 'Al-Taqrib': 'Trustworthy.' As for Al-Nawawi's statement in 'Al-Majmu' (5/181): 'Narrated by Abu Dawud and others, and its chain is weak,' it is rejected. If this is the case, the answer is from two aspects: First: It is from the narration of Sufyan Al-Thawri from him, and he is among the most reliable people regarding him [Abu Ishaq], as in 'Al-Tahdhib'. text: 88 - A Muslim is not buried with a disbeliever, nor a disbeliever with a Muslim. Rather, the Muslim is buried in the Muslims' graveyards, and the disbeliever in the polytheists' graveyards. This was the command during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), and it has continued to our time. Among the evidences for this is the hadith of Bashir bin Al-Khasasiyyah who said: "While I was walking with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) (he was holding my hand), he said: 'O Ibn Al-Khasasiyyah, what (have you become) resentful of regarding Allah? (1) You have become one walking with the Messenger of Allah (he said: I think he said: holding his hand).' So I said: '(O Messenger of Allah, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you), I (have become) not resentful of Allah regarding anything; Allah has done every good for me.' Then he came upon the graves of the polytheists and said: 'These have preceded a great good (or in a narration: missed a great good)' three times. Then he came upon the graves of the Muslims and said: 'These have attained a great good,' three times. While he was walking, a glance from him occurred, and behold, there was a man walking between the graves wearing sandals. He said: 'O you with the Sibtiyyah sandals! Woe to you, throw off your Sibtiyyah sandals!' The man looked, and when he recognized the Messenger of Allah

Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/72), Al-Nasa'i (1/288), Ibn Majah (1/474), Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/170), and Al-Hakim (1/373) - the phrasing is his. From his path, it was narrated by Al-Bayhaqi (4/80), Al-Tayalisi (1123), and Ahmad (5/83, 83, 224). The additions are his, and the second one belongs to Al-Bayhaqi and is not in Al-Mustadrak. Al-Tahawi (1/293) narrated from it the story of the man with the Sibtiyyah sandals. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain." Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and Al-Hafiz confirmed it in "Al-Fath" (3/160). Ibn Majah narrated from Abdullah bin Uthman - who is Al-Basri - from Shu'bah that he said: A good (Jayyid) hadith. Ibn al-Qayyim quoted in "Tahdhib al-Sunan" (4/343) from Imam Ahmad that he said: Its chain is good. Al-Nawawi said in "Al-Majmu'" (5/312): "Its chain is Hasan (Good)." Ibn Hazm (5/142, 143) used it as evidence that a Muslim is not buried with a polytheist. In another place, he used it as evidence for the prohibition of walking with sandals between graves, as will be discussed in the commentary on Issue (126). 89 - The Sunnah is burial in the graveyard, because the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) used to bury the dead in the Baqi' graveyard, as the reports have become Mutawatir (mass transmitted) regarding that, and some have preceded in various contexts, the closest being the hadith of Ibn Al-Khasasiyyah which I cited in the previous issue. It has not been transmitted from any of the Salaf that he was buried anywhere other than a graveyard, except what is also Mutawatir that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was buried in his chamber, and that is one of his specific characteristics (peace and blessings be upon him), as indicated by the hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): She said: "When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) passed away, they differed regarding his burial. Abu Bakr said: I heard from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) something I have not forgotten. He said: 'Allah does not take the soul of a Prophet except in the place where he loves to be buried.' So they buried him in the place of his bedding." Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (2/129) who said: "A Gharib (strange) hadith, and Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Bakr Al-Maliki is weakened due to his memory." I say: However, the hadith is established due to its paths and supporting evidences: A - Narrated by Ibn Majah (1/498, 499), Ibn Sa'd (2/71), and Ibn Adi in 'Al-Kamil' (Folio 94/2) via the path of Ibn Abbas from Abu Bakr.

text: B - And Ibn Sa'd and Ahmad (No. 27) via two disconnected paths from Abu Bakr. C - And Malik narrated it (1/230) and from him Ibn Sa'd as a Balagh (report reaching him). D - And Ibn Sa'd narrated it with an authentic chain from Abu Bakr in an abbreviated form as a Mawquf report, but it has the ruling of a Marfu' report. Al-Tirmidhi also narrated it in "Al-Shama'il" (2/272) regarding the story of his death (peace and blessings be upon him). Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said (1/420): "Its chain is authentic, but it is Mawquf (stopped at the Companion), but the one before it is more explicit in intent. If his burial in his house is interpreted as a specificity, it is not far-fetched to prohibit others from that; rather, it is pertinent, because continued burial in houses might turn them into graveyards, making prayer in them disliked (Makruh)." Al-Bukhari deduced the dislike from his saying (peace and blessings be upon him): "Perform some of your prayers in your houses, and do not take them as graves." He included it in the "Chapter on the Dislike of Prayer in Graveyards" from the hadith of Ibn Umar. Al-Hafiz said: "The wording of Abu Huraira's hadith in Muslim is more explicit than the chapter's hadith, which is his saying: 'Do not make your houses graveyards,' for its apparent meaning implies a prohibition of burial in houses absolutely." 90 - Excluded from the above are martyrs in battle; they are buried in the places of their martyrdom and are not transported to graveyards, due to the hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) went out from Medina to the polytheists to fight them. My father Abdullah said: 'O Jabir son of Abdullah, do not worry about being among the onlookers of the people of Medina until you know what our matter comes to. For by Allah, were it not that I am leaving daughters behind me, I would have loved for you to be killed before me.' He said: So while I was among the onlookers, my aunt came with my father and my uncle, balancing them on a camel used for irrigation. She entered Medina with them to bury them in our graveyards - when a man caught up calling out: 'Behold! The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commands you to return the slain to be buried in their places of death where they were killed.' So we returned with them and buried them where they were killed."

text: Narrated by Ahmad (3/397-398) with an authentic chain, and parts of it are in Abu Dawud and others in summary. It was previously mentioned in Issue (17, p. 14). 92 - Burial is not permissible in the following situations except for necessity: A - Burial during the three times [forbidden for prayer], due to the hadith of Uqbah bin Amir mentioned previously (p. 130) with the wording: "There are three hours (times) during which the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade us to pray or to bury our dead: when the sun begins to rise until it is high, when the shade of a spear stands still at noon until the sun passes the meridian, and when the sun inclines to setting until it sets." The hadith clearly indicates what we mentioned. Ibn Hazm adopted this view in "Al-Muhalla" (5/114-115) as did other scholars. Among the far-fetched, indeed invalid interpretations, is the saying of some: "His saying: (bury) means pray [the funeral prayer]." Abu Al-Hasan Al-Sindi said: "It is not hidden that this is a distant meaning that does not come to mind from the wording of the hadith. Some said: 'One says he buried him (Qabarahu) if he put him in the grave, and one does not say he buried him (Qabarahu) if he prayed over him.' The closest view is that the hadith leans towards the opinion of Ahmad and others that burial is disliked (Makruh) during these times." (1) B - During the night, due to the hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him):

(1) I say: Imam Al-Nawawi also rejected that interpretation, but in the course of explaining that, he fell into another interpretation similar to this one and claimed a claim that is not established. He said in 'Sharh Muslim': 'Some said that what is meant by burial implies the funeral prayer. This is weak because the funeral prayer is not disliked at this time by consensus, so it is not permissible to interpret the hadith in a way that contradicts the consensus. Rather, the correct view is that its meaning is intentionally delaying the burial until these times, just as it is disliked to intentionally delay the Asr prayer until the yellowing of the sun without excuse... As for if the burial happens during these times without intent, it is not disliked.' I say: This is an interpretation with no evidence. The hadith is absolute and includes the intentional and others. The truth is the impermissibility of burial even for the unintentional; whoever is overtaken by it [the time] should wait until the time of dislike passes. As for his claim that the funeral prayer is not disliked during such times by consensus, it is a delusion from him (may Allah have mercy on him). The issue is disputed, and the correct view regarding it is dislike (Karahah), contrary to the alleged consensus. This has been previously clarified in Issue (89) in the commentary on it (p. 130). =

text: "That the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) mentioned a man from his companions who died and was shrouded in a shroud that was not substantial and was buried at night. So the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) reprimanded that a man be buried at night until he is prayed over, unless a person is compelled to do that." Narrated by Muslim and others, and it was previously mentioned in Issue (35, p. 56). The hadith clearly indicates what we mentioned. It is the view of Ahmad (may Allah have mercy on him) in a narration from him mentioned in "Al-Insaf" (2/547). He said: "He should not do it except out of necessity. And in another [narration] from him: It is disliked." I say: The first is closer to the apparent meaning of his saying "reprimanded" (zajara), for it is stronger in prohibition than the word "forbade" (naha) which can be interpreted as dislike, although the default ruling for it is prohibition (Tahrim), and there is nothing to divert it to dislike. (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) However, what we mentioned is complicated by his saying in the hadith "until he is prayed over." For its apparent meaning also indicates the permissibility of burial at night after the prayer, because that is the goal of the prohibition. If it is achieved, the prohibition is lifted. But this is countered by his saying "unless a person is compelled to do that," for the demonstrative pronoun in it refers to the prohibited act, which is burial at night before the prayer, except in case of necessity, then it is permissible. This is very far-fetched, because it is easy to imagine the mourners being compelled to bury at night for many reasons as will come from Ibn Hazm, but we cannot imagine in any way that they would be compelled to bury him without praying over him. What makes it even more remote is that this meaning renders the restriction of "night" useless, since burial before prayer, just as it is not permissible at night, is likewise not permissible during the day. If it were permissible at night for necessity, it would be permissible during the day for its sake with no difference. So what is the benefit of the restriction to "night" then? There is no doubt that the benefit does not appear strongly unless we prefer what we initially deduced regarding the impermissibility of burial at night. The explanation of that is: Burial at night is a presumed cause for few people praying over the deceased. So he forbade burial at night so that he would be prayed over during the day, because people during the day are more active in praying over him. Thus, a large number of people praying over him is achieved; this large number is one of the objectives of the Sharia and is more hopeful for the acceptance of their intercession for the deceased, as previously explained in "Issue (63), (p. 96)." Al-Nawawi said in "Sharh Muslim": "As for the prohibition of burial at night until he is prayed over, it was said the reason is that burial during the day is attended by many people who pray over him, while only individuals attend at night. And it was said because they used to do that due to the poor quality of the shroud, so it wouldn't be noticeable at night. The beginning and end of the hadith support this. Al-Qadi said: Both reasons are correct. He said: It is apparent that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) intended both together. He said: And other things have been said." I say: If it is known that the reason is the small number of worshipers and fear regarding the poor quality of the shroud, the result is that if he was prayed over during the day, then his burial was delayed for an excuse until the night, there is no impediment to burying him in it due to the absence of the cause and the realization of the goal, which is the large number of worshipers. Based on this, is it permissible to delay burying the deceased during the day to achieve the mentioned goal? Al-San'ani considered this good in "Subul al-Salam" (2/166), but I do not see that, because the mentioned cause is restricted, so it is not permissible to extend it to the day due to the great difference between the two circumstances, for =

text: 92 - If they are compelled to bury him at night, it is permissible even with the use of a lamp and descending with it into the grave to facilitate the burial process. The evidence is the hadith of Ibn Abbas: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) placed a man in his grave at night, and a lamp was lit in his grave." Narrated by Ibn Majah (1/464) and Al-Tirmidhi (2/157) more completely, and he said: "A Hasan (Good) hadith."
foot_note: 1. = Fewness at night is a natural matter, unlike the day where abundance is natural. Furthermore, this abundance has no limit, so the more the deceased is delayed, the greater the abundance. Therefore, we see some affluent people who love to show off and seek reputation, even at the expense of the deceased, delaying him for a day or two so that the largest possible number of mourners attend the funeral. If the permissibility of that were stated, it would lead to opposing the Lawgiver in his command to hasten with the funeral as previously explained in Issue (17) (p. 13) due to the reason of abundance which has no control. After this, the answer to the problem I raised regarding his saying "until he is prayed over" becomes clear to us, as it appeared that the meaning is until he is prayed over during the day for the large congregation. Thus, it becomes clear that the demonstrative pronoun in his saying "unless a person is compelled to do that" refers to burial at night even with few worshipers, not to burial while abandoning the prayer over him entirely. So reflect, for it is worthy of reflection. Then Al-Nawawi said in "Sharh Muslim": "Scholars differed regarding burial at night. Al-Hasan Al-Basri disliked it except for necessity, and this hadith is used as evidence for him. The majority of scholars from the Salaf and Khalaf said: It is not disliked. They used as evidence that Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) and a group of the Salaf were buried at night without objection, and the hadith of the black woman: And the man who used to clean the mosque who died at night and they buried him at night. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) asked them about him, and they said: He died at night and we buried him at night. He said: Why did you not inform me? They said: It was dark. And he did not rebuke them. They answered regarding this hadith that the prohibition was for leaving the prayer, and he did not forbid mere burial at night, but rather for leaving the prayer, or for the fewness of worshipers, or for the poor shroud, or for the combination as preceded." I say: The first answer, that the prohibition was for leaving the prayer, is incorrect, because if it were so, there would be no difference between burial at night or day as previously explained. Rather, the correct view is that the prohibition was indeed for the two matters mentioned previously in Al-Qadi's speech. Therefore, Ibn Hazm chose that no one should be buried at night except out of necessity. He used this hadith as evidence for that, then answered the hadiths mentioned regarding burial at night and similar reports by saying (5/114-115): "Everyone who was buried at night, including him (peace be upon him), his wives, and his companions (may Allah be pleased with them), that was only for a necessity that obligated it, such as fear of the heat for those attending - and it is severe in Medina - or fear of change [decomposition], or other things that permit burial at night. It is not lawful for anyone to think otherwise of them (may Allah be pleased with them)." Then he narrated the dislike of burial at night from Saeed bin Al-Musayyib. I say: It is possible that some of those buried at night had been prayed over during the day, and in that case there is no contradiction based on what was previously explained. That is the reality in his case (peace be upon him), for they prayed over him on Tuesday and then buried him on the night of Wednesday, as Ibn Hisham mentioned in his Sirah (4/314) from Ibn Ishaq. And Allah knows best.

text: I say: He means that it is Hasan due to other factors (li-ghayrihi). This is a specific terminology of Al-Tirmidhi that if he says: "Hadith Hasan," he only intends Hasan due to others, as he himself stated in "Al-Ilal" mentioned at the end of his book. A witness (supporting narration) has come for it as follows, and therefore Ibn Al-Qattan's criticism of him, which was recounted by the author of "Tuhfat Al-Ahwadhi," does not apply to Al-Tirmidhi's grading of Hasan. As for the witness, it is from the hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah. Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/63), Al-Hakim (1/368), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/53). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic on the condition of Muslim." Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and Al-Nawawi exceeded them both, saying in "Al-Majmu'" (5/302): "Abu Dawud narrated it with a chain on the condition of Al-Bukhari and Muslim." I say: All of that is incorrect, for the pivot of its chain is Muhammad bin Muslim Al-Ta'ifi. Although he is trustworthy in himself, he was weak in his memory. Therefore, the two Sheikhs did not use him as a primary proof; rather, Al-Bukhari narrated from him in a suspended form (Ta'liq), and Muslim as supporting evidence (Istishhad). It is amazing that Al-Hakim and Al-Dhahabi were aware of some of this, for Al-Mizzi mentioned that this Al-Ta'ifi has only one hadith in Muslim. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: "And it is a supporting narration in his [Muslim's book], as Al-Hakim stated." Similarly, Al-Dhahabi stated in his biography in "Al-Mizan" that Muslim narrated from him as a follow-up (Muta'ba'ah). It has another witness from the hadith of Abu Dharr similar to it. Al-Hakim narrated it with a chain containing an unnamed man, while the rest of its narrators are trustworthy. 93 - It is obligatory to deepen, widen, and improve the grave. There are two hadiths regarding this: First: From Hisham bin Amir who said: "On the Day of Uhud, Muslims were stricken (killed) and people suffered wounds. (So we said: O Messenger of Allah, digging for each person is difficult for us), (so how do you command us?). He said: Dig, widen, (deepen), (and improve), and bury two and three in a grave, and prioritize the one who knew the most Quran. (He said: My father was the third of three, and he knew the most Quran, so he was prioritized)."
foot_note: None

text: Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/70), Al-Nasa'i (1/283-284), Al-Tirmidhi (3/36), Al-Bayhaqi (4/34), Ahmad (4/19, 20), and Ibn Majah in summary. The phrasing belongs to Al-Nasa'i, and all the additions are his in one narration. They are also present in Ahmad except for the first one. The third addition is in Abu Dawud and Al-Bayhaqi. The fourth is in Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Al-Bayhaqi. The fifth is in Al-Tirmidhi, and he said: "A Hasan Sahih hadith." I say: The pivot of its chain is Humaid bin Hilal. Ayyub Al-Sakhtiyani narrated it from him in three ways: First: From him from Hisham bin Amir. Second: From him from Abu Al-Dahma' from Hisham. Third: From him from Sa'd bin Hisham from his father Hisham. Sulaiman bin Al-Mughirah followed him on the first way from Humaid with it. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi (3/413), and Ahmad. Jarir bin Hazim followed him on the third way: Humaid bin Hilal told us from Sa'd bin Hisham bin Amir. Narrated by the three mentioned, as well as Abu Dawud, and from him Al-Bayhaqi (3/414). This way is more likely to me for this follow-up, and it is more likely than the first follow-up for two reasons: First: Muslim used Sulaiman bin Al-Mughirah as proof but Al-Bukhari did not; he narrated from him coupled with others. Unlike Jarir bin Hazim, for both Muslim and Al-Bukhari used him as proof. Second: It contains an addition from a trustworthy narrator, which is considered, so it was one of the preponderating factors. Based on this, the chain of the hadith is authentic as Al-Tirmidhi said, and it is on the condition of the two Sheikhs. Second: From a man from the Ansar who said: We went out with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) in the funeral of a man from the Ansar, and I was a boy with my father. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) sat
foot_note: None

text: at the edge of the grave, and began instructing (and in a narration: gesturing to) the digger, saying: Widen from the head side, and widen from the foot side, for there is a cluster of dates for him in Paradise." (1). Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/83), Al-Bayhaqi (3/414), the other narration is his, and Ahmad (5/408) - the wording is his. Its chain is authentic as said by Al-Nawawi in "Al-Majmu'" (5/286) and Al-Hafiz in "Al-Talkhis" (5/201). 94 - Both Lahd (2) and Shaqq (trench) are permissible in the grave because the practice of both occurred during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), but the first (Lahd) is better. There are hadiths regarding this: First: From Anas bin Malik who said: "When the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) died, there was a man in Medina who used to make Lahd, and another who used to make Shaqq (trench). They said: We seek guidance from our Lord and send for both of them; whichever of them arrives first, we will let him do it. So they sent for both, and the owner of the Lahd arrived first, so they made a Lahd for the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him)." Narrated by Ibn Majah (1/472), Al-Tahawi (4/45), and Ahmad (3/99). I say: Its chain is Hasan as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Talkhis" (5/204). It has two witnesses: First: From Ibn Abbas. Narrated by Ibn Majah (1/298), Ahmad (39, 3358), Ibn Sa'd (2/2/72), and Al-Bayhaqi (3/407). The other: From Aisha. Narrated by Ibn Majah and Ibn Sa'd. The chain of each of them is weak as Al-Hafiz said. But the first of them has another path with the wording:
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: The apparent command in the two hadiths implies the obligation of what is mentioned in them regarding deepening, widening, and improving. It is known from the Shafi'is and others that deepening is recommended (Mustahabb). As for Ibn Hazm, he explicitly stated in 'Al-Muhalla' (5/116) that it is obligatory (Fard). They differed on the limit of deepening according to opinions you can see in 'Al-Majmu' or elsewhere. 
2. With Fath on the Lam and Damm with Sukun on the Ha (Lahd). It is the digging in the side of the grave towards the Qibla. The Shaqq is the trench (Darih), which is to dig downwards like a river.

text: "Al-Abbas, Ali, and Al-Fadl entered the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), and a man from the Ansar leveled his Lahd; he is the one who leveled the Lahds of the graves of the martyrs on the Day of Badr." Narrated by Al-Tahawi in "Mushkil al-Athar" (4/47), Ibn al-Jarud (268), and Ibn Hibban (2161). Its chain is authentic. Ibn Abbas has another hadith regarding the Lahd from the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) coming after one hadith, and a witness from the hadith of Ali coming in Issue (97) (p. 147). Second: From Amir bin Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas from his father that he said: "Make a Lahd for me, and set up bricks over me, just as was done for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him)." Narrated by Muslim (2/61), Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad (1489, 1601, 1602). Third: From Ibn Abbas regarding the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) saying: "The Lahd is for us, and the Shaqq is for others." Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/69), Al-Nasa'i (1/283), Al-Tirmidhi (2/152), Ibn Majah (4711), Al-Tahawi (4/48), and Al-Bayhaqi (3/408) with a weak chain as Al-Hafiz said (5/203). Ibn Al-Sakan authenticated it. I say: Perhaps due to its witnesses and paths, among which is: From Jarir raised [to the Prophet] similarly. Narrated by Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi (669), and Ahmad (4/357, 359, 362) from Uthman bin Umayr Abu Al-Yaqzan from Zadhan from him. This Uthman is weak as Al-Hafiz said, but Al-Tahawi narrated it from a second path and Ahmad from two other paths. These are four paths for the hadith of Jarir strengthening each other. If added to the hadith of Ibn Abbas, it strengthens it and raises it to the rank of Hasan or even Sahih. (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Nawawi said in 'Al-Majmu' (5/287): "The scholars have agreed that burial in the Lahd and Shaqq are permissible. However, if the earth is solid and its soil does not collapse, the Lahd is better due to the previous evidences. If it is soft and collapses, the Shaqq is better."

text: 98 - (1) There is no harm in burying two or more people in it [the grave] in cases of necessity, and the best of them should be placed first. There are hadiths regarding this: First: From Jabir bin Abdullah who said: "The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) used to combine two men (and three) of those killed at Uhud in one cloth (2), then say: 'Which of them knew more Quran?' When one was pointed out to him, he would place him first in the Lahd (before his companion and say: 'I am a witness over these on the Day of Resurrection.' He ordered them to be buried in their blood; they were not washed nor prayed over. (Jabir said: My father and my uncle (3) were buried in one grave that day)." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/163-165, 169, 7/300), Al-Nasa'i (1/277), Al-Tirmidhi (2/147) who authenticated it, Ibn Majah (1/461), Ibn Al-Jarud (270), Al-Bayhaqi (4/14), and Ahmad (5/431). The third addition is his; Al-Bukhari has its meaning. The second belongs to him and Al-Bayhaqi. The third belongs to Ibn Majah. Al-Shawkani (4/25) attributed it to Al-Tirmidhi, which is a mistake. In the second half of the hadith is an addition mentioned previously in Issue (32), (p. 54). Second: From Abu Qatadah that he was present at that event, he said: "Amr bin Al-Jamuh came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, do you see if I fight in the way of Allah until I am killed, will I walk with this leg of mine sound in Paradise?' His leg was lame. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: 'Yes.' So they were killed on the Day of Uhud: he, his brother's son, and a freed slave of theirs. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) passed by him and said: 'It is as if I am looking at you walking with this leg of yours sound in Paradise.' So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) ordered concerning them and their freed slave, and they were placed in one grave." Narrated by Ahmad (5/299) with a good chain as Al-Hafiz said (3/168). Regarding this topic, there is the narration of Hisham bin Amir, and his hadith passed in Issue (93) Hadith One,
foot_note:
1. (1) The issue numbering skipped from 94 to 98 to correct a numbering error, so apologies. 
2. Meaning in a piece of it, even if it didn't cover his whole body. See note (2) p. 60. 
3. It appears he means his father's brother, but it is not so. Rather, he meant Amr bin Al-Jamuh mentioned in the hadith after it. He was a friend of Jabir's father and the husband of his sister Hind bint Amr. It seems Jabir called him his uncle out of respect, as Al-Hafiz said in 'Al-Fath' and cited reports supporting that, so refer to it (3/168).

text: (p. 141) and from Anas bin Malik, and it preceded in Issue (37), (p. 59-60) (1). 99 - Men should undertake lowering the deceased - even if female - not women, for several reasons: First: It was the practice during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), and the practice of Muslims has continued upon it until today. The hadith of Anas in Issue (99) will cover this. Second: Men are stronger for that. Third: If women undertook it, it would lead to the exposure of parts of their bodies in front of strangers, which is not permissible. 100 - The relatives (Awliya') of the deceased have more right to lower him, due to the generality of the Almighty's saying: {But those of [blood] relationship (2) are more entitled [to inheritance] in the decree of Allah. Indeed, Allah is Knowing of all things} [Al-Anfal: 75]. And due to the hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "I washed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and went to look for what usually comes from the dead, but I saw nothing. He was pure alive and dead. Four people undertook his burial and laying him in the grave excluding other people: Ali, Al-Abbas, Al-Fadl, and Salih the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). A Lahd was made for the Messenger of Allah, and bricks were set up over him." Narrated by Al-Hakim (1/362) and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/53) with an authentic chain. Al-Hakim authenticated it on the condition of the two Sheikhs and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It has a witness from the hadith of Ibn Abbas previously mentioned in Issue (94), (p. 144-145) and another witness from Al-Sha'bi as a Mursal report, and he did not mention Salih the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/69) with an authentic chain from him. And he has [a report] from Marhab or Ibn Abi Marhab "that they (meaning Ali, Al-Fadl and his brother) entered with them
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: In these hadiths is an apparent virtue for the reciter of the Quran. Al-Hafiz said in 'Al-Fath' (3-166): 'And attached to him are the people of Fiqh, Zuhd (asceticism), and other aspects of virtue.' Al-Shafi'i said in 'Al-Umm' (1-245): 'In places of necessity due to tightness and haste, two or three dead are buried in a grave. The one towards the Qibla among them should be the most virtuous and oldest. I do not like for a woman to be buried with a man in any case, but if it is necessary and there is no other way, the man should be in front of her and she behind him, and a barrier of soil should be made between the man and the woman in the grave.' 
2. They are the father and his fathers, the son and his sons, then full brothers, then those on the father's side, then their sons, then paternal uncles of full blood, then of the father's side, then their sons, then every Mahram relative. Thus in 'Al-Muhalla' (5/143), and similar in 'Al-Majmu' (5/290).

text: Abd al-Rahman bin Awf. When Ali finished, he said: Indeed, a man's family should handle his affairs." Marhab or Ibn Abi Marhab is disputed regarding his companionship. (1) And from Abd al-Rahman bin Abza who said: "I prayed with Umar bin Al-Khattab over Zainab bint Jahsh in Medina. He said four Takbirs then sent to the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him): Who do they order to place her in the grave? He said: And he liked to be the one to handle that. They sent to him: Look at who used to see her during her lifetime, let him be the one to place her in the grave. Umar said: You have spoken the truth." Narrated by Al-Tahawi (3/304-305) and Al-Bayhaqi (3/53) with an authentic chain. 101 - It is permissible for the husband to undertake the burial of his wife himself, due to the hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) entered upon me on the day his illness began, and I said: 'O my head!' He said: 'I wish that had happened while I was alive, so I would prepare you and bury you.' She said: I said - my jealousy stirred -: 'It is as if I see you on that day like a groom with some of your wives.' He said: 'Rather, I, O my head! Call for me your father and your brother so I can write a writing for Abu Bakr, for I fear that a sayer might say or a wisher might wish: I am more entitled, but Allah the Mighty and Majestic and the believers refuse anyone but Abu Bakr.'" Narrated by Ahmad (6/144) with an authentic chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs. It is in "Sahih Al-Bukhari" with similar wording (10/101 / 102), and Muslim (7/110) abbreviated. It has another path from Aisha mentioned previously (p. 50). (2) 102 - But that is conditional on whether he did not have intercourse that night; otherwise, it is not prescribed for him to bury her, and someone else would be more entitled to bury her, even if a stranger, under the mentioned condition. Due to the hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "We witnessed [the funeral of] a daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was sitting by the grave, and I saw his eyes shedding tears.
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: This, and the one before it from the Mursal of Al-Sha'bi, is a strong witness for the hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him). 
2. The Shafi'is held the view of the permissibility of a man burying his wife; rather, they said: He is more entitled to that than her guardians whom we mentioned. Ibn Hazm reversed that and placed him after them in entitlement, and perhaps that is closer due to the aforementioned generality of the verse.

text: Then he said: Is there any man among you who did not commit *muqarafah* (1) (intercourse) tonight (with his wife)? Abu Talha said: (Yes), I am, O Messenger of Allah! He said: Then descend. He said: So he descended into her grave (and buried her)." In a narration from him: "When Ruqayyah (may Allah be pleased with her) died, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: No man who committed *muqarafah* (intercourse) tonight with his wife should enter the grave. So Uthman bin Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) did not enter the grave." The first narration was extracted by Al-Bukhari in his "Sahih" (3/122, 162), Al-Tahawi in "Al-Mushkil" (3/304), Al-Hakim (4/47), Al-Bayhaqi (4/53), and Ahmad (3/126, 228), and the context belongs to him. He has the second addition in a narration of his. Al-Tahawi and Al-Hakim have the first [addition], and Al-Bukhari has the last. The second narration was extracted by Ahmad (3/229-270), Al-Tahawi (3/202), Al-Hakim (4/47), and Ibn Hazm (5/145) from another path from Anas. The context belongs to Ahmad, and the addition to Al-Hakim who said: "An authentic hadith on the condition of Muslim." It is as he said, and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. However, some Imams disapproved of him naming the daughter "Ruqayyah". Al-Bukhari said in "Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat": "I do not know what this is? For Ruqayyah died while the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was at Badr and did not witness her [funeral]." Al-Hafiz preferred in "Al-Fath" that the error is from Hammad bin Salamah, and that she was Umm Kulthum, the wife of Uthman, so refer to it. This is what Al-Tahawi asserted in "Al-Mushkil" and said: "Her death was in the year nine of the Hijra" (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Meaning to have intercourse as in "Al-Nihayah". Al-Tahawi considered this interpretation unlikely without any evidence, so no attention is paid to it. 
2. Al-Nawawi said in "Al-Majmu'" (5/289): "This hadith is among the hadiths used as proof that men are the ones who undertake placing into the grave and burial, even if the deceased is a woman. He said: It is known that Abu Talha (may Allah be pleased with him) was a stranger [non-Mahram] to the daughters of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), but he was among the righteous of those present, and there was no Mahram man there except the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), so perhaps he had an excuse regarding descending into her grave. Likewise her husband. It is known that her sister Fatima and others of her Mahrams and other women were there, so this indicates that women have no role in entering the grave and burial." Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath": =

text: 103 - The Sunnah is to insert the deceased from the rear of the grave, due to the hadith of Abu Ishaq who said: "Al-Harith instructed that Abdullah bin Yazid pray over him. So he prayed over him, then inserted him into the grave from the foot of the grave and said: This is from the Sunnah." Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4/130) and Abu Dawud (2/69), and via his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/54) who said: This is an authentic chain, and since he said: 'This is from the Sunnah', it becomes Marfu' (elevated to the Prophet)." I say: He then narrated witnesses for it from the hadith of Ibn Abbas and others, and said: "This is what is well-known among the people of Hijaz." Then he cited two hadiths stating that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was inserted from the direction of the Qibla, and he weakened them, which is as he mentioned. Al-Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) criticized the second hadith textually as well, arguing that it is practically impossible. He said in "Al-Umm" (1/241): "Trustworthy companions of ours informed me that the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) is on the right of the entrant from the house, adhering to the wall. The wall next to which the Lahd is, is the Qibla of the house, and his Lahd is under the wall. So how can he be inserted sideways while the Lahd is adhering to the wall with nothing to stand on? It is not possible except to slide him gently or enter from opposite the Qibla. Matters of the dead and their insertion are among the well-known matters among us due to the frequency of death and the presence of Imams and trustworthy people. It is among the general matters where a hadith is dispensed with, and the hadith in it would be like assigning a task based on the general public's knowledge of it. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), the Muhajirun, and the Ansar were among us, transmitted generally from the general public without differing in that the deceased is slid gently. Then
foot_note: 1. = "In the hadith, there is preference for the one distant from pleasures in burying the dead, even if a woman, over the father and husband. It was said: He favored him with that because it was his profession, but there is questionable aspect to this, for the apparent context is that he chose him for that because no intercourse occurred from him that night." I say: The hadith clearly indicates what we translated it for. Ibn Hazm (may Allah have mercy on him) held this view (5/144-145). It is strange that the general books of Fiqh that I have seen or reviewed on this occasion did not address this issue, neither negating nor affirming. This is one of many proofs that the Faqih cannot do without the books of Sunnah, contrary to what the partisan followers of Madhhabs think, that books of Fiqh suffice over books of Hadith, and even over the Book of Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, high above what the wrongdoers say. See "Silsilat Al-Ahadith Al-Sahihah" (Vol 1, p. 128-129, Islamic Office print).

text: a comer (1) came to us from other than our land teaching us how to insert the dead (2). Then he did not know (so in the original, and in 'Al-Majmu' quoting from 'Al-Umm': [did not accept/approve] (which is likely correct)) until he narrated from Hammad from Ibrahim that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was inserted sideways." Then Al-Shafi'i cited the hadith of Ibn Abbas and others that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was slid from the direction of his head. I say: Its narrators are trustworthy narrators of the two Sheikhs except for Al-Shafi'i's sheikh who is unknown and unnamed, because Al-Shafi'i said: "The trustworthy one informed us from Amr from Ata from him." And from Ibn Sirin who said: "I was with Anas in a funeral, and he ordered regarding the deceased, so he was slid from the foot of the grave." Narrated by Ahmad (4081) and Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/130) and its chain is authentic. 104 - The deceased is placed in his grave on his right side, his face facing the Qibla, his head and feet to the right and left of the Qibla. This has been the practice of the people of Islam from the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) until our day, and this is every graveyard on the face of the earth. So in "Al-Muhalla" (5/173) and others. 105 - The one who places him in his Lahd says: "In the name of Allah, and upon the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, or: the religion (Millah) of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him)." The evidence for it is the hadith of Ibn Umar:
foot_note:
1. (1) He is Hammad bin Abi Sulayman, one of Abu Hanifa's sheikhs as in 'Fath al-Qadir' and others. I say: Rather, it appears to be Abu Hanifa himself, evidenced by Al-Shafi'i's coming statement: "until he narrated from Hammad." This is explicit that he is other than Hammad, rather he is Abu Hanifa. 
2. What this suspended hadith and the raised one before it indicate is the Madhhab of Ahmad, and most of his companions are upon it as in 'Al-Insaf' (2/544), contrary to the Hanafis as preceded in Al-Shafi'i's speech. Ibn Al-Humam argued for them with the hadith of Ibn Abbas that he (peace be upon him) entered a grave... and took him from the direction of the Qibla... Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi who said: "Hasan Hadith." Ibn Al-Humam said (1/470): "Even though it contains Al-Hajjaj bin Artah and Minhal bin Khalifa, and they differed regarding them, he said: That lowers the hadith from the rank of Sahih, not Hasan." I say: Rather, that lowers it from the rank of Hasan because Al-Hajjaj is a Mudallis and used 'an'anah, and the hadith of a Mudallis using 'an'anah is not accepted by scholars. It is one of the two hadiths that Al-Bayhaqi weakened as indicated at the beginning of the issue. Therefore, Al-Nawawi (5/295) rejected Al-Tirmidhi's grading of it as Hasan, saying: "Al-Tirmidhi's statement that it is Hasan is not accepted because Al-Hajjaj bin Artah is weak by the agreement of Hadith scholars." Al-Zayla'i said: =

text: "That the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), when he placed the deceased in the grave, said: (And in a wording: That the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: When you place your dead in the graves, say): In the name of Allah, and upon the Sunnah (and in a narration: the religion/Millah) of the Messenger of Allah." Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/70), Al-Tirmidhi (2/152, 153), Ibn Majah (1/470), Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (773), Al-Hakim (1/366), Al-Bayhaqi (4/55), and Ahmad (No. 4990, 5233, 6111) from two paths from Ibn Umar. The first wording belongs to Abu Dawud, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Al-Sunni, and the other wording belongs to the rest. As for the other narration, it belongs to Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, and a narration of Ahmad, and their meaning is one. Al-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Hadith." Al-Hakim said, and Al-Dhahabi agreed: "Authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs." I say: It is as they said. The fact that some narrated it as Mawquf (stopped at the companion) does not harm it for two reasons: First: The one who raised it (to the Prophet) is trustworthy, so it is an addition from him, which must be accepted. This is supported by the second reason: It was narrated raised from the other path. Or he says: "In the name of Allah, and by Allah, and upon the religion (Millah) of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him)." Due to the hadith of Al-Bayadi (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that he said: "The deceased, when placed in his grave: let those who place him say when he is placed in the Lahd: In the name of Allah, and by Allah, upon the religion of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him)." Al-Hakim extracted it as a witness for the hadith before it. And its chain is Hasan. 106 - It is recommended for those at the grave to throw three handfuls of soil with both hands after finishing closing the Lahd, due to the hadith of Abu Huraira:
foot_note: 1. = (2/300) after quoting Al-Tirmidhi's statement: "And it was rejected because its pivot is on Hajjaj bin Artah, who is a Mudallis and did not mention hearing, and Minhal was weakened by Ibn Ma'in..." I say: This is the truth according to those who are fair, that this hadith is weak and the hadith of Abdullah bin Yazid is authentic. It is strange that Ibn Al-Humam accepted its authenticity, but rejected it fundamentally on the pretext that it was an action of a companion who thought it was the Sunnah! He says this even though his Madhhab is that the saying of a Companion, "The Sunnah is such-and-such," has the meaning of a Musnad (connected/raised) Hadith, as we quoted from him in Issue (77) (p. 120). Refer to Issue (73) (p. 109, 110), for in it is a refutation of another type of bias and declaring Companions mistaken without proof!

text: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) prayed over a funeral then came to the deceased and threw [soil] upon him from the direction of his head three times." Narrated by Ibn Majah (1/474) with a chain he said (5/292): "Good (Jayyid)." But Al-Hafiz said: "Its appearance implies correctness (Sahha)." Then he mentioned it has a defect due to the 'an'anah of some of its narrators as I explained in "Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad", but the hadith is strong due to its supporting evidences. Al-Hafiz mentioned them in "Talkhis Al-Habir" (5/222), so let whoever wishes refer to them. Then it became clear to me that the mentioned defect is not damaging, as I verified in Al-Irwa (743) (1). 107 - It is Sunnah after finishing his burial to do several things: First: To raise the grave above the ground slightly, about a span, and not to level it with the ground, so that it is distinguished and thus protected and not disrespected, due to the hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): "That a Lahd was made for the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), bricks were set up over him, and his grave was raised from the ground about a span." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (2160) and Al-Bayhaqi (3/410), and its chain is Hasan.
foot_note: 1. (1) As for the recommendation by some late jurists to say in the first handful (From it We created you), in the second (And into it We return you), and in the third (And from it We bring you out another time), it has no basis in any of the hadiths we indicated above. As for Al-Nawawi's saying (5/293-294): It may be evidenced by the hadith of Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When Umm Kulthum, daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), was placed in the grave, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (From it We created you, and into it We return you, and from it We bring you out another time)." Narrated by Imam Ahmad from the narration of Ubaidullah bin Zahr from Ali bin Zaid bin Jud'an from Al-Qasim, and all three are weak, but weak hadiths are used for virtues of deeds..." The answer to this is from several aspects: First: The hadith does not contain the detailed [practice] alleged to be recommended, so there is no proof in it at all even if its chain were authentic. Second: The mentioned detail is not established in the Shari'ah as being among the virtues of deeds so that it can be said this hadith acts upon it because it is regarding virtues of deeds. Rather, permitting action by it means establishing the legitimacy of an act by a weak hadith, and that is not permissible because legitimacy's lowest degree is recommendation (Istihbab): which is one of the five rulings that are not established except by authentic evidence, and weak [evidence] is of no avail in it by the agreement of scholars. Third: The hadith is very weak, rather it is fabricated (Mawdu') in the criticism of Ibn Hibban. It is in "Musnad Ahmad" (5/254) via Ubaidullah bin Zahr from Ali bin Yazid, who is Al-Alhani, and Al-Nawawi's saying "Ali bin Zaid bin Jud'an" is a mistake, contradicting what is in the "Musnad". Ibn Hibban said: "Ubaidullah bin Zahr narrates fabrications from trustworthy narrators, and if he narrates from Ali bin Yazid, he brings calamities. And if Ubaidullah, Ali bin Yazid, and Al-Qasim Abu Abd al-Rahman gather in a chain of a report, that report is nothing but what their hands wrought"! Ibn Hajar in "Tabyin al-Ajab fi ma Warada fi Fadl Rajab".

text: It has a witness from Salih bin Abi Salih who said: "I saw the grave of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) a span or about a span [high]." Narrated by Abu Dawud in "Al-Marasil". This is supported by what will come regarding the prohibition of adding to the soil taken out of the grave, for it is known that the soil taken out of the Lahd occupied by the body of the deceased remains after the burial on the grave, and that equals roughly the amount mentioned in the hadith. (1) Second: That it be made humped (Musannam), due to the hadith of Sufyan Al-Tammar who said: "I saw the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) (and the grave of Abu Bakr and Umar) humped." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/198-199) and Al-Bayhaqi (4/3). Ibn Abi Shaybah and Abu Nu'aym narrated it in "Al-Mustakhraj" as in "Al-Talkhis", and the addition belongs to them. This is not contradicted by what was narrated from Al-Qasim who said: "I entered upon Aisha and said: O Mother, uncover for me the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and his two companions (may Allah be pleased with them). She uncovered for me three graves, neither high nor flattened, spread with the pebbles of the red courtyard." Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/70), Al-Hakim (1/369), and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/3) and Ibn Hazm (5/134) via Amr bin Uthman bin Hani from Al-Qasim with it. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain"! And Al-Dhahabi agreed! As for Al-Bayhaqi, he said: "It is more authentic than the hadith of Sufyan Al-Tammar"!! Ibn Al-Turkumani refuted him: "This is contrary to the terminology of the people of this discipline. Rather, the hadith of Al-Tammar is more authentic because it is extracted in Sahih Al-Bukhari, and the hadith of Al-Qasim was not extracted in any of the Sahihs."
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Shafi'i said in "Al-Umm" (1/245-246) in summary: "I like that no soil from elsewhere is added to the grave, because if added, it becomes very high. I only like it to be raised above the surface of the earth a span or so." Al-Nawawi quoted in "Al-Majmu'" (5/296) the agreement of Al-Shafi'i's companions on the recommendation of raising it by the mentioned amount.

text: I say: This refutation is insufficient. Sometimes the chain of a hadith opposing Al-Bukhari's hadith is more authentic and stronger than Al-Bukhari's chain. Prioritizing Al-Tammar's hadith is not complete unless the defect of Al-Qasim's hadith is explained, or at least that it is below it in authenticity. That is the case here, for its defect is Amr bin Uthman bin Hani, who is 'Mastur' (hidden/unknown condition) as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Taqrib", and no one authenticated him at all. So Al-Hakim's authentication of his hadith is from his known leniency, and Al-Dhahabi's agreement with him is one of his many oversights not hidden from those who track his speech in "Talkhis Al-Mustadrak". Furthermore, even if it were authentic, it does not contradict Al-Tammar's hadith, because his saying "Mabtuh" (spread/level) does not mean flat, but rather covered with "Batha" which is small pebbles as in "Al-Nihayah", and it is apparent in the report itself: "spread with the pebbles of the red courtyard". This does not negate humping. Ibn al-Qayyim combined the two hadiths with this, saying in "Al-Zad": "His grave is humped, spread with the pebbles of the red courtyard, neither built up nor plastered with clay, and likewise were the graves of his two companions." Third: To mark it with a stone or similiar to bury near it those of his family who die, due to the hadith of Al-Muttalib bin Abi Wada'ah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When Uthman bin Maz'un died, he was brought out in his funeral and buried. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) ordered a man to bring him a stone, but he could not carry it. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) went to it and rolled up his sleeves from his arms. Al-Muttalib said: The one who informs me from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: It is as if I am looking at the whiteness of the arms of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) when he uncovered them. Then he carried it and placed it at his head, and said: I mark with it the grave of my brother, and I will bury near it those who die of my family." Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/69) and from him Al-Bayhaqi (3/412) with a Hasan chain as Al-Hafiz said (5/229). Al-Muttalib is a known Companion who accepted Islam on the Day of Conquest. It has two witnesses which I mentioned in "Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad". Fourth: Not to prompt (Talqin) the deceased with the Talqin known today, because the hadith reported regarding it is not authentic (1).

text: Rather, he stands over the grave praying for steadfastness for him, asks forgiveness for him, and commands those present to do so, due to the hadith of Uthman bin Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), when he finished burying the deceased, would stand over him and say: Ask forgiveness for your brother, and ask for steadfastness for him, for he is now being questioned." Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/70), Al-Hakim (1/370), Al-Bayhaqi (4/56), and Abdullah bin Ahmad in "Zawa'id Al-Zuhd" (p. 129). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain," and Al-Dhahabi agreed: It is as they said. Al-Nawawi said (5/292): "Its chain is good." 108 - It is permissible to sit by it during the burial to remind those present of death and what comes after it, due to the hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib who said: "We went out with the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in a funeral of a man from the Ansar. We reached the grave and it had not yet been dug [the niche]. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) sat (facing the Qibla), and we sat around him as if birds were on our heads. In his hand was a stick with which he was scratching the ground. (He began looking at the sky and looking at the ground, and began raising his gaze and lowering it, three times). Then he said: Seek refuge in Allah from the punishment of the grave, twice or thrice. (Then he said: O Allah, I seek refuge in You from the punishment of the grave) (three times). Then he said: Indeed, the believing servant, when he is in departure from the world and approach to the Hereafter, angels descend to him from the sky, with white faces, as if their faces were the sun, having with them a shroud from the shrouds of Paradise, and Hanut (1) from the Hanut of Paradise, until they sit from him as far as the eye can see. Then the Angel of Death (peace be upon him) (2) comes
foot_note:
1. = "And implied from the speech of Imams of no verification is that it is a weak hadith, and acting upon it is an innovation (Bid'ah), and one should not be deceived by the large number of those who do it." I admire his saying: "And acting upon it is an innovation." This is a truth often overlooked by scholars, for they legislate many matters with such a hadith and deem them recommended relying on the rule "Weak hadith is acted upon in virtuous deeds," without noticing that its place is in what has been established by the Book and Sunnah as legitimate, not by the mere weak hadith. An example of this preceded in the commentary (p. 153). I recall that Imam Al-Shatibi has good words regarding this rule in "Al-Muwafaqat", so let it be reviewed. 
1. With Fath on the Mim (Hanut), it is what is mixed of perfumes for the shrouds of the dead and their bodies specifically. 
2. I say: This is his name in the Book and Sunnah (Angel of Death). As for naming him (Azrael), it has no basis, contrary to what is famous among people. Perhaps it is from the Israelite traditions (Isra'iliyyat)!

text: until he sits at his head and says: O good soul (and in a narration: reassured), come out to forgiveness from Allah and pleasure. He said: So it comes out flowing as a drop flows from the mouth of a waterskin, so he takes it. (In a narration: Until when his soul comes out, every angel between the heaven and earth and every angel in the heaven prays upon it, and the gates of heaven are opened for it; there is no people of a gate except they supplicate Allah that his soul ascends from their direction). When he takes it, he does not leave it in his hand for a blink of an eye until they take it and place it in that shroud and in that Hanut. (That is His saying: {Our messengers take him, and they do not fail} [Al-An'am: 61]). And there comes out from it like the scent of the best musk found on the face of the earth. He said: So they ascend with it, and they do not pass by - meaning with it - a group of angels except they say: What is this good soul? They say: So-and-so son of So-and-so - with the best of his names they used to name him with in the world, until they end with it to the lowest heaven. They ask for it to be opened, and it is opened for them. The close ones (angels) of every heaven accompany it to the heaven that follows it, until it ends with it to the seventh heaven. So Allah Almighty says: Write the book of My servant in Illiyyin, {And what can make you know what is Illiyyun? It is a register inscribed. Which is witnessed by those brought near} [Al-Mutaffifin: 19-21]. So his book is written in Illiyyin. Then it is said: Return him to the earth, for I (promised them that I) created them from it, and into it I return them, and from it I bring them out another time. He said: So (he is returned to the earth, and) his soul is returned to his body. (He said: For indeed he hears the sound of his companions' sandals when they turn away from him) (departing). Then two angels (severe in reprimand) come to him, so (they reprimand him, and) make him sit up and say to him: Who is your Lord? He says: My Lord is Allah. They say to him: What is your religion? He says: My religion is Islam. They say to him: What is this man who was sent among you? He says: He is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). They say to him: And what is your knowledge? He says: I read the Book of Allah and believed in it and attested to it. (So he reprimands him and says: Who is your Lord? What is your religion? Who is your Prophet? And it is the last trial presented to the believer. That is when Allah Almighty says {Allah keeps firm those who believe, with the firm word, in worldly life..}). So he says: My Lord is Allah, my religion is Islam, and my Prophet is Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). Then a caller calls from the heaven: My servant has spoken the truth, so furnish him from Paradise, clothe him from Paradise, and open for him a door to Paradise. He said: So its breeze and fragrance come to him, and his grave is expanded for him as far as his eye can see. He said: And there comes to him (in a narration: appears to him) a man with a handsome face, handsome clothes, and a good scent, who says: Rejoice with what pleases you, (rejoice with pleasure from Allah, and gardens in which is enduring bounty). This is your day which you were promised. He says to him: (And you, may Allah give you glad tidings
foot_note: None

text: of good), who are you? For your face is the face that brings good. He says: I am your righteous deed. (By Allah, I did not know you except quick in obedience to Allah, slow in disobedience to Allah, so may Allah reward you with good). Then a door from Paradise and a door from Hell are opened for him. It is said: This would have been your place had you disobeyed Allah; Allah has exchanged this for you instead of it. When he sees what is in Paradise, he says: My Lord, hasten the establishment of the Hour so that I may return to my family and wealth. (It is said to him: Rest). He said: And indeed the disbelieving servant (in a narration: the wicked) when he is in departure from the world and approach to the Hereafter, angels (harsh and severe) descend to him from the sky, black of faces, having with them Musuh (1) (from Hell). They sit from him as far as the eye can see. Then the Angel of Death comes until he sits at his head and says: O wicked soul, come out to anger from Allah and wrath. He said: So it scatters throughout his body, and he tears it out as the skewer (with many branches) is torn from wet wool, (cutting with it the veins and nerves). (Every angel between the heaven and earth and every angel in the heaven curses him, and the gates of heaven are closed. There is no people of a gate except they supplicate Allah that his soul does not ascend from their direction). So he takes it. When he takes it, he does not leave it in his hand for a blink of an eye until they put it in those Musuh. And there comes out from it like the most foul stench of a carcass found on the face of the earth. They ascend with it, and they do not pass by - meaning with it - a group of angels except they say: What is this wicked soul? They say: So-and-so son of So-and-so - with the ugliest of his names he used to be called by in the world, until he ends with it to the lowest heaven. He asks for it to be opened, but it is not opened for him. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) read: (The gates of Heaven will not be opened for them, nor will they enter Paradise until a camel enters into the eye of a needle) (2). So Allah Almighty says: Write his book in Sijjin, in the lowest earth. (Then it is said: Return My servant to the earth, for I promised them that I created them from it, and into it I return them, and from it I bring them out another time). So his soul is thrown (from the heaven) a throwing (until it falls into his body). Then he read {And whoever associates others with Allah - it is as though he had fallen from the sky and was snatched by the birds or the wind carried him down into a remote place} [Al-Hajj: 31]. So his soul is returned to his body. (He said: For indeed he hears the sound of his companions' sandals when they turn away from him). Then two angels (severe in reprimand) come to him, so (they reprimand him, and) make him sit up and say to him: Who is your Lord?

1. (1) Plural of Masah (Musuh), with Kasra on Mim. It is what is worn of hair weave on the body for austerity and suppressing the body. 
2. Meaning the hole of the needle. And the 'Jamal' refers to the known animal (camel), which is what has reached nine years.

text: (He says: Hah, Hah (1), I do not know. He says to him: What is your religion? He says: Hah, Hah, I do not know). They say: So what do you say about this man who was sent among you? But he does not find his name. It is said: Muhammad! He says: Hah, Hah, I do not know (I heard people saying that! He said: It is said: You did not know), (and you did not follow/recite). Then a caller calls from the heaven that he has lied, so furnish him from the Fire, and open for him a door to the Fire. So its heat and hot wind come to him, and his grave narrows upon him until his ribs interlock. And there comes to him (in a narration: appears to him) a man with an ugly face, ugly clothes, and a foul stench, who says: Receive tidings of what displeases you, this is your day which you were promised. He says (And you, may Allah give you tidings of evil), who are you? For your face is the face that brings evil? He says: I am your wicked deed? (By Allah, I did not know except that you were slow in obedience to Allah, quick to disobedience to Allah), (so may Allah reward you with evil. Then a blind, deaf, dumb [being] is assigned to him, holding a sledgehammer! If a mountain were struck with it, it would turn to dust. He strikes him a blow until he becomes dust, then Allah restores him as he was, then he strikes him another blow, and he screams a scream that everything hears except the two weightly beings [humans and jinn]. Then a door from the Fire is opened for him, and bedding from the Fire is spread). He says: Lord, do not establish the Hour." Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/281), Al-Hakim (1/37-40), Al-Tayalisi (No. 753), and Ahmad (4/287, 288, 288, 295, 296) - the context is his - and Al-Ajurri in "Al-Shari'ah" (367-370). Al-Nasa'i (1/282) and Ibn Majah (1/469-470) narrated the first part of it up to his saying: "As if birds were on our heads." It is a narration of Abu Dawud (2/70) in shorter form, and likewise Ahmad (4/297). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs." Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Ibn Al-Qayyim authenticated it in "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (1/214), "Tahdhib Al-Sunan" (4/337), and quoted its authentication from Abu Nu'aym and others (2).

text: 109 - It is permissible to exhume the dead from the grave for a valid reason, such as if he was buried before washing and shrouding and the like, due to the hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) came to Abdullah bin Ubayy after he had been placed in his hole (grave). He ordered him to be brought out, placed him on his knees, and blew some of his saliva on him, and clothed him in his shirt (Jabir said: And he prayed over him), and Allah knows best, (1) (And he had clothed Abbas in a shirt)." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/167) - the context with the last addition is his - Muslim (8/120), Al-Nasa'i (1/284) - the first addition is his - Ibn Al-Jarud (260), Al-Bayhaqi (3/402), and Ahmad (3/381) via the path of Amr bin Dinar who heard it from Jabir. It has another path: From Abu Al-Zubayr from Jabir who said: "When Abdullah bin Ubayy died, his son came to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, if you do not come to him, we will always be shamed by this. So the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) came to him and found he had been placed in his hole. He said: Why not before you placed him? So he was brought out of his hole, and he spat upon him from his head to his feet, and clothed him in his shirt." Narrated by Ahmad (3/371) and Al-Tahawi in "Al-Mushkil" (1/14/15) with a chain on the condition of Muslim, but Abu Al-Zubayr is a Mudallis and used 'an'anah. 110 - It is not recommended for a man to dig his grave before he dies, for neither the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) did

text: (15) Condolences (Ta'ziyah) 111 - It is prescribed to offer condolences to the family of the deceased (1). There are two hadiths regarding this: First: From Qurrah Al-Muzani (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) sat, a group of his companions would sit with him. Among them was a man who had a young son whom he would bring from behind his back and seat in front of him. (The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said to him: Do you love him? He said: O Messenger of Allah, may Allah love you as I love him!). Then he [the son] died, and the man refrained from attending the circle due to the memory of his son, and he grieved for him. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) missed him and said: Why do I not see So-and-so? They said: O Messenger of Allah, his little son whom you saw has died. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) met him and asked him about his son. He informed him that he had died. So he consoled him for him, then said: O So-and-so? Which is more beloved to you: that you enjoy him for your lifespan, or that you do not come tomorrow to any gate of the gates of Paradise except that you find he has preceded you to it and opens it for you? He said: O Prophet of Allah! Rather, that he precedes me to the gate of Paradise and opens it for me is more beloved to me. He said: Then that is for you. (A man (from the Ansar) said: O Messenger of Allah (may Allah make me your ransom), is it for him specifically or for all of us? He said: Rather, for all of you)." Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (1/296) - the context is his - Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", Al-Hakim (1/384), and Ahmad (5/35). Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain," and Al-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said.
foot_note: 1. (1) It is urging patience by promising reward, and supplicating for the deceased and the afflicted.

text: Al-Nasa'i also narrated it (1/264) similarly, as did Al-Bayhaqi (4/59 & 60) except that he did not mention its beginning fully, and he has all the additions up to the first one. The hadith has a witness in "Al-Majma" (3/10). Second: From Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) who said: "Whoever consoles his believing brother in his affliction, Allah will clothe him in a green garment by which he will be envied (honored) on the Day of Resurrection. It was said: O Messenger of Allah, what is 'yujbar' (honored)? He said: He will be envied (yughbat)." Narrated by Al-Khatib in "Tarikh Baghdad" (7/397) and Ibn Asakir in "Tarikh Dimashq" (15/91 / 1). It has a witness from Talhah bin Ubaidullah bin Kurayz as a Maqtu' narration. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4/164). It is a Hasan (good) hadith with the sum of the two paths as I clarified in "Irwa' Al-Ghalil fi Takhrij Ahadith Manar Al-Sabil" No. (756). Know that relying on these two hadiths - especially the first one - for condolences is better than relying on the hadith: "Whoever consoles an afflicted person has the like of his reward," even though the majority of authors followed it, because it is a weak hadith from all its paths as explained by Al-Nawawi in "Al-Majmu'" (5/305) and Al-Asqalani in "Al-Talkhis" (5/251) and in "Irwa' Al-Ghalil" (No. 757). 112 - He should console them with what he thinks will comfort them, restrain their grief, and encourage them to contentment and patience, from what is established from him (peace be upon him), if he knows and recalls it. Otherwise, with whatever good words are easy for him that achieve the purpose and do not contradict the Sharia. There are hadiths regarding this: First: From Usama bin Zaid who said: "Some of his daughters sent to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him): That a son of hers, or a daughter (in a narration: Umaymah bint Zainab) (1) was dying, so witness us. He said: He sent to her conveying the Salam and saying:
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: Then this Umaymah (or Umamah) lived until Ali married her after Fatima (may Allah be pleased with them).

text: "Indeed, to Allah belongs what He took, and to (Allah) belongs what He gave, and everything with Him has an appointed term. So let her be patient and seek reward." She sent swearing upon him (to come to her). So he stood up, and we stood up. The boy was lifted to the lap - or in the lap - of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), and his soul was rattling (as if it were in a dried skin). In the group were Sa'd bin Ubadah, (Mu'adh bin Jabal), Ubayy (bin Ka'b) I think, (and Zaid bin Thabit, and men). The eyes of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) overflowed. Sa'd said to him: What is this, O Messenger of Allah (when you have forbidden weeping)? He said: (Indeed) This is a mercy that Allah places in the hearts of whomever He wills of His servants, and Allah is only merciful to those of His servants who are merciful." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/120-122), Muslim (3/39), Abu Dawud (2/58), Al-Nasa'i (1/263), Ibn Majah (1/280), Al-Bayhaqi (4/65-68-69), and Ahmad (5/204, 206-207). The context is his, as is the second narration. The first, seventh, and eighth additions are all in Al-Bayhaqi. The second addition is in the two Sheikhs, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Bayhaqi. The third is in them. Likewise the fourth and fifth in all except Muslim. The sixth is in Al-Bukhari and Al-Nasa'i. I say: This formula of condolence, although narrated regarding someone approaching death, condolences with it for someone who has already died is more appropriate by indication of the text. For this reason, Al-Nawawi said in "Al-Adhkar" and elsewhere: "This hadith is the best thing to give condolences with." Second: From Buraydah bin Al-Husaib who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to check on the Ansar, visit them, and ask about them. He was informed about a woman from the Ansar whose son died and she had no other, and that she grieved over him intensely. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) came to her (with his companions. When he reached the woman's door, it was said to the woman: The Prophet of Allah wants to enter to console her. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) entered and said: It has reached me that you grieved over your son. He commanded her to fear Allah and be patient. She said: O Messenger of Allah (why should I not grieve when) I am a *Raqub* woman who does not give birth, and I had no other? The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: The *Raqub* is the one whose child survives. Then he said:
foot_note: None

text: There is no Muslim man or woman who has three children die [and seeks reward for them] except that Allah enters him into Paradise by them. Umar [who was on the right of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him)] said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, what about two? He said: And two). Narrated by Al-Hakim (1/384) who said: (Authentic chain), and Al-Dhahabi agreed. I say: Rather, it is on the condition of Muslim, for all its narrators are narrators of his Sahih, but one of them has weakness due to his memory. However, his hadith does not fall below the rank of Hasan. The hadith was cited by Al-Haythami in (Al-Majma') (3/8) with similar wording and the additions are from it. He said: (Narrated by Al-Bazzar and its narrators are narrators of the Sahih). Third: His saying (peace be upon him) when he entered upon Umm Salama (may Allah be pleased with her) after the death of Abu Salama: (O Allah, forgive Abu Salama, raise his degree among the guided, grant him a successor in his descendants among those who remain, forgive us and him, O Lord of the Worlds, make his grave spacious, and fill it with light for him). Narrated by Muslim and others, and it passed fully in Issue (17) (p. 12). Fourth: His saying (peace be upon him) in his condolence to Abdullah bin Ja'far regarding his father: (O Allah, replace Ja'far in his family, and bless Abdullah in the transaction of his right hand, he said it three times). Narrated by Ahmad with an authentic chain during a hadith that will come fully in the next issue (1). 113 - Condolence is not limited to three days not to be exceeded. Rather, whenever he sees a benefit in condolence, he should perform it. It is established from him (peace be upon him) that he gave condolences after three days in the hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said:
foot_note: 1. (1) There are other hadiths regarding condolences which I ignored due to their weakness. I have clarified that in (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad), including the hadith of the Prophet (peace be upon him) writing to Mu'adh bin Jabal consoling him on the death of his son, which is fabricated (Mawdu') as stated by Al-Dhahabi, Al-Asqalani, and others. Al-Shawkani overlooked this and was followed by Siddiq Hasan Khan, so they declared it Hasan following Al-Hakim! Do not be deceived by that, for every steed has a stumble, nay, stumbles.

text: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent an army and appointed Zaid bin Harithah over them and said: If Zaid is killed or martyred, then your commander is Ja'far. If he is killed or martyred, then your commander is Abdullah bin Rawahah. They met the enemy, and Zaid took the banner and fought until he was killed. Then Ja'far took the banner and fought until he was killed. Then Abdullah took it and fought until he was killed. Then Khalid bin Al-Walid took the banner and Allah granted him victory. The news reached the Prophet (peace be upon him), so he went out to the people, praised Allah and extolled Him, and said: Your brothers met the enemy. Zaid took the banner and fought until he was killed and martyred. Then... then... then Khalid bin Al-Walid, a sword of the swords of Allah, took the banner and Allah granted him victory. So he waited, then gave the family of Ja'far three days respite to come to them. Then he came to them and said: Do not weep for my brother after today. Call for me the sons of my brother. He said: We were brought like chicks. He said: Call the barber for me. The barber was brought and he shaved our heads. Then he said: As for Muhammad, he resembles our uncle Abu Talib. And as for Abdullah, he resembles my creation and character. Then he took my hand and raised it and said: O Allah, replace Ja'far in his family, and bless Abdullah in the transaction of his right hand, he said it three times. He said: Our mother came and mentioned our orphanhood to him, and began to express grief (1) to him. He said: Is it poverty you fear for them while I am their guardian in this world and the Hereafter!?). Narrated by Ahmad (No. 1750) with an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. From his path, Al-Hakim (3/298) narrated a piece of it. Abu Dawud and Al-Nasa'i narrated from it the story of the three days respite with the shaving. Part of it preceded in Issue (18) (p. 21). Al-Hakim said: (Authentic chain), and Al-Dhahabi agreed. The hadith has a witness mentioned in Al-Musnad (3/467) containing weakness. A group of Imam Ahmad's companions held the view we mentioned that condolence is not limited by a time limit, as in (Al-Insaf) (2/564). It is also a view in the Shafi'i school. They said: Because the purpose is supplication, urging patience, and forbidding discontent, and that is achieved over a long time. Imam Al-Haramain narrated it, and Abu Al-Abbas Ibn Al-Qass of their Imams asserted it definitively. Although some objected to him, that was based on the well-known view of the Madhhab, not the evidence. See (Al-Majmu') (5/306).
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning she was grieving him and making him sad, from 'afraha' meaning to distress and remove joy, and debt 'afraha' meaning it burdened him.

text: 114 - Two matters should be avoided even if people habitually do them: A - Gathering for condolences in a specific place like the house, graveyard, or mosque. B - The family of the deceased preparing food to host those coming for condolences.
