This is due to the hadith of Jarir bin Abdullah Al-Bajali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: (We used to count (and in a narration: consider) (1) gathering at the deceased's family, and making food after his burial as wailing [Niyahah]). Narrated by Ahmad (No. 6905) and Ibn Majah (1/490) - the other narration is his. Its chain is authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs. Al-Nawawi (5/320) and Al-Busiri in (Al-Zawa'id) authenticated it. 115 - The Sunnah is rather for the relatives and neighbors of the deceased to make food for the deceased's family that satisfies them, due to the hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: (When the news of Ja'far's death came when he was killed, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: Make food for the family of Ja'far, for there has come to them a matter that occupies them, or there has come to them what occupies them). Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/59), Al-Tirmidhi (2/134) who graded it Hasan, Ibn Majah (1/490), as well as Al-Shafi'i in (Al-Umm) (1/247), Al-Daraqutni (194, 197), Al-Hakim (1/372), Al-Bayhaqi (4/61), and Ahmad (1/175). Al-Hakim said:
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu') (5/306): (As for sitting for condolences, Al-Shafi'i, the author [Al-Shirazi], and all the companions explicitly stated its dislike (Karahah). They said: By sitting for it, they mean that the family of the deceased gathers in a house so those who want to offer condolences come to them. They said: Rather, they should go about their needs, and whoever meets them consoles them. There is no difference between men and women in the dislike of sitting for it). The text of Imam Al-Shafi'i referred to by Al-Nawawi is in the book (Al-Umm) (1/248): (And I dislike the gathering places for mourning (Ma'atim), which is the gathering, even if they do not have crying, for that renews grief and imposes costs, along with the narration passed regarding it). It seems he refers to this hadith of Jarir. Al-Nawawi said: (The author and others used another proof for it, which is that it is an innovation). Similarly, Ibn Al-Humam stated in Sharh Al-Hidayah (1/473) the dislike of hosting a feast of food from the deceased's family and said: (It is an ugly innovation). This is the Hanbali school as in (Al-Insaf) (2/565).

text: (Authentic chain). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Ibn Al-Sakan also authenticated it, as in (Al-Talkhis) (5/253). In my view, it is a Hasan hadith as Al-Tirmidhi said, for it has a witness from the hadith of Asma bint Umays, and I have clarified that in (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad). And (Aisha used to order Talbinah for the sick and for the one grieving over a deceased person, and she used to say: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: (The Talbinah soothes (1) the heart of the sick and removes some of the grief). Narrated by Al-Bukhari (10/119-120) - wording is his - Muslim (7/26), Al-Bayhaqi (4/61), and Ahmad (6/155). (2) 116 - It is recommended to wipe the head of the orphan and honor him, due to the hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far who said: (If you had seen me, Qutham, and Ubaidullah bin Abbas when we were children playing, when the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) passed by on a mount and said: Lift this one to me. He said: He carried me in front of him. And he said regarding Qutham: Lift this one to me. So he carried him behind him. Ubaidullah was more beloved to Abbas than Qutham, but he did not feel shy from his uncle to carry Qutham and leave him. He said: Then he wiped my head three times and said every time he wiped: O Allah, replace Ja'far in his son. He said: I said to Abdullah: What happened to Qutham? He said: He was martyred. He said: I said: Allah and His Messenger know best about the good. He said: Yes). Narrated by Ahmad (1760) - context is his - Al-Hakim (1/372), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/60). Its chain is Hasan. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic) and Al-Dhahabi agreed. What benefits the deceased 117 - The deceased benefits from the action of others in several matters: First: The supplication of a Muslim for him, if the conditions of acceptance are met, due to the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted:
foot_note:
1. (1) Meaning comforts it. Talbinah: A broth made from flour or bran, and sometimes honey is put in it. 
2. Imam Al-Shafi'i said in (Al-Umm) (1/247): (I like for the neighbors of the deceased or relatives to make food for the family of the deceased on the day he dies and his night that satisfies them, for that is Sunnah and a noble remembrance. It is from the action of the people of good before us and after us). Then he cited the mentioned hadith from Abdullah bin Ja'far.

text: (And those who came after them say: 'Our Lord, forgive us and our brothers who preceded us in faith and put not in our hearts [any] resentment toward those who have believed. Our Lord, indeed You are Kind and Merciful.') [Surah Al-Hashr 10]. As for the hadiths, they are very numerous. Some have passed, and some will come in [the section on] visiting graves, and the Prophet's supplication for them and his command for that. Among them is his saying (peace be upon him): (The supplication of a Muslim man for his brother in his absence is answered. At his head is an entrusted angel; whenever he supplicates for his brother with good, the angel entrusted with him says: Amen, and for you the like). Narrated by Muslim (8/86, 87) - context is his - Abu Dawud (1/240), and Ahmad (6/452) from the hadith of Abu Darda. Indeed, the funeral prayer itself is largely a witness to that, because most of it is supplication for the deceased and seeking forgiveness for him, as previously explained. Second: The guardian (Wali) of the deceased making up the fast of a vow (Nadhr) on his behalf. There are hadiths regarding this: First: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (Whoever dies and has fasting due upon him, his guardian fasts on his behalf). Narrated by Al-Bukhari (4/156), Muslim (3/155), and Abu Dawud (1/376). From his path Al-Bayhaqi (6/279), Al-Tahawi in Mushkil Al-Athar (3/140, 141), and Ahmad (6/69). Second: From Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him): (That a woman rode the sea and vowed that if Allah, Blessed and Exalted, saved her, she would fast a month. Allah, Mighty and Majestic, saved her, but she did not fast until she died. A female relative of hers [either her sister or daughter] came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and mentioned that to him. He said: [Do you see if she had a debt, would you pay it off? She said: Yes. He said: Then the debt of Allah is more deserving to be paid], [so] pay it off [on behalf of your mother]). Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/81), Al-Nasa'i (2/143), Al-Tahawi (3/140), Al-Bayhaqi (4/255, 256, 10/85), Al-Tayalisi (2630), and Ahmad (1861, 1970, 3137, 3224, 3420). The context with the second addition belongs to him, and its chain is [authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs. The first addition belongs to Abu Dawud and Al-Bayhaqi.
foot_note: None

text: It was narrated by Al-Bukhari (4/158-159), Muslim (3/156), Al-Tirmidhi (2/42-43) who authenticated it, and Ibn Majah (1/535) similarly. They all have the second addition, and Muslim has the last one. Third: From him also. (That Sa'd bin Ubadah (may Allah be pleased with him) asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) for a verdict saying: My mother died and she had a vow upon her? He said: Fulfill it on her behalf). Narrated by Al-Bukhari (5/400, 494), Muslim (6/76), Abu Dawud (2/81), Al-Nasa'i (2/130, 144), Al-Tirmidhi (2/375) who authenticated it, Al-Bayhaqi (4/256, 6/278, 10/85), Al-Tayalisi (2717), and Ahmad (1893, 3049, 6/47) (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: These hadiths explicitly indicate the legitimacy of the guardian fasting on behalf of the deceased for the fast of a vow. However, the first hadith, by its generality, indicates something additional to that, which is that he fasts for him the obligatory fast [Ramadan] as well. The Shafi'is held this view, and it is the school of Ibn Hazm (7/2, 8) and others. The Hanbalis held the first view [only vows], and it is the text of Imam Ahmad. Abu Dawud said in (Al-Masa'il) (96): (I heard Ahmad bin Hanbal say: One does not fast for the dead except in a vow). His followers interpreted the first hadith as referring to the fast of a vow, evidenced by what Amrah narrated: That her mother died and she had [fasts] from Ramadan due. She asked Aisha: Shall I make it up for her? She said: No, but give charity on her behalf in place of every day, half a Sa' for every poor person. Narrated by Al-Tahawi (3/142) and Ibn Hazm (7/4) - wording is his - with a chain Ibn Al-Turkumani said is: (Authentic). Al-Bayhaqi weakened it, then Al-Asqalani. If they meant weakening it from this specific route, there is no basis for it, and if they meant another, it does not harm it. And evidenced by what Saeed bin Jubayr narrated from Ibn Abbas who said: (If a man falls ill in Ramadan then dies and did not fast, food is given on his behalf and he does not have to make it up. If he had a vow upon him, his guardian makes it up for him). Narrated by Abu Dawud with an authentic chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs. It has another route similar to it in Ibn Hazm (7/7) who authenticated its chain. And it has a third route in Al-Tahawi (3/142), but it appears something fell from its text from the scribe or printer, corrupting the meaning. I say: This detailed explanation adopted by the Mother of the Believers and the Ink of the Nation Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them), and followed by the Imam of the Sunnah Ahmad bin Hanbal, is what the soul finds tranquility in and the chest opens to. It is the fairest of opinions on this issue and the most moderate. It involves acting upon all the hadiths without rejecting any of them, with the correct understanding of them, especially the first one. The Mother of the Believers did not understand from it that absolute generality covering the fast of Ramadan, and she is its narrator. It is established that the narrator of a hadith knows best the meaning of what they narrated, especially if what they understood agrees with the rules and principles of Sharia, as is the case here. The verifier Ibn Al-Qayyim (may Allah have mercy on him) clarified this, saying in (I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in) (3/554) after mentioning the hadith and authenticating it: =

text: Third: Paying off the debt on his behalf by any person, whether a guardian or otherwise. There are many hadiths regarding this, many of which were previously mentioned in Issue (17). Fourth: The righteous deeds performed by the righteous child; the parents have the like of his reward, without anything diminishing from his reward, because the child is from their striving and earning. Allah the Mighty and Majestic says: {And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives} [Al-Najm: 39]. And the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: (The best of what a man eats is from his earnings, and indeed his child is from his earnings). Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/108), Al-Nasa'i (2/211), Al-Tirmidhi (2/287) who graded it Hasan, Al-Darimi (2/247), Ibn Majah (2/2 - 430), Al-Hakim (2/46), Al-Tayalisi (1580), and Ahmad (6/41, 126, 127, 162, 173, 193, 201, 202, 220). Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs), and Al-Dhahabi agreed, which is an error from several aspects that there is no space to explain. It has a witness from the hadith of Abdullah bin Amr. Narrated by Abu Dawud, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad (2/179, 204, 214) with a good chain. What the verse and hadith indicate is supported by specific hadiths regarding the parent benefiting from the deed of his righteous child, such as charity, fasting, manumission, and the like. They are:
foot_note: 1. = (A group took this on its generality and absolute nature, and said: The vow and the obligatory [Ramadan] fast are fasted for him. Another group refused that and said: Neither vow nor obligation is fasted for him. A group differentiated and said: The vow is fasted for him but not the original obligation. This is the saying of Ibn Abbas and his companions, and it is the correct one, because the obligation of fasting runs the course of prayer. Just as no one prays for anyone, and no one becomes Muslim for anyone, likewise fasting. As for the vow, it is a commitment in the dhimmah (liability) similar to a debt, so the guardian's payment of it is accepted just as he pays his debt. This is pure jurisprudence. The consistent application of this is that Hajj is not performed for him, nor Zakat paid for him unless he was excused in delaying it, just as the guardian feeds on behalf of one who broke the fast in Ramadan due to an excuse. As for the one who breaks the fast without any excuse at all, the performance of others for the obligations of Allah that he neglected does not benefit him. He was the one commanded with them as a test and trial, not the guardian. So the repentance of one does not benefit another, nor his Islam for him, nor the performance of prayer for him, nor other obligations of Allah Almighty that he neglected until he died). I say: Ibn Al-Qayyim (may Allah have mercy on him) further clarified and verified this discussion in (Tahdhib Al-Sunan) (3/279-282), so refer to it for it is important.

text: First: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her). (That a man said: My mother died suddenly (1) [and did not make a will], and I think if she had spoken she would have given charity. Will she have a reward if I give charity on her behalf [and will I have a reward]? He said: Yes, [so give charity on her behalf]). Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/198, 5/399-400), Muslim (3/81, 5/73), Malik in (Al-Muwatta) (2/228), Abu Dawud (2/15), Al-Nasa'i (2/129), Ibn Majah (2/160), Al-Bayhaqi (4/62, 6/277-278), and Ahmad (6/51). The context belongs to Al-Bukhari in one of his narrations, and the last addition belongs to him in the other narration, and Ibn Majah; he has the second addition, and Muslim has the first. Second: From Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him). (That Sa'd bin Ubadah - the brother of Banu Sa'idah - his mother passed away while he was absent from her. He said: O Messenger of Allah, my mother passed away while I was absent from her. Will it benefit her if I give something in charity on her behalf? He said: Yes. He said: Then I make you witness that my fruit-bearing garden (Mikhraf) (2) is charity on her behalf). Narrated by Al-Bukhari (5/297, 301, 307), Abu Dawud (2/15), Al-Nasa'i (2/130), Al-Tirmidhi (2/25), Al-Bayhaqi (6/278), and Ahmad (3080 - 3504 - 3508). The context is his. Third: From Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him): (That a man said to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him): My father died and left wealth and did not make a will. Will it expiate for him if I give charity on his behalf? He said: Yes). Narrated by Muslim (5/73), Al-Nasa'i (2/129), Ibn Majah (2/160), Al-Bayhaqi (6/278), and Ahmad (2/371). Fourth: From Abdullah bin Amr: (That Al-Aas bin Wa'il Al-Sahmi willed that a hundred slaves be freed on his behalf. His son Hisham freed fifty
foot_note:
1. (1) With Damma on the Ta' and Kasra on the Lam (Uftulitat), passive voice, meaning snatched away, i.e., died suddenly. 
2. Meaning fruitful, named so because fruit is harvested (yukhrafu) from it.

text: slaves, and his son Amr wanted to free the remaining fifty on his behalf. He said: Until I ask the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). So he came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, my father willed that a hundred slaves be freed on his behalf. Hisham freed fifty on his behalf, and fifty remain upon him. Shall I free them on his behalf? The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (If he was a Muslim and you freed slaves on his behalf, or gave charity on his behalf, or performed Hajj on his behalf, that would reach him. (And in a narration): If he had acknowledged Monotheism (Tawhid) and you fasted and gave charity on his behalf, that would benefit him). (1) (Narrated by Abu Dawud at the end of (Wills) (2/15) and Al-Bayhaqi (6/279) - the context is his - and Ahmad (No. 6704) - the other narration is his. Their chain is good (Hasan).
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Shawkani said in (Nayl Al-Awtar) (4/79): (The hadiths of the chapter indicate that charity from the child reaches the parents after their death without a will from them, and its reward reaches them. Thus, the generality of His saying: (And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives) is specified by these hadiths. But the hadiths of the chapter only contain the reaching of charity from the child, and it is established that a person's child is from his striving, so there is no need to claim specification. As for from other than the child, the apparent meaning from the Quranic generalities is that its reward does not reach the deceased. So one should stop at that until evidence necessitating its specification comes). I say: This is the truth necessitated by scientific rules, that the Verse is on its generality and that the reward of charity and other things reaches from the child to the parent because he is from his striving, unlike other than the child. However, Al-Nawawi and others reported Consensus (Ijma') that charity counts for the deceased and its reward reaches him. They said (the deceased) generally and did not restrict it to the parent. If this Consensus is valid, it would be a specifier for the generalities Al-Shawkani pointed to regarding charity, and everything else would remain under the generality, like fasting, Quran recitation, and similar acts of worship. But I am in great doubt regarding the validity of the mentioned Consensus, for two reasons: First: That Consensus in the technical sense cannot be realized in other than matters known from religion by necessity, as verified by prominent scholars like Ibn Hazm in (Usul Al-Ahkam), Al-Shawkani in (Irshad Al-Fuhul), Professor Abdul Wahhab Khallaf in his book (Usul Al-Fiqh), and others. Imam Ahmad pointed to this in his famous statement refuting those who claim Consensus - narrated from him by his son Abdullah bin Ahmad in (Al-Masa'il). Second: That I have reviewed many issues in which they reported Consensus, and found disagreement in them to be known! Rather, I saw the majority opinion contrary to the claim of Consensus in them. If I wanted to list examples of that, the discussion would be long and we would deviate from our subject. Suffice it now to mention one example, which is Al-Nawawi reporting Consensus that funeral prayer is not disliked in the disliked times! Yet the disagreement on it is old and known, and most people of knowledge hold the contrary to the alleged Consensus, as previously verified in Issue (87). Another nearby example will come for you, God willing. =

text: Fifth: What he leaves behind of righteous traces and ongoing charities (Sadaqah Jariyah), due to the saying of the Blessed and Exalted: {We record what they have put forth and their traces} [Ya-Sin: 12]. There are hadiths regarding this:
foot_note: 1. = Some went to drawing an analogy between non-parents and parents. This is an invalid analogy for several reasons: First: It contradicts Quranic generalities like His saying {And whoever purifies himself only purifies himself for [the benefit of] his own soul} [Fatir: 18] and other verses that link success and entering Paradise to righteous deeds. There is no doubt that the parent purifies himself by raising his child and caring for him, so he has his reward, unlike others. Second: It is an analogy with a discrepancy (Qiyas ma'a al-fariq) if you remember that the Lawgiver made the child from the parent's earning as in the hadith of Aisha, so he is not an earning for others. Allah the Mighty and Majestic says: {Every soul, for what it has earned, will be retained} [Al-Muddathir: 38] and says {For it is what it has earned, and against it is what it has committed} [Al-Baqarah: 286]. Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in the interpretation of His saying {And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives} [Al-Najm: 39]: (Meaning just as he does not bear the burden of another, likewise he does not attain reward except what he himself earned. From this noble verse, Al-Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) and those who followed him deduced that the gift of the reward of recitation does not reach the dead because it is not from their deed nor their earning. For this reason, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did not recommend it to his nation, nor urged them to it, nor guided them to it by text or indication. Nor was that reported from any of the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them). If it were good, they would have preceded us to it. The chapter of acts of worship is restricted to texts and is not handled with types of analogies and opinions). Al-Izz bin Abd al-Salam said in (Al-Fatawa) (24/2 - year 1692): (Whoever performs an act of obedience to Allah Almighty, then gifts its reward to a living or dead person, its reward does not transfer to him, since {there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives}. If he initiates the obedience intending it to fall on behalf of the deceased, it does not fall on his behalf, except in what the Sharia excluded like charity, fasting, and Hajj). What Ibn Kathir mentioned from Al-Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) is the opinion of most scholars and a group of Hanafis as quoted by Al-Zubaidi in (Sharh Al-Ihya) (10/369). * Third: That if this analogy were correct, it would imply the recommendation of gifting reward to the dead. If it were so, the Salaf would have done it, because they are more eager for reward than us without doubt, yet they did not do that as per Ibn Kathir's words. This indicates that the mentioned analogy is incorrect, which is the point. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat Al-Ilmiyyah) (p. 54): (It was not the habit of the Salaf that if they prayed a voluntary prayer, or fasted a voluntary fast, or performed a voluntary Hajj, or read the Quran, they would gift the reward of that to the Muslims' dead. So one should not deviate from the path of the Salaf for it is better and more complete). The Sheikh (may Allah have mercy on him) has another opinion on the issue, in which he contradicted what he mentioned just now about the Salaf, where he held that the deceased benefits from all acts of worship from others! Ibn Al-Qayyim (may Allah have mercy on him) adopted this view and supported it in his book (Al-Ruh) with what does not stand up from analogy which we clarified the invalidity of shortly before. That is contrary to what we knew of him (may Allah have mercy on him) regarding avoiding expansion in = _________ - * I say: From what preceded you learn the invalidity of the Consensus mentioned by Ibn Qudamah in (Al-Mughni) (2/569) on the arrival of the reward of recitation to the dead. How can it not be invalid when Imam Al-Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) is at the forefront of the dissenters? This is another example of what Consensus was claimed in while it is incorrect, and attention has been drawn to this recently.

text: First: From Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said:
foot_note: 1. = Analogy in purely devotional matters, especially what was contrary to what the Righteous Salaf (may Allah be pleased with them) practiced. The scholar Sayyid Muhammad Rashid Rida summarized his words in (Tafsir Al-Manar) (8/254-270) then refuted him with a good, strong refutation. Let whoever wishes to expand on the issue refer to it. Many innovators have exploited this saying and used it as a pretext to fight the Sunnah, arguing with the Sheikh and his student against the helpers of the Sunnah and its followers. Those innovators ignored or pretended to ignore that the helpers of the Sunnah do not imitate a specific man in the religion of Allah Almighty as those do! Nor do they prefer over the truth that has become clear to them the saying of any scholar, no matter how good their belief in his knowledge and righteousness is. They only look at the saying, not the speaker, and at the evidence, not imitation, keeping before their eyes the saying of the Imam of the abode of Hijrah: (There is no one among us except he refutes and is refuted, except the owner of this grave)! And he said: (Everyone's saying is taken or rejected except the owner of this grave). If it is accepted among the people of knowledge that every belief or opinion one adopts in this life has an effect on his behavior, if good then good, and if evil then evil, then it is also accepted that the effect indicates the effector, and that one of them is linked to the other, good or evil as we mentioned. Based on this, we do not doubt that this saying has a bad effect on whoever holds or adopts it. For example, its holder relies on others to obtain reward and high ranks, knowing that people gift good deeds hundreds of times a day to all living and dead Muslims, and he is one of them. So why shouldn't he dispense with his own striving and earning by relying on others' deeds! Do you not see, for example, that some Sheikhs who live on the earnings of some of their students do not strive themselves to obtain their daily sustenance by the sweat of their brow and the toil of their right hand! The only reason for that is they dispensed with that by others' earnings! So they relied on it and left work. This is an observed matter in material things, comprehensible in spiritual things as is the case in this issue. Would that it stopped there and did not exceed to what is more dangerous. There is a saying permitting Hajj on behalf of others even if not excused, like most rich people who abandon obligations. This opinion leads them to be lenient regarding Hajj and neglecting it, because he rationalizes it and says inwardly: They will perform Hajj for me after my death! Indeed, there is something even more harmful, which is the saying of the obligation to drop prayer [by payment/fidya] for the deceased who abandoned it! This is one of the major factors for some Muslims abandoning prayer, because he rationalizes that people will drop it for him after his death! To other sayings whose bad effect on society is not hidden. It is obligatory on the scholar who wants reform to discard these sayings for contradicting the texts of Sharia and its good objectives. Compare the effect of these sayings with the effect of the saying of those who stop at the texts and do not exit them by interpretation or analogy; you will find the difference as [clear as] the sun. For he who does not take such referred opinions cannot rely on others for deed and reward, because he sees that nothing saves him except his deed, and he has no reward except what he himself strove for. Rather, it is expected of him to strive as much as possible to leave behind a good trace whose reward comes to him while he is alone in his grave, instead of those illusory good deeds. This is one of the many reasons for the advancement of the Salaf and our backwardness, and Allah's victory for them and His forsaking of us. We ask Allah Almighty to guide us as He guided them, and grant us victory as He granted them victory.

text: (When a human being dies, his deed is cut off (1) except from three [things]: except from ongoing charity, or knowledge that is benefited from, or a righteous child (2) who prays for him). Narrated by Muslim (5/73) - context is his - Al-Bukhari in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) (p. 8), Abu Dawud (2/15), Al-Nasa'i (2/129), Al-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil) (1/85), Al-Bayhaqi (6/278), and Ahmad (2/372). The addition is for Abu Dawud and Al-Bayhaqi. Second: From Abu Qatadah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (The best of what a man leaves behind him are three: a righteous child who prays for him, a charity which runs [continues] and its reward reaches him, and knowledge which is acted upon after him). Narrated by Ibn Majah (1/106), Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) (No. 84, 85), Al-Tabarani in (Al-Mu'jam Al-Saghir) (p. 79), and Ibn Abd al-Barr in (Jami' Bayan al-Ilm) (1/15). Its chain is authentic as Al-Mundhiri said in (Al-Targhib) (1/58). Third: From Abu Huraira also who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (Indeed, among what follows the believer of his deed and good deeds after his death are: knowledge he taught and spread, a righteous child he left, a copy of the Quran (Mushaf) he bequeathed, a mosque he built, a house for the wayfarer he built, a river he caused to flow, or a charity he brought out from his wealth during his health and life; it follows him after his death).
foot_note:
1. (1) Meaning the benefit of his deed and the renewal of his reward. Al-Khattabi said in (Al-Ma'alim): (In it is evidence that fasting, prayer, and what falls under their meaning of physical actions do not accept deputation. It may be used as evidence by those who hold that if someone performs Hajj for a deceased, the Hajj is in reality for the Hajji (performer) not the one performed for, but the supplication reaches him [the deceased], and he has the reward in the money he gave if Hajj was performed for him with money). 
2. Restricted by 'righteous' because reward is not obtained from other than that. As for the burden, it does not attach to the parent from his child's sin if his intention was to achieve good. Mentioning supplication for him is to urge supplication for the father, not because it is a restriction, for the reward is obtained for the parent from his righteous child whenever he does a righteous deed, whether he supplicated for his father or not, like one who plants a tree gets reward from eating its fruit whether the eater supplicated for him or not. Likewise the mother. Thus in (Mabariq Al-Azhar fi Sharh Mashariq Al-Anwar) by Ibn Al-Malik.

text_en:
Reported by Ibn Mājah (1/106) with a good chain, and also narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah in his Ṣaḥīḥ, and al-Bayhaqī as stated by al-Mundhirī. Fourth: From Jurrīr ibn ‘Abdullāh (may Allah be pleased with him), he said: “We were with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ at the beginning of the day when some barefooted, naked men from Muḍar came, wearing only swords, all of them from Muḍar. The face of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ changed when he saw their poverty. He entered, then came out, and ordered Bilāl to call to prayer and perform the Ẓuhr prayer. Then he ascended a small pulpit and delivered a sermon, praising Allah and extolling Him. He said: ‘As for what follows, Allah has revealed in His Book: “O mankind, fear your Lord who created you from a single soul and created from it its mate, and dispersed from both many men and women. And fear Allah through whom you ask one another, and [respect] the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever Watchful over you” [al-Nisā’: 1]. And the verse in al-Ḥashr: “[O you who believe, fear Allah. Let every soul look to what it has sent forth for tomorrow. And fear Allah. Indeed Allah is Acquainted with what you do]” [al-Ḥashr: 18], “[And be not like those who forgot Allah, so He made them forget themselves. Those are the defiantly disobedient]… [The companions of the Fire are not equal to the companions of Paradise; the companions of Paradise are the successful]” [al-Ḥashr: 19–20].’ 

He encouraged giving charity before it is too late. A man gave from his dinar, his dirham, his clothing, a sa‘ of barley, a sa‘ of dates, until the Prophet ﷺ said: ‘Let no one belittle any act of charity,’ even if it is half a date. The people delayed until the anger appeared on his face. Then a man from the Ansār gave a bowl [of gold in some narrations], which he could hardly hold, and handed it to the Prophet ﷺ on the pulpit, saying: ‘O Messenger of Allah, this is in the way of Allah.’ The Prophet ﷺ accepted it. Abu Bakr then stood and gave, followed by ‘Umar, then the Muhājirūn and Ansār, giving continuously. I saw heaps of food and clothing, and the face of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ lit up as if it shone like gold. The Prophet ﷺ said: ‘Whoever introduces a good practice in Islam will have its reward and the reward of those who act upon it after him, without diminishing their reward. And whoever introduces a bad practice in Islam will bear its burden.’
text_ar: أخرجه ابن ماجه (1/ 106) بإسناد حسن، ورواه ابن خزيمة في (صحيحه) أيضا والبيهقي كما قال المنذري. الرابع: عن جرير بن عبد الله رضي الله عنه قال: (كنا عند رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم في صدر النهار، فجاءه أقوام حفاة عراة مجتابي النمار أو العباء، متقلدي السيوف، [وليس عليهم أزر ولا شئ غيرها] عامتهم من مضر، بل كلهم من مضر، فتمعر (وفي رواية: فتغير - ومعناهما واحد) وجه رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم لما رأى بهم من الفاقة، فدخل، ثم خرج، فأمر بلالا فأذن وصلى [الظهر، ثم صعد منبرا صغيرا]، ثم خطب [فحمد الله وأثنى عليه] فقال: [أما بعد فإن الله أنزل في كتابه]: {يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ اتَّقُوا رَبَّكُمُ الَّذِي خَلَقَكُمْ مِنْ نَفْسٍ وَاحِدَةٍ وَخَلَقَ مِنْهَا زَوْجَهَا وَبَثَّ مِنْهُمَا رِجَالًا كَثِيرًا وَنِسَاءً وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ الَّذِي تَسَاءَلُونَ بِهِ وَالْأَرْحَامَ إِنَّ اللَّهَ كَانَ عَلَيْكُمْ رَقِيبًا} [النساء: 1]، والآية التي في (الحشر): {[يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا] اتَّقُوا اللَّهَ وَلْتَنْظُرْ نَفْسٌ مَا قَدَّمَتْ لِغَدٍ وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ إِنَّ اللَّهَ خَبِيرٌ بِمَا تَعْمَلُونَ} [الحشر: 18] [{وَلَا تَكُونُوا كَالَّذِينَ نَسُوا اللَّهَ فَأَنْسَاهُمْ أَنْفُسَهُمْ أُولَئِكَ هُمُ الْفَاسِقُونَ (19) لَا يَسْتَوِي أَصْحَابُ النَّارِ وَأَصْحَابُ الْجَنَّةِ أَصْحَابُ الْجَنَّةِ هُمُ الْفَائِزُونَ (20)} [الحشر: 19، 20]. تصدقوا قبل أن يحال بينكم وبين الصدقة]، تصدق رجل من ديناره، من درهمه، من ثوبه، من صاع بره، [من شعيره]، من صاع تمره، حتى قال: [ولا يحقرن أحدكم شيئا من الصدقة]، ولو بشق تمرة، [فأبطؤوا حتى بان في وجهه الغضب]، قال: فجاء رجل من الانصار بصرة [من ورق (وفي رواية: من ذهب)] كادت كفه تعجز عنها، بل قد عجزت [فناولها رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم وهو على منبره] [فقال: يا رسول الله هذه في سبيل الله]، [فقبضها رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم]، [قام أبو بكر فأعطى، ثم قام عمر فأعطى، ثم قام المهاجرون والانصار فأعطوا]، ثم تتابع الناس [في الصدقات]، [فمن ذي دينار، ومن ذي درهم، ومن ذي، ومن ذي] حتى رأيت كومين من طعام وثياب، حتى رأيت وجه رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم يتهلل كأنه مذهبة فقال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم: من سن في الاسلام سنة حسنة فله أجرها، و [مثل] أجر من عمل بها بعده من غير أن ينقص من أجورهم شئ، ومن سن سنة في الاسلام سيئة كان عليه وزرها.
foot_note: None

text:
and [like] the burden of the one who acts upon it after him without decreasing anything from their burdens, [then he recited this verse: (We record what they have put forth and their traces)], [He said: So he divided it among them]). Narrated by Muslim (3/ 88, 89, 8/ 61, 62), An-Nasa'i (1/ 355, 356), Ad-Darimi (1/ 126, 127), and At-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil) (1/ 93, 97), Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 175, 176), At-Tayalisi (670), Ahmad (4/ 357, 358, 359, 360, 361, 362), and Ibn Abi Hatim also in his (Tafsir), as in Ibn Kathir (3/ 565). The addition before the last one belongs to him, and its chain is authentic. At-Tirmidhi (3/ 377) — and he authenticated it — and Ibn Majah (1/ 90) narrated the two sentences before the indicated addition along with the two additions in them. As for the first addition, it belongs to Al-Bayhaqi, and what follows it up to the fourth belongs to him and Muslim. The fifth up to the eighth belong to Al-Bayhaqi. At-Tayalisi has the fifth. The ninth belongs to Ad-Darimi and Ahmad, and Muslim has something similar, as do At-Tayalisi and Ahmad. The tenth, twelfth, fifteenth, and nineteenth belong to Al-Bayhaqi. The eleventh and seventeenth belong to At-Tahawi and Ahmad. The fourteenth belongs to At-Tayalisi. The sixteenth and seventeenth belong to Muslim, At-Tirmidhi, Ahmad, and others. The second narration belongs to An-Nasa'i and Al-Bayhaqi, and the third to At-Tahawi and Ahmad.

Visiting Graves: 118 - Visiting graves is prescribed for taking lessons from them and remembering the Hereafter, provided that one does not say at them what angers the Lord, Glory be to Him, such as supplicating to the buried, seeking aid from him instead of Allah the Exalted, or purifying him and asserting Paradise for him, and similar things. Regarding this, there are hadiths: First: On the authority of Buraydah ibn al-Husam, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (I used to forbid you from visiting graves, so visit them, [for they remind you of the Hereafter], [and let their visit increase you in goodness], [so whoever wants to visit, let him visit, and do not say *hujr* (bad words)]) (1). Narrated by Muslim (53/ 6, 6/ 82), Abu Dawood (2/ 72, 131) and via his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 77), An-Nasa'i (1/ 285, 286, 2/ 329, 330), and Ahmad (5/ 350, 355, 356, 361).
foot_note: None

text: The first and second additions belong to him. Abu Dawood has the first with a similar wording, and An-Nasa'i has the second and third. An-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Al-Majmu') (5/ 310): 'Al-Hujr: False speech. The prohibition was initially due to their proximity to the Time of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah), so they might have spoken with the false speech of Jahiliyyah. When the foundations of Islam were established, its rulings paved, and its signs became famous, visiting was permitted for them, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) took precaution by saying: (and do not say *hujr*).' I say: It is not hidden that what the common people and others do during visitation, such as supplicating to the dead, seeking aid from him, and asking Allah by his right, is of the greatest *Hujr* and false speech. So it is upon the scholars to explain to them Allah's ruling on that, and make them understand the prescribed visitation and its purpose. As-San'ani said in (Subul as-Salam) (2/ 162) following hadiths on visitation and its wisdom: (All of it indicates the legitimacy of visiting graves and explains the wisdom in it, and that it is for admonition... so if it is devoid of this, it is not intended by the Shariah). Second: On the authority of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (I forbade you from visiting graves, so visit them, for in them is a lesson. [And do not say what angers the Lord]). Narrated by Ahmad (3/ 38, 63, 66) and Al-Hakim (1/ 374 - 375), and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 77), then he said: (Authentic according to the condition of Muslim), and Adh-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Al-Bazzar also narrated it, and the addition belongs to him as in (Majma' al-Haythami) (3/ 58), and he said: (Its chain implies its men are men of the Sahih). I say: It is with Ahmad with a similar wording from another path, and its chain is acceptable in corroborations, and it has a witness from the hadith of Abdullah bin Amr with the wording of Al-Bazzar. Narrated by At-Tabarani in (Al-Mu'jam as-Saghir) (p. 183) and its men are trustworthy. Third: On the authority of Anas bin Malik who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said:
foot_note: None

text: (I used to forbid you from visiting graves; now visit them, for they soften the heart, bring tears to the eye, and remind of the Hereafter, and do not say *hujr*). Narrated by Al-Hakim (1/ 376) with a good (Hasan) chain, then he narrated it (1/ 375, 376) and Ahmad (3/ 237, 250) from another path from him with a similar wording, and it contains weakness. In the chapter, there is a narration from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, which will come later. 119 - Women are like men in the recommendation of visiting graves, for several reasons: First: The generality of his saying (peace be upon him) (...so visit graves), which includes women. The explanation: The Prophet (peace be upon him), when he forbade visiting graves in the beginning, there is no doubt that the prohibition included both men and women. When he said (I used to forbid you from visiting graves), it was understood that he meant both genders, necessarily, as he was informing them about the prohibition that existed in the beginning for both genders. If this is the case, it is necessary that the address in the second sentence of the hadith, which is his saying: (so visit them), was intended for both genders as well. This is supported by the fact that the address in the rest of the actions mentioned in Muslim's addition in the hadith of Buraydah mentioned previously: (And I forbade you from the meat of sacrificial animals beyond three days, so keep what seems good to you; and I forbade you from Nabidh except in a waterskin, so drink from all containers but do not drink an intoxicant). I say: The address in all these actions is directed to both genders definitively, as is the case in the first address: (I used to forbid you). If it were said that the address in his saying (so visit them) is specific to men, the structure of the speech would be disturbed and its freshness lost, a matter that does not befit the one who was given the comprehensive words, and the one who is the most eloquent to speak the letter *Dad*, peace be upon him. This is further supported by the following points: Second: Their sharing with men in the cause for which visiting graves was prescribed: (For they soften the heart, bring tears to the eye, and remind of the Hereafter). Third: That the Prophet (peace be upon him) permitted them to visit graves in two hadiths preserved for us by the Mother of the Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her:
foot_note: None

text: 1 - On the authority of Abdullah bin Abi Mulaykah: (That Aisha came one day from the graveyards, so I said to her: O Mother of the Believers, from where have you come? She said: From the grave of Abdul Rahman bin Abi Bakr. I said to her: Did not the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbid visiting graves? She said: Yes, then he ordered visiting them). In a narration from her: (That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) granted permission for visiting graves). Narrated by Al-Hakim (1/ 376) and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 78) via the path of Bastam bin Muslim from Abu At-Tayyah Yazid bin Humayd from Abdullah bin Abi Mulaykah. The other narration is by Ibn Majah (1/ 475). I say: Al-Hakim remained silent about it, and Adh-Dhahabi said (Authentic/Sahih), and Al-Busiri said in (Az-Zawa'id) (1/988): (Its chain is authentic, its men are trustworthy). And it is as they said. Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in (Takhrij Al-Ihya) (4/ 418): (Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it in [Al-Qubur] and Al-Hakim with a good chain) (1). 2 - On the authority of Muhammad bin Qays bin Makhramah bin Al-Muttalib, that he said one day: Shall I not tell you about myself and my mother? We thought he meant his mother who gave birth to him. He said: Aisha said: Shall I not tell you about myself and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)? We said: Yes. She said:
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: Ibn al-Qayyim found fault with it with something strange, and the other with nothing! He said in (Tahdhib as-Sunan) (4/ 350): (As for the narration of Al-Bayhaqi, it is from the narration of Bastam bin Muslim, and even if it were authentic, Aisha interpreted it as others interpreted the entry of women)! I say: Bastam is trustworthy without any dispute I know of, so there is no basis for Ibn al-Qayyim's criticism of him, and the chain is authentic with no doubt in it. Nor is it flawed by what At-Tirmidhi narrated (2/ 157) via the path of Ibn Jurayj from Abdullah bin Abi Mulaykah who said: Abdul Rahman bin Abi Bakr died at (Al-Hubshi) (a place twelve miles from Mecca), so he was carried to Mecca and buried there. When Aisha arrived, she came to the grave of Abdul Rahman bin Abi Bakr and said: *We were like the two drinking companions of Jadhimah for a long time / Until it was said: They will never separate. / When we separated, it was as if I and Malik / due to the length of gathering, never spent a night together.* Then she said: By Allah, had I been present with you, I would not have buried you except where you died, and had I witnessed you, I would not have visited you). Also narrated by Ibn =

text: (When it was my night which the Prophet (peace be upon him) was with me, he turned over, put down his outer garment (rida'), took off his sandals and placed them by his feet, spread the edge of his waist-wrapper (izar) on his bedding, and lay down. He stayed only long enough to think that I had fallen asleep, then he took his outer garment slowly, put on his sandals slowly, opened the door [slowly], and went out, then closed it slowly. I put my chemise on my head, covered myself, and wrapped my waist-wrapper (1), then I set out on his trail until he came to Al-Baqi'. He stood and prolonged his standing, then he raised his hands three times, then he turned and I turned, he hastened and I hastened. He ran and I ran. He arrived and I arrived. I preceded him and entered, and no sooner had I lain down than he entered and said: What is the matter with you, O 'A'ish (2), out of breath (3) and heavy chested? She said: I said: Nothing [O Messenger of Allah]. He said: You will tell me or the Subtle, the All-Aware will inform me. She said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, and I told him [the news]. He said: So you were the dark figure I saw in front of me? I said: Yes. So he poked me in the chest a poke (4) that hurt me, then he said: Did you think that Allah and His Messenger would treat you unjustly!? She said: Whatever people conceal, Allah knows it. [He said]: Yes. He said: For Gabriel came to me when you saw, and he called me - hiding it from you, and I answered him - hiding it from you. He would not enter upon you while you had put aside your clothes, and I thought that you had fallen asleep, so I disliked waking you, and I feared you would be lonely. He said: Your Lord commands you to come to the people of Al-Baqi' and ask forgiveness for them,
foot_note:
1. = Abi Shaybah in (Al-Musannaf) (4/ 140), and Al-Haythami added it in (Al-Majmu') saying (3/ 60): (Narrated by At-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and its men are men of the Sahih). He erred in the addition regarding At-Tirmidhi narrating it. Its men are the men of the two Sheikhs, but Ibn Jurayj is a *mudallis* (one who conceals sources) and he used 'an' (from). This is the flaw of the hadith. Despite that, Ibn al-Qayyim claimed (4/ 349) that it is (preserved despite what is in it). Thus he said, but rather it is denounced (Munkar) for what we mentioned and because it contradicts the narration of Yazid bin Humayd, who is trustworthy and firm, from Ibn Abi Mulaykah. The contradiction is apparent from her saying (Had I witnessed you, I would not have visited you), for it is explicit that the reason for the visit was only her absence from his death; so had she witnessed it, she would not have visited. Whereas the hadith of Ibn Humayd is explicit that she visited because the Prophet (peace be upon him) ordered visiting graves. So his hadith is the preserved one, contrary to what Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, adopted. As for what he mentioned about Aisha's interpretation, it is possible, but the other possibility—that she visited based on an instruction from him (peace be upon him)—is stronger due to the testimony of her following hadith.
1. Without the transitive 'ba', meaning I wore my izar, so it is transitive by itself.
2. It is permissible in (A'ish) to use a fatha on the Shin or a damma; both are valid aspects in all truncated vocatives (Murakkhamat).
3. With a fatha on the unpointed letter and sukun on the pointed one. It means the breathlessness (hasha) befell you, which is the asthma and agitation that happens to one speeding in his walk due to the rising and frequency of breath. And the saying: (Rabiyah) means rising of the belly.
4. Al-Lahz: Striking with the fist in the chest.

text: She said: I said: How do I say to them, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Say: Peace be upon the people of the abodes from the believers and Muslims, and may Allah have mercy on those who have gone ahead of us and those who come later, and we, if Allah wills, shall join you). Narrated by Muslim (3/ 14) and the context is his, An-Nasa'i (1/ 286 /, 2/ 160, 160 - 161), and Ahmad (6/ 221). The additions are his except the first and third, which belong to An-Nasa'i (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Hafiz used this hadith as evidence in (At-Talkhis) (5/ 248) for the permissibility of visiting for women, and it is apparent in its indication of that. It supports that the permission included them along with men, because this story happened in Medina, as it is known that the Prophet (peace be upon him) consummated the marriage with Aisha in Medina, and the prohibition was only in the beginning in Mecca. We are certain of this even if we do not know a history that supports it, because correct deduction testifies to it, from his saying (peace be upon him): (I used to forbid you). For it is inconceivable regarding such a prohibition that it would be legislated in the Medinan period, excluding the Meccan period where most legislated rulings related to Tawhid and Creed. The prohibition of visiting is of this type because it is blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhara'i), and its legislation suits the Meccan period because people were new to Islam and their era of Shirk was recent. So he (peace be upon him) forbade them from visiting so it would not be a means to Shirk. Until Tawhid settled in their hearts and they knew what contradicts it of types of Shirk, he permitted them to visit. As for leaving them throughout the Meccan period with their habit of visiting, then forbidding them from it in Medina, it is very far from the wisdom of legislation. Therefore, we asserted that the prohibition was legislated in Mecca. If this is so, his permission to Aisha to visit in Medina is clear evidence for what we mentioned. Ponder this, for it is something that sparked in my mind, and I have not seen anyone who explained it in this way. If I am correct, it is from Allah, and if I erred, it is from myself. As for the deduction of the author of the treatise (Wasiyyah Shar'iyyah) regarding this with his saying (p. 26): (And the Messenger (peace be upon him) approved his daughter Fatima, may Allah be pleased with her, visiting the grave of her uncle Hamza, may Allah be pleased with him), it is a false deduction, because the mentioned approval has no basis in any of the books of Sunnah, and I think it is merely a delusion of the author. What is narrated from her, may Allah be pleased with her, is only visiting; there is no mention of the alleged approval at all. Furthermore, that is not proven from her, for it is from the narration of Sulayman bin Dawood from Ja'far bin Muhammad from his father from Ali bin Al-Hussein from his father that Fatima the daughter of the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to visit the grave of her uncle Hamza every Friday, pray, and weep there. Thus narrated by Al-Hakim (1/ 377) and via his path Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 78) and he said: (Thus he said. It has been said from Sulayman bin Dawood from his father from Ja'far bin Muhammad from his father without mentioning Ali bin Al-Hussein from his father in it, so it is disconnected). Al-Hakim said: (Its narrators to the last of them are trustworthy)! Adh-Dhahabi refuted him saying: (I say: This is very weak/denounced (Munkar), and Sulayman is weak). I say: And I think he is Sulayman bin Dawood bin Qays Al-Farra' Al-Madani. Abu Hatim said (An elder, I do not understand him only as he should be). Al-Azdi said: (He was spoken against). For this reason, Adh-Dhahabi listed him in (Ad-Du'afa) and quoted Al-Azdi's statement mentioned. So do not be deceived =

text: Fourth: The Prophet's (peace be upon him) implicit approval of the woman he saw at the grave in the hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by a woman at a grave while she was weeping, so he said to her: Fear Allah and be patient...) Narrated by Al-Bukhari and others, and it has passed in full in Issue (19) (p. 22). He titled it (Chapter: Visiting Graves). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (The point of evidence from it is that he (peace be upon him) did not rebuke the woman for sitting at the grave, and his tacit approval is a proof). Al-Ayni said in (Al-Umdah) (3/ 76): (In it is the permissibility of visiting graves absolutely, whether the visitor is a man or a woman, and whether the visited is a Muslim or a disbeliever, due to the lack of separation in that). Al-Hafiz also mentioned something similar at the end of his discussion on the hadith, saying after his phrase (due to lack of seeking detail in that): (An-Nawawi said: The majority definitively stated permissibility. The author of Al-Hawi said: Visiting the grave of a disbeliever is not permissible, which is a mistake (1). End quote). What the hadith indicates regarding the permissibility of women visiting is what comes to mind from the hadith, but this is only valid if the story did not happen before the prohibition. This is the apparent case, if we remember what we mentioned previously that the prohibition was in Mecca, and the story was narrated by Anas who is Medinan; his mother Umm Sulaym brought him to the Prophet (peace be upon him) when he arrived in Medina, and Anas was ten years old. So the story is Medinan, establishing it was after the prohibition, so the deduction for permissibility stands. As for Ibn al-Qayyim's statement in (Tahdhib as-Sunan) (4/ 350):
foot_note:
1. = by Al-Hafiz's silence on this report in (At-Talkhis) (p. 167), even if Al-Shawkani followed him on it as is his habit in (Nayl al-Awtar) (4/ 95)!! Moreover, it appeared in the former as (Ali bin Al-Hussein from Ali), making it from the Musnad of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, while it is from the narration of his son Al-Hussein, may Allah be pleased with them both, as in Al-Hakim, or from the narration of Ja'far bin Muhammad from his father as in the suspended narration of Al-Bayhaqi. Perhaps what is in (At-Talkhis), which is his saying (from Ali), is a corruption of (from his father). All of this was omitted by As-San'ani in (Subul as-Salam) (2/ 151), so he attributed it to Al-Hakim from the hadith of Ali bin Al-Hussein that Fatima...
... Then he said: (I say: It is a Mursal hadith, for Ali bin Al-Hussein did not meet Fatima the daughter of Muhammad)! The hadith is actually from the narration of Ali bin Al-Hussein from his father as previously explained.
1. I say: The evidence for it is in the following issue.

text: (And fearing Allah implies doing what He commanded and leaving what He forbade, and among that is the prohibition of visiting). This would be correct if the woman had knowledge of the prohibition of women visiting and that it continued and was not abrogated. Then his saying: (And among that is the prohibition of visiting) would be established. But since this is unknown to us, it is an incorrect deduction. It is supported by the fact that if the prohibition were still continuing, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) would have forbidden her from visiting explicitly and explained that to her, and would not have sufficed with ordering her to fear Allah in a general manner. This is apparent, if Allah the Exalted wills. 120 - However, it is not permissible for them to visit graves frequently and go back and forth to them, because that may lead them to contradict the Shari'ah, such as wailing, displaying adornment (Tabarruj), taking graves as places for picnics, and wasting time in idle talk, as is witnessed today in some Islamic lands. This is the intended meaning - God willing - of the famous hadith: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) cursed (and in a wording: Allah cursed) the women who frequently visit graves [*zawwarat*]). It has been narrated from a group of Companions: Abu Hurayrah, Hassan bin Thabit, and Abdullah bin Abbas. 1 - As for the hadith of Abu Hurayrah, it is from the path of Umar bin Abi Salamah from his father from him. Narrated by At-Tirmidhi (2/ 156 - Tuhfah), Ibn Majah (1/ 478), Ibn Hibban (789), Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 78), At-Tayalisi (1/ 171 - his arrangement), and Ahmad (2/ 337). The other wording belongs to At-Tayalisi and Al-Bayhaqi. At-Tirmidhi said: (A good authentic [Hasan Sahih] hadith. Some people of knowledge viewed that this was before the Prophet permitted visiting graves. When he permitted it, men and women entered into his permission. Others said: He only disliked visiting graves for women due to their lack of patience and excessive anxiety). I say: The men of the hadith's chain are all trustworthy, except that there is some talk about Umar bin Abi Salamah. Perhaps his hadith does not drop below the rank of Hasan, but this hadith of his is authentic due to the witnesses that follow. 2 - As for the hadith of Hassan bin Thabit, it is from the path of Abdul Rahman bin Bahman from Abdul Rahman bin Thabit from his father with it.
foot_note: None

text: Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/ 141), Ibn Majah (1/ 478), Al-Hakim (1/ 374), Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (2/ 243). Al-Busiri said in (Az-Zawa'id) (Folio 98/ 2): (Its chain is authentic, its men are trustworthy). Thus he said, but this Ibn Bahman was not authenticated by anyone except Ibn Hibban and Al-Ijli, and they are known for leniency in authentication. Ibn Al-Madini said about him: (We do not know him). Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (At-Taqrib): (Acceptable), meaning when corroborated. I did not find a corroborator for him, but the witness before it and after it acts as corroboration, so the hadith is acceptable. 3 - As for the hadith of Ibn Abbas, it is from the path of Abu Salih from him with the first wording except that he said: (female visitors [*za'irat*] of graves) and in a narration (frequent visitors [*zawwarat*]). Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/ 140), the authors of the four Sunan, Ibn Hibban (788), Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, At-Tayalisi - and the other narration belongs to the latter two - and Ahmad (No. 2030, 2603, 2986, 3118). At-Tirmidhi said: (A Hasan hadith. This Abu Salih is the freed slave of Umm Hani bint Abi Talib and his name is Badhan, also said: Badham). I say: He is weak; rather, some accused him. I have listed his hadith in (Silsilat Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah) due to an addition he was unique in. I mentioned some statements of the Imams regarding his status, so refer to (223). It has become clear from the extraction of the hadith that the preserved wording in it is (Zawwarat) [frequent visitors] due to the agreement of the hadith of Abu Hurayrah and Hassan on it, as well as the hadith of Ibn Abbas in the narration of the majority, despite its weakness. If it is not suitable for evidence alone, it does not harm, as the other narration from the hadith of Ibn Abbas does not harm the mentioned agreement, as is apparent. If the matter is so, then this wording (Zawwarat) only indicates cursing women who visit frequently. Unlike others, the curse does not include them. Therefore, it is not permissible to oppose the previously mentioned hadiths indicating the recommendation of visiting for women with this hadith, because it is specific and those are general. So both are applied in their places. This reconciliation is better than the claim of abrogation. A group of scholars held the view similar to what we mentioned. Al-Qurtubi said:
foot_note: None

text: (The curse mentioned in the hadith is only for those who visit frequently, due to what the form implies of exaggeration. Perhaps the reason is what that leads to of wasting the husband's rights and displaying adornment (Tabarruj), and what arises of wailing and the like. It may be said: If all that is safe, there is no prohibition in permitting them, because remembering death is needed by both men and women). Al-Shawkani said in (Nayl al-Awtar) (4/ 95): (This speech is what should be relied upon in reconciling the hadiths of the chapter that contradict in appearance) (1). 121 - And it is permissible to visit the grave of one who died upon other than Islam for admonition only. Regarding this, there are two hadiths: First: On the authority of Abu Hurayrah who said: (The Prophet (peace be upon him) visited his mother's grave. He wept and made those around him weep. He said: I asked my Lord for permission to ask forgiveness for her, but I was not granted permission. And I asked Him for permission to visit her grave, and He granted me permission. So visit graves, for they remind of death).
foot_note: 1. (1) As-San'ani also went to this reconciliation in (Subul as-Salam), but he used evidence for permissibility that is questionable, so I liked to point it out. First: The hadith of Al-Hussein bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both (That Fatima the daughter of the Prophet, peace be upon him, used to visit the grave of her uncle Hamza every Friday, pray, and weep). Narrated by Al-Hakim (1/ 377) and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 78) stating (It is disconnected). Al-Hafiz remained silent about it in (At-Talkhis) (5/ 248) and As-San'ani followed him! The silence of these two and Al-Bayhaqi limiting the flaw to disconnection might create the illusion that it is free from other flaws. It is not so, as previously explained shortly before. Second: The hadith of Al-Bayhaqi in (Shu'ab al-Iman) as Mursal: (Whoever visits the grave of his parents or one of them every Friday, he is forgiven and written as righteous). As-San'ani also remained silent about it. It is very weak, rather it is fabricated. It is not just Mursal as As-San'ani mentioned, but it is problematic (Mu'dal) because the one who raised it is Muhammad bin An-Nu'man, who is not a Tabi'i. Al-Iraqi said in (Takhrij Al-Ihya) (4/ 418): (Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it in [Al-Qubur] and it is Mu'dal; Muhammad bin An-Nu'man is unknown). I say: He received it from Yahya bin Al-Ala Al-Bajali with his chain from Abu Hurayrah. At-Tabarani narrated it in Al-Saghir (199). Waki' and Ahmad called Yahya a liar. Ibn Abi Hatim said (2/ 209) from his father: (The hadith is very Munkar, as if it is fabricated).

text: Narrated by Muslim (3/ 65), Abu Dawood (2/ 72), An-Nasa'i (1/ 286), Ibn Majah (1/ 476), At-Tahawi (3/ 189), Al-Hakim (1/ 375 - 376) and from him Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 76), and Ahmad (2/ 441). Second: On the authority of Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: (We were with the Prophet (peace be upon him) [on a journey, and in a narration: in the Campaign of the Conquest], so he dismounted with us and we were with him, nearly a thousand riders. He prayed two rak'ahs, then turned to us with his face, his eyes shedding tears. Umar bin Al-Khattab stood up to him, may he be ransomed with father and mother, saying: O Messenger of Allah, what is the matter? He said: I asked my Lord, Mighty and Majestic, regarding asking forgiveness for my mother, but He did not permit me, so my eyes shed tears out of mercy for her from the Fire. [And I asked my Lord permission to visit her, and He permitted me]. And I used to forbid you from visiting graves, so visit them, and let their visit increase you in goodness). Narrated by Ahmad (5/ 355, 357, 359) and Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/ 139). The other narration belongs to them, and its chain in Ibn Abi Shaybah is authentic. Also Al-Hakim (1/ 376), Ibn Hibban (791), and Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 76). The first addition belongs to her (referring to a source or text). The other narration regarding it belongs to those previously mentioned. The other addition belongs to Al-Hakim and he said: (Authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs) and Adh-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said. At-Tirmidhi narrated it briefly and authenticated it. Muslim and others narrated from it the permission to visit only, as presented in Issue (118, p. 178) First Hadith. (1) The purpose of visiting graves is two things: 1 - The benefit of the visitor by remembering death and the dead, and that their destination is either Paradise or Hell. This is the primary purpose of the visit, as indicated by the previous hadiths.
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Nawawi said in the explanation of the first hadith of Abu Hurayrah: (In it is the permissibility of visiting polytheists in life, and their graves after death, because if visiting them is permissible after death, then in life it is more appropriate. And in it is the prohibition of asking forgiveness for disbelievers. Iyad said: The reason for his (peace be upon him) visiting her grave was that he intended the strength of admonition and remembrance by viewing her grave. This is supported by his saying (peace be upon him): So visit graves, for they remind you of death).

text: 2 - Benefiting the dead and being kind to him by greeting him, and supplicating and asking forgiveness for him. This is specific to the Muslim. Regarding this, there are hadiths: First: On the authority of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: (That the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to go out to Al-Baqi' and pray for them. So Aisha asked him about that? He said: I was commanded to pray for them). Narrated by Ahmad (6/ 252) with an authentic chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs. Its meaning is found in Muslim and others from another path at length, and it has passed completely in Issue (119). Second: On her authority also, she said: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), whenever it was her night with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), used to go out in the last part of the night and say: Peace be upon you, [people of] the abode of a believing people, and we and you are delayed to what you were promised for tomorrow, and we, if Allah wills, shall join you. O Allah, forgive the people of Baqi' Al-Gharqad). Narrated by Muslim (3/ 63), An-Nasa'i (1/ 287), Ibn As-Sunni (585), Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 79), and Ahmad (6/ 180). Ahmad does not have the supplication for forgiveness (and the addition belongs to him and Ibn As-Sunni). Third: On her authority also in her long hadith referred to shortly before, she said: (How do I say to them, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Say: Peace be upon the people of the abodes from the believers and Muslims, and may Allah have mercy on those who have gone ahead of us and those who come later, and we, if Allah wills, shall join you). Narrated by Muslim and others. Fourth: On the authority of Buraydah who said: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to teach them when they went out to the graveyards; so one of them would say:
foot_note: None

text: Peace be upon you, people of the abodes from the believers and Muslims, and we, if Allah wills, shall join [you]. [You are our predecessors (farat) and we are your followers]. I ask Allah for us and for you well-being). Narrated by Muslim (3/ 65), An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah (1/ 469), as well as Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/ 138), Ibn As-Sunni in (582), Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (5/ 353, 359, 360). The two additions belong to all of them except Ibn Majah and Muslim. The second addition was narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah from the hadith of Ali and its chain is authentic, and from the hadith of Salman (and its chain is good), both being halted (Mawquf) at them. Fifth: On the authority of Abu Hurayrah: (That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) came to the graveyard and said: Peace be upon you, abode of a believing people, and we, if Allah wills, shall join you. I wished that we had seen our brothers. They said: Are we not your brothers, O Messenger of Allah? He said: [Nay], you are my companions, and our brothers are those who come after. [And I am your predecessor at the Cistern]. They said: How will you know those of your nation who have not come yet, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Do you not see that if a man has horses with white blazes (1) and white limbs among horses that are purely black (2), would he not know his horses? They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: For they will come [on the Day of Resurrection] with white faces and limbs from wudu'. [He says it three times]. And I am their predecessor at the Cistern. Verily, men [from among you] will be driven away from my Cistern just as a stray camel is driven away. I call them: Come here, [come here]. It will be said: They have changed after you, [and they ceased not to turn back on their heels]. So I say: [Be away], far away, far away). Narrated by Muslim (1/ 150 - 151), Malik (1/ 49 - 50), An-Nasa'i (1/ 35), Ibn Majah (2/ 580), Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 78), and Ahmad (2/ 300, 408). All additions belong to him except the last two which belong to Ibn Majah. Malik has the first three with the sixth. An-Nasa'i has the first and third.
foot_note:
1. (1) With a damma then shadda, plural of Agharr, which is the white-faced. (Muhajjalin) is the passive participle of Tahjil; a Muhajjal from animals is one whose legs are white.
2. With two dammas or a sukun on the second, which is more famous for pairing. It is an emphasis for (Duhm), plural of Adham, which is the black.

text: In the chapter, there is a narration from Bashir bin Al-Khasasiyah, and I mentioned his wording in the commentary on Issue (88), (p. 135). Also from Ibn Abbas, which contains weakness as will be pointed out at the end of the issue after the next one. And from Umar and others, and they contain weakness as explained by Al-Hafiz Al-Haythami in (Al-Majmu') (3/ 60). 122 - As for reading the Qur'an when visiting them, it has no basis in the Sunnah. Rather, the hadiths mentioned in the previous issue imply its lack of legislation. For if it were prescribed, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) would have done it and taught it to his Companions, especially since Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who was among the most beloved people to him (peace be upon him), asked him what to say if she visited graves? So he taught her the Greeting (Salam) and Supplication. He did not teach her to read Al-Fatiha or anything else from the Qur'an. If reading were prescribed, he would not have concealed that from her. How could he, when delaying clarification beyond the time of need is not permissible as established in the science of Usul, so what about concealment? And had he (peace be upon him) taught them anything of that, it would have been transmitted to us. Since it has not been transmitted with an established chain, it indicates that it did not happen. What strengthens the lack of legislation is his saying (peace be upon him): (Do not make your houses graveyards, for Satan flees from the house in which Surah Al-Baqarah is read). Narrated by Muslim (2/ 188), At-Tirmidhi (4/ 42) - and he authenticated it - and Ahmad (2/ 284, 337, 378, 388) from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah. It has a witness from the hadith of Salsal bin Ad-Dalhams. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi in (Ash-Shu'ab) as in (Al-Jami' as-Saghir). The Prophet (peace be upon him) indicated that graves are not a place for reading according to Shari'ah. Therefore, he encouraged reading the Qur'an in houses and forbade making them like graveyards where reading is not done, just as he indicated in the other hadith that they are not a place for prayer either, which is his saying: (Pray in your houses, and do not take them as graves). Narrated by Muslim (2/ 187) and others from Ibn Umar. It is in Al-Bukhari with a similar wording, and he titled it: (Chapter: Dislike of Prayer in Graveyards), indicating that Ibn Umar's hadith implies the dislike of...
foot_note: None

text: prayer in graveyards, so likewise the hadith of Abu Hurayrah implies the dislike of reading the Qur'an in graveyards, and there is no difference (1). For that reason, the school of the majority of the Salaf like Abu Hanifa, Malik, and others (2) was the dislike of reading at graves. It is the opinion of Imam Ahmad. Abu Dawood said in his Masa'il (p. 158):
foot_note:
1. (1) A group of scholars used the hadith as evidence for what Al-Bukhari used it for, and Al-Hafiz supported him in his explanation. I have mentioned his words in the following issue (No. 128, paragraph 7).
2. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned it from them in (Iqtida' as-Sirat al-Mustaqim Mukhalafat Ashab al-Jahim) (p. 128) and said: (No speech is preserved from Ash-Shafi'i himself on this issue, because that was an innovation to him. Malik said: I have not known anyone doing that, so it is known that the Companions and the Tabi'un did not do it). He said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat al-Ilmiyyah) (p. 53): (And reading over the dead after his death is an innovation (Bid'ah), unlike reading over the dying person, for it is recommended to read Ya-Sin). I say: But the hadith of reading Ya-Sin is weak as presented (p. 11), and recommendation is a legal ruling, and it is not established by a weak hadith as is known from Ibn Taymiyyah's own words in some of his works and others. As for what came in (Kitab ar-Ruh) by Ibn al-Qayyim (p. 13): Al-Khallal said: Al-Hasan bin Ahmad Al-Warraq informed me: Ali bin Musa Al-Haddad - and he was truthful - told us: I was with Ahmad bin Hanbal and Muhammad bin Qudamah Al-Jawhari in a funeral. When the dead was buried, a blind man sat reading at the grave. Ahmad said to him: O you, reading at the grave is a Bid'ah! When we left the graveyard, Muhammad bin Qudamah said to Ahmad bin Hanbal: O Abu Abdullah, what do you say about Mubashir Al-Halabi? He said: Trustworthy. He said: Did you write anything from him? He said: Yes. He said: Mubashir informed me from Abdul Rahman bin Al-Ala bin Al-Lajlaj (Original: Al-Hallaj, which is a mistake) from his father that he requested that when he is buried, the opening of Al-Baqarah and its end be read at his head, and he said: I heard Ibn Umar recommending that. Ahmad said to him: Go back and tell the man to read). The answer to it is from several aspects: First: There is doubt about the authenticity of this story from Ahmad, because Al-Khallal's sheikh, Al-Hasan bin Ahmad Al-Warraq, I did not find a biography for him in the books of narrators I have now. Similarly, his sheikh Ali bin Musa Al-Haddad, I did not know him. Even if it is said in this chain that he was truthful, the apparent meaning is that the speaker is this Al-Warraq, and you have known his condition. Second: If it is proven from him, it is more specific than what Abu Dawood narrated from him, and the result of reconciling the two narrations from him is that his school is the dislike of reading at the grave except at burial. Third: The chain of this report is not authentic from Ibn Umar, even if we assume it is proven from Ahmad, because Abdul Rahman bin Al-Ala bin Al-Lajlaj is counted among the unknown narrators, as indicated by Adh-Dhahabi's statement in his biography in (Al-Mizan): (Nothing was narrated from him except by this Mubashir). Ibn As-Asakir narrated it from his path (13/ 399 / 2). As for Ibn Hibban's authentication of him, it is not relied upon due to his fame for leniency in authentication. Therefore, Al-Hafiz did not rely on it in (At-Taqrib) when he said about the subject: (Acceptable), meaning when corroborated, otherwise the hadith is soft as he stated in the introduction. What supports what we mentioned is that At-Tirmidhi, despite his leniency in authentication, when he narrated another hadith for him (2/ 128) and he has no other with him, remained silent about it and did not authenticate it! =

text: (I heard Ahmad being asked about reading at the grave? He said: No). 123 - And it is permissible to raise the hands in supplication for them, due to the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said:
foot_note: 1. = Fourth: That even if its chain were proven from Ibn Umar, it is halted (Mawquf) and he did not raise it to the Prophet (peace be upon him), so there is no proof in it at all. Like this report is what Ibn al-Qayyim also mentioned (p. 14): (And Al-Khallal mentioned from Ash-Sha'bi who said: The Ansar, if a dead person died among them, used to go to his grave to read the Qur'an). We are in doubt about the authenticity of that from Ash-Sha'bi with this specific wording. I saw Al-Suyuti cited it in (Sharh as-Sudur) (p. 15) with the wording: (The Ansar used to read Surah Al-Baqarah at the dead person). He said: (Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah and Al-Marwazi). He included it in (Chapter: What a person says during final illness, and what is read at him). Then I saw it in (Al-Musannaf) by Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/ 74) and he titled it: (Chapter: What is said at the sick person when he is dying). It became clear that its chain contains Mujalid, who is Ibn Sa'id. Al-Hafiz said in (At-Taqrib): (He is not strong, and he changed in the end of his life). It appeared from this that the report is not about reading at the grave but at the time of dying, and even then, it has a weak chain. As for the hadith (Whoever passes by graveyards and reads [Qul Huwa Allahu Ahad] eleven times then gifts its reward to the dead, he is given reward according to the number of the dead). It is a false, fabricated hadith. Narrated by Abu Muhammad Al-Khallal in (Reading at Graves) (Folio 201/ 2) and Ad-Daylami from the copy of Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Amir from his father from Ali Ar-Rida from his fathers. It is a fabricated, false copy that is not free from the fabrication of this Abdullah or his father, as Adh-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan) and Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar followed him in (Al-Lisan), then Al-Suyuti in (Dhayl al-Ahadith al-Mawdu'ah), and he mentioned this hadith for him, and Ibn Iraq followed him in (Tanzih ash-Shari'ah al-Marfu'ah 'an al-Ahadith ash-Shi'ah al-Mawdu'ah). Then Al-Suyuti overlooked that, so he cited the hadith in (Sharh as-Sudur) (p. 130) with the narration of Abu Muhammad As-Samarqandi in (Virtues of Qul Huwa Allahu Ahad) and remained silent about it! Yes, he indicated its weakness before that, but this is not enough because the hadith is fabricated by his admission, so it is not permissible to limit it to weakening, nor is it permissible to remain silent about it, as Sheikh Ismail Al-Ajluni did in (Kashf al-Khafa') (2 - 382) for he attributed it to Ar-Rafi'i in his history and remained silent about it! Even though he wrote his book as a reminder to uncover (what is famous of hadiths on people's tongues)! Moreover, the silence of specialists regarding a hadith may give the illusion to those with no knowledge that the hadith is suitable for argumentation or acting upon in virtuous deeds as they say. This is what happened to this hadith, for I saw some Hanafis arguing with this hadith for reading at graves, namely Sheikh At-Tahtawi on (Maraqi al-Falah) (p. 117)! He attributed this to Ad-Daraqutni, and I think it is a delusion. I did not find anyone else attributing it to him. Furthermore, it is known among those busy with this science that attribution to Ad-Daraqutni absolutely implies his book (As-Sunan), and I did not see this hadith in it. And Allah knows best.

text: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went out one night, so I sent Barirah to follow him to see where he went! She said: He took the path towards Baqi' Al-Gharqad, stopped at the nearest part of Al-Baqi', then he raised his hands, then he left. Barirah returned to me and informed me. When I woke up, I asked him. I said: O Messenger of Allah, where did you go tonight? He said: I was sent to the people of Al-Baqi' to pray for them). Narrated by Ahmad (6/ 92), and it is in (Al-Muwatta') (1/ 239 - 240). An-Nasa'i narrated from him (1/ 287) similarly, but it does not mention raising the hands, and its chain is good (Hasan). Raising hands was proven in another story of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, which proceeded in Issue (119). 124 - However, he does not face the graves when supplicating for them, but rather the Kaaba, due to his (peace be upon him) prohibition of praying towards graves as will come. And supplication is the marrow of prayer and its core as is known, so it has its ruling. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: (Supplication is worship, then he recited {And your Lord said, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you"}).
