Narrated by Ibn Al-Mubarak in (Az-Zuhd) (10/ 151), Al-Bukhari in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) No. (714), Abu Dawood (1/ 551 - with 'Awn explanation), At-Tirmidhi (4/ 178, 223), Ibn Majah (2/ 428 - 429), Ibn Hibban (2396), Al-Hakim (1/ 491), Ibn Mandah in (At-Tawhid) (Folio 69/ 1), and Ahmad (4/ 167, 271, 276, 277). Al-Hakim said: (Authentic chain) and Adh-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said. At-Tirmidhi said: (A good authentic [Hasan Sahih] hadith). Abu Ya'la narrated it from the hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib as in (Al-Jami' as-Saghir). In the chapter, there is a narration from Anas bin Malik raised (Marfu') with the wording: (Supplication is the marrow of worship). Narrated by At-Tirmidhi (2234) and he said: (A strange [Gharib] hadith from this face; we do not know it except from the hadith of Ibn Lahi'ah). I say: He is weak due to his poor memory, so he is used for corroboration unless it is from the narration of one of the 'Abadilah

text: from him, so it is used as evidence then. This is not one of them, but its meaning is correct due to the hadith of An-Nu'man. Al-Tibi said in his explanation: (He used the pronoun of separation and the predicate defined by 'Al' [is the worship] to indicate restriction/exclusivity, and that worship is nothing other than supplication. Others said: The meaning is that it is the greatest of worship, so it is like the report (Hajj is Arafah) meaning its greatest pillar. This is because it indicates that the doer turns his face to Allah, turning away from everything else, because he is commanded to do so, and doing the commanded act is worship. He called it worship to humble the supplicant and show his humiliation, destitution, and poverty, for worship is humiliation, submission, and poverty). Mentioned by Al-Munawi in (Al-Fayd). I say: If supplication is among the greatest of worship, how can one turn in it to other than the direction commanded to face in prayer? Therefore, it is established among the investigative scholars that (One does not face in supplication except what is faced in prayer). Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said in (Iqtida' as-Sirat al-Mustaqim Mukhalafat Ashab al-Jahim) (p. 175): (This is a continuous principle that it is not recommended for the supplicant to face except what is recommended to pray towards. Do you not see that when a man was forbidden from praying towards the East and other directions, he is forbidden from seeking to face them at the time of supplication. Some people seek to face the direction where a righteous man is at the time of their supplication, whether it is in the East or elsewhere. This is manifest error and clear evil. Just as some people refrain from turning their backs to the direction where some righteous people are, while they turn their backs to the direction where the House of Allah is! And the grave of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)! All these things are innovations that resemble the religion of the Christians). He mentioned lines before that from Imam Ahmad and the companions of Malik that the prescribed action is facing the Qiblah in supplication even at the grave of the Prophet (peace be upon him) after greeting him. It is the school of the Shafi'is as well. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu') (5/ 311): Imam Abu Al-Hasan Muhammad bin Marzuq Az-Za'farani - who was among the investigative jurists - said in his book on (Funerals): (One does not touch the grave with his hand, nor kiss it). He said: (And upon this the Sunnah passed). He said: (Touching graves and kissing them, which the common people do now, are among the repugnant innovations

text: legally, doing it should be avoided, and the doer should be forbidden). He said: (Whoever intends to greet a dead person greets him facing his face, and if he wants to supplicate, he turns from his place and faces the Qiblah). It is the school of Abu Hanifa as well. Sheikh al-Islam said in (Al-Qa'idah Al-Jalilah fi At-Tawassul wal-Wasilah) (p. 125): (The school of the four Imams: Malik, Abu Hanifa, Ash-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and others from the Imams of Islam is that if a man greets the Prophet (peace be upon him) and wants to pray for himself, he faces the Qiblah. They differed regarding the time of greeting him. The three - Malik, Ash-Shafi'i, and Ahmad - said: He faces the Chamber and greets him facing his face. Abu Hanifa said: He does not face the Chamber at the time of greeting, just as he does not face it at the time of supplication by their agreement. Then within his school there are two opinions: It is said: He turns his back to the Chamber. And it is said: He puts it on his left. This is their dispute regarding the time of greeting. As for the time of supplication, they did not dispute that he only faces the Qiblah, not the Chamber). The reason for the mentioned difference is simply that the Honored Chamber, being outside the Mosque, and the Companions used to greet him, it was not possible for anyone to face his face (peace be upon him) and turn his back to the Qiblah (1), as became possible after its inclusion into the Mosque after the Companions. So if a Muslim among them faced the Qiblah, the Chamber would be on his left. If they faced the Chamber, the Qiblah would be on their right and the direction of the West behind them. Sheikh al-Islam said in (Al-Jawab Al-Bahir) (p. 14) after mentioning this meaning: So then if they were facing him and turning their backs to the West, the opinion of the majority is more likely. If they were facing the Qiblah then and putting the Chamber on their left, the opinion of Abu Hanifa is more likely). I say: The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, left the issue suspended, so he did not decide whether they used to face it or face the grave, as if due to the lack of a proven narration from them on that. But if we assume they were facing him, you have known that in this case they would be turning their backs to the West, not the Qiblah,

text: because of the impossibility of that in their time. It proceeded that the majority say one should face his face (peace be upon him) also when greeting him, and this necessitates turning one's back to the Qiblah. A matter we are certain did not happen in the time of the Companions as preceded. This is an additional matter to facing the Chamber, and it must have evidence to prove it. Does it have existence? That is something I do not know, nor have I seen anyone from the scholars address this, whether specifically for the grave of the Messenger (peace be upon him) or graves in general. Yes, some of them used the hadith of Ibn Abbas as evidence: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by the graves of Medina, so he turned his face towards them and said: Peace be upon you, O people of the graves! May Allah forgive us and you; you are our predecessors and we are on the trail). Narrated by At-Tirmidhi (2/ 156) and Ad-Diya in (Al-Mukhtarah) (58/ 192 / 1) via the path of At-Tabarani. At-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Gharib). I say: In its chain is Qabus bin Abi Zabyan. An-Nasa'i said: (He is not strong). Ibn Hibban said: (Bad memory, he narrates uniquely from his father things that have no basis). I say: And this is from his narration from his father, so it is not used as proof. Perhaps At-Tirmidhi's grading of his hadith as Hasan is only in consideration of its witnesses, for its meaning is established in authentic hadiths, and a good portion of them has passed recently. Except that his saying: (so he turned his face towards them) is denounced (Munkar) due to this weak narrator being unique in it. If you know this, Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in (Mirqat al-Mafatih) (2/ 407): (In it is evidence that it is recommended during the greeting of the dead that one's face be towards the face of the dead, and to continue like that in supplication as well. This is the practice of the general Muslims, contrary to what Ibn Hajar said that the Sunnah according to us is that in the state of supplication one faces the Qiblah as known from other hadiths regarding supplication in general). I say: In this deduction is an apparent flaw, since there is nothing in the hadith except his (peace be upon him) turning his face to the graves. As for turning to the faces of the dead, that is another thing which needs another text
foot_note: None

text: other than this, which is something I do not know. The truth is that if the chain of the hadith were proven, it would be clear evidence that the passerby at graves faces them with his face when greeting and praying for them, however the facing may be, and as it happens without intending the faces of the dead. But since the chain is weak as previously explained, it is not suitable for evidence at all. Nor does what was mentioned previously from Imam Malik about the lack of legitimacy of facing the Chamber during supplication contradict the story in which it is said that Malik, when Al-Mansur Al-Abbasi asked him about facing the Chamber, ordered him to do so and said: It is your means (wasilah) and the means of your father Adam. Because it is a false story, fabricated against Malik, and has no known chain. Moreover, it contradicts what is proven and transmitted from him with chains of trustworthy narrators in the books of his companions, as Ismail mentioned in (Ishaaq Al-Qadi) and others. Similar to it is what they mentioned about him being asked about people who prolong standing facing the Chamber praying for themselves, so Malik denied that and mentioned that it is among the innovations that the Companions and the Tabi'un did not do with excellence, and he said (Nothing will rectify the end of this nation except what rectified its beginning) (1). 125 - And if he visits the grave of a disbeliever, he does not greet him, nor pray for him, but rather gives him tidings of the Fire. Likewise, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) commanded in the hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas who said: (A Bedouin came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: My father used to maintain ties of kinship, and was such and such, so where is he? He said: In the Fire. It was as if the Bedouin found that difficult. He said: O Messenger of Allah! Then where is your father? He said: (Wherever you pass by the grave of a disbeliever, give him tidings of the Fire). He said: So the Bedouin became Muslim afterwards and said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) tasked me with a burden! I never passed by a grave of a disbeliever except that I gave him tidings of the Fire). Narrated by At-Tabarani in (Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir) (1/ 191 / 1) and Ibn As-Sunni in (Amal al-Yawm wa al-Laylah)

text: No. (588) and Ad-Diya Al-Maqdisi in (Al-Ahadith Al-Mukhtarah) (3331) with an authentic chain. Al-Haythami said (1/ 117 - 118): (Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani in Al-Kabir, and its men are men of the Sahih). Ibn Majah (1/ 476 - 477) narrated it from this face but made it from the Musnad of Abdullah bin Umar. Al-Busiri said in (Az-Zawa'id) (Folio 98/ 2): (Its chain is authentic, its men are trustworthy). I say: But it is odd (Shadh), and the preserved narration is that it is from the Musnad of Sa'd as I explained in (Silsilat Al-Ahadith As-Sahihah) (18). The hadith has a witness from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah raised (Marfu') with the wording: (If you pass by our graves and your graves from the people of Jahiliyyah, inform them that they are from the people of the Fire). Narrated by Ibn As-Sunni in (Al-Yawm wa al-Laylah) (No. 587) with a chain containing Yahya bin Yaman, who has a poor memory, from Muhammad bin Umar. I did not know him from Abu Salamah from him. But the apparent is that he is (Ibn Amr) with a fatha on the Ayn and sukun on the Mim then Waw after the Ra; the letter Waw fell from the typesetter. He is Hasan in hadith. What we mentioned in this issue is the school of the Hanbalis as in (Kashsaf al-Qina') (2/ 134) and others of their books. 126 - And he should not walk between the graves of Muslims in his sandals, due to the hadith of Bashir bin Al-Hanzaliyyah who said: (While I was walking with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)... he came upon the graves of Muslims... While he was walking, a glance came from him, and he saw a man walking between the graves wearing two sandals. He said: O owner of the Sibtite sandals, throw away your Sibtite sandals. He looked, and when the man recognized the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), he took off his sandals and threw them). Narrated by the authors of the Sunan and others, and it has passed in full in Issue (88) (1).

If it were good, they would have preceded us to it. And Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: (Every innovation is misguidance, even if people see it as good) (1). Narrated by Ibn Battah in (Al-Ibanah 'an Usul ad-Diyanah) (2/ 112 / 2) and Al-Lalaka'i in (As-Sunnah)
foot_note:
1. = Sibtite sandals specifically to the exclusion of others! This is severe rigidity. As for Al-Khattabi's saying: It seems the prohibition regarding them is due to the pride in them, it is critiqued by the fact that Ibn Umar used to wear Sibtite sandals and say: The Prophet (peace be upon him) used to wear them. And it is an authentic hadith. At-Tahawi said: (The prohibition of the mentioned man is interpreted as his sandals having filth, for the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to pray in his sandals as long as he did not see harm in them). I say: This possibility is far-fetched; rather Ibn Hazm asserted (5/ 137) its invalidity, and that it is speaking about Allah without knowledge! The closer view is that the prohibition is out of respect for the dead, so it is like the prohibition of sitting on the grave coming in Issue (128, paragraph 6). Based on this, there is no difference between Sibtite sandals and other sandals that have hair, as all are in the same position regarding walking in them between graves and contradicting the respect for them. Ibn al-Qayyim explained that in (Tahdhib as-Sunan) (4/ 343 - 345) and quoted from Imam Ahmad that he said: (The hadith of Bashir has a good chain, I adopt it except due to a defect). It is proven that Imam Ahmad used to act upon this hadith. Abu Dawood said in his Masa'il (p. 158): (I saw Ahmad, when he followed a funeral and got close to the graveyards, take off his sandals). May Allah have mercy on him, how much he followed the Sunnah.
1. What we mentioned does not contradict the hadith of Ibn Abbas regarding the Prophet (peace be upon him) placing two halves of a palm branch on the two graves and saying: (Perhaps it will be lightened for them as long as they do not dry). Agreed upon, and I extracted it in (Sahih Abi Dawood) (15). Because it is specific to him (peace be upon him) evidenced by the fact that the Salaf did not act upon it, and for other reasons to be explained. Al-Khattabi, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said in (Ma'alim as-Sunan) (1/ 27) commenting on the hadith: (It is seeking blessings through the trace of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and his supplication for lightening for them. It is as if he made the duration of the moisture remaining in them a limit for what the request for lightening the punishment for them occurred, and that is not because the wet palm branch has a meaning not found in the dry one. The common people in many lands plant palm branches on the graves of their dead, and I see they went to this opinion. But there is no validity for what they undertook of that). Sheikh Ahmad Shakir said in his commentary on At-Tirmidhi (1/ 103) following this: (And Al-Khattabi spoke the truth. The common people have increased in persistence on this action which has no basis, and went to extremes in it, especially in the lands of Egypt, imitating the Christians, until they started putting flowers on graves and gifting them among themselves, so people put them on the graves of their relatives and acquaintances as a greeting to them and courtesy to the living. It even became a custom similar to official protocol in international courtesies, so you find the great ones among Muslims, if they visit a town in Europe, they go to the graves of its greats or to the grave of the one they call (The Soldier =

text: (1/ 21 / 1) suspended (Mawquf) with an authentic chain, and Al-Harawi in (Dhamm al-Kalam) (2/ 36 / 1) raised (Marfu').
foot_note: 1. = Unknown) and put flowers on them. Some of them put artificial flowers that have no moisture, imitating the Franks, and following the ways of those before them. The scholars who resemble the common people do not deny that; rather, you see them doing it themselves at the graves of their dead. I have learned that most endowments called charitable endowments have their proceeds dedicated to palm branches and basil placed on graves. All these are innovations and forbidden acts that have no basis in the religion, and no support from the Book and Sunnah. It is obligatory upon the people of knowledge to deny them and invalidate these customs as much as they can)... I say: Supporting the fact that placing the palm branch on the grave is specific to him, and that the lightening was not due to the moisture of its split part, are several matters: A - The long hadith of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, in (Sahih Muslim) (8/ 231 - 236), in which the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: (I passed by two graves being punished, so I liked that by my intercession it be withheld from them as long as the two branches are moist). This is explicit that lifting the punishment is only due to his (peace be upon him) intercession and supplication, not due to the moisture. Whether this story of Jabir is the same as the story of Ibn Abbas mentioned previously as Al-Ayni and others preferred, or different as Al-Hafiz preferred in (Al-Fath). On the first probability, it is clear. On the other probability, correct observation requires that the cause be one in both stories due to the similarity between them, and because moisture being a cause for lightening punishment for the dead is not known legally or rationally. If the matter were so, the lightest people in punishment would be the disbelievers who are buried in cemeteries resembling gardens due to the abundance of plants and trees planted there that remain green summer and winter! Added to the above is that some scholars like Al-Suyuti mentioned that the reason for the effect of moisture in lightening is that it praises Allah Almighty. They said: So if it goes from the wood and it dries, its praising is cut off! This reasoning contradicts the generality of His Blessed and Exalted saying: (And there is not a thing except that it exalts [Allah] by His praise, but you do not understand their [way of] exalting). B - In the hadith of Ibn Abbas itself, there is an indication that the secret is not in the moisture, or rather it is not the cause for lightening the punishment. That is his saying (then he called for a palm branch and split it in two), meaning lengthwise. It is known that splitting it causes the moisture to leave the split part and dry quickly, so the duration of lightening would be less than if he did not split it. If it were the cause, he (peace be upon him) would have kept it without splitting and placed a branch or at least half of it on every grave. Since he did not do so, it indicates that moisture is not the cause, and it is determined that it is a sign for the duration of lightening which Allah permitted in response to the intercession of His Prophet (peace be upon him), as explicitly stated in Jabir's hadith. Thus the two hadiths agree on identifying the cause, even if they might differ in the incident and its multiplicity. Ponder this, for it is something that sparked in my mind, and I did not find anyone who stated it or pointed to it among the scholars. If it is correct, it is from Allah Almighty, and if it is incorrect, it is from me, and I seek His forgiveness for everything that does not please Him. C - If moisture were intended in itself, the Salaf as-Salih would have understood that and acted according to it, and they would have placed palm branches and myrtle and the like on graves when visiting them. Had they done so, it would have been famous from them, then trustworthy narrators would have transmitted it to us, because it is of the matters that draw attention and motives call for its transmission. Since it was not transmitted, it indicates it did not happen, and that drawing near to Allah with it is an innovation. So the intended meaning is established. =

text: And I see it only as a delusion. And only the first half of it is authentic as raised (Marfu') and the hadith of Jabir has passed.
foot_note: 1. = And when this becomes clear, it becomes easy then to understand the invalidity of that flimsy analogy which Al-Suyuti quoted in (Sharh as-Sudur) from someone he did not name: (If it is lightened for them by the praising of the branch, then how about the believer reading the Qur'an? He said: And this hadith is a basis for planting trees at graves)! I say: It is said to him: (Establish the Throne then engrave), and (Can the shadow be straight while the stick is crooked)? If the analogy were correct, the Salaf would have rushed to it because they are more eager for good than us. So what preceded indicates that placing the palm branch on the grave is specific to him (peace be upon him), and that the secret in lightening the punishment for the two graves was not in the moisture of the branch but in his (peace be upon him) intercession and supplication for them. This is something that cannot happen again after his (peace be upon him) transition to the Highest Companion, nor for anyone else after him (peace be upon him), because knowing the punishment of the grave is one of his specifics, peace be upon him, and it is of the Unseen that no one views except the Messenger as came in the text of the Qur'an (Knower of the unseen, and He does not disclose His unseen to anyone / Except whom He has approved of messengers). Know that what Al-Suyuti cited in (Sharh as-Sudur) (131) does not contradict what we explained: (And Ibn As-Asakir extracted via the path of Hammad bin Salamah from Qatadah that Abu Barzah Al-Aslami, may Allah be pleased with him, used to narrate that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by a grave whose companion was being punished, so he took a palm branch and planted it in the grave, and said: Perhaps it will be relieved for him as long as it is moist. And Abu Barzah used to recommend: If I die, put two palm branches with me in my grave. He said: So he died in a desert between (Kirman) and (Qumis). They said: He used to recommend us to put two branches in his grave and this is a place where we do not find them. While they were like that, a caravan appeared from the direction of (Sijistan), and they found palm fronds with them. So they took two branches and put them with him in his grave. And Ibn Sa'd extracted from Murriq who said: Buraydah recommended that two palm branches be placed in his grave). I say: The reason for lack of contradiction is that there is nothing in these two reports - assuming both are proven - indicating the legitimacy of placing palm branches *when visiting graves*, the innovation of which we claimed due to the Salaf not acting upon it. The most they contain is placing the two branches *with the dead in his grave*, which is another issue, even if it is like the one before it in lack of legislation because the hadith narrated by Abu Barzah, like other Companions, does not indicate that. Especially since the hadith mentions placing one branch, and he recommended placing two branches in his grave. Moreover, the report's chain is not authentic. Al-Khatib narrated it in the History of (Baghdad) (1/ 183 - 182) and via his path Ibn As-Asakir in (Tarikh Dimashq) at the end of the biography of Nadlah bin Ubayd bin Abi Barzah Al-Aslami from Ash-Shah bin Ammar who said: Abu Salih Sulayman bin Salih Al-Laythi told us, he said: An-Nadr bin Al-Mundhir bin Tha'labah Al-Abhadi informed us from Hammad bin Salamah with it. I say: This is a weak chain, and it has two defects: First: The anonymity of Ash-Shah and An-Nadr, for I did not find a biography for them. The other: The 'an'anah (narrating with 'from') of Qatadah, for they did not mention a narration for him from Abu Barzah, and he is mentioned for Tadlis (concealing sources), so his 'an'anah is feared in a chain like this. =

text: 2 - Raising them above the earth extracted from them. 3 - Coating them with lime and the like. 4 - Writing on them. 5 - Building on them. 6 - Sitting on them. In this regard, there are hadiths: First: On the authority of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade that the grave be plastered, sat upon, built over, [or added to], [or written upon]). Narrated by Muslim (3/ 62), Abu Dawood (2/ 71), An-Nasa'i (1/ 284 - 285, 286), At-Tirmidhi (2/ 155) - and he authenticated it -, Al-Hakim (1/ 370), Al-Bayhaqi (4/ 4), and Ahmad (3/ 295, 332, 339, 399). The two additions belong to Abu Dawood and An-Nasa'i. The first belongs to Al-Bayhaqi. The second is with At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim, who authenticated its chain and Adh-Dhahabi agreed. Al-Mundhiri (4/ 341) and others found fault with it due to disconnection between Sulayman bin Musa and Jabir. But this is regarding the path of Abu Dawood and others; otherwise, Al-Hakim narrated it via the path of Ibn Jurayj from Abu Az-Zubayr from Jabir. This is a chain on the condition of Muslim. Ibn Jurayj explicitly stated hearing it from Abu Az-Zubayr and the latter from Jabir in his narration, so the doubt of their Tadlis (concealing sources) was removed. From this face, the first addition came according to those we mentioned. Al-Nawawi said (5/ 296): (Its chain is authentic). Then he used it as evidence that it is recommended not to add to the grave over the earth extracted from it and said: (Ash-Shafi'i said: If he adds, there is no harm. Our companions said: It means it is not disliked). I say: This contradicts the apparent prohibition, for the principle in it is prohibition (Tahrim). The truth is what Ibn Hazm said in (Al-Muhalla) (5/ 33): (It is not lawful to build the grave, nor to plaster it, nor to add anything to its dust, and all that should be demolished).

text: This is apparent from the statement of Imam Ahmad. Abu Dawood said in (Al-Masa'il) (p. 158): (I heard Ahmad say: Nothing should be added to the grave from other earth, unless it is to level it with the ground so it is not known. As if he permitted it then). But it was mentioned in (Al-Insaf) (2/ 548) from him that it is only disliked (Karaha)! Imam Muhammad said in (Al-Athar) (p. 45): (Abu Hanifa informed us from Hammad from Ibrahim who said: It used to be said: Raise the grave so it is known as a grave and not stepped on. Muhammad said: And we take this view, and we do not see adding to what came out of it, and we dislike that it be plastered, or mudded, or that a place of prayer (masjid) or a mark be made at it, or that it be written upon. And we dislike baked bricks for building or entering the grave. And we see no harm in sprinkling water on it. This is the saying of Abu Hanifa). I say: The hadith indicates by implication the permissibility of raising the grave as much as the earth extracted from it allows, and that would be about a hand span. It agrees with the text mentioned in Issue (107). As for plastering (Tajsis), it is from (Jiss) which is lime. The meaning is coating with it. It says in (Al-Qamus): (And he Jassasa the vessel: filled it; and the building: coated it with lime). Perhaps the prohibition of plastering is because it is a type of decoration as some early scholars said. Based on this, what is the ruling on mudding (Tat'yin) the grave? The scholars have two opinions: First: Dislike (Karaha). Imam Muhammad explicitly stated it as I quoted from him just now. Dislike according to him implies prohibition (Tahrim) if used absolutely. Abu Hafs from the Hanbalis said it implies dislike as in (Al-Insaf) (2/ 549). The other: That there is no harm in it. Abu Dawood (158) narrated it from Imam Ahmad. It was asserted in (Al-Insaf). At-Tirmidhi (2/ 155) narrated it from Imam Ash-Shafi'i. Al-Nawawi said following it: (The majority of companions did not address it, so the correct view is that there is no dislike in it as explicitly stated, and no prohibition came regarding it). I say: Perhaps the correct view is detailing it as follows: If the intention of mudding is preserving the grave and keeping it raised as much as the Shari'ah permitted, and so winds do not blow it away nor rains scatter it, then it is permissible without doubt because it achieves a legitimate purpose. Perhaps this is the perspective of those Hanbalis who said
foot_note: None

text: that it is recommended. And if the intention is decoration and the like which has no benefit, then it is not permissible because it is innovated. As for writing, the apparent meaning of the hadith is its prohibition. This is the apparent meaning of Imam Muhammad's speech. The Shafi'is and Hanbalis explicitly stated only dislike! Al-Nawawi said (5/ 298): (Our companions said: Whether the writing on the grave is on a board at its head as is the habit of some people, or elsewhere, all of it is disliked due to the generality of the hadith). Some scholars made an exception for writing the name of the deceased, not for decoration, but for identification, by analogy to the Prophet (peace be upon him) placing the stone on the grave of Uthman bin Maz'un as proceeded in the issue referred to just now (p. 155). Al-Shawkani said: (This is restricting by analogy, and the majority have said it, not that it is an analogy opposing the text as said in [Daw' an-Nahar], but the issue is in the validity of this analogy). And what I see - and Allah knows best - is that the opinion of the validity of this analogy absolutely is far-fetched. The correct view is restricting it to when the stone does not achieve the purpose for which the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) placed the stone, which is identification, due to the abundance of graves for example and the abundance of identification stones! Then it becomes permissible to write the name as much as the mentioned purpose is achieved. And Allah knows best. As for Al-Hakim's statement following the hadith: (Practice is not upon this, for the Imams of Muslims from East to West have writing on their graves, and it is a practice taken by the later generations from the early ones). Adh-Dhahabi refuted him saying: (You have not said anything significant, nor do we know a Companion who did that. Rather, it is something initiated by some Tabi'un and those after them - and the prohibition did not reach them). Second: On the authority of Abu Sa'id, who is Al-Khudri (That the Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade building on the grave).

As for the hadith famous on the tongues with the wording: (The best of graves are the effaced ones), it has no basis in any of the books of Sunnah, and it is denounced (Munkar) by its appearance, because the grave should not be obliterated, but should remain visible raised above the ground about a hand span as preceded, so it is known and preserved, not insulted, and visited, not abandoned. Furthermore, the apparent meaning of Fadalah's hadith (He used to order us to level graves) is leveling them with the ground so they are not raised at all. This apparent meaning is definitely not intended, evidenced by the fact that the Sunnah is raising about a hand span as previously indicated. This is supported from the hadith itself by Fadalah's saying (Lighten) meaning the earth, so he did not order removing the earth from it entirely. The scholars interpreted it this way, see (Al-Mirqat) (2/ 372). text: Narrated by Muslim (3/ 62), the authors of the three Sunan, and others. It has a witness from the hadith of Ibn Abbas narrated by Ad-Diya Al-Maqdisi in (Al-Ahadith Al-Mukhtarah). I spoke about its chain in (Takhrij Sifat Salat an-Nabi, peace be upon him) then in (Tahdhir as-Sajid) (p. 21). In these three hadiths is evidence for the prohibition of sitting and stepping on the grave of a Muslim. This is the school of the majority of scholars as narrated by Al-Shawkani (4/ 57) and others. However, Al-Nawawi and Al-Asqalani narrated from them only dislike (Karaha), and it is the text of Imam Ash-Shafi'i in (Al-Umm) (1). Similarly, Imam Muhammad explicitly stated in (Al-Athar) (p. 45) the dislike and said: (And it is the saying of Abu Hanifa). I say: Dislike according to them, if used absolutely, implies prohibition (Tahrim). This is closer to correctness than saying just dislike. The truth is the opinion of prohibition because it is what the hadith of Abu Hurayrah and Uqbah explicitly state, due to the severe threat in them. A group of Shafi'is said this, including Al-Nawawi, and As-San'ani went to it in (Subul as-Salam) (1/ 210). The jurist Ibn Hajar Al-Haytami inclined in (Az-Zawajir) (1/ 143) to it being a major sin, due to what we indicated of severe threat, and that is not far from the truth. 7 - Praying towards graves, due to the hadith mentioned just now (Do not pray towards graves...). In it is evidence for the prohibition of prayer towards the grave due to the apparent prohibition. It is Al-Nawawi's choice. Al-Munawi said in (Fayd al-Qadir) explaining the hadith:

Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1/ 420), Muslim (2/ 187), and Ahmad (No. 4511, 4653, 6045). Fourth: On the authority of Abu Hurayrah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (Do not make your houses graveyards, verily Satan flees from the house in which Surah Al-Baqarah is read). Narrated by Muslim. Al-Bukhari titled the third hadith with his saying: (Chapter: Dislike of Prayer in Graveyards). Al-Hafiz explained the reason for that in his commentary, saying in summary: (He deduced from his saying in the hadith: (do not take them as graves) that graves are not a place for worship, so prayer in them is disliked. Al-Isma'ili disputed the author in this title saying: The hadith indicates the dislike of prayer *in* the grave, not *in* the graveyards. I say: It was reported with the wording 'graveyards' as Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah with the wording (Do not make your houses graveyards). Ibn at-Tin said: Al-Bukhari interpreted it as the dislike of prayer in graveyards. A group interpreted it that it is an encouragement for prayer in houses, since the dead do not pray, as if he said: Do not be like the dead who do not pray in their houses which are the graves. He said: As for the permissibility of prayer in graveyards or preventing it, there is nothing in the hadith from which that is taken. I say: If he meant it is not taken from it by way of explicit wording (mantuq), then granted. If he meant denying that absolutely, then no, for we have presented the mode of his deduction. Ibn Al-Mundhir reported from most people of knowledge that they used this hadith as evidence that the graveyard is not a place for prayer. Al-Baghawi said likewise in (Sharh as-Sunnah) and Al-Khattabi).

text: I say: And this is the most likely, that the hadith indicates that the graveyard is not a place for prayer, especially with the wording of Abu Hurayrah, for it is more explicit in indication. Al-Isma'ili's saying: It indicates the dislike of prayer in the grave not in the graveyards, along with its explicit contradiction to the hadith of Abu Hurayrah, it is not proper to carry Ibn Umar's hadith on it, because prayer in the grave is not possible usually, so how can the Lawgiver's speech be carried on it!? And the saying of Ibn at-Tin: (He is one of the commentators on (Sahih Al-Bukhari) and his name is Abdul Wahid) (The dead do not pray). is not correct, because no text came in the Shari'ah denying that, and it is of the Unseen matters that should not be decided upon except with a text, and that is missing. Rather, what invalidates generalizing the saying of it has come, which is the prayer of Moses (peace be upon him) in his grave as the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saw him on the Night of Isra' as Muslim narrated in his (Sahih). Likewise, the prayer of the Prophets (peace be upon them) following him on that night as proven in the (Sahih). Rather, it is proven from him (peace be upon him) that he said: (The Prophets are alive in their graves, praying). Narrated by Abu Ya'la with a good chain, and I extracted it in (Al-Ahadith As-Sahihah) (622). Rather, there came from him (peace be upon him) what is more general than what we mentioned, in the hadith of Abu Hurayrah regarding the questioning of the believer by the two angels in the grave: (It is said to him sit, so he sits while the sun is represented to him as setting. It is said to him: What do you say about this man who was among you? And what do you testify against him? He says: Leave me until I pray. They say: You will do so). Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) (781) and Al-Hakim (1/ 379 - 380) and he said (Authentic on the condition of Muslim) and Adh-Dhahabi agreed! But it is only Hasan, because it contains Muhammad bin Amr and Muslim did not rely on him; he only narrated for him coupled with others or as corroboration. This hadith is explicit that the believer also prays in his grave. Thus, the saying that the dead do not pray is invalidated, and it is preferred that the meaning of Ibn Umar's hadith is that the graveyard is not a place for prayer. And Allah knows best.

text: The hadith and what was mentioned with it indicate the dislike of prayer in the graveyard, and it is for prohibition (Tahrim) due to the apparent prohibition in some of them. Some scholars went to the invalidity of prayer in it because the prohibition indicates the corruption of the prohibited act. It is the opinion of Ibn Hazm, and chosen by Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, and Al-Shawkani in (Nayl al-Awtar) (2/ 112). Ibn Hazm narrated (4/ 27 - 28) from Imam Ahmad that he said: (Whoever prays in a graveyard or towards a grave repeats forever) (1). Then the dislike of prayer in the graveyard includes every place in it, whether the grave is in front of the worshipper, behind him, on his right, or on his left, because the prohibition is absolute. It is established in the science of Usul that the absolute is applied on its absoluteness until what restricts it comes, and nothing of that came here. Some Hanafi jurists and others explicitly stated what we mentioned as follows. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat al-Ilmiyyah) (p. 25): (And prayer is not valid in the graveyard nor towards it. The prohibition of that is only to block the means to Shirk. A group of our companions mentioned that a grave or two do not prevent prayer, because the name 'graveyard' does not apply to it; rather a graveyard is three graves and up. There is not in the speech of Ahmad and the generality of his companions this distinction. Rather, the generality of their speech, reasoning, and deduction necessitates preventing prayer at a single grave among
