He said: All these reports are truth, so prayer is not lawful where we mentioned except the funeral prayer, for it is prayed in the graveyard, and on the grave whose owner has been buried as the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did. We forbid what he forbade, and we count doing what he did as drawing near to Allah Almighty! His command and prohibition are truth, and his action is truth, and whatever is other than that is false). I say: And in what he said regarding the funeral prayer, there is a point of view, because there is no text for its permissibility in the graveyard. If Ibn Hazm were of those who say in analogy, we would have said he analogized that to prayer *on* the grave. But he says analogy is invalid from its root. And the funeral prayer in the graveyard is contrary to the Sunnah which did not come except with praying it in the prayer place (Musalla) and in the Mosque as previously explained in its place. Rather, the explicit prohibition came regarding praying it between graves as in a narration in the hadith of Anas mentioned in this chapter, which is the second hadith of it.

text: graves, and that is the correct view. A graveyard (Maqbarah) is everything in which burial takes place, not that it is the plural of grave. Our companions said: And everything that enters the name of graveyard from what is around the graves, one does not pray in it. This specifies that the prevention covers the prohibited zone (harim) of the single grave and its courtyard added to it. Al-Amidi and others mentioned: It is not permissible to pray in it - meaning the mosque whose Qiblah is towards the grave - until there is another barrier between the wall and the graveyard. Some of them mentioned: This is the text of Ahmad). In the words of the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, is the explicit statement that the reason for prohibiting prayer in the graveyard is blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhara'i). This is one of two opinions of scholars on that. The other opinion is that the reason is the impurity of the graveyard's soil! Both are opinions in the Hanafi school. Ibn Abidin looked into the second of them in (Al-Hashiyah) (1/ 352), because transformation (Istihalah) is purifying according to them, so how can this reason be correct!? There is no doubt to us that the first opinion is the correct one, and Sheikh al-Islam explained that in his books and provided evidence for it not found with others. So refer, for example, to his book (Iqtida' as-Sirat al-Mustaqim) (152, 193). It was followed in (Al-Haniyah) from the Hanafi books. At-Tahtawi pointed to it in his footnote on (Maraqi al-Falah) saying at the author's phrase (And prayer in the graveyard is disliked) (1/ 208) (with a triple vowel on Ba', because it is imitation of Jews and Christians. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Allah's curse is on Jews and Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques. Whether it is above him, behind him, or under what he stands on. Exceptions are the graves of Prophets, peace be upon them, so prayer is not disliked in them absolutely, whether exhumed or not, provided the grave is not in the direction of the Qiblah, because they are alive in their graves)! I say: And this exception is false, explicitly false. How so, when it contradicts the reason he mentioned and the hadith he used as evidence for it? And how can such an exception be valid when hadiths are widespread regarding cursing the People of the Book for taking the graves of their prophets as mosques, then it is authentic that the Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade us from that? So the prohibition is focused on taking the graves of Prophets directly, and others are attached to them. So how is it conceivable to exclude them!? The truth is that such an exception only aligns with the second opinion that the reason is impurity, and the graves of Prophets are undoubtedly pure because he (peace be upon him) said: (Verily Allah forbade the earth to eat the bodies of Prophets). But this reason is false, and what is built on falsehood is false. (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) And I have detailed the discussion on Al-Tahtawi's error and contradiction in the mentioned exception in my book (Ath-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab).

text: 9 - Building mosques over them. There are hadiths regarding this: First: On the authority of Aisha and Abdullah bin Abbas together, they said: (When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was close to death, he began to cast a Khamisah (2) of his over his face. When he felt distressed by it, he uncovered his face and said while in that state: 'May the curse of Allah be upon the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques,' warning against what they did). It was recorded by Al-Bukhari (1/422, 6/386, 8/116), Muslim (2/67), Al-Nasa'i (1/115), Al-Darimi (1/326), Al-Bayhaqi (4/80), and Ahmad (1/218, 6/34, 229, 275). The addition is from Muslim, Al-Darimi, and others. Second: On the authority of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said during his illness from which he did not recover: (May Allah curse the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques). She said: Were it not for that, his grave would have been made prominent, but he feared it would be taken as a mosque. It was recorded by Al-Bukhari (3/156, 198, 8/114), Abu Awana (2/399), and Ahmad (6/80, 121, 255). He also has another route from her (6/146, 252). Third: On the authority of Abu Huraira, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: (May Allah fight the Jews [and in a narration: May Allah curse the Jews and Christians]; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques). It was recorded by Al-Bukhari (1/422), Muslim, Abu Awana (2/400), Abu Dawood (2/71), Al-Bayhaqi (4/80), and Ahmad (2/284, 366, 396, 453, 518). The second narration is his, and for Muslim and Abu Awana, and it is from another route from Abu Huraira. Fourth: From him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: (O Allah, do not make my grave an idol. May Allah curse a people who took the graves of their prophets as mosques). It was recorded by Ahmad (2/246), Ibn Sa'd in (Al-Tabaqat) (2/362), and Abu Nu'aym in (Al-Hilyah).
foot_note: None

text: (7/317) with a Sahih (authentic) chain. As for the statement of Al-Haythami in (Majma' Al-Zawa'id) (23): (It was narrated by Abu Ya'la, and in it is Ishaq bin Abi Isra'il, regarding whom there is some discussion due to his stopping [Waqf] regarding the Quran, but the rest of its men are trustworthy), this view is questionable from several aspects: 1 - He limited the attribution to Abu Ya'la, giving the impression it is not in (Musnad Ahmad), which is not the case as you have known. 2 - The mentioned Ishaq is trustworthy (Thiqah), and his stopping regarding the Quran is not a valid disparagement as established in the science of Hadith terminology. 3 - He was not the only one to narrate it; it is in Ahmad through a route other than his. Thus, the Hadith is authentic without doubt. It has a Mursal supporting evidence recorded by Malik in (Al-Muwatta) (1/185-186) with a Sahih chain. It was also narrated as connected (Mawsul) from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. Fifth: On the authority of Jundub, who said: I heard the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, five days before he died, saying: [I certainly had brothers and friends among you, and] I declare myself clear before Allah from taking a Khalil (close friend) from among you, for Allah the Exalted has taken me as a Khalil just as He took Ibrahim as a Khalil. If I were to take a Khalil from my Ummah, I would have taken Abu Bakr as a Khalil. Beware! Those before you used to take the graves of their prophets and righteous people as mosques. Beware! Do not take graves as mosques; I forbid you from that). It was recorded by Muslim (2/67-68) excluding the other six. Al-Shawkani (2/114) also attributed it to Al-Nasa'i, perhaps meaning his (Al-Sunan Al-Kubra), as he did not attribute it in (Al-Dhakha'ir) except to Muslim alone. Yes, Abu Awana recorded it in his (Sahih) (2/401), and the addition is his. Sixth: On the authority of Abdullah bin Mas'ud, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: (Indeed, among the worst of people are those upon whom the Hour comes while they are alive, and those who take graves as mosques). It was recorded by Ahmad (No. 3844, 4143, 4144, 4342) with two Hasan (good) chains from him. It was also narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih), and Ibn Taymiyyah said:
foot_note: None

text: (Its chain is Jayyid [good]). Al-Haythami overlooked its presence in the Musnad, so he said (2/27): (It was narrated by Al-Tabarani in [Al-Kabir] and its chain is Hasan). Seventh: On the authority of Aisha, who said: (When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was ill, some of his wives mentioned a church in the land of Abyssinia called 'Mariyah'—Umm Salamah and Umm Habibah had been to the land of Abyssinia—and they mentioned its beauty and its images. She said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: Indeed, those people, when a righteous man among them [died], they built a mosque over his grave, then they painted those images in it. Those are the worst of creation in the sight of Allah [on the Day of Judgment]). It was recorded by Al-Bukhari (1/416, 422), Muslim (2/66-67), Al-Nasa'i (1/115), as well as Abu Awana (2/400-401), Al-Bayhaqi (4/80)—the wording is theirs—Ahmad (6/51), and Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/140). The two additions belong to him, the two Sheikhs, and others. In this chapter, there are other hadiths from a group of other Companions, which I cited in (Tahdhir Al-Sajid min Ittikhadh Al-Qubur Masajid). They indicate decisively that taking graves as mosques is Haram (forbidden) because of the curse upon those who do so. Therefore, the jurist Al-Haytami said in (Al-Zawajir) (1/120-121): (The ninety-third major sin: Taking graves as mosques). Then he cited some of the preceding hadiths and others not meeting our criteria, then said: (Counting this as a major sin appeared in the speech of some Shafi'is, and it seems he took that from what is mentioned in these hadiths. Its reasoning is clear, because he cursed those who did that to the graves of their prophets, and he made those who did that to the graves of their righteous ones the worst of creation in the sight of Allah on the Day of Judgment. This contains a warning for us, as in the narration (warning against what they did), meaning he warns his Ummah by telling them that, lest they do as those did, and thus be cursed as they were cursed... Some Hanbalis said: A man's intention to pray at a grave seeking blessing by it is the essence of opposing Allah and His Messenger, and innovating a religion which Allah has not authorized. There is prohibition against it, then consensus,
foot_note: None

text: for the greatest of prohibitions and causes of Shirk (polytheism) is praying at them, taking them as mosques, or building over them. The opinion of [mere] dislike (Karahah) is interpreted to mean other than that, for it is not thought of scholars that they would permit an act for which the curse upon its doer has been mutawatir (mass transmitted) from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. It is obligatory to hasten to demolish them and demolish the domes over the graves, for they are more harmful than the Mosque of Harm (Masjid al-Dirar) because they were founded on disobedience to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, because he forbade that. And the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, commanded the leveling of elevated graves. It is obligatory to remove every lamp or lantern on a grave, and endowing or vowing for it is invalid. End quote). This 'taking' mentioned in the preceding hadiths includes several matters: First: Praying towards the graves, facing them. Second: Prostrating on the graves. Third: Building mosques over them. The second meaning is apparent from 'taking', and the other two, while included in it, have been explicitly mentioned in some of the preceding hadiths. I have detailed the discussion on that and cited the sayings of scholars as evidence in our specific book (Tahdhir Al-Sajid min Ittikhadh Al-Qubur Masajid) [Warning the Prostrator against Taking Graves as Mosques], and I mentioned therein the history of the inclusion of the Prophetic Grave into the Noble Mosque, and the opposition to the preceding hadiths therein, and that prayer is not disliked in it specifically (due to necessity/context). Whoever wishes to see the detailed discussion on all of that should refer to it. 10 - Taking it as an 'Eid' (Festival): Intending to visit it at specific times and known seasons for worship there, or for other reasons. This is due to the hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: (Do not take my grave as an 'Eid' (festival), and do not make your houses graves, and send blessings upon me wherever you are, for your blessings reach me). It was recorded by Abu Dawood (1/319) and Ahmad (2/367) with a Hasan chain, and it meets the criteria of Muslim. It is authentic due to its routes and supporting evidences. It has another route from Abu Huraira in Abu Nu'aym's (Al-Hilyah) (6/283).
foot_note: None

text: And it has a Mursal witness with a strong chain from Suhayl who said: (Al-Hasan bin Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib saw me at the Grave, and he called me while he was in Fatima's house having supper. He said: 'Come to supper.' I said: 'I do not want it.' He said: 'Why did I see you at the Grave?' I said: 'I greeted the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.' He said: 'When you enter the mosque, greet him.' Then he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'Do not take my grave as an 'Eid', nor take your houses as graves, and send blessings upon me, for your blessings reach me wherever you are. May Allah curse the Jews; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques.' You and those in Andalusia are but the same). Narrated by Sa'id bin Mansur as in (Al-Iqtida') by Ibn Taymiyyah. It is also with Sheikh Ismail bin Ishaq Al-Qadi in (Fadl Al-Salah 'ala Al-Nabi, peace be upon him) (No. 30)(1) without the phrase (May Allah curse the Jews...). Ibn Abi Shaybah also narrated it (4/140) limiting it to the Marfu' (elevated to the Prophet) part only. It has another witness similar to this from the route of Ali bin Al-Hussein from his father from his grandfather, Marfu'. It was recorded by Ismail Al-Qadi (No. 20) and others. See (Tahdhir Al-Sajid) (98-99). The hadith is proof of the prohibition of taking the graves of prophets and righteous people as an 'Eid'. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in (Al-Iqtida') (pp. 155-156): (The indication is that the grave of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, is the best grave on the face of the earth, yet he forbade taking it as an 'Eid'. So, the grave of anyone else is more deserving of the prohibition, whoever he may be. Then he coupled that with his saying: 'And do not make your houses graves'), meaning do not empty them of prayer, supplication, and recitation, such that they become like graves. So he commanded seeking worship in houses and forbade seeking it at graves, contrary to what the polytheists among the Christians and those who imitate them do. He said: This is the best of the Tabi'in from his household, Ali bin Al-Hussein, may Allah be pleased with them, forbidding that man from seeking to supplicate at his grave, peace be upon him, and reasoning with the hadith he heard from his father Al-Hussein from his grandfather Ali. He is more knowledgeable of its meaning than others. Thus, it became clear that his intent was
foot_note: 1. (1) First published by Al-Maktab Al-Islami with our verification; it can be requested from them.

text: that a man intending the grave to greet him and the like, other than when entering the mosque, and viewing that as supplication and the like, constitutes taking it as an 'Eid'. Similarly, his cousin Hasan bin Hasan, the sheikh of his household, disliked taking it as an 'Eid'. Look at this Sunnah, how its source is from the people of Medina and the Ahl al-Bayt, who have the closeness of lineage and location to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, for they were in more need of that than others, so they were more disciplined regarding it. 'Eid', if used as a name for a place, is the place intended for gathering and coming to for worship or other than worship, just as the Sacred Mosque, Mina, Muzdalifah, and Arafat were made by Allah as an 'Eid' and a place of return for people, where they gather and frequent for supplication, remembrance, and rituals. The polytheists had places they frequented for gathering; when Islam came, Allah erased all of that. This type of place includes the graves of prophets and righteous people). Then the Sheikh said (pp. 175-181): (For this reason, Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, and others of the people of knowledge disliked for the people of Medina that every time one of them entered the mosque, he would go and greet the grave of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and his two companions. He said: This is only for one of them if he arrives from a journey or intends a journey and the like. Some permitted greeting him when entering the mosque for prayer and the like, but as for intending it constantly for prayer and greeting, I know of no one who permitted it, because that is a type of taking it as an 'Eid'... even though it has been prescribed for us when we enter the mosque to say ('Peace be upon you, O Prophet, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings') (1) just as we say that at the end of our prayer. He said: So Malik and others feared that doing that at the grave every hour would be a type of taking the grave as an 'Eid'. Also, that is an innovation (Bid'ah), for the Muhajirun and Ansar during the time of Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and Ali, may Allah be pleased with them, used to come to the mosque every day knowing, may Allah be pleased with them, what
foot_note: 1. () I say: I have not seen this formula in any of the hadiths narrated regarding the etiquette of entering and leaving the mosque. He took it from the general saying: (When one of you enters the mosque, let him greet the Prophet, peace be upon him...) The hadith was recorded by Abu Awana in his Sahih (1/414) and Abu Dawood in his Sunan (No. 465). Its remoteness is obvious, especially since the formula came in the hadith of Fatima, may Allah be pleased with her, with the wording (Peace be upon the Messenger of Allah, O Allah, send blessings upon Muhammad and the family of Muhammad). Recorded by Al-Qadi Ismail (82-84) and others. See (Nuzul Al-Abrar) (72) and (Al-Kalam Al-Tayyib, No. 63, my verification, published by Al-Maktab Al-Islami).

text: the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, disliked of that and what he forbade them from, and that they greet him upon entering the mosque and leaving it, and in the Tashahhud, just as they used to greet him during his life. How excellent is what Malik said: 'The latter part of this nation will not be rectified except by what rectified its first part.' But whenever nations' adherence to the covenants of their prophets weakens, and their faith decreases, they compensate for that with what they innovate of heresies, Shirk, and other things. For this reason, the Ummah disliked touching the grave and kissing it. And they built a structure preventing people from praying towards it. He said: We have mentioned from Ahmad and others that he commanded whoever greeted the Prophet and his two companions and then wanted to supplicate, to turn away and face the Qiblah. Likewise, the early scholars like Malik and others denounced that, and the later ones like Abu Al-Wafa' Ibn Aqil and Abu Al-Faraj Ibn Al-Jawzi. I do not memorize from any Companion, nor Tabi'i, nor known Imam that he recommended intending any grave for supplication at it, nor did anyone narrate anything regarding that, neither from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, nor from his Companions, nor from any of the known Imams. People have written about supplication, its times, and its places, and mentioned narrations therein, yet none of them mentioned a single letter about the virtue of supplication at graves as far as I know. So how can it be permissible, given this situation, that supplication at them is more answered and better, while the Salaf denounce it, do not recognize it, forbid it, and do not command it!? He said: The belief in the responsiveness of supplication at them and its virtue has necessitated that they be frequented and intended for that reason, and perhaps many gatherings occur at them in specific seasons. This is exactly what the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade by saying: (Do not take my grave as an 'Eid'). He said: Even some graves are gathered at on a day of the year, and people travel to them either in Muharram, Rajab, Sha'ban, Dhul-Hijjah, or others. Some gather at them on the day of Ashura, some on the day of Arafah, and some on the middle of Sha'ban, and some at another time, such that they have a day of the year in which they are intended and gathered at, just as Arafah, Muzdalifah, and Mina are intended on known days of the year, and just as the prayer place of the city is intended on the two Eid days. Nay, perhaps the concern for these gatherings in religion and worldly matters is more important and intense [to them]. Among them are those traveled to from regions at a specific time, or an unspecified time, intending supplication there and worship there, just as the Sacred House of Allah is intended for that. This travel, I know of no disagreement among Muslim scholars regarding its prohibition. He said:
foot_note: None

text: And among them are those where gathering is intended on a specific day of the week. In summary, what is done at these graves is exactly what the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade by saying: (Do not take my grave as an 'Eid'). For the habit of intending a specific place at a specific time, recurring with the return of the year, month, or week, is exactly the meaning of 'Eid'. Then he forbids the small and large aspects of that. This is what was previously mentioned from Imam Ahmad regarding his denunciation. He (meaning Ahmad) said: People have gone to great excess in this and have done much. And he mentioned what is done at the grave of Al-Hussein. Then the Sheikh said: This includes what is done in Egypt at the grave of Nafisa and others, and what is done in Iraq at the grave said to be the grave of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, and the grave of Al-Hussein, and Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman, and... and... and what is done at the grave of Abu Yazid Al-Bistami to many graves in most lands of Islam that cannot be counted. He said: Making a habit of intending these graves at a specific time, and the general gathering at them at a specific time, is taking them as an 'Eid' as preceded, and I know of no disagreement among the Muslim scholars regarding that. One should not be deceived by the multitude of corrupt customs, for this is from the imitation of the People of the Two Books (Jews and Christians) which the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, informed us would happen in this Ummah. The root of that is solely the belief in the virtue of supplication at them; otherwise, if this belief were not established in the hearts, all of that would be erased. So if intending them leads to these evils, it is Haram (forbidden) like praying at them, and even more so, and that is a trial (Fitnah) for creation, an opening of the door to Shirk, and a closing of the door to Faith). I say: And what enters into this primarily is what is witnessed today in Medina Munawwarah, of people intending the grave of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, after every obligatory prayer to greet him and supplicate at him and by him, raising their voices before him, such that the mosque buzzes with them, especially in the Hajj season, as if that were one of the Sunnahs of prayer! Indeed, they maintain this more than they maintain the Sunnahs. All of this happens within the sight and hearing of the authorities, and none of them denounces it. To Allah we belong and to Him we return. Alas for the strangeness of the religion and its people, and in the Mosque of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, which should be the furthest of mosques, after the Sacred Mosque, from contradicting his Sharia, peace be upon him. Having said this, it has preceded in the words of Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah that some scholars permitted coming to the Noble Grave to greet him when entering the mosque for prayer and the like. It seems this is restricted
foot_note: None

text: to not doing it excessively or repeatedly, evidenced by his saying after that: (As for intending it constantly for prayer and greeting, I know of no one who permitted it). I say: This permission which the Sheikh narrated from some scholars is what we narrate and rely upon, subject to the mentioned condition. Thus, it is permissible for someone in Medina to come to the Noble Grave to greet him, peace be upon him, occasionally, because that is not taking it as an 'Eid' as is apparent. Greeting him and his two companions is prescribed by general evidences, so it is not permissible to negate its legitimacy absolutely due to his prohibition, peace be upon him, against taking his grave as an 'Eid', because it is possible to reconcile [the texts] by observing the condition we mentioned. It does not contradict this that we do not know that any of the Salaf used to do that, because lack of knowledge of a thing does not necessitate knowledge of its non-existence, as scholars say. In such a case, general evidences are sufficient to establish its legitimacy as long as nothing contradicting them is proven in our context. Furthermore, Sheikh Al-Islam mentioned in (Al-Qa'idah Al-Jalilah) (p. 80, Al-Manar edition) from Nafi' that he said: Ibn Umar used to greet the Grave. I saw him a hundred times or more coming to the Grave saying: 'Peace be upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, peace be upon Abu Bakr, peace be upon my father,' then he would leave. Its appearance suggests he used to do that while being a resident, not traveling, because his saying 'a hundred times' makes it unlikely to interpret this narration as being in the state of travel... 11 - Traveling to them: There are hadiths regarding this: First: On the authority of Abu Huraira from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: (Mounts are not to be saddled [for travel] except to three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, the Mosque of the Messenger, peace be upon him, and the Farthest Mosque [Al-Aqsa]). In another narration from him with the wording: (Travel is only undertaken to three mosques: The Mosque of the Kaaba, my Mosque, and the Mosque of Aelia [Jerusalem]). Recorded by Al-Bukhari with the first wording, and Muslim with the other wording from a second route from him. It was recorded from the first route by the authors of the Sunan and others.
foot_note: None

text: It has a third route: In Ahmad (2/501) and Al-Darimi (1/330). I have detailed the Hadith in (Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab). Second: On the authority of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: (Mounts are not to be saddled [and in a wording: Do not saddle mounts] except to three mosques: This Mosque of mine, the Sacred Mosque, and the Farthest Mosque). Recorded by the two Sheikhs and others. It has four routes from him which I cited in the previous source. The other wording belongs to Muslim. The fourth route: Narrated by Shahr bin Hawshab, and from him two people: One of them: Layth bin Abi Sulaym from him, who said: (We met Abu Sa'id while we were intending [to go to] Tur [Mount Sinai], so he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: Mounts should not be worked except...) the Hadith. The other: Abdul Hamid bin Bahram from him, who said: (I heard Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, and prayer at Tur was mentioned in his presence, so he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: It is not befitting for mounts to have their saddles fastened to a mosque in which prayer is sought other than the Sacred Mosque...). The Hadith. Ahmad recorded both (3/93, 64). Shahr is weak, and he is alone in this addition (to a mosque in which prayer is sought), so it is Munkar (denounced) due to its absence in other routes from Abu Sa'id, even in the route of Layth from Shahr. Likewise, it did not appear in the other hadiths, which are eight, most of which have more than one route. I have cited all of them in (Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab). The absence of this addition in any of these hadiths, despite their abundance and multiple sources, is the greatest proof of the addition's oddity and invalidity. It is from the delusions of Shahr bin Hawshab or the narrator from him, Abdul Hamid, for there is some weakness in him regarding his memory. Al-Hafiz said in the biography of Shahr in (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful [Saduq], makes many mistakes [Kathir al-Awham]).
foot_note: None

text: Third: On the authority of Abu Basra Al-Ghifari that he met Abu Huraira while he was coming. He said: From where did you come? He said: I came from Tur; I prayed in it. He said: Had I caught you before you left, you would not have gone. I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: (Mounts are not to be saddled except to three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, this Mosque of mine, and the Farthest Mosque). Recorded by Al-Tayalisi (1348) and Ahmad (6/7), and the context is his, and its chain is Sahih. It has two other routes in Ahmad; the chain of the first is Hasan, and the other is Sahih. Malik, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Tirmidhi recorded it and corrected it from the third route, except that one of the narrators erred in its chain, making it from the Musnad of Basra bin Abi Basra. And in its text where he said: (Mounts should not be worked). Fourth: On the authority of Qaza'a who said: (I wanted to go out to Tur, so I asked Ibn Umar, and he said: Did you not know that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: (Mounts are not to be saddled except to three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, the Mosque of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the Farthest Mosque), so leave Tur alone and do not go to it). Recorded by Al-Azraqi (in Akhbar Makkah) (p. 304) with a Sahih chain whose men are men of the Sahih. Al-Haythami cited the Marfu' part in (Al-Majma') (4/4) and said: (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and Al-Awsat, and its men are trustworthy). In these hadiths is the prohibition of traveling to any blessed place, such as the graves of prophets and righteous people. Even if it is in the form of negation (not to be saddled), the meaning is prohibition as Al-Hafiz said, on the pattern of His saying: (There is no sexual intercourse, nor disobedience, nor disputing in Hajj), which is as Al-Tibi said: (It is more emphatic than explicit prohibition, as if he said: It is not correct that a journey be intended except to these places due to their specific exclusivity).
foot_note: None

text: I say: What attests to the negation here being in the sense of prohibition is a narration by Muslim in the second hadith: (Do not saddle). Then Al-Hafiz said: (His saying: 'except to three mosques', the exception is emptied [Mufarragh], and the estimation is: Saddles are not fastened to a place, and its implication is preventing travel to every place other than them, because the excluded-from in the emptied exception is estimated as the most general of the general. But it is possible that the general intended here is specific, which is the mosque). I say: This probability is weak, and the correct view is the first estimation. Because of what preceded in the hadith of Abu Basra and Ibn Umar regarding the denunciation of travel to Tur. Its clarification will come. Then Al-Hafiz said: (In this hadith is the virtue of these mosques and their advantage over others due to being the mosques of Prophets, and because the first is the Qiblah of the people and to it is their Hajj, the second was the Qiblah of past nations, and the third was founded on piety. [He said:] Opinions differed regarding saddling mounts to other than them, like going to visit the righteous, living or dead, and to virtuous places, intending blessing by them and praying in them. Sheikh Abu Muhammad Al-Juwayni (1) said: (It is forbidden to saddle mounts to other than them, acting upon the apparent meaning of the hadith). Al-Qadi Hussein indicated his choice of this, and Iyad and a group said it. This is indicated by what the authors of the Sunan narrated regarding Abu Basra Al-Ghifari's objection to Abu Huraira for his going out to Tur, saying to him: 'Had I caught you before you went out, you would not have gone out,' and he used this hadith as evidence. This indicates he sees the hadith should be taken on its general meaning, and Abu Huraira agreed with him. The correct view according to Imam Al-Haramayn and others of the Shafi'is is that it is not forbidden, and they answered the hadith with answers: 1 - That the meaning is that complete virtue is only in saddling mounts to these mosques contrary to others, for that is permissible. It occurred in a narration by Ahmad which will be mentioned with the wording: 'It is not befitting for mounts to be worked', which is a wording apparent in other than prohibition.
foot_note: 1. (1) He is Abdullah bin Yusuf, Sheikh of the Shafi'is and father of Imam Al-Haramayn Abdul Malik bin Abdullah. He was an Imam in Exegesis, Jurisprudence, and Literature. Died in the year (438).

text: 2 - That the prohibition is specific to one who vows upon himself to pray in a mosque from the other mosques apart from the three, for fulfillment of it is not obligatory. This was said by Ibn Battal. 3 - That the meaning is the ruling of mosques only, and that mounts are not saddled to a mosque of the mosques to pray in it other than these three. As for intending other than mosques to visit a righteous person, relative, friend, seeking a scholar, trade, or recreation, it does not enter into the prohibition. This is supported by what Ahmad narrated from the route of Shahr bin Hawshab who said: I heard Abu Sa'id - and prayer at Tur was mentioned in his presence - so he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'It is not befitting for mounts to have their saddles fastened to a mosque in which prayer is sought other than the Sacred Mosque, the Farthest Mosque, and this Mosque of mine.' Shahr is Hasan in Hadith, even if there is some weakness in him). I say: Al-Hafiz, may Allah have mercy on him, was lenient in his saying about Shahr that he is Hasan in Hadith. Even though he said about him in (Al-Taqrib): (Makes many mistakes) as preceded. It is known that whoever is like that, his hadith is weak and not used as proof, as Al-Hafiz himself established in (Sharh Al-Nukhba). Then assume he is Hasan in Hadith; he is only so when there is no contradiction. But since he has contradicted all narrators who narrated the hadith from Abu Sa'id, and others who narrated it from other Companions as explained, how can he be Hasan in Hadith with this contradiction!? Rather, he is Munkar (denounced) in Hadith in such a case, without any doubt or suspicion. Add to that his saying in the hadith (to a mosque), which is not established from Shahr himself, for Abdul Hamid mentioned it from him while Layth bin Abi Sulaym did not mention it from him, and this narration from him is weightier for agreeing with the narrations of the trustworthy ones as you knew. Also, whoever contemplates his hadith finds in it another proof of the invalidity of mentioning this addition in it, which is his statement: That Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri used the hadith as argument against Shahr for his going to Tur. If it contained this addition which restricts its ruling to mosques excluding other virtuous places, it would not be permissible for Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, to use it as argument against him, because Tur is not a mosque. Rather, it is the holy mountain upon which Allah spoke to Moses, so the hadith would not include it if the addition were established in it. And Abu Sa'id's reasoning with it, in this case, would be a delusion, which is inconceivable that Shahr and those with him would remain silent about. All of this confirms the invalidity of this addition and that it has no basis from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.
foot_note: None

text: Thus, it is proven from what preceded that there is no evidence restricting the hadith to mosques. So, it is obligatory to remain on its general meaning, which Abu Muhammad Al-Juwayni and those mentioned with him went to. And it is the truth. It remains for us to answer their first and second answers, so I say: 1 - This answer is invalid from two aspects: First: That the wording they used as proof (It is not befitting...) is not established in the hadith because Shahr was alone in it, and he is weak as previously explained. Second: Even if it were an established wording, we do not concede that it is apparent in other than prohibition. Rather, the opposite is correct, and evidences for that from the Book and Sunnah are many. I will suffice with some: A - His statement, Exalted is He: (They said: Glory be to You! It was not befitting for us to take allies besides You) [Al-Furqan: 18]. B - His statement, peace be upon him: (It is not befitting that anyone should punish with fire except the Lord of the fire). Narrated by Abu Dawood (2675) from the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, and Al-Darimi (2/222) from the hadith of Abu Huraira. C - (It is not befitting for a truthful man to be a curser). Narrated by Muslim. D - (Indeed, charity is not befitting for the family of Muhammad...). Narrated by Muslim. E - (It is not befitting for a slave to say: I am better than Yunus bin Matta). Narrated by Al-Bukhari. Third: Assume it is apparent in other than prohibition; it indicates dislike (Karahah), and they do not say [even] that. For in (Sharh Muslim) by Al-Nawawi: (The correct view according to our companions is that it is neither forbidden nor disliked)!
foot_note: None

text: So the hadith is an argument against them in any case. 2 - This answer, like the one before it, is devoid of consideration, because there is no evidence for specification. The obligation is to remain on the general meaning, especially since it is supported by the understanding of the Companions who narrated the Hadith: Abu Basra, Abu Huraira, Ibn Umar, and Abu Sa'id - if authentic from him. They all used it as evidence for the prevention of traveling to Tur, and they are more knowledgeable of its intended meaning than others. Therefore, Al-San'ani said in (Subul Al-Salam) (2/251): (The majority went to the view that it is not forbidden, and they used evidence that does not stand, and interpreted the hadith of the chapter with far-fetched interpretations. Interpretation is not befitting unless the evidence stands against what they interpreted). (Fath Al-'Allam) added after it (1/310): (And there is no evidence. The hadiths narrated encouraging the Prophetic visit and its virtue do not contain the command to saddle mounts to it, alongside the fact that they are all weak or fabricated; none of them is fit for reasoning. Most people did not notice the difference between the issue of visiting and the issue of traveling for it, so they diverted the hadith of the chapter from its clear explicit meaning without evidence calling for it). I say: Due to the confusion referred to, Sheikh Al-Subki, may Allah forgive us and him, accused Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah of denying the visit to the Prophetic Grave even without saddling a mount, whereas he was among those who stated it [is permitted] and mentioned its virtue and etiquettes. He cited that in more than one of his good books (1). The scholar Al-Hafiz Muhammad bin Abdul Hadi undertook clarifying this truth and refuting Al-Subki's accusation in a large work titled (Al-Sarim Al-Munki fi Al-Radd 'ala Al-Subki) [The Sharp Sword in Refuting Al-Subki]: He quoted therein from Ibn Taymiyyah many texts regarding the permissibility of visiting without traveling for it. He cited therein the hadiths narrated regarding its virtue, discussed them in detail, and clarified the weakness and fabrication in them. In it are many other benefits, jurisprudential, hadith-related, and historical, worthy for every student of knowledge to strive to view.
foot_note: 1. (1) Like his book (Manasik Al-Hajj) (3/390) from (Majmu'at Al-Rasa'il Al-Kubra).

text: Furthermore, sound reasoning judges the correctness of the saying of those who went to the view that the hadith remains on its general meaning. Because if explicitly it prevents traveling to a mosque other than the three mosques, knowing that worship in any mosque is better than in a non-mosque, and he, peace be upon him, said: (The most beloved of places to Allah are mosques), even if that mosque is the mosque founded on piety, namely the Quba Mosque about which the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (A prayer in the Quba Mosque is like an Umrah), if the matter is so, then for the hadith to prevent traveling to other places is more worthy and appropriate. Especially if the intention is a mosque built on the grave of a prophet or righteous person, for the sake of praying in it and worshipping at it. You have known the curse upon whoever does that, so is it conceivable that the Wise Lawgiver allows traveling to such a thing and prevents traveling to the Quba Mosque!? Conclusion: What Abu Muhammad Al-Juwayni Al-Shafi'i and others went to regarding the prohibition of traveling to other than the three mosques among virtuous places is what must be resorted to. No wonder major investigative scholars known for their independence in understanding and depth in Fiqh from Allah and His Messenger chose it, such as the two Sheikhs of Islam Ibn Taymiyyah and Ibn Al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on them, for they have many beneficial researches on this important issue. Among these virtuous ones is Sheikh Waliullah Al-Dehlawi; among his words on that is what he said in (Hujjat Allah Al-Baligha) (1/192): (The people of Jahiliyyah used to intend places glorified in their claim, visiting them and seeking blessing by them. In this was distortion and corruption not hidden. So he, peace be upon him, blocked the corruption, lest other than rituals be attached to rituals, and lest it becomes a means to worshipping other than Allah. The truth according to me is that the grave, the place of worship of a saint among saints, and Tur [Mount Sinai] are all equal in the prohibition). It is good to point out in the conclusion of this research that traveling for trade and seeking knowledge does not enter into the prohibition, for the travel is only to seek that need wherever it is, not for the specificity of the place. Likewise, traveling to visit a brother in Allah, for he is the intended one, as Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in (Al-Fatawa) (2/186). 12 - Lighting lamps over them. The evidence for that is several matters:
foot_note: None

text: First: It being an introduced innovation (Bid'ah) not known to the righteous predecessors, and he, peace be upon him, said: (Every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire). Narrated by Al-Nasa'i and Ibn Khuzaimah in his (Sahih) with a Sahih chain. Second: It involves wasting money, which is forbidden by the text as preceded in Issue (42 p. 64). Third: It involves imitation of the Majus (Zoroastrians), worshippers of fire. Ibn Hajar the Jurist said in (Al-Zawajir) (1/134): (Our companions stated explicitly the prohibition of a lamp on a grave, even if small, where no resident or visitor benefits from it. They reasoned it with extravagance, wasting money, and imitation of the Majus. It is not far-fetched in this case that it be a major sin). I say: He did not cite, in addition to the reasoning mentioned, our first evidence, though it is a valid evidence, possibly the strongest of evidences. Because those who light lamps on graves only intend thereby to draw closer to Allah the Exalted - so they claim - and do not intend illumination for a resident or visitor, evidenced by their lighting them while the sun is rising in the broad daylight! Thus, for that reason, it was a misguided innovation. If it is said: Why did you not use as evidence the famous hadith narrated by the authors of Sunan and others from Ibn Abbas: (Allah cursed the female visitors of graves, and those who take mosques and lamps over them)? My answer to it: This hadith, despite its fame, has a weak chain; it does not stand as proof. Even if many authors were lenient and included it in this chapter and remained silent about its defect, as Ibn Hajar did in (Al-Zawajir), and before him the scholar Ibn Al-Qayyim in (Zad Al-Ma'ad), and the masses of Salafis and Ahl al-Hadith were deceived by it so they used it as proof in their books, letters, and lectures. I had criticized Ibn Al-Qayyim for that in what I commented on his book, and I clarified the defect of the hadith in detail there, then in (Silsilat Al-Ahadith Al-Da'ifah) (No. 223). Then I saw Ibn Al-Qayyim in (Tahdhib Al-Sunan) (4/342) quoting Abdul Haq Al-Ishbili that in the chain of the hadith is Badham, the companion of Al-Kalbi, and he is very weak according to them. Ibn Al-Qayyim affirmed him. Praise be to Allah for His success. As for the first sentence of the hadith, it is Sahih, having two witnesses from the hadith of Abu Huraira and Hassan bin Thabit which I cited in Issue (119 p. 185, 186).
foot_note: None

text: As for the second sentence, it is also Sahih, mutawatir in meaning, and I mentioned in this chapter in the seventh issue seven authentic hadiths witnessing to it. 13 - Breaking their bones. The evidence for it is his saying, peace be upon him: (Breaking the bone of a believer when dead is like breaking it when alive). Recorded by Abu Dawood (2/69), Ibn Majah (1/492), Al-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil) (2/108), Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) (No. 776 Mawarid), Ibn Al-Jarud in (Al-Muntaqa) (p. 551), Al-Daraqutni in his Sunan (367), Al-Bayhaqi (4/58), Ahmad (6/58, 105, 168, 200, 264) - wording is his, Abu Nu'aym in (Al-Hilyah) (7/95), and Al-Khatib in (Tarikh Baghdad) (12/106, 13:120) from routes from Amrah from her. I say: Some of its routes are Sahih according to the criteria of Muslim, and Al-Nawawi strengthened it in (Al-Majmu') (5/300). Ibn Al-Qattan said: (Its chain is Hasan) as in (Al-Mirqat) (2/380). It has two other routes from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. The first: In Ahmad (6/100). The other: In Al-Daraqutni (367). It has a witness from the hadith of Umm Salamah. Recorded by Ibn Majah (1) and he added at its end: (In sin). But its chain is weak. It is in Al-Daraqutni in the first hadith in some of its routes from the first aspect. But it appears it is Mudraj (interpolated) in the hadith, for in another narration of it the wording is: (Meaning in sin).
foot_note: 1. (1) Attributed in (Al-Imam) to Muslim, which was refuted as in (Fayd Al-Qadir). (Al-Imam) is a very great book in rulings by Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid. Al-Dhahabi said: (Had its writing and final draft been completed, it would have come in fifteen volumes).

text: This is apparent that this addition is not from the Hadith but from the explanation of some narrators. This is supported by a narration by Ahmad with the wording: (He said: They view that it is in sin. Abdul Razzaq said: I think it is the saying of Dawood). I say: Meaning Dawood bin Qays, who is the sheikh of Abdul Razzaq in it. It is apparent that this explanation is what is intended by the Hadith. Al-Tahawi asserted this and dedicated a specific chapter for it in his (Mushkil), so let whoever wishes refer to it. The Hadith is proof of the prohibition of breaking the bone of a dead believer. For this reason, it came in the Hanbali books: (It is forbidden to cut anything from the limbs of the dead, destroy his essence, or burn him, even if he willed it). So in (Kashshaf Al-Qina') (2/127), and similar in other schools. Indeed, Ibn Hajar the Jurist asserted in (Al-Zawajir) (1/134) that it is among the major sins. He said: (Because you knew from the Hadith that it is like breaking the bone of the living) (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) The Hanbalis went to extremes in that, such that they said as in (Al-Kashshaf) (2/130): (If a pregnant woman dies with a fetus whose life is hoped for, it is forbidden to cut open her belly for the sake of the pregnancy, whether she is Muslim or Dhimmi, because of the violation of a certain sanctity for the survival of a presumed life, because the dominant probability and appearance is that the child will not live. Ahmad argued for that in the narration of Abu Dawood with what Aisha narrated...). I say: Then he mentioned the Hadith and the text of Abu Dawood in (Al-Masa'il) (p. 150): (I heard Ahmad asked about a woman who dies and the child moves in her belly, should she be cut open? He said: No, breaking the bone of the dead is like breaking it when alive). Sayyid Muhammad Rashid Rida commented on it saying: (Using it as evidence to leave a living fetus in its mother's belly to die absolutely has strangeness from two aspects: First: Cutting the belly does not involve breaking a bone of the dead. Second: If the fetus is fully formed and removed from its mother's belly by cutting it, it may live as happens repeatedly. So here is saving it and preserving its life, while preserving the dignity of its mother based on cutting the belly being like breaking a bone. There is no doubt that the first is weightier, moreover, cutting the belly for such a reason is not considered an insult to the dead as is apparent in the custom of all people. The correct view is the saying of those who obligate cutting the belly and extracting it if the doctor considers its life probable after exit. Some of them stated this explicitly). And he said in Manar Al-Sabil (1/178): And if part of it comes out alive, it is cut for the remainder due to the certainty of its life after it was presumed. I say: What Sayyid, may Allah have mercy on him, chose is the most correct view according to the Shafi'is as Al-Nawawi said (5/301), and he attributed it to the saying of Abu Hanifa and most jurists, and it is the school of Ibn Hazm (5/166-167), and it is the truth if Allah the Exalted wills.

text: Benefited from the Hadith: 1 - The sanctity of exhuming the grave of a Muslim because it exposes his bones to breakage. Therefore, some of the Salaf disliked being buried in a graveyard where burial is frequent. Imam Al-Shafi'i said in (Al-Umm) (1/245): (Malik informed us from Hisham bin Urwah from his father who said: I do not like to be buried in Baqi'! To be buried elsewhere is more beloved to me. It is only one of two men: Either an oppressor, so I do not like to be in his vicinity, or a righteous man, so I do not like for his bones to be exhumed. He said: And if the bones of a dead person are brought out, I would like them to be returned and buried). Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu') (5/303) in summary: (It is not permissible to exhume a grave for other than a legal reason by agreement of the Companions [Shafi'i scholars]. It is permissible for legal reasons like what preceded (in Issue 109). Summary: It is permissible to exhume the grave if the dead has decayed and become dust; then it is permissible to bury another in it. It is permissible to cultivate that land and build on it, and all modes of benefit and disposal in it by agreement of the Companions. This is all if no trace of bone or other remains of the dead. This varies with the variation of lands and earth. The word of experts regarding it is relied upon). I say: From this, you know the prohibition of what some Islamic governments commit of leveling some Islamic graveyards and exhuming them for the sake of urban planning, without any regard for their sanctity, or concern for the prohibition of treading on them and breaking their bones and the like. Let no one imagine that the mentioned planning justifies such violations. Nay, for it is not among the necessities, but among the luxuries which do not justify aggression against the dead. It is upon the living to organize their affairs without harming their dead. Among the wonders that draw attention is seeing these governments respecting stones and buildings standing over some dead more than their respect for the dead themselves. For if some of these buildings of domes or churches and the like stood in the way of the alleged planning, they would leave them as they are and adjust the planning map for their sake to preserve them, because they consider them ancient monuments!
foot_note: None

text: As for the graves of the dead themselves, they do not deserve such adjustment according to them! Rather, some of those governments strive—as far as we know—to place graves outside the town and prevent burial in old graves. This is another violation in my view, because it causes Muslims to miss the Sunnah of visiting graves, as it is not easy for the common people to travel long distances to be able to reach them, visit them, and pray for them! The motive for these violations—I believe—is nothing but blind imitation of materialist, disbelieving Europe, which wants to eliminate every manifestation of belief in the Hereafter and everything that reminds of it, not the observance of health rules as they claim. If that were true, they would have hastened to fight causes which no rational person doubts the harm of, such as selling alcohol and drinking it, and immorality and debauchery in its various forms and names. Their lack of concern for eliminating these apparent evils, and their striving to remove everything that reminds of the Hereafter and keep it away from their eyes, is the greatest proof that the intent is contrary to what they claim and declare, and what their chests conceal is greater. 2 - That there is no sanctity for the bones of non-believers, due to the attribution of the bone to the believer in his saying: (bone of the believer). It implied that the bone of the disbeliever is not so. Al-Hafiz indicated this meaning in (Al-Fath) by saying: (It is benefited from it that the sanctity of the believer after his death remains as it was during his life) (1). From this, the answer to the question frequently asked by many students in medical colleges is known, which is: Is it permissible to break bones to examine them and conduct medical investigations on them? The answer: It is not permissible for the bones of a believer, and it is permissible for others. This is supported by what comes in the following issue: 129 - It is permissible to exhume the graves of disbelievers, because they have no sanctity as indicated by the concept of the previous Hadith. Witness to it is the hadith of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said:
foot_note: 1. (1) He mentioned it in (Al-Fayd) (4/551).

text: (The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, arrived in Medina and stayed in the upper part of Medina among a tribe called Banu Amr bin Awf. He stayed among them for fourteen nights. Then he sent for Banu Al-Najjar, and they came with swords hanging from their necks. It is as if I am looking at the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, on his mount with Abu Bakr behind him, and a group of Banu Al-Najjar around him, until he arrived at the courtyard of Abu Ayyub. He used to like to pray wherever the prayer caught him, and he would pray in sheepfolds. He ordered the building of the mosque, so he sent for a group of Banu Al-Najjar and said: 'O Banu Al-Najjar, name a price for this garden of yours.' They said: 'No, by Allah, we do not ask for its price except from Allah.' He said: In it were graves of the polytheists, ruins, and date palms. So the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ordered the graves of the polytheists, and they were exhumed; then the ruins, and they were leveled; and the date palms, and they were cut. They aligned the date palms towards the Qiblah of the mosque and made its jambs of stone. They began moving the rock while chanting poetry, and the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was with them saying: [while moving the bricks: This burden (1) is not the burden of Khaybar * This is more righteous to our Lord and purer] O Allah, there is no good except the good of the Hereafter * So forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirah. In a narration from the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: O Allah, the reward is the reward of the Hereafter * So have mercy on the Ansar and the Muhajirah). Recorded by the two Sheikhs and others from the hadith of Anas, and the context is his. Al-Bukhari recorded it from the hadith of Aisha, and what is between the brackets is from her. I have recorded the two hadiths in (Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (In the Hadith is the permissibility of disposal in a graveyard owned by gift and sale, the permissibility of exhuming obliterated graves if they are not respected [i.e., of non-Muslims], the permissibility of praying in the graveyards of polytheists after exhuming them and removing what is in them, and the permissibility of building mosques in their places).
foot_note: 1. (1) 'Himal' with Kasra from 'Haml' (load). 'What is carried from Khaybar' refers to dates, meaning this (building the mosque) is better in the Hereafter than that and more praiseworthy in outcome. It can be plural of 'Himl' (with Kasra on Mim) or 'Haml' (with Fatha on Mim), and it can be the verbal noun of 'Hamala' or 'Hamil', as in (Al-Nihayah).

text: This is the last of what Allah the Exalted enabled me to collect of (Ahkam Al-Jana'iz). Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise, I bear witness that there is no god but You, I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You). Damascus 1/7/1373 And its drafting finished on the afternoon of Sunday 19/4/1382 (1) And praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds.
