text: Innovations of Funerals
foot_note: None

text: Innovations of Funerals To complete the benefit of the book, I saw fit to follow it with a special chapter on the innovations of funerals, so that the Muslim may be on guard against them and his deed may be safe for him according to the Sunnah alone. The wise poet says: I knew evil not for evil's sake * But to avoid it And whoever does not know good * From evil falls into it And in the hadith of Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman, he said: (People used to ask the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, about good, and I used to ask him about evil for fear that it would overtake me). Recorded by Al-Bukhari (13/29) and others. Were it not that the material for the indicated chapter was ready with me, my time now would not have allowed for collecting and appending it to the book. But it is present with me, and it is part of extensive material I had started collecting more than a year ago to compose a comprehensive book gathering various religious innovations, suitable to be like a dictionary for them. I extracted them from dozens of books, and I had a few other books left to read to then turn to arranging them all and composing it. But I was diverted from it, so I seized this opportunity and extracted from the material I have the mentioned chapter, and arranged it in the order intended for the original, as you will see. It is that I quote the innovation from the book I extracted it from in its text or meaning, then follow it by indicating the part number and page from it. If I do not follow it with anything, that is an indication that it is from me, and my knowledge led to it being among innovations. These are very few compared to the abundant material of the chapter or the book. Before starting to list them, it is necessary to mention the rules and foundations upon which this chapter was built, following the original, so I say:
foot_note: None

text: The innovation stated as misguidance by the Lawgiver is: A - Everything that opposed the Sunnah in sayings, actions, or beliefs, even if it was out of Ijtihad. B - Every matter by which one draws closer to Allah, which the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade. C - Every matter that cannot be legislated except by a text or Tawqif (divine instruction), and there is no text for it; it is an innovation unless it is from a Companion. D - What has been attached to worship from the customs of disbelievers. E - What some scholars, especially the later ones, stated as recommended without evidence. F - Every worship whose method came only in a weak or fabricated hadith. G - Extremism/Exaggeration in worship. H - Every worship which the Lawgiver made absolute and people restricted with some restrictions like place, time, description, or number. Detailed discussion on these principles belongs to the independent book if Allah the Exalted wills. Let us start now with the intent, so I say: * * *
foot_note: None

text: Before Death 1 - The belief of some that devils come to the dying person in the form of his parents in the guise of a Jew and a Christian to offer him every religion to mislead him. (Ibn Hajar Al-Haytami said in (Al-Fatawa Al-Hadithiyyah) quoting Al-Suyuti: (This has not been reported)). 2 - Placing the Mushaf (Quran) at the head of the dying person. 3 - Instructing (Talqin) the dying person to acknowledge the Prophet and the Imams of Ahl al-Bayt, peace be upon them (1). 4 - Reciting Surah (Ya-Sin) over the dying person. (See Issue 15). 5 - Turning the dying person towards the Qiblah. (Saaid bin Al-Musayyib denounced it as in (Al-Muhalla) (5/174) and Malik as in (Al-Madkhal) (3/229-230) and no hadith regarding it is authentic).
foot_note: 1. (1) See (Miftah Al-Karamah) from Shia books (1/408).

text: After Death 6 - The saying of the Shia: (The human becomes impure by death except the Infallible (1), and the martyr and the one whose killing became obligatory so he washed before his killing then was killed for that very reason) (2) (See the first Hadith of Issue 31). 7 - Removing menstruating women, postpartum women, and Junub (ritually impure) persons from his presence! 8 - Abandoning work by those who attended the exit of the dead person's soul until seven days pass! (Al-Madkhal by Ibn Al-Hajj 3/276-277). 9 - The belief of some that the soul of the dead hovers around the place where he died. 10 - Keeping a candle with the dead on the night of his death until morning. (Al-Madkhal 3/236). 11 - Placing a green branch in the room where he died. 12 - Reciting Quran near the dead until washing him begins. 13 - Trimming the nails of the dead and shaving his pubic hair. Al-Mudawwanah by Imam Malik (1/180), Madkhal (3/240). 14 - Inserting cotton into his anus, throat, and nose! 15 - Placing dust in the eyes of the dead and saying at that time: (Nothing fills the eye of the son of Adam except dust) (Al-Madkhal 3/261). 16 - The family of the dead refraining from eating until they finish burying him. (From it 3/276). 17 - Committing to weeping at lunch and dinner.
foot_note:
1. (1) Meaning the Imams of the Shia, for they believe in their infallibility! 
2. The previous source (1/153) cited Shia consensus on it! Which contradicts the indicated Hadith.

text: 18 - A man tearing his garment for a father and brother (1) (See the Hadith preceded in (Paragraph B, C) of Issue 22). 19 - Mourning for the dead for a full year wherein women do not dye with henna, do not wear beautiful clothes, and do not wear jewelry. When the year ends, they do what is known of them of engraving and writing prohibited in Sharia. They do that along with those who committed to mourning with them, and they call that (Breaking the Mourning) (Al-Madkhal 3/277). 20 - Some of them letting their beard grow out of sadness for the dead. (See Issue 22 (Paragraph) F). 21 - Turning over cushions and carpets and covering mirrors and chandeliers. 22 - Abandoning the use of water that was in the house in a jar or other vessel, viewing it as impure, reasoning that the soul of the dead dived into it when it ascended! (Al-Madkhal). 23 - If one of them sneezes while eating, they say to him: Speak to so-and-so or such-and-such of those who must be alive by name - reasoning lest he follows the dead! (From it). 24 - Refraining from eating Molokhia and fish for the duration of their sadness for their dead. (From it 3/281). 25 - Refraining from eating grilled meat, grilled liver, and kibbeh. 26 - The saying of Sufis: Whoever weeps for a dead person has exited the path of the people of knowledge (Gnostics)! (Talbis Iblis by Ibn Al-Jawzi p. 340-342, see hadiths in Issue 18). 27 - Leaving the clothes of the dead without washing until the third day claiming that repels the punishment of the grave from him. (Al-Madkhal 3/276). 28 - The saying of some: Whoever dies on Friday or Friday night has the punishment of the grave for one hour, then the punishment is cut off from him and does not return until the Day of Judgment. (Narrated by Sheikh Ali Al-Qari in (Sharh Al-Fiqh Al-Akbar) (p. 96) and he refuted it. See the Hadith under Paragraph (Three) of Issue 25).
foot_note: 1. (1) It is the school of the Imamiyyah as in (Miftah Al-Karamah) (1/509).

text: 29 - Another saying: The sinful believer has the punishment of the grave cut off from him on Friday and Friday night, and it does not return to him until the Day of Judgment. (1) 30 - Announcing the death of the deceased from the minarets. (3/245-246 of Al-Madkhal) and see Issue 22 (Paragraph G). 31 - Their saying when informing someone of death: Al-Fatiha for the soul of so-and-so. (See Issue 24).
foot_note: 1. (1) Quoted by Sheikh Ali Al-Qari in (Sharh Al-Fiqh Al-Akbar) (p. 91) and he refuted it saying: (It is false). More obviously false than it is the other saying: That the punishment of the grave is lifted from the disbeliever on Friday and the month of Ramadan due to the sanctity of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. The Sheikh also narrated it and refuted it.

text: Washing the Dead 32 - Placing a loaf of bread and a jug of water in the place where the dead was washed for three nights after his death. (Al-Madkhal 3/276). 33 - Lighting a lamp or lantern in the place where the dead was washed for three nights from sunset to sunrise, and according to some seven nights, and some increase on that, and they do the same in the place where he died. (From it). 34 - The washer reciting a specific Dhikr (remembrance) at every limb he washes. (From it 3/329). 35 - Loudness in Dhikr during funeral washing and procession. (Al-Khadimi in (Sharh Al-Tariqah Al-Muhammadiyyah) (4/22)). 36 - Letting the hair of the deceased woman hang between her breasts. (See Hadith of Umm Atiyyah in Issue 28). * * *
foot_note: None

text: The Shroud and Going Out with the Funeral 37 - Transporting the dead to distant places to bury him near the graves of the righteous like Ahl al-Bayt and the like. 38 - The saying of some: The dead boast in their graves about shrouds and their beauty, reasoning that those of the dead with lowly shrouds are shamed by it (1) (Al-Madkhal 3/277). 39 - Writing the name of the dead and that he testifies the two testimonies, and the names of Ahl al-Bayt, peace be upon them, with the soil of Al-Hussein, peace be upon him, if found, and throwing that into the shroud! (2) 40 - Writing a supplication on the shroud (3). 41 - Decorating the funeral bier. (Al-Ba'ith 'ala Inkar Al-Bida' wa Al-Hawadith by Abu Shama p. 67). 42 - Carrying flags in front of the funeral. 43 - Placing a turban on the wooden bier. (Ibn Abidin stated explicitly in (Al-Hashiyah) (1/806) the dislike of this and the one before it). Attached to it is the Tarboosh (Fez) and the bride's crown and everything indicating the personality of the deceased.
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: Something of this was narrated in some weak hadiths, the closest to here is the hadith of Jabir: Beautify the shrouds of your dead for they boast and visit each other in them in their graves. Narrated by Al-Daylami and in its chain are a group I did not know. Similar to it are two other hadiths mentioned by Ibn Al-Jawzi in (Al-Mawdu'at) and criticized by Al-Suyuti in (Al-La'ali) (2/234) with what is of no avail. 
2. The Imamiyyah are upon this as in (Miftah Al-Karamah) (1/455-456). 
3. Some legislated that by analogy to writing: (Lillah) [For Allah] on Zakat camels! Refuted in (Al-Taratib Al-Idariyyah) (1/440) quoting (Al-Muhtar 'ala Al-Durr Al-Mukhtar) - thus in the quote from him, and the word (Radd) fell from me or the printer because the book is named (Radd Al-Muhtar) and the mentioned discussion is in the first volume of it (1/847-848).

text: 44 - Carrying wreaths, myrtle, flowers, and the picture of the deceased in front of the funeral! 45 - Slaughtering sheep when the funeral leaves under the threshold of the door. (Al-Ibda' fi Madar Al-Ibtida' by Sheikh Ali Mahfuz p. 114) and the belief of some that if this is not done, three of the deceased's family will die! 46 - Carrying bread and sheep in front of the funeral and slaughtering them after burial and distributing them with bread. (Al-Madkhal 266-267)! 47 - The belief of some that if the funeral is righteous, its weight becomes light on its bearers and it speeds up. 48 - Giving charity with the funeral. (Al-Ikhtiyarat Al-'Amaliyyah p. 53 and Kashshaf Al-Qina' 2/134). And from it is giving licorice drink, lemon, and the like. 49 - Committing to starting carrying the funeral with the right side. (Al-Mudawwanah 176). 50 - Carrying the funeral ten steps from each of its four sides (1). 51 - Slowness in walking with it. (Al-Ba'ith by Abu Shama p. 51, 67, Zad Al-Ma'ad 1/299). 52 - Crowding over the bier. (Al-Muhalla by Ibn Hazm 5/178) (2). 53 - Abandoning getting close to the funeral. (Al-Ba'ith p. 67). 54 - Abandoning silence in the funeral. (From it and Hashiyah Ibn Abidin 1/810). This text covers raising the voice with Dhikr as in the paragraph after it, people talking to one another, and the like.
foot_note:
1. (1) Some jurists used as evidence for that the Hadith: (Whoever carries a funeral forty steps, forty major sins are expiated from him). Quoted in Al-Bahr Al-Ra'iq (2/207-208) from (Al-Bada'i). And in (Sharh Al-Munyah): (Narrated by Abu Bakr Al-Najjar) as in the Hashiyah (1/833). Thus some transmit it from others without indicating the status of the Hadith, and it is not authentic because it contains Ali bin Abi Sarah who is weak. This Hadith is among what was denounced of him as Al-Dhahabi said, and for that we made it among (Mawdu'at Al-Jami' Al-Saghir) [Fabrications of the Small Collection]. Despite this, the Hadith does not indicate this innovation, so take note. 
2. Then he narrated from Qatada: I witnessed a funeral in which was Abu Al-Sawwar - he is Hurayth bin Hassan Al-Adawi - and they crowded over the bed. Abu Al-Sawwar said: Do you consider these better or the Companions of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace! If a man among them saw a place to carry, he carried; otherwise, he stepped aside and did not harm anyone.

text: 55 - Loudness in Dhikr or reciting Quran or Al-Burda or Dala'il Al-Khayrat and the like. (Al-Ibda' p. 110, Iqtida' Al-Sirat Al-Mustaqim p. 57, Al-I'tisam by Imam Al-Shatibi (1/372), Sharh Al-Tariqah Al-Muhammadiyyah 1/114 and see Issue 48). 56 - Dhikr behind the funeral with 'Allah', Al-Burda, or Al-Dala'il and the Beautiful Names. (Al-Sunan wa Al-Mubtada'at by Sheikh Muhammad bin Ahmad Khader Al-Shuqayri p. 67). 57 - Saying behind it: (Allah is Greatest, Allah is Greatest, I testify that Allah gives life and causes death and He is Living who does not die, Glory be to the One who is mighty in power and permanence, and subdued slaves with death and annihilation) (1). 58 - Shouting behind the funeral with: (Ask forgiveness for him, Allah will forgive you) and the like. (Al-Madkhal 2/221, Al-Ibda' p. 113). 59 - Shouting the word (Al-Fatiha) when passing by the grave of a righteous person, and at crossroads. 60 - The observer of the funeral saying: (Praise be to Allah who did not make me of the cut-off multitude) (2). 61 - The belief of some that if the funeral is righteous, it stops at the grave of the Wali (saint) when passing by it despite its bearers. 62 - Saying when seeing it: (This is what Allah and His Messenger promised us, and Allah and His Messenger spoke the truth, O Allah increase us in faith and submission) (3). 63 - Following the dead with a censer. (Al-Mudawwanah 1/180 and see Issue 74). 64 - Circumambulating (Tawaf) with the funeral around shrines. (Meaning shrines of saints. Al-Ibda' 109). 65 - Circumambulating with it around the Ancient House (Kaaba) seven times. (Al-Madkhal 2/227). 66 - Announcing funerals at the doors of mosques. (Al-Madkhal 2/221, 262-263).
foot_note:
1. (1) Recommended in (Sharh Shir'at Al-Islam)! (p. 665). 
2. Stated explicitly in (Miftah Al-Karamah) (91/46-471) that it is recommended! 
3. Cited in Sharh Al-Shir'ah (665) as completion of a hadith beginning: (Death is terrifying, so if you see a funeral stand and say...) then he mentioned it. I do not know it with this completion; its beginning is in Al-Musnad (3/317) and Al-Bayhaqi (4/26) from the hadith of Jabir, and its men are trustworthy. The hadiths commanding standing are many, and even if abrogated as previously explained in its place, they do not contain this addition, indicating its denial.

text: 67 - Entering the dead through the Gate of Mercy in Al-Aqsa Mosque and placing him between the Gate and the Rock, and gathering of some Sheikhs reciting some Adhkar. 68 - Eulogizing when attending the funeral in the mosque before praying over it or after and before lifting it or following burial of the dead at the grave. (Al-Ibda' 124-125). 69 - Committing to carrying the funeral on a car and following it in cars. (See Issue 54). 70 - Carrying some dead on a gun carriage! * * *
foot_note: None

text: Praying over it 71 - Praying over the funerals of Muslims who died in regions of the earth as Absentee Prayer after sunset of every day. (Al-Ikhtiyarat 53, Al-Madkhal 4/214, Al-Sunan 67). 72 - Praying over the absentee with knowledge that he was prayed over in his homeland. (See Issue 59 Paragraph (Seventh)). 73 - The saying of some when praying over it: (Glory be to the One who subdued His slaves with death, and Glory be to the Living who does not die). (Al-Sunan wa Al-Mubtada'at 66). 74 - Removing sandals when praying over it even if they have no apparent impurity, then standing on them! 75 - The Imam standing at the middle of the man and chest of the woman. (See Issue 73). 76 - Reciting the Opening Supplication (Du'a al-Istiftah). (See commentary on Issue 77 p. 119). 77 - Dislike of reciting Al-Fatiha and a Surah in it. (See commentary on previous Issue p. 120). 78 - Dislike of Taslim (Salutation) in it. (1) 79 - The saying of some after praying over it with a loud voice: What do you testify regarding him? So those present say likewise: He was among the righteous. And similar! (Al-Ibda' 108, Al-Sunan 66 and see Issue 26 p. 44).
foot_note: 1. (1) It is among the singularities of the Imamiyyah from other Muslims as in (Miftah Al-Karamah) (1/483) of their books.

text: Burial and its Attachments 80 - Slaughtering a buffalo upon the arrival of the funeral to the graveyard before burying it and distributing the meat to those present. (Al-Ibda' 114). 81 - Placing the blood of the sacrifice slaughtered at the exit of the funeral from the house into the grave of the dead. 82 - Dhikr around the bed of the dead before burying him. (Al-Sunan 67). 83 - Adhan when placing the dead in his grave. (Hashiyah Ibn Abidin 1/837). 84 - Lowering the dead into the grave from the head of the grave. (See Issue 103 p. 150). 85 - Placing some of the soil of Al-Hussein, peace be upon him, with the dead when lowering him into the grave because it is safety from every fear (1). 86 - Spreading sand under the dead without necessity. (Al-Madkhal 3/261). 87 - Placing a pillow or the like under the head of the dead in the grave. (From it 3/260). 88 - Sprinkling rose water on the dead in his grave. (Al-Madkhal 3/262, 2/222). 89 - Those present throwing soil with the backs of the palms saying 'Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi raji'un'! (2). 90 - Reciting: (From it We created you) in the first handful, and (In it We return you) in the second, and (And from it We bring you out another time) in the third. (See Issue 106).
foot_note:
1. (1) So claimed in (Miftah Al-Karamah)! (1/497). 
2. It is the school of the Imamiyyah as in (Miftah Al-Karamah) (1/499), and it seems they intended by this form to oppose Ahl al-Sunnah who argue that he, peace be upon him, used to throw soil with the inside of palms! See Issue 103 p. 151.

text: 91 - Saying in the first handful: Bismillah, and in the second: Al-Mulk Lillah (Dominion belongs to Allah), and in the third: Al-Qudra Lillah (Power belongs to Allah), and in the fourth: Al-Izza Lillah (Glory belongs to Allah), and in the fifth: Al-Afu wa Al-Ghufran Lillah (Pardon and Forgiveness belong to Allah), and in the sixth: Al-Rahma Lillah (Mercy belongs to Allah), then reading in the seventh His saying: {Everyone upon it will perish} [Al-Rahman: 26] the verse. And reciting His saying: {From it We created you...} [Ta-Ha: 55] the verse. 92 - Reciting the seven Surahs: Al-Fatiha, Al-Mu'awwidhatan (last two surahs), Al-Ikhlas, Idha Ja'a Nasrullah, Qul Ya Ayyuha Al-Kafirun, and Inna Anzalnahu. And this supplication: O Allah I ask You by Your Great Name, and I ask You by Your Name which is the support of the religion, and I ask You... and I ask You... and I ask You... and I ask You by Your Name which if You are asked by it You give, and if You are called by it You answer, Lord of Gabriel, Michael, Israfil, and Azrael... etc. All that upon burying the dead. (1) 93 - Reciting Fatiha of the Book at the head of the dead, and Fatiha of Al-Baqarah at his feet. (2) 94 - Reciting Quran when pouring soil over the dead (Al-Madkhal 3/262-263). 95 - Talqin (Instruction) of the dead. (Al-Sunan 67, Subul Al-Salam by Al-San'ani and see Issue 103 p. 154). 96 - Erecting two stones on the woman's grave. (Nayl Al-Awtar by Al-Shawkani 4/73). 97 - Eulogizing following burial of the dead at the grave. (Al-Ibda' 124-125). 98 - Transferring the dead before burial or after to the Noble Shrines (3). (See Issue 106 p. 159). 99 - Living near the dead after his burial in a house in the graveyard or near it. (Al-Madkhal 3/278). 100 - Their refraining from entering the house if they return from burial until they wash their limbs from the trace of the dead. (From it 3/276). 101 - Placing food and drink on the grave for people to take. 102 - Charity at the grave. (Al-Iqtida' 183, Kashshaf Al-Qina' 2/134). 103 - Pouring water on the grave from its head, then circling it, and pouring the surplus on its middle! (4)
foot_note:
1. (1) Recommended in (Sharh Al-Shir'ah) (p. 568), and what indicates the invention of this is that it contains mention of the name (Azrael) which has no basis in the Sunnah absolutely as previously noted (p. 156). 
2. This was narrated in a hadith from Ibn Umar Marfu', weakened by Al-Haythami (3/45). Narrated from him Mawquf (stopped at companion) and it is also weak as preceded in Issue (122 p. 192). (3 and 4) They are from the school of Imamiyyah as in (Miftah Al-Karamah) (1/507, 500).

text: Condolences and its Attachments 104 - Condolences at the graves. (Hashiyah Ibn Abidin 1/843). 105 - Gathering in a place for condolences. (Zad Al-Ma'ad 1/304, Safar Al-Sa'adah by Al-Fayruzabadi p. 57, Islah Al-Masajid 'an Al-Bida' wa Al-'Awa'id by Al-Qasimi p. 180-181, and see Issue 110 p. 161). 106 - Limiting condolences to three days. (See Issue 113 p. 165). 107 - Leaving carpets placed in the dead person's house for sitting of those coming for condolences, leaving them as such until seven days pass, then after that removing them. (Al-Madkhal 3/279-280). 108 - Condolences with: (May Allah make your reward great, inspire you with patience, and grant us and you gratitude, for our souls, wealth, families, and children are among Allah's delightful gifts and entrusted loans; He gave you enjoyment of him in happiness and joy, and took him from you with a great reward: Prayer, Mercy, and Guidance if you seek reward. So be patient, and let not your panic cancel your reward lest you regret. Know that panic does not return anything nor repel grief, and what is descended is as if it has happened) (1). 109 - Condolences with: (Indeed in Allah is consolation for every calamity, and compensation for every loss, so trust in Allah, and hope in Him, for the deprived is he who is deprived of reward) (2).
foot_note: 1. (1 and 2) He deemed them good in (Sharh Al-Shir'ah) (p. 562, 263) and others. The first was narrated from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that he consoled Mu'adh bin Jabal for his son, but it is a fabricated hadith. The other was narrated from the condolence of Al-Khidr for his death, peace be upon him, to his household, peace be upon him, and it is weak as previously noted in the commentary on Issue (112 p. 165).

text: 110 - Taking hospitality of food from the family of the dead. (Talbis Iblis 341, Fath Al-Qadir by Ibn Al-Humam 1/473, Al-Madkhal 3/275-276, Islah Al-Masajid 181, and see Issue 114). 111 - Taking hospitality for the dead on the first day, the seventh, the fortieth, and the completion of the year. (Al-Khadimi in Sharh Al-Tariqah Al-Muhammadiyyah 3224, Al-Madkhal 2/114, 3/278-279). 112 - Taking food from the family of the dead on the first Thursday. 113 - Answering the invitation of the dead's family to food. (Imam Muhammad Al-Birgivi in (Jala' Al-Qulub 77)). 114 - Their saying: The food table is not lifted for the three nights except by the one who placed it. (Al-Madkhal 3/276). 115 - Making Zalabya or buying it and buying what is eaten with it on the seventh day. (Al-Madkhal 3/292). 116 - The will to prepare food and hospitality on the day of his death or after it, and giving counted dirhams to one who recites Quran for his soul or glorifies or says Tahlil for him. (Al-Tariqah Al-Muhammadiyyah 4/325). 117 - The will that men sleep at his grave for forty nights or more or less. (From it 4/326). 118 - Endowing endowments, especially money, for reciting the Great Quran or to pray voluntary prayers or to say Tahlil or pray upon the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and gift its reward to the soul of the endower or the soul of whoever visited him. (From it 4/323). 119 - The guardian of the dead giving charity for him before the passing of the first night with whatever is easy for him; if he does not find, he prays two Rak'ahs reciting in each Rak'ah Fatiha of the Book and Ayat Al-Kursi once, and Surah Al-Takathur ten times, then when finished he says: (O Allah, I prayed this prayer and You know what I intended by it, O Allah send its reward to the grave of so-and-so the dead)! (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Among the strange things is that the book from which I quoted this innovation, which is (Sharh Al-Shir'ah) (p. 568), said: (And the Sunnah is that the guardian of the dead gives charity... etc.) and there is absolutely no basis for this in the Sunnah. Perhaps he means the Sunnah of the Sheikhs, as some annotators interpreted the saying of one of the commentators: That it is from the Sunnah to pronounce the intention upon entering prayer!

text: 120 - Giving charity on behalf of the dead with foods the dead used to love! 121 - Giving charity for the soul of the dead in the three months Rajab, Sha'ban, and Ramadan. 122 - Dropping of Prayer (Isqat Al-Salah). (Islah Al-Masajid 281-283) (See commentary p. 174 Issue 113). 123 - Reading for the dead and over them. (Al-Sunan 63-65), and see (Issue 117 p. 173 and Issue 122 p. 191). 124 - Rosary (Subhah) for the dead. (From it 11, 65). 125 - Liberation ( 'Ataqah) for him. (From it) (1). 126 - Reading Quran for him and completing it (Khatm) at his grave. (Safar Al-Sa'adah 57, Al-Madkhal 1/266, 267). 127 - The Subhah (Morning Visit) for the sake of the dead: It is their going early to the grave of their dead whom they buried yesterday, they and their relatives and acquaintances. (Al-Madkhal 2/113-114, 2783, Islah Al-Masajid 270-271). 128 - Spreading carpets and others in the graveyard for those coming to the Subhah and others. (Al-Madkhal 3/278). 129 - Erecting a tent over the grave. (From it). 130 - Sleeping at the grave for forty nights or less or more. (Jala' Al-Qulub 83). 131 - Memorializing the dead on the night of the fortieth or at the passing of every year, called the Remembrance (Tidhkar). (Al-Ibda' 125). 132 - Digging the grave before death in preparation for it. (See Issue 110).
foot_note: 1. (1) And he said: The Hadith: (Whoever reads Qul Huwa Allah Ahad a thousand times has purchased himself from the Fire) is fabricated.

text: Visiting Graves 133 - Visiting graves after death on the third day calling it 'Al-Farq', visiting it at the head of a week, then on the fifteenth, then on the fortieth, calling them 'Al-Tal'at', and some of them limit to the last two. (Nur Al-Bayan fi Al-Kashf 'an Bida' Akhir Al-Zaman p. 53-54). 134 - Visiting the grave of parents every Friday. (And the Hadith narrated regarding it is fabricated as preceded before Issue 121 p. 187). 135 - Their saying that if the dead is not visited on Friday night, his heart remains broken among the dead, and they claim he sees them if they exit the wall of the town. (Al-Madkhal 3/277). 136 - Women intending the Umayyad Mosque from dark of Saturday to Duha to visit the Yahyawi Shrine, and their claim that persisting on this action for forty Saturdays [achieves] what is intended for it! (Islah Al-Masajid 230). 137 - Intending the grave of Sheikh Ibn Arabi for forty Fridays claiming fulfillment of need! 138 - Visiting graves on the Day of Ashura. (Al-Madkhal 1/290). 139 - Visiting them on the night of mid-Sha'ban and lighting fire at them. (Talbis Iblis 429, Al-Madkhal 1/310). 140 - Their going to graveyards on the two Eid days, Rajab, Sha'ban, and Ramadan. (Al-Sunan 104). 141 - Visiting them on Eid day. (Al-Madkhal 1/286, Al-Ibda' 135, Al-Sunan 71). 142 - Visiting them on Monday and Thursday. 143 - Some visitors standing a little with utmost humility at the door as if asking permission! Then entering. (Al-Ibda' 99).
foot_note: None

text: 144 - Standing in front of the grave placing hands as if praying, then sitting. (From it). 145 - Tayammum (Dry ablution) for visiting the grave. 146 - Praying two Rak'ahs upon visiting, reading in each Rak'ah Al-Fatiha and Ayat Al-Kursi once, and Surah Al-Ikhlas three times, and making its reward for the dead! (1) 147 - Reading Al-Fatiha for the dead. (Tafsir Al-Manar 8/268). 148 - Reading (Ya-Sin) at graveyards (2). 149 - Reading (Qul Huwa Allah) eleven times. (Its hadith is fabricated as passed at end of Issue 122 p. 193). 150 - Supplicating saying: O Allah I ask You by the sanctity of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace! That You do not punish this dead person (3). 151 - Greeting them with the wording: (Alaykum Al-Salam) putting (Alaykum) before (Al-Salam) (While the Sunnah is the reverse as in all Hadiths narrated in the chapter and they preceded in Issue 121) (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Mentioned in (Sharh Al-Shir'ah) (p. 570) saying: (The Sunnah in visiting is to start and perform ablution and pray two Rak'ahs reading in each Rak'ah... etc.)! There is nothing of this in the Sunnah; rather, in it is the prohibition of intending prayer at graves as preceded, and see what we commented shortly. 
2. The Hadith: (Whoever enters graveyards and reads Surah (Ya-Sin), Allah lightens from them and they have Hasanat equal to their number) has no basis in any books of Sunnah. When Al-Suyuti cited it in (Sharh Al-Sudur) (p. 130), he did not add in its extraction to saying: (Recorded by Abdul Aziz, companion of Al-Khallal, with his chain from Anas)! Then I found its chain and it is a destroyed chain as I verified in (Al-Ahadith Al-Da'ifah) (1291). 
3. Al-Birgivi cited it in (Ahwal Atfal Al-Muslimin) (p. 229) saying: (And in the report: Whoever visits the grave of a believer and says: O Allah I ask You... etc., Allah lifts the punishment from him until the Day the Trumpet is blown)! This is a false hadith having no basis in any books of Sunnah, and I do not know how Al-Birgivi, may Allah have mercy on him, permitted quoting it without attributing it to any of the Muhaddithin despite what it contains of innovated Tawassul which is forbidden and disliked to the point of prohibition according to him as he established in the mentioned treatise (p. 352). 
4. The doubt of the one saying this innovation, among them the commentator of (Al-Shir'ah) (p. 750), is the hadith of Jabir bin Sulaym saying: I met the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace... so I said Alayka Al-Salam, so he said: Alayka Al-Salam is the greeting of the dead...! The Hadith. Recorded by Abu Dawood (2/179) and Al-Tirmidhi (2/120 Bulaq edition) and Al-Hakim (4/186) and he corrected it and Al-Dhahabi agreed, and it is as they said. Al-Khattabi said: =

1. (1) I say: As for what Abu Al-Jawza' Aws bin Abdullah narrated saying: The people of Medina suffered a severe drought, so they complained to Aisha. She said: Look at the grave of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and make a skylight from it towards the sky so that there is no roof between it and the sky. He said: So they did, and we were rained upon until the grass grew and the camels became fat until they burst from fat, so it was named the Year of Bursting [Al-Fatq]) - it is not authentic. Recorded by Al-Darimi in his Sunan (1/43-44) and in it is Abu Al-Nu'man, who is Muhammad bin Al-Fadl known as 'Arim', and he had become confused in the end of his life as Al-Uqayli and others of the people of Hadith said. Sheikh Al-Islam said in Al-Radd 'ala Al-Bakri (p. 68): (And what was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, of opening a skylight from his grave to the sky so rain would descend is not authentic, nor is its chain established. He said: What clarifies the lie of this is that during the lifetime of Aisha, the house did not have a skylight; rather, part of it remained as it was during the time of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, partly roofed and partly open, and the sun used to descend into it as established in the two Sahihs from her that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to pray Asr while the sun was in her chamber and the shadow had not yet appeared). 
2. It is regrettable that this innovation and the two after it were quoted from (Kitab Al-Madkhal) by Ibn Al-Hajj (1/259, 264) where he cited them accepting them as if they were matters stipulated in Sharia! He has many examples of this manner, some of which preceded without alerting that they are from him, and we will mention a large part of them in the specific book on innovations if Allah the Exalted wills. One might wonder at that given that his book is a great source in stipulating items of innovation, and this chapter with which I ended the book is a just witness to that. But if you knew that he was a follower of others in his knowledge, and influenced to a large extent by the schools of Sufism and their nonsense, the wonder leaves you and you increase in certainty of the correctness of Malik's saying: (There is none among us but he rejects and is rejected, except the owner of this grave), peace be upon him.
